PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the ordinances of Manhattan, Kansas, of a general and permanent nature. As expressed in the Adopting Ordinance, the Code supersedes all such ordinances not included herein or recognized as continuing in force by reference thereto. 
    The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the Comparative Tables appearing in the back of the volume, the reader can locate any section of the 1973 Code and any subsequent ordinance included herein. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this volume. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash, the figure before the dash representing the chapter number and the figure after the dash indicating the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-1 and the second section of chapter 6 is 6-2. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and, at the same time, new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper places, simply by using the decimal system for amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three sections that would logically come between sections 6-2 and 6-3 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 6-2.1, 6-2.2 and 6-2.3 respectively. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between chapters 12 and 13 it will be designated as chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. 
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this Code is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental service, by which the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances they will be properly edited and the page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the Code, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. Each such amendment, when incorporated into the Code, may be cited as a part thereof, as provided in section 5 of the Adopting Ordinance. 
    The successful maintenance of this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    The publication of this Code was under the direct supervision of George R. Langford, President, and Bill Carroll, Supervising Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publishers are most grateful to the City Attorney, Mr. William L. Frost, the Assistant City Manager, Mr. James R. Pearson, the City Manager, Mr. M. Don Harmon and the Executive Secretary, Mrs. Linda L. Spielman, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this Code. 
August, 1981 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida 
ORDINANCE NO. 3876 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code of Ordinances for The City of Manhattan, Kansas; Establishing the Same; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing for the Effective Date Thereof and a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; And Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code. 
Be It Ordained By The Governing Body Of The City Of Manhattan Kansas: 
    Section 1. The Code of Ordinances, consisting of chapters 1 through 34, each inclusive, and constituting a codification of the city's ordinances in conformity with sections 12-3014 and 12-3015 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, as authorized by Ordinance Number 3798, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas," and the same shall be treated and considered as a new and comprehensive ordinance which shall supersede all other general and permanent ordinances passed by the governing body on or before March 17, 1981, to the extent provided in section 2 hereof. 
    Section 2. All provisions of such Code shall be in full force and effect from and after the 18th day of October, 1981, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted by the governing body on or before March 17, 1981, and not included in such Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are hereby repealed from and after the 18th day of October, 1981. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of such Code. Such repeal shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Whenever in such Code an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such Code the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of such Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for a period not exceeding six (6) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court, as provided in section 1-7 of such Code. 
    Section 5. Any and all additions and amendments to such Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the governing body to make the same a part thereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in such Code so that reference to the "Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas," shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. In case of the amendment of any section of such Code for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty as provided in section 4 of this ordinance and section 1-7 of such Code shall apply to the section as amended; or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty is provided in another section in the same chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. 
    Section 7. Any ordinances adopted after September 16, 1980, which amend or refer to ordinances which have been codified in such Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of such Code. 
    Section 8. One (1) copy of such Code shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk with the ordinance books of the city, and such copy shall constitute an ordinance book, as provided in section 12-3015 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated. It shall be the duty of the city clerk, or someone authorized by the clerk, to maintain such copy by inserting in their designated places all amendments and ordinances which indicate the intention of the governing body to make the same a part of such code, when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and by extracting from such copy all provisions which are repealed by the governing body. This copy of such Code shall be available to all persons desiring to examine the same. 
    Section 9. It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of Manhattan to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 4 of this ordinance. 
    Section 10. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed. 
    Section 11. This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, approval and publication in the official city newspaper of the City of Manhattan. 
/s/ ;hg;T. Russell Reitz 
Mayor 
ATTEST: 
/s/ Gregg W. Gibson 
City Clerk 
Passed and Approved: August 18, 1981. 
Published: August 23, 1981. 
SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
    The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code and are considered "Omitted." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The chapters, articles, divisions and sections embraced in this Code of Ordinances shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas," and may be so cited. This Code may also be cited as the "Manhattan Code." 
State Law reference- Revision and codification of ordinances, K.S.A. 12-3014-12-3016. 
Sec. 1-2. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be deemed to affect the validity of any of the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Charter ordinances; 
(2)  Ordinances pertaining to the acquisition of property or interests in property by gift, purchase, devise, bequest, appropriation or condemnation; 
(3)  Ordinances opening, dedicating, widening, vacating or narrowing streets, avenues, alleys and boulevards; 
(4)  Ordinances establishing and changing grades of streets, avenues, alleys and boulevards; 
(5)  Ordinances naming or changing the names of streets, avenues and boulevards; 
(6)  Ordinances authorizing or directing public improvements to be made; 
(7)  Ordinances creating districts for public improvements of whatsoever kind or nature; 
(8)  Ordinances levying general taxes; 
(9)  Ordinances levying special assessments or taxes; 
(10)  Ordinances granting any rights, privileges, easements or franchises therein mentioned to any person; 
(11)  Ordinances authorizing the issuance of bonds and other instruments of indebtedness by the city; 
(12)  Ordinances authorizing contracts; 
(13)  Ordinances establishing the limits of the city or pertaining to annexation or exclusion of territory; 
(14)  Ordinances pertaining to zoning; 
(15)  Ordinances pertaining to local traffic and parking regulations for specific streets; 
(16)  Ordinances which are policy-making in nature; 
(17)  Ordinances relating to compensation and benefits of officials, officers and employees of the city; 
Provided, that the above enumeration of exceptions shall not be held or deemed to be exclusive, it being the purpose and intention to exempt from repeal any and all ordinances not of a general nature and general ordinances specifically excepted by this section. 
(Ord. No. 3126, § 3, 3-6-73) 
Sec. 1-3. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, before the effective date of this Code. 
Sec. 1-4. - Amendments or additions to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any section, such repealed section may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages. Whenever any ordinance expresses the intent of the governing body that it be made a part of this Code and the same is thereafter included in a supplement to this Code, such inclusion shall have the same force and effect as if the ordinance had been included at the time of the original adoption of this Code by the governing body. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _______ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, is hereby amended to read as follows: ..." The section, as amended, shall then be set out in full. 
(c)  If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _______, which said section reads as follows: ..." The new section shall then be set out in full. 
State Law reference- Amendments to looseleaf codes, K.S.A. 12-3015. 
Sec. 1-5. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the governing body. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the governing body or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections (_______ to _______)" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-6. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the governing body that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable and, if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be held invalid or unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such holding shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the governing body without the incorporation in this Code of any such invalid or unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
Sec. 1-7. - General penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations. 
    Whenever in this Code or in any ordinances of the city an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine of not exceeding $500.00 or by imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment as may be just for any one offense, recoverable with costs of suit, together with judgment of imprisonment until the fine and costs are paid or satisfied. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
Sec. 1-8. - Class A violations. 
    Any section of this Code may specifically provide that the violation of such section is a Class A violation, for the purpose of establishing the amount of court costs applicable to such section, pursuant to the Charter Ordinance of the city establishing such court costs. In addition to those offenses specifically designated as Class A violations, violations of the following sections are considered Class A violations: 
(a)  Sec. 4-3. Purchase, consumption and possession of alcoholic liquor and cereal malt beverage by minors; furnishing to minors. 
(b)  Sec. 6-7. Keeping of dangerous or vicious animals prohibited. 
(c)  Sec. 6-24. Nuisances. 
(d)  Sec. 6-25. Dangerous dogs. 
(e)  Sec. 21-52. [Disorderly house nuisance] Violation. 
(f)  Sec. 22-16. Assault. 
(g)  Sec. 22-17. Battery. 
(h)  Sec. 22-29. Criminal trespass. 
(i)  Sec. 22-36. Interference with public officials and employees. 
(j)  Sec. 22-37. Resisting arrest. 
(k)  Sec. 22-47. Disorderly conduct. 
(l)  Sec. 22-50. Riot. 
(m)  Sec. 22-51. Incitement to riot. 
(n)  Sec. 22-53. Window peeping. 
(o)  Sec. 22-66. Deadly weapons. 
(p)  Sec. 22-67. Discharging firearms. 
(q)  Aiding or abetting, as defined in section 22-1, another in the commission of any violation listed above. 
(r)  Attempting, as defined in section 22-2, to commit any violation listed above. 
(Ord. No. 6309, § 1, 12-2-02) 
Sec. 1-9. - Admissibility of forensic examinations. 
(a)  In any hearing or trial, a report concerning forensic examinations and certificate of forensic examination executed pursuant to this section shall be admissible in evidence if the report and certificate are prepared and attested by a criminalist or other employee of the Kansas bureau of investigation, Kansas highway patrol or any laboratory of the federal bureau of investigation, federal postal inspection service, federal bureau of alcohol, tobacco and firearms or federal drug enforcement administration. If the examination involves a breath test for alcohol content, the report must also be admissible pursuant to subsection (f)(1) of K.S.A. 8-1001, and amendments thereto, and be conducted by a law enforcement officer or other person who is certified by the department of health and environment as a breath test operator as provided by K.S.A. 65-1107 et seq. and amendments thereto. 
(b)  Upon the request of any law enforcement agency, such person as provided in subsection (a) performing the analysis shall prepare a certificate. Such person shall sign the certificate under oath and shall include in the certificate an attestation as to the result of the analysis. The presentation of this certificate to a court by any party to a proceeding shall be evidence that all of the requirements and provisions of this section have been complied with. This certificate shall be sworn to before a notary public or other person empowered by law to take oaths and shall contain a statement establishing the following: The type of analysis performed; the result achieved; any conclusions reached based upon that result; that the subscriber is the person who performed the analysis and made the conclusions; the subscriber's training or experience to perform the analysis; the nature and condition of the equipment used; and the certification and foundation requirements for admissibility of breath test results, when appropriate. When properly executed, the certificate shall, subject to the provisions of subsection (c) and notwithstanding any other provision of law, be admissible evidence of the results of the forensic examination of the samples or evidence submitted for analysis and the court shall take judicial notice of the signature of the person performing the analysis and of the fact that such person is that person who performed the analysis. 
(c)  Whenever a party intends to proffer in a criminal or civil proceeding, a certificate executed pursuant to this section, notice of an intent to proffer that certificate and the reports relating to the analysis in question, including a copy of the certificate, shall be conveyed to the opposing party or parties within 20 days after arraignment, if a criminal proceeding or at least 20 days before a civil trial begins. An opposing party who intends to object to the admission into evidence of a certificate shall give notice of objection and the grounds for the objection within ten days upon receiving the adversary's notice of intent to proffer the certificate. Whenever a notice of objection is filed, admissibility of the certificate shall be determined not later than two days before the beginning of the trial. A proffered certificate shall be admitted in evidence unless it appears from the notice of objection and grounds for that objection that the conclusions of the certificate, including the composition, quality or quantity of the substance submitted to the laboratory for analysis or the alcohol content of a blood or breath sample will be contested at trial. A failure to comply with the time limitations regarding the notice of objection required by this section shall constitute a waiver of any objections to the admission of the certificate. The time limitations set forth in this section may be extended upon a showing of good cause. 
(Ord. No. 6309, § 2, 12-2-02) 
Secs. 1-10-1-20. - Reserved. 
Article II - RULES OF CONSTRUCTION AND DEFINITIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Rules of statutory construction, K.S.A. 77-201. 

Sec. 1-21. - Application of article. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the governing body, the rules set out in this article shall be observed and the definitions prescribed in this article shall apply, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the governing body. 
Sec. 1-22. - General rules of construction. 
    The provisions of this Code shall be liberally construed to effect the purposes expressed therein or implied from the expressions thereof. In case of doubt or ambiguity in the meaning of such provisions, the general shall yield to the particular. Reference for interpretation and construction shall tend to further the accomplishment of the elimination of the particular mischiefs for which the provisions were enacted. Words shall be construed according to the context and the approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases, and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law, shall be construed according to such meaning. 
Sec. 1-23. - Applicability of state law relative to misdemeanors. 
    The provisions of the laws of the state relating to misdemeanors, with reference to defense and construction of terms, insofar as the same relate to and are applicable, shall apply to this Code. 
State Law reference- Kansas Criminal Code, K.S.A. 21-3101 et seq. 
Sec. 1-24. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and, unless otherwise specifically provided, they shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-25. - Parenthetical and reference matter. 
    The matter in parentheses at the end of sections is for information only and is not a part of the Code. Citations to the 1973 Code of the city (Code 1973) and to later ordinances indicate only the source of such section and the text may or may not be changed by this Code. Reference matter not in parentheses is for information only and is not a part of this Code. 
Sec. 1-26. - Reference to Code, conflicts. 
    In addition to the rules of construction and definitions specified in this chapter, the following rules shall be observed in the construction of this Code: 
(1)  All references to chapters, articles or sections are to the chapters, articles and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
(2)  If the provisions of different chapters of this Code conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions of each chapter shall prevail as to all matters and questions growing out of the subject matter of such chapter. 
(3)  If conflicting provisions be found in different sections of the same chapter the provisions of the section which is last in numerical order shall prevail unless such construction would be inconsistent with the meaning of such chapter. 
Sec. 1-27. - City. 
    The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Manhattan, in the Counties of Riley and Pottawatomie, and State of Kansas. 
Sec. 1-28. - City officers, departments, etc. 
    Whenever reference is made to an officer, department, commission or other agency, the same shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Manhattan, Kansas." 
Sec. 1-29. - Code. 
    The term "Code" or "this Code" shall mean the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, as designated and cited in section 1-1. 
Sec. 1-30. - County. 
    The term "county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Riley or Pottawatomie, Kansas, whichever is applicable. 
Sec. 1-31. - Delegation of authority. 
    Whenever a provision appears in this Code requiring an officer of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize such officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section expressly designates otherwise. 
Sec. 1-32. - Gender. 
    A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships, associations and corporations, as well as to males. 
Sec. 1-33. - Governing body. 
    The term "governing body" shall mean the Board of Commissioners or City Commission of the City of Manhattan. 
Sec. 1-34. - Health officer; board of health. 
    Whenever the term health officer is used within the Code, that term shall mean the health officer of the Riley County-Manhattan Board of Health, or his authorized representative, and he shall have the full authority to enforce the ordinances of the city which pertain to health and sanitation. The terms "board of health" and "health department" shall refer to the Riley County-Manhattan Board of Health and Riley County-Manhattan Department of Health, respectively. 
(Ord. No. 3810, § 2, (9-102), 9-2-80) 
Sec. 1-35. - K.A.R. 
    The letters "K.A.R." shall mean the Kansas Administrative Regulations, as amended. 
Sec. 1-36. - K.S.A. 
    The letters "K.S.A." shall mean the Kansas Statutes Annotated, as amended. 
Sec. 1-37. - Month. 
    The word "month" shall mean a calendar month, unless otherwise expressed. 
Sec. 1-38. - Number. 
    Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
Sec. 1-39. - Oath. 
    The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
Sec. 1-40. - Or, and. 
    "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
Sec. 1-41. - Parkings. 
    The word "parkings" shall mean the area between the roadway and right-of-way line. 
Sec. 1-42. - Person. 
    The word "person" shall extend to corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. Such word shall also include unincorporated clubs, sororities, fraternities, associations and organizations of whatever name and nature. Where criminal prosecution may lie, the officers of any corporation shall jointly and severally be subject be prosecution as being included within the term "person." 
Sec. 1-43. - State. 
    The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Kansas. 
Sec. 1-44. - Tense. 
    Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
Sec. 1-45. - Written or in writing. 
    The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing, engraving, lithography or otherwise, except in those cases where the written signature or mark of any person is required. 
Sec. 1-46. - Year. 
    The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animal shelter, § 6-51 et seq.; airport advisory board, § 7-11 et seq.; building board of appeals, § 8-11 et seq.; electricians' board of examiners, § 8-76; plumbers' examining board, § 8-116; cemetery board, § 9-46 et seq.; human relations board, § 10-21 et seq.; public housing advisory board, § 11-11 et seq.; elections, Ch. 12; Riley County-Manhattan Board of Health, § 17-11 et seq.; library board, § 18-11 et seq.; licenses generally, Ch. 19; offenses affecting governmental functions, § 22-36 et seq.; advisory park board, § 23-16 et seq.; planning and zoning, Ch. 26; urban area planning board, § 26-16 et seq.; Big Lakes Regional Planning Commission, § 26-29 et seq.; police, Ch. 27; utilities, Ch. 32. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Public records; access, fees. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this section to establish reasonable fees and charges for the provision of access to or copies of open public records in the possession of the city to avoid the necessity of using general public funds of the city to subsidize special services and benefits to a record requester. The official record custodian shall periodically recommend to the governing body such changes in this section as may be necessary to secure this purpose. 
(b)  Inspection fee: 
(1)  Where a request has been made for inspection of any public record which is readily available to the record custodian, there shall be no inspection fee charged to the requester. 
(2)  In all cases not covered by subsection (b)(1) of this section, a record inspection fee shall be charged at the rate of $6.00 per hour per employee engaged in the record search. 
(c)  Copying fee: 
(1)  A fee of $0.10 per page shall be charged for photocopying public records, such fee to cover the cost of labor, materials and equipment. 
(2)  For copying any public records which cannot be reproduced by the city's photocopying equipment, the requester shall be charged the actual cost to the city, including staff time, in reproducing such records. 
(d)  Prepayment of fees: 
(1)  A record custodian may demand prepayment of the fees established by this section whenever he or she believes this to be in the best interest of the city. The prepayment amount shall be an estimate of the inspection and/or copying charges accrued in fulfilling the record request. Any overage or underage in the prepayment shall be settled prior to inspection of the requested record or delivery of the requested copies. 
(2)  Prepayment of inspection and/or copying fees shall be required whenever, in the best estimate of the record custodian, such fees are estimated to exceed $10.00. 
(3)  Where prepayment has been demanded by the record custodian, no record shall be made available to the requester until such prepayment has been made. 
(e)  Payment. All fees charged under this section shall be paid to the custodian of the records inspected and/or copied unless the requester has established an account, for purposes of billing and payment, with the city. All fees received shall be paid to the city treasurer daily. 
(Ord. No. 4126, §§ 1-5, 4-3-84) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4126, §§ 1-5, adopted Apr. 3, 1984, being nonamendatory of the Code, has been codified herein as § 2-1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2-2-2-10. - Reserved. 
Article II - GOVERNING BODY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Meetings of governing body, App. A, No. 7. 

Sec. 2-11. - Composition. 
    The governing body shall consist of five commissioners as provided by statute and they shall be elected as provided by law. The governing body may be referred to in this Code as the "city commission," "commission," "board of commissioners" or "governing body." 
(Code 1973, § 1-101) 
State Law reference- Governing board under commission-manager plan, K.S.A. 12-1006. 
Sec. 2-12. - Election, term of commissioners. 
(a)  Any person may become a candidate for city office elected at large by having had filed on their behalf, a nomination petition or a declaration of candidacy, accompanied by any fee required by law. The nomination petition must be signed by 50 qualified electors of the City of Manhattan. 
(b)  Three commissioners are elected on the Tuesday succeeding the first Monday of November in every odd-numbered year, the candidates receiving the largest and second largest number of votes, respectively, being elected for a four-year term, and the candidate receiving the third largest number of votes being elected for a two-year term. The three commissioners, two being elected to a four-year term, and one being elected to a two-year term, shall assume their official duties on the second Monday in January following certification of odd-year elections; provided, that said commissioners have otherwise executed their oath of office and filed their bond and done anything else necessary to qualify them to serve in such office. 
(Code 1973, § 1-102; Ord. No. 7195, § 1, 2-2-16) 
Sec. 2-13. - Powers generally. 
    All powers exercised by cities of the first class, or which shall hereafter be conferred upon them, shall be exercised by the governing body, insofar as they do not conflict with the provisions of the statutes relating to the city manager plan of government. 
(Code 1973, § 1-103) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1002. 
Sec. 2-14. - Title. 
    No distinction shall be made in title or duties among the commissioners, except as the governing body shall organize itself for business. 
(Code 1973, § 1-104) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1006. 
Sec. 2-15. - Chairman, mayor. 
    The governing body shall choose its own chairman annually, and the chairman shall have the title of mayor during the year of his office, to the end that the city shall have an official head on formal occasions. 
(Code 1973, § 1-105) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1007. 
Sec. 2-16. - Designation of acting mayor. 
    The mayor of the city shall be and is hereby empowered to designate from among the other members of the governing body then serving with him, a person who shall serve as acting mayor, such acting mayor to otherwise do and perform the duties of mayor during the absence of the regularly elected mayor and for the period of time specified by the regularly elected mayor. 
(Code 1973, § 1-106) 
Sec. 2-17. - Order of business. 
    The governing body shall determine its own order of business. 
(Code 1973, § 1-107) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1007. 
Sec. 2-18. - Ordinances. 
    The governing body shall pass all ordinances needful for the welfare of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 1-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1010; ordinances, K.S.A. 12-3001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-19. - Determination of officers and salaries. 
    The governing body shall provide for such offices as shall be necessary to carry out the provisions of the statutes relating to the city manager plan of government and determine salaries for the same. 
(Code 1973, § 1-109) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1010. 
Sec. 2-20. - Appointment of city manager. 
    The governing body shall appoint a manager as provided in this Code, and shall be responsible for his efficient administration of the city's business. 
(Code 1973, § 1-110) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1010. 
Sec. 2-21. - Departments. 
    Administrative departments shall be created by the governing body as the public business may demand. Such departments are hereinafter created in this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 1-112) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1015. 
Sec. 2-22. - Members not to interfere with conduct of departments. 
    No member of the city governing body shall directly interfere with the conduct of any department, except at the express direction of the governing body. 
(Code 1973, § 1-111) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1014. 
Sec. 2-23. - Emergency government. 
    When an emergency as defined by K.S.A. 48-1201 through 1210 occurs, it is contemplated that vacancies in local governmental offices both on the governing body and the position of city manager and other subordinate positions in the executive branch of the city government may result. The governing body or such members thereof as are capable of fulfilling and discharging their duties, in the event of an emergency such as hereinbefore referred to, shall have full, final and complete authority to fill any vacancies, that may occur on the governing body or in the office of city manager. The person appointed by reason of the authority of this section shall only receive such appointment if the duly elected or appointed person filling that position is unavailable as defined in K.S.A. 48-1201 through 1210 and such person so appointed shall continue to fulfill the office where such vacancy occurs for the period of time permitted by the applicable laws of the state. 
(Code 1973, § 1-113) 
State Law reference- Emergency interim executive and judicial succession act, K.S.A. 48-1201 et seq. 
Sec. 2-24. - Common disaster. 
    Unless otherwise provided, in the event of a catastrophe in which all, or a majority, of the members of the governing body are fatally injured, the interim governing body shall be composed of the surviving members, the city attorney, the city clerk, and a sufficient number of the appointed officials selected in the order of the greatest seniority in office to make up a governing body of the prescribed number. 
(Code 1973, § 1-114) 
Secs. 2-25-2-35. - Reserved. 
Article III - CITY MANAGER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- City manager plan, K.S.A. 12-1001 et seq. 

Sec. 2-36. - Administrator. 
    The administration of the city's business shall be in the hands of a manager. 
(Code 1973, § 1-201) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1011. 
Sec. 2-37. - Appointment; term. 
    The governing body shall, whenever by virtue of a vacancy in the office it becomes necessary, appoint a manager who shall be responsible for the administration of all of the affairs of the city, and hold office at the pleasure of the board. 
(Code 1973, § 1-202) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1011. 
Sec. 2-38. - Qualifications. 
    The person appointed as city manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of administrative ability and the choice shall not be limited by any residence qualifications. 
(Code 1973, § 1-202) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1012. 
Sec. 2-39. - Salary; bond. 
    The manager shall receive a salary to be fixed by the governing body and shall give bond for the faithful performance of his duties in such amount as may be provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 1-203) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1013. 
Sec. 2-40. - Duties generally. 
    The manager shall be responsible for the administration of all of the affairs of the city. He shall see that the laws and ordinances are enforced. He shall appoint and remove all heads of departments and all subordinate officers and employees of the city. All such appointments shall be made upon merit and fitness alone. He shall be responsible for the discipline of all appointive officers, and may, without notice, cause the affairs of any department or the conduct of any officer or employee to be examined. He shall prepare and submit the annual budget to the governing body and also keep the city fully advised as to the financial condition and needs of the city. He may make recommendations to the commissioners on all matters concerning the welfare of the city, and shall have a seat, but no vote, in all of the public meetings of the governing body. He shall perform such other and further duties as may be required by law or ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 1-204) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1014. 
Secs. 2-41-2-50. - Reserved. 
Article IV - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-51-2-55. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - OATHS AND BONDS 

Sec. 2-56. - Oath required for officers. 
    All elected or appointed officers of the city shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe an oath or affirmation as follows: 
    "I do solemnly swear (or affirm, as the case may be) that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Kansas, and faithfully discharge the duties of _______. So help me God." 
(Code 1973, § 1-401) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 54-106. 
Sec. 2-57. - Bonds required. 
    Officers and employees of the city shall each, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices and jobs give a good and sufficient surety company bond to the city, approved by the governing body, in the amount specified herein or as shall be required by the governing body, conditioned upon the officer's or employee's faithful performance and faithful discharge of the officer's or employee's respective duties. Bonds for the following officers and employees shall be in the following amounts: 
(1)  Commissioners, each ..... $5,000.00 
(2)  City treasurer ..... 50,000.00 
(3)  All other employees of the city will be covered by a faithful performance blanket position bond in the amount of ..... 5,000.00 
(Code 1973, §§ 1-402, 1-403) 
State Law reference- Bond of mayor and commissioners, K.S.A. 13-1805. 
Sec. 2-58. - Condition of bonds. 
    The bonds provided for in this division shall be made payable to the city and shall be conditioned for the faithful discharge and performance of the respective duties of the officers and employees of the city and to save the city free from all loss caused by their neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. 
(Code 1973, § 1-404) 
Sec. 2-59. - How bonds approved. 
    All bonds provided for in this division shall be submitted to and approved by the city attorney as to form; and after such approval by the city attorney such bonds shall be approved by the city manager as to sufficiency. 
(Code 1973, §§ 1-405, 1-410) 
State Law reference- Approval of bonds, K.S.A. 13-2005. 
Sec. 2-60. - Premiums on bonds paid by city. 
    The premiums on all surety bonds required by this division shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 1-406) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 78-111. 
Sec. 2-61. - Surety company bonds required. 
(a)  All bonds for the use, benefits or protection of the city, required to be taken by the statutes of the state and by the ordinances of the city and by resolution of the governing body of the city from any person to secure the faithful performance of any contract with the city, or to indemnify the city against loss, damage or liability growing out of any contract with the city, or out of the issuance of any license or permit by the city where a bond is required, shall be signed and executed as surety by some responsible surety company lawfully doing business in the state. No bond signed and executed by an individual as surety shall be accepted and approved by the city manager in such cases. 
(b)  All bonds required for the use, benefit or protection of the city as set forth in subsection (a), shall be signed and executed as surety by some responsible surety company lawfully doing business in the state and maintaining a local agent in the city, through whose agency such bonds must pass before being approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 1-408) 
Sec. 2-62. - How bonds signed and executed; to whom made. 
    All bonds provided for in this division shall be signed and executed by the party or parties from whom such bonds are required in addition to the sureties on such bonds, and except where otherwise provided by law, the bonds shall be made to the city. 
(Code 1973, § 1-409) 
Division 3 - DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN 

Sec. 2-63. - Deferred compensation plan. 
(a)  The City of Manhattan hereby elects to join and participate in the Kansas Public Employees Deferred Compensation Plan, as authorized by K.S.A. 75-5529a; and by virtue of the power vested in the city by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, the city hereby elects to establish additional deferred compensation plans. 
(b)  There is hereby established a city deferred compensation committee which shall consist of three officers and/or employees of the city. The human resources director shall be a member and chairman of the committee, the city clerk shall be a member and secretary of the committee, and the city manager shall be a member. The purpose of the deferred compensation committee shall be to select companies that participate in the city's deferred compensation plans and to review other administrative matters related to the deferred compensation plans. 
(c)  The human resources director is hereby charged with the duties of serving as local administrator of the plans and shall provide forms to all city employees to specify the amount of any compensation voluntarily deferred, make appropriate reductions from the gross compensation of such employees, and serve as chairman of the deferred compensation committee established by subsection (b) of this section. The human resources director shall transfer to the Aetna Company the amount so deferred in accordance with the conditions established under the plan joinder agreement for the Kansas Public Employees Deferred Compensation Plan and shall transfer to the designated third party the amount so deferred in accordance with the conditions established under any additional deferred compensation plan agreements. 
(d)  The city, being authorized to become a joint contract owner with the state of the group annuity contract issued by Aetna Life Insurance and Annuity Company, in conjunction with the Kansas Public Employees Deferred Compensation Plan, hereby authorizes and approves execution of a plan joinder agreement and a contract joinder agreement and any other contracts and agreements necessary to implement any deferred compensation plans. The mayor shall sign such agreements. 
(e)  The city clerk shall cause an accounting to be made to each employee participating in the city's deferred compensation plans of the amount contributed, and such other information as may be required by the committee. The city shall not be responsible for any loss incurred by an employee under the city's deferred compensation plans adopted and approved by this section. 
(Ord. No. 6235, § 1, 9-4-01) 
Secs. 2-64-2-70. - Reserved. 
Article V - ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENTS 
Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-71. - Created. 
(a)  There are hereby created in and for the City of Manhattan, Kansas, the following administrative departments: 
(1)  Department of community development; 
(2)  Department of finance; 
(3)  Department of human resources; 
(4)  Department of law; 
(5)  Department of administration; 
(6)  Airport department; 
(7)  Department of fire services; 
(8)  Department of parks and recreation; 
(9)  Department of public works. 
(b)  Wherever the codes, or ordinances of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, refer to the "director of services" or, the "director of services department", such phrase shall be deemed to mean the department of public works if the context deals with streets, engineering services, or various utilities of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 1-301; Ord. No. 3326, § 1, 11-19-74; Ord. No. 4979, § 1, 7-9-96; Ord. No. 6335, § 1 5-20-03) 
Sec. 2-72. - Administration generally. 
    The manner in which each individual department is structured shall be established by the city manager. The affairs of the various administrative departments of the city shall be administered by officers and employees, or departments or boards as may be provided by the Code or other ordinances, all of whom shall be appointed by the city manager, unless otherwise provided by law, and shall hold office at his/her pleasure; provided, that the manager need not appoint or employ any officer or employee herein provided for, when the business of the city shall not require it. The duties of such officers and employees, departments or boards shall be as determined by the city manager, unless established by provisions of this Code, other ordinances of the city, or by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1973, § 1-302; Ord. No. 3326, § 2, 11-19-74; Ord. No. 4979, § 2, 7-9-96) 
Sec. 2-73. - Manager may act in any capacity. 
    The city manager may perform the duties of any office or department whose office he is qualified to fill and in such cases the appointment or employment of such officer may be dispensed with until such time as the city manager shall in his discretion fill the department or function. 
(Code 1973, § 1-312; Ord. No. 3326, § 12, 11-19-74) 
Secs. 2-74-2-80. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - DEPARTMENT OF LAW 

Secs. 2-81-2-83. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 4979, adopted July 9, 1996, repealed §§ 2-81-2-83 in their entirety. Former §§ 2-81-2-83 pertained to the creation, composition and purpose of the city's department of law and derived from the 1973 Code, §§ 1-301-1-303; Ord. No. 3326, §§ 1-3, adopted Nov. 19, 1974; and Ord. No. 3498, § 1, adopted June 21, 1977. 
Sec. 2-84. - City attorney-Qualifications. 
    No person shall be eligible to the office of city attorney who is not by profession an attorney at law admitted to practice in the supreme court of the state. 
(Code 1973, § 1-303; Ord. No. 3326, § 3, 11-19-74; Ord. No. 3498, § 1, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 2-85. - Same-Duties generally. 
    The city attorney or his assistant shall appear and prosecute or defend all cases wherein the city is a party in all courts, he shall advise the governing body, the city manager, and officers of the city upon all legal questions affecting the duties of their offices or the interest of the city as may be submitted to him, and perform other professional services incident to his office. 
(Code 1973, § 1-303; Ord. No. 3326, § 3, 11-19-74; Ord. No. 3498, § 1, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 2-86. - Municipal judge-Qualifications. 
    No person shall be eligible to the office of municipal judge who is not by profession an attorney at law admitted to practice in the supreme court of the state, and who has not served in the active profession of the practice of law for a minimum of five years. 
(Code 1973, § 1-303; Ord. No. 3326, § 3, 11-19-74; Ord. No. 3498, § 1, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 2-87. - Same-Duties generally. 
    The municipal judge will perform the judicial function of the city. He is authorized and empowered to exercise his independent judgment in all cases brought before his court without influence or interference by any city official elected or appointed. The municipal judge shall hear all cases brought into the municipal court, and shall have the power to bring before the municipal court all parties for trial upon complaints duly and properly made. He shall possess and exercise all the powers as conferred and defined by law. The city manager is authorized to appoint additional municipal judges or divisions of court from time to time as necessary. The city manager shall designate the judge of one of the divisions as administrative judge. The administrative judge shall have the authority to appoint a clerk to assist in the administration of the court, said clerk to be a salaried employee of the city. The administrative judge shall keep, and require other divisions of the court to keep, such dockets and other records as required by law, and shall make periodic accountings of all monies received as required by good accounting and audit procedures. 
(Code 1973, § 1-303; Ord. No. 3326, § 3, 11-10-74; Ord. No. 3498, § 1, 6-21-77) 
Secs. 2-88-2-95. - Reserved. 
Division 3 - DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN RESOURCES[4] 

Footnotes:

No. 3326, §§ 1, 2, 4, adopted Nov. 19, 1974.

Division 6 - FIRE DEPARTMENT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention, Ch. 13. 

Secs. 2-136-2-138. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 4979, adopted July 9, 1996, repealed §§ 2-136-2-138 in their entirety. Former §§ 2-136-2-138 pertained to the creation, supervision and functions of the fire department and derived from the 1973 Code, §§ 1-301, 1-307; and Ord. No. 3326, §§ 1, 7, adopted Nov. 19, 1974. 
Sec. 2-139. - Fire equipment reserve fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created a special revenue fund of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, to be known as the fire equipment reserve fund. 
(b)  Each year there may be a mill levy in the fire equipment reserve fund not to exceed two mills. 
(c)  Monies in the fire equipment reserve fund shall be expended only for the purchase of fire equipment as may be budgeted by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 4530, §§ 1-3, 8-16-88) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4530, §§ 1-3, adopted Aug. 16, 1988, being not expressly amendatory of this Code, has been included as § 2-139 at the discretion of the editor. 
State Law reference- Authority for establishment of fund, K.S.A. 12-1106. 
Secs. 2-140-2-145. - Reserved. 
Division 7 - SERVICES DEPARTMENT 

Secs. 2-146-2-149. - Reserved.

Former §§ 2-146-2-149, 2-151-2-153 pertained to the creation, composition, supervision and divisions of the services department; and derived from the 1973 Code, §§ 1-301, 1-302, 1-308; Ord. No. 3326, §§ 1, 2, 8, adopted Nov. 19, 1974; and Ord. No. 3441, § 2, adopted Sept. 28, 1976.

No. 3919, § 4, adopted Dec. 15, 1981, and included herein as § 2-184. Former § 2-150 was derived from Code 1973, § 1-308; Ord. No. 3326, § 8, adopted Nov. 19, 1974; and Ord. No. 3441, § 2, adopted Sept. 28, 1976.

Division 10 - DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3919, adopted Dec. 15, 1981, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-8 as §§ 2-181-2-188 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Douglass Center Board, § 2-226 et seq.; cemeteries, Ch. 9; parks and recreation, Ch. 23. 

Sec. 2-181. - Created. 
    There is hereby created, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-1914, a combined parks and recreation department for the City of Manhattan, Kansas. 
(Ord. No. 3919, § 1, 12-15-81) 
Sec. 2-182. - Appointment of director, officers and employees. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to appoint such officers and employees as may be necessary for the proper operation of the parks and recreation department, including the appointment of a director of the parks and recreation department. 
(Ord. No. 3919, § 2, 12-15-81) 
Sec. 2-183. - Director responsible to city manager. 
    The parks and recreation department shall be under the direction and control of the director of parks and recreation who shall be responsible to the city manager for the functions described below and such other functions as assigned by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 3919, § 3, 12-15-81) 
Sec. 2-184. - Organization. 
    The parks and recreation department shall be composed of the following: 
(a)  Divisions. 
(1)  Parks and facilities division: 
a.  Parks. 
b.  Cemetery. 
c.  Forestry. 
d.  Facilities maintenance. 
(2)  Recreation division: 
a.  Sports activities. 
b.  Arts and crafts. 
(b)  Special activities. 
(1)  Douglass Center. 
(2)  Zoo. 
(Ord. No. 3919, § 4, 12-15-81) 
Sec. 2-185. - Parks and facilities division. 
    The parks and facilities division shall plan, supervise and maintain the parks, cemetery, and forestry of the city as well as all facilities located within the department, with the exception of those located within the aforementioned special activities. 
(Ord. No. 3919, § 5, 12-15-81) 
Sec. 2-186. - Recreation division. 
    The recreation division shall plan and supervise all recreation programs within the city, with the exception of those located at the aforementioned special activities. 
(Ord. No. 3919, § 6, 12-15-81) 
Sec. 2-187. - Director of Douglass Center. 
    The director of Douglass Center shall be responsible for all facilities located at the center as well as all recreation activities and community programs that take place there. The director of Douglass Center is hereby specifically directed to cooperate with the superintendent of the parks and facilities division as well as the superintendent of the recreation division for functions that overlap with those divisions. The director of Douglass Center shall report directly to the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 3919, § 7, 12-15-81) 
Sec. 2-188. - Curator of the zoo. 
    The curator of the zoo shall be responsible for all facilities located at the zoo as well as all recreation activities that take place there. The curator of the zoo is hereby specifically directed to cooperate with the superintendent of the parks and facilities division as well as the superintendent of the recreation division for functions that overlap with those divisions. The curator of the zoo shall report directly to the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 3919, § 8, 12-15-81) 
Secs. 2-189, 2-190. - Reserved. 
Article VI - BOARDS, AGENCIES AND COMMISSIONS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Airport advisory board, § 7-11 et seq.; building board of appeals, § 8-11 et seq.; electricians' board of examiners, § 8-76; plumbers' examining board, § 8-116; cemetery board, § 9-46 et seq.; human relations board, § 10-21 et seq.; public housing advisory board, § 11-11 et seq.; Riley County-Manhattan Board of Health, § 17-11 et seq.; library board, § 18-11 et seq.; advisory park board, § 23-16 et seq.; urban area planning board, § 26-16 et seq.; Big Lakes Regional Planning Commission, § 26-29 et seq. 

Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-191. - Governing body to assume duties of urban renewal agency board. 
(a)  Pursuant to the constitution and laws of the state, the governing body does hereby and herein assume all powers formerly exercised by the urban renewal agency board. 
(b)  This assumption of powers and duties of the urban renewal agency board by the governing body shall include all past, present and future activities relating to urban renewal including the exercise of the power of eminent domain, substitution of parties in any and all pending litigation and any future litigation, the ownership of and power to convey full title to all property, both real and personal of the urban renewal agency, and any and all other powers and duties created by operation of law. 
(Ord. No. 3374, 8-26-75) 
State Law reference- Urban renewal law, K.S.A. 17-4742 et seq. 
Secs. 2-192-2-205. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - CITY ENVIRONMENTAL BOARD 

Sec. 2-206. - Created. 
    There is hereby created in and for the city a group to be known as the city environmental board. 
(Code 1973, § 1-601) 
Sec. 2-207. - Purposes. 
    It shall be the purpose of the city environmental board to conduct investigations, hold public meetings, undertake comprehensive studies and do and perform those things necessary in order to ascertain whether or not there exists in this community, environmental conditions which are in fact detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city. Generally, it is recommended to said board that they inquire into, and endeavor to ascertain whether or not, air, water, sight or noise pollution is existing or whether other conditions prevail, all of which are dangerous to, or otherwise inimical to the well being of the city and its occupants. 
(Code 1973, § 1-604) 
Sec. 2-208. - Composition. 
    The city environmental board shall be composed of nine members. 
(Code 1973, § 1-602) 
Sec. 2-209. - Appointment. 
    The members of the city environmental board shall be appointed by the governing body. 
(Code 1973, § 1-602) 
Sec. 2-210. - Terms. 
    Of the members first appointed to the city environmental board, three shall be appointed for a term of one year; three shall be appointed for a term of two years and three shall be appointed for a term of three years. On the expiration of the term of each board member, he or his successor, shall be appointed for a term of three years. 
(Code 1973, § 1-602) 
Sec. 2-211. - Filling vacancies. 
    Any vacancy occurring in the membership of the city environmental board shall be filled by appointment of the governing body for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1973, § 1-602) 
Sec. 2-212. - Officers. 
    The members of the city environmental board shall elect a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary from among their numbers. 
(a)  The chairman shall preside at all meetings and otherwise serve as the official head of such board. 
(b)  The vice-chairman shall act in the absence of the chairman. 
(c)  The secretary shall record the proceedings of the board and otherwise maintain a written record of their deliberations and activities. This will include a permanent file of minutes in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1973, § 1-603; Ord. No. 3240, § 1, 2-19-74) 
Sec. 2-213. - Meetings. 
    The city environmental board shall hold meetings within their requirements whether on call and/or on work schedule as necessary, and a regular public meeting to be held each quarter at a time and place established by the board itself; provided, however, that the chairman will cause publication notice of the date, time and place of each regular meeting to be had in the official city newspaper at least two days in advance of the meeting. 
(Code 1973, § 1-603; Ord. No. 3240, § 1, 2-19-74) 
Sec. 2-214. - Make recommendations. 
    It shall be the purpose of the city environmental board, after ascertaining the true facts about the conditions existing in the community, to thereafter make recommendations to the body as to policies which may be adopted or a specific course of action which may be pursued by the governing body in order to terminate, abate or nullify said detrimental condition. Further the board shall make recommendations to the governing body of positive programs designed to improve the health, safety, welfare and attractiveness of the city, and the conservation and wise use of the resources of this community. 
(Code 1973, § 1-605) 
Sec. 2-215. - Liaisons appointed. 
    The city environmental board will work closely with the city planning board and the city park board in pursuance of these goals, and the board shall appoint one of its members to act as liaison with the city planning board and one of its members to act as liaison with the city park board. Furthermore, these three city boards will exchange minutes of their respective meetings with each other. 
(Code 1973, § 1-606) 
Sec. 2-216. - Annual report. 
    The city environmental board will make an annual report in writing to the governing body on its activities, accomplishments and needs, which report will be submitted in January of each year. 
(Code 1973, § 1-607) 
Secs. 2-217-2-225. - Reserved. 
Division 3 - DOUGLASS CENTER BOARD[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Organizations of parks and recreation department, § 2-184; director of Douglass Centers, § 2-187. 

Sec. 2-226. - Created. 
    There is hereby created in and for the city an advisory board to be known as the Douglass Center Board. 
(Code 1973, § 1-701) 
Sec. 2-227. - Purposes. 
    The Douglass Center Board shall recommend administration policy to the governing body for the operation of the Douglass Center in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 1-701) 
Sec. 2-228. - Composition. 
    The personnel of the Douglass Center Board shall consist of seven members. Four of the members shall be residents of either Ward 1 or Ward 4, Precinct 1, of the city. The remaining three members may be residents of any part of the city. A reasonable, and good faith, effort shall be made to appoint two persons to the board who are under the age of 18. If the mayor, after reasonable, and good faith, effort is unable to find enough qualified persons under 18 who are willing to serve on the Douglass Center Board, the mayor shall notify the board of that situation. Upon such notification the board shall have 45 days to recommend qualified person(s) to fill the vacancy or vacancies. In such instance the board may recommend any qualified person, regardless of age. The mayor, upon receiving such recommendation from the board may choose to appoint the person(s) recommended or may appoint person(s) of his/her own choosing. 
(Code 1973, § 1-701; Ord. No. 6099, § 1, 11-2-99; Ord. No. 6251, § 1, 12-18-01; Ord. No. 6622, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 2-229. - Appointment. 
    The members of the Douglass Center Board shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the governing body. 
(Code 1973, § 1-702; Ord. No. 5088, § 1, 1-20-98) 
Sec. 2-230. - Terms. 
(a)  Each member of the Douglass Center Board shall serve for a period of three years. Except initially: three for one year, three for two years, and three for three years. If a petition is submitted to the governing body, signed by 20 percent or more of those qualified and registered to vote and who further reside in the specified geographical area as set forth in section 2-228, then and in that event, the governing body may authorize an election to elect the five members of the board to come from the specified geographical area. The rules and regulations for conducting the election shall be determined by the governing body. The Douglass Center Board shall be responsible for the conduct of the election pursuant to the rules and regulations as promulgated by the governing body. 
(b)  The members of the board, while appointed for a term for the convenience of the city, shall serve in that term at the pleasure of the governing body. 
(Code 1973, § 1-702; Ord. No. 5088, § 2, 1-20-98) 
Sec. 2-231. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No 5088, adopted Jan. 20, 1998, repealed § 2-231 which pertained to removal from the Douglass Center Board and derived from § 1-703 of the 1973 Code. 
Sec. 2-232. - Filling vacancies. 
    In the event of a vacancy in the membership of the Douglass Center Board, the same shall be filled by the governing body for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1973, § 1-702) 
Sec. 2-233. - Ex officio member. 
    The human relations board shall appoint one of its members who will serve as ex officio member of the Douglass Center Board. Such ex officio member may participate in the deliberations of the Douglass Center Board, but shall not be entitled to vote. 
(Code 1973, § 1-703) 
Sec. 2-234. - Meetings. 
    The Douglass Center Board shall hold regular monthly public meetings at a time and place to be specified by the board. The Douglass Center Board may hold additional public meetings upon the call of the chairman or upon written request from four or more members of the board. 
(Code 1973, § 1-703) 
Sec. 2-235. - Uses of center. 
    The governing body does hereby declare that the Douglass Center is open to all persons of this community, regardless of race, color, creed, age, sex or national origin. Further, it shall be one of the purposes of the Douglass Center Board to determine and suggest to the governing body certain specific policies which will encourage and enhance the fullest and wisest use of Douglass Center. 
(Code 1973, § 1-704) 
Sec. 2-236. - Advisory powers. 
    The governing body does hereby specifically state that the Douglass Center Board shall have advisory powers in the following areas, to wit: 
(1)  Board shall advise the governing body on the scope and content of programs to be initiated at Douglass Center. The governing body does specifically instruct board to be mindful of the fact that said programs should be designed to serve the interest and needs of the community and provide for all groups in the community without restriction to race, religion, age, sex or national origin. The board is further authorized to employ all public resources available in order to insure effective implementation of programs once commenced. 
(2)  The board shall prepare an annual budget for the operation of the Douglass Center and shall recommend the adoption of the same to the governing body. 
(3)  The board shall advise and counsel with the city manager and the governing body on the size and quality of the staff, both volunteers and professionals, who may be needed to work with the director of Douglass Center in order to implement the programs of the center. The board shall formulate a job description and specify qualifications desired for director of the center or other staff positions. 
(4)  The board shall aid in the solicitation of applications for all staff members. In the case of director and supervisor, notice of openings or vacancies in either or both of these positions shall be advertised in the official city newspaper for not less than five consecutive days and by whatever other means the board may deem necessary. The board will assist in determining the contents of the advertising for these positions but the city manager will be responsible for its publication and distribution. After examining the applications for director, supervisor or any other potential staff member, the board shall make effective recommendations in writing to the city manager who shall then be charged with the responsibility for filling these positions. 
(5)  The board shall submit to the governing body written monthly and annual reports covering all aspects of the operations of the Douglass Center. 
(Code 1973, § 1-705) 
Sec. 2-237. - Utilization of resources. 
    The governing body recognizing the contribution now made at Douglass Center by the recreation commission and other groups in the community, does instruct the Douglass Center Board to continue to utilize the resources of the recreation commission and such other groups in the planning, scheduling and implementation of activities and programs at the center. The governing body does further direct that the Douglass Center Board be constantly alert to initiate measures designed to stimulate enjoyment and creativity in the use of leisure time, strengthen family life, encourage interest in learning, and try to stimulate pride and accomplishment to the members of our community. The governing body does further direct the Douglass Center Board to initiate measures incorporating philosophies of integration in all areas of community life in this city. 
(Code 1973, § 1-706) 
Sec. 2-238. - By-laws; quorum. 
    The Douglass Center Board shall adopt by-laws as necessary for the conduct of the board, subject to approval by the governing body. The by-laws shall establish that four members of the board shall constitute a quorum and be necessary for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 5088, § 4, 1-20-98) 
Division 4 - PUBLIC BUILDING COMMISSION[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4495, §§ 1, 2, adopted Feb. 2, 1988, being not specifically amendatory of this Code, has been included as §§ 2-239, 2-240 at the discretion of the editor, treated as superseding former §§ 2-239-2-244, which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3945, §§ 1-6, adopted Apr. 20, 1982. 

Sec. 2-239. - Creation; membership; term. 
    There is hereby created a public building commission which shall be a municipal corporation, the governing body of which shall consist of five members, all of whom shall be the duly elected or appointed city commissioners of the City of Manhattan, Kansas. Each such elected or appointed city commissioner of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, shall automatically become and be a member of the governing body of the public building commission and shall so serve during the entire time, but only so long as he or she shall continue as a duly elected or appointed city commissioner of said city. 
(Ord. No. 4495, § 1, 2-2-88) 
Sec. 2-240. - Purposes, functions and powers. 
    The public building commission is hereby created for the following purposes and shall be and is hereby authorized to exercise the following functions and powers, to wit: 
(a)  To acquire a site or sites for and construct, reconstruct, equip and furnish a building or buildings or other facilities of a revenue-producing character, including parking facilities, or purchase or otherwise acquire such building or buildings or facilities, and such building or buildings or facilities shall be maintained and operated for the housing and accommodation of city offices, county courthouses, jails or correctional facilities, offices for school districts, or offices for state or federal agencies, or such other purposes as are commonly carried on in connection with such facilities. 
(b)  To acquire land and facilities, including leasehold interest therein, adjacent to or near Kansas State University, and constructing, reconstructing, equipping and furnishing such facilities on such land and the leasing or subleasing of such land and facilities to any board of trustees of Kansas State University or to the official governing body of said university. 
(c)  To rent all or any part of its buildings or other facilities to any federal, state or county governmental agency, or any municipal corporation, quasi municipal corporation, political subdivision or body politic, or agency thereof doing business, maintaining an office, or rendering a public service within the City of Manhattan or within Riley or Pottawatomie Counties. Further, to rent any space as may be needed by such governmental agencies for such service facilities as the public building commission may determine will primarily service the comfort and convenience of the occupants of its buildings or other facilities. 
(d)  If the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a tenant of any building or facility owned by the public building commission, the commission shall have the power to allow the city to sublease all or any portion of such building or facility to any other governmental agency or to any private entity. However, if the City of Manhattan, Kansas, chooses to lease all or any part of such building to a private entity, the governing body of the city shall determine that the portion so leased to a private entity is not needed for any public purpose of the city. 
(e)  To issue revenue bonds of the public building commission to provide funds for the purposes set forth herein and to pay all costs and expenses incident thereto or to refund its outstanding bonds. 
(f)  To establish and fix rates, rentals, fees and charges for the use of any and all buildings or space therein or other facilities owned and operated by the commission, sufficient at all times to pay maintenance and operation costs of such buildings or facilities, as well as the principle of an interest on all bonds issued by the commission when the same shall become due and payable, and to make all payments to any accounts created by any bond resolution. 
(g)  To acquire the fee simple title to real property or a leasehold interest in real property, including easements and reversionary interests in the streets, alleys and other public places and personal property required for its purposes, by purchase, gift, devise or by exercise of the power of eminent domain of the state, and title thereto shall be taken in the corporate name of the commission. 
(h)  To enter into written leases with tenants of its buildings or facilities under such terms and conditions as it shall deem appropriate, not inconsistent with the provisions of this division, the laws of the State of Kansas, and Charter Ordinance No. 26 of the City of Manhattan, Kansas. 
(i)  To convey title to real estate it shall hold title to and sell, assign, transfer, trade any of its interest in personal property. 
(j)  To do all things necessary and incidental to the purpose of constructing or acquiring or enlarging, furnishing and equipping, and operating and maintaining buildings to be made available for use pursuant to this division, together with all powers afforded it by the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1757 et seq., and Charter Ordinance No. 26. 
(Ord. No. 4495, § 2, 2-2-88) 
Secs. 2-241-2-245. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to Art. VI, Div. 4. 
Article VII - FINANCE 
Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-246-2-250. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - INVESTMENT OF IDLE FUNDS 

Sec. 2-251. - Background. 
    The city receives and disburses substantial amounts of money.
