While certain requirements relating to the handling of public monies are set forth in state law, a written statement of policies and procedures governing the management and investment of monies under the custody of the city is advisable to provide direction to all officers and employees and to inform the general public and concerned financial institutions as to the policies and practices of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 1, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-252. - Purposes and goals. 
    It is the purpose of this division to set forth the public policies of the city relating to the investment of public monies and to establish procedural requirements as to investment management practices. The objectives of the investment policy and program of the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  The safeguarding of all public monies shall be of the highest priority. Public money shall not be invested or managed in any manner which would jeopardize the safety of the principal. 
(2)  Consistent with the requirements of safety, the objective of the investment program shall be to aggressively manage and invest all public monies to maximize net earnings, consistent with the cost of administering the investment program. The city has a public responsibility to secure the maximum, safe investment return possible from monies assigned to its stewardship, to relieve demands on the property tax and to otherwise reduce the cost of public services. 
(3)  The investment program shall be conducted in a businesslike manner and without preferential treatment of any person. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 2, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-253. - General investment programs. 
    The public funds of the city shall be managed according to the following categories: 
(1)  Investment of special fund monies; 
(2)  Investment of temporary inactive monies; and 
(3)  Management of active funds, as hereinafter described. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 3, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-254. - Investment of special fund monies. 
    Monies in special funds such as bond funds, housing authority funds and cemetery perpetual care funds, the investment of which is governed by state law, shall be invested only in accordance with the provisions of such law, namely K.S.A. 10-131, K.S.A. 17-2345 and K.S.A. 17-1319 respectively. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 4, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-255. - Investment of inactive monies. 
(a)  Public monies which are not immediately required by the city for the purpose for which the monies were collected or received, shall be invested in: 
(1)  Temporary notes; 
(2)  Time deposit, open accounts or certificates of deposit; 
(3)  United States treasury bills or notes; and 
(4)  Share or savings deposits of state or federally chartered savings and loan associations; 
(5)  In repurchase agreements of less than 30 days duration with commercial banks or trust companies. 
(b)  All of the above types of investments shall be made in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1675 and K.S.A. 17-5002. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 5, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-256. - Management of active funds. 
    Active funds or monies may be maintained or invested as follows: 
(1)  In checking accounts in any bank which has been designated as a public depository of the city; 
(2)  In savings accounts in any bank which is providing checking account services for the city. The transfer of monies between checking accounts and savings accounts shall be in conformity with any applicable state or federal laws or regulations. The finance director-treasurer or city clerk may authorize such transfers in the name of the city by notification in writing, in person or by telephone; 
(3)  In repurchase agreements with any state or national bank; 
(4)  In such other investments as may be authorized by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 6, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-257. - Investment procedures. 
    The finance director-treasurer shall develop and implement a cash management and investment program in accordance with the provisions of this division and shall report in writing monthly to the city manager and at least quarterly to the governing body as to the progress and interest earnings of the program. A cash flow analysis shall be maintained by such officer to assure that the maximum feasible amount is invested or deposited in savings accounts at all times. Notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1671, the liquidity and maturity of all invested monies shall be such as to permit the prompt payment of all financial obligations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 7, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-258. - Care of securities. 
    Securities purchased pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be under the joint care and custody of the finance director-treasurer and the city clerk, or shall be held in the custody of a state or national bank or trust company. Securities in original or receipt form shall be held in the name of the city and their redemption, transfer or withdrawal shall be permitted by authorization in person of either the finance director-treasurer or the city clerk and by endorsement of the security or receipt form when required. If there are any negotiable securities entrusted to the city, such securities shall be deposited in a safety deposit box of a bank or trust company, access to which shall be permitted only in the personal presence and under the signature of at least two officials from the following offices: City treasurer, city clerk, assistant city manager and city manager. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 8, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-259. - Transfer or sale of securities. 
    If, in order to maintain sufficient monies on demand deposit in any fund, it becomes necessary to transfer or sell any securities invested pursuant to this division, the finance director-treasurer or city clerk may transfer such securities to any other fund or funds in which there are temporary inactive monies, or may sell such securities and, for such purposes, the finance director-treasurer or city clerk shall have authority to make any necessary written directions, endorsements or assignments for and on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 9, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-260. - Crediting and use of earnings. 
    All interest or other earnings received from investments made pursuant to this division shall be credited to the fund from which monies are invested with the exception of interest earned on transfer accounts (passbook savings in banks) and repurchase agreements wherein such interest earned shall be prorated monthly to the general revenue sharing fund, water fund and sewage fund with the balance to be credited to the general operating fund. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 10, 6-3-80) 
Sec. 2-261. - Records and reports required. 
    The finance director-treasurer shall maintain a complete and detailed record at all times of all investments made pursuant to this division, and shall keep such other schedules and prepare such reports as may be necessary or as requested by the governing body or the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 3793, § 11, 6-3-80) 
Chapter 3 - ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Advertisements at airports, § 7-56; loudspeakers, amplifiers, for advertising, § 22-55(2). 
State Law reference- Highway advertising control act, K.S.A. 68-2231 et seq. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Billposting in streets. 
    No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp or paste any sign, advertisement, or any other matter upon any signpost, electric light, railway, telegraph or telephone pole, shade tree, fire hydrant; or on any bridge, pavement, sidewalk or crosswalk, public building or any property or thing belonging to the city, or on any article or thing within any park. Public officers posting any notice required or permitted by law shall be excepted from the provisions of this section. 
Sec. 3-2. - Billposting in private places. 
    No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp or paste any sign, advertisement, or other matter upon any house, wall, fence, gate, post, tree, without first having obtained the permission of the owner, or occupants of the premises and having complied with all provisions of this Code pertaining thereto. 
Secs. 3-3-3-15. - Reserved. 
Article II - DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS 

Sec. 3-16. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Handbill. Any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature. 
    Newspaper. Any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the post office department of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year, and sold to the public, and shall mean and include any other copyrighted material. 
    Vehicle. Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-21 et seq. 
Sec. 3-17. - Exemption for mail and newspapers. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States, nor to newspapers, except that newspapers shall be placed on private property in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
Sec. 3-18. - Inhabited private premises. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except by handling or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant or other person then present in or upon such private premises. Provided, however, that in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted, such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such premises if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or sidewalks, streets or other public places, and except that mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulation. 
Sec. 3-19. - Protection of lawns. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the distribution of handbills to cut across or walk upon any lawn, front yard or court yard except upon sidewalks, where sidewalks are provided, or upon regularly established paths where no sidewalks have been provided to the house or building. 
Sec. 3-20. - Prohibited where properly posted. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any handbill upon any private premises, if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on such premises a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisement," or any similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of such premises do not wish to have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any handbills left upon such premises. 
Cross reference- Similar provisions for peddlers, § 24-4. 
Sec. 3-21. - Depositing on uninhabited or vacant premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any private premises which is uninhabited or vacant. 
Sec. 3-22. - Restricted in public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute or sell any handbill in any public place; except that a handbill may be personally delivered to any person willing to accept the same. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 30. 
Sec. 3-23. - Placing on automobiles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, as principal or agent, to place or cause to be placed any handbills in, or hang the same upon any part of any motor vehicle, while such motor vehicle is in use upon the streets or standing parked upon the streets or in public off street parking areas of the city; provided, that this section shall not be construed to prevent the officers or employees of the city from so doing for any municipal purposes. 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 31. 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Secs. 1-67 of Ord. No. 6958, adopted Aug. 14, 2012, amended ch. 4 in its entirety to read as herein set out. See Code Comparative Table for prior amendatory history. 
Cross reference- Consumption of alcohol at airport, § 7-60; alcoholic liquor prohibited in memorial auditorium, § 23-52. 
State Law reference- Intoxicating liquors and beverages, K.S.A. Ch. 41 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Alcoholic liquor means alcohol, spirits, wine, beer and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer and capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being, but shall not include any cereal malt beverage. 
    Alcoholic liquor retailer means a person who sells at retail, or offers for sale at retail, alcoholic liquors, but shall not include a microbrewery, microdistillery, or farm winery. 
    Caterer means an individual, partnership or corporation which sells alcoholic liquor by the individual drink, and provides services related to the serving thereof, on unlicensed premises which may be open to the public, but does not include a holder of a temporary alcoholic liquor permit, selling alcoholic liquor in accordance with the terms of such permit. 
    Cereal malt beverage means any fermented but undistilled liquor brewed or made from malt or from a mixture of malt or malt substitute or any flavored malt beverage, as defined in K.S.A. 41-2729 and amendments thereto, including beer as defined by K.S.A. 41-102, but not including any such liquor which is more than six percent alcohol by weight. 
    Cereal malt beverage retailer means any person who sells or offers for sale any cereal malt beverage for use or consumption and not for resale in any form. 
    Class A club means a premises which is owned or leased by a corporation, partnership, business trust or association and which is operated thereby as a bona fide nonprofit social, fraternal or war veterans' club, as determined by the State of Kansas, for the exclusive use of the corporate stockholders, partners, trust beneficiaries or associates (hereinafter referred to as members), and their families and guests accompanying them. 
    Class B club means a premises operated for profit by a corporation, partnership or individual, to which members of such club may resort for the consumption of food or alcoholic beverages and for entertainment. 
    Club means a Class A or Class B club. 
    Distributor or wholesaler means the person importing or causing to be imported into the state, or purchasing or causing to be purchased within the state, alcoholic liquor for sale or resale to retailers licensed under the Kansas Liquor Control Act and this chapter, or cereal malt beverage for sale or resale to any off-premises cereal malt beverage retailer or any on-premises cereal malt beverage retailer licensed under this chapter. 
    Drinking establishment means premises which may be open to the general public, where alcoholic liquor by the individual drink is sold. 
    Employee means any person employed in the business of selling cereal malt beverages or alcoholic liquor by a licensee. 
    Farm winery means a winery licensed by the State of Kansas to manufacture, store and sell domestic table wine and domestic fortified wine, as defined by state law. 
    Fundraising location means any location where complimentary alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages are provided pursuant to K.S.A. 41-104(h) and amendments thereto. 
    Licensee means the person who has been properly issued a license to sell cereal malt beverages and/or alcoholic liquor within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Manufacturer means every brewer, fermenter, distiller, rectifier, wine maker, blender, processor, bottler or person who fills or refills an original package and others engaged in brewing, fermenting, distilling, rectifying or bottling alcoholic liquor, beer or cereal malt beverage, but shall not include a microbrewery, microdistillery, or a farm winery. 
    Microbrewery means a brewery licensed by the State of Kansas to manufacture, store and sell domestic beer, as defined by state law. 
    Microdistillery means a facility which produces spirits from any source or substance that is licensed by the State of Kansas to manufacture, store and sell spirits. 
    Minor means a person under 21 years of age. 
    Off-premises cereal malt beverage retailer means a licensee who has a license to sell or offer for sale cereal malt beverages in original and unopened containers and not for consumption on the premises or for resale in any form. 
    On-premises cereal malt beverage retailer means a licensee who has a license to sell or offer for sale cereal malt beverages for consumption on the licensed premises and not for resale in any form. 
    Open space area means any unimproved tract, parcel or piece of land presently owned or leased or hereafter owned or leased by the city, which land shall be maintained primarily in a natural state or condition. 
    Park or recreation area shall mean any tract, parcel or piece of land designated by the city as a park or recreation area. 
    Person means any natural person, corporation, partnership or association. 
    Place of business means any place where cereal malt beverages are sold. 
    Premises means the specific area described in a license or permit application and approved as the location upon which the cereal malt beverages and/or alcoholic liquor may be sold, served, and/or consumed under the license or permit. 
    School means any public or private facility which conducts regular classes, pre-kindergarten through grade 12, or any portion thereof, and which meets the minimum educational standards set forth by the State of Kansas. In addition, school shall also include any publicly owned or operated vocational-technical institution. 
    Sell at retail, sale at retail, or sold at retail mean sales for use or consumption and not for resale in any form and sales to clubs, licensed drinking establishments, licensed caterers or holders of temporary permits. It does not refer to or mean sales by a distributor, a microbrewery, a farm winery, a licensed club, a licensed drinking establishment, a licensed caterer, or a holder of a temporary permit. 
    Temporary alcoholic liquor permit means a temporary permit, issued in accordance with the laws of the State of Kansas, which allows the permit holder to offer for sale, sell and serve alcoholic liquor for consumption on unlicensed premises, which may be open to the public, subject to the terms of such permit. 
    Temporary cereal malt beverage permit means a temporary permit, issued in accordance with the laws of the State of Kansas, which allows the permit holder to offer for sale, sell and serve cereal malt beverages for consumption on unlicensed premises, which may be open to the public, subject to the terms of such permit. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 1, 8-14-12; Ord. No. 7403, § 1, 2-19-19) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-21 et seq. 
State Law reference- Similar definitons, K.S.A. 41-2701. 
Sec. 4-2. - Consumption and possession in certain places forbidden. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage, or to possess an open container holding such cereal malt beverage or alcoholic liquor, while upon the public streets, sidewalks, alleys, parking lots, roads, parks, recreation areas, open space areas, or highways within the city, or upon property owned by the state or any governmental subdivision thereof, pursuant to K.S.A. 41-719, and amendments thereto. 
(b)  Neither subsection (a) nor K.S.A. 41-719 shall apply to persons possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage within the Sunset Zoological Park, so long as such alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage is possessed and consumed in conformity with state law, city ordinances, and all rules and regulations governing the use of the Sunset Zoological Park. 
(c)  Neither subsection (a) nor K.S.A. 41-719 shall apply to persons possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage within the confines of the Manhattan Regional Airport passenger terminal, so long as such alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage was purchased from an airport concessionaire licensed to sell alcoholic liquor and/or cereal malt beverages, and, so long as such alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage is possessed and consumed only in areas designated by the airport director for such activities, and done so in a manner that conforms with state law, city ordinances, and airport rules and regulations. 
(d)  Neither subsection (a) nor K.S.A. 41-719 shall apply to persons possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage within the confines of the Union Pacific Depot, so long as such alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage is possessed and consumed in conformity with state law, city ordinances, and all rules and regulations governing the use of the Union Pacific Depot. 
(e)  Neither subsection (a) nor K.S.A. 41-719 shall apply to persons possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage within the confines of the Jon and Ruth Ann Wefald Pavilion, so long as such alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage is possessed and consumed in conformity with state law, city ordinances, and all rules and regulations governing the use of the Wefald Pavilion. 
(f)  Neither subsection (a) nor K.S.A. 41-719 shall apply to persons possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage within the confines of the Flint Hills Discovery Center, within its outdoor terraces, or within the driveway and parking lot south and southeast of the Flint Hills Discovery Center, more particularly described as Lot 7 of the Downtown Entertainment District Commercial PUD, so long as such alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage is possessed and consumed in conformity with state law, city ordinances, all rules and regulations governing the use of the Flint Hills Discovery Center, and, when applicable, the terms and conditions of a city special event permit. 
(g)  Neither subsection (a) nor K.S.A. 41-719 shall apply to persons possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage within the public park known, for purposes of this article, as Blue Earth Plaza, and more particularly described as Lot 8 of the Downtown Entertainment District Commercial PUD, so long as such alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage is possessed and consumed only in areas designated by the parks and recreation director for such activities, and done so in a manner that conforms with state law, city ordinances, all rules and regulations governing the use of Blue Earth Plaza, and, when applicable, the terms and conditions of a city special event permit. 
(h)  Neither subsection (a) nor K.S.A. 41-719 shall apply to persons possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage on specified property, title of which is vested in the city, that the city has exempted by ordinance or resolution, if such possession and consumption is in accordance with the ordinance or resolution. 
(i)  A violation of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than $50.00 or more than $200.00, or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 2, 8-14-12; Ord. No. 7379, § 1, 10-2-18) 
Sec. 4-3. - Purchase, consumption and possession of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages by minors; furnishing to minors; hosting minors under the age of 21. 
(a)  No person under the age of 21 shall obtain or purchase, or attempt to obtain or purchase, alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage from any person. 
(b)  No person under the age of 21 shall possess or consume alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage, except: 
(1)  Said persons may possess or consume cereal malt beverage only when such cereal malt beverage is furnished and the possession or consumption is permitted and supervised by the person's parent or legal guardian. Such possession or consumption may not occur on premises licensed to sell cereal malt beverage or alcoholic liquor or at any other location where possession or consumption is prohibited by law. 
(2)  An employee who is not less than 18 years of age may dispense or sell cereal malt beverage, if the place of business of the employer is licensed solely as an off-premises cereal malt beverage retailer and not for consumption on the premises; or the place of business of the employer is a licensed food service establishment, as defined by K.S.A. 36-501 and amendments thereto, and not less than 50 percent of the gross receipts from the place of business is derived from the sale of food for consumption on the premises. 
(3)  Such person may serve alcoholic liquor as permitted by state law. 
(c)  No person shall furnish alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage to any person under the age of 21. Furnishing alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage to a minor is recklessly, directly or indirectly, buying for or distributing any alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage to any minor. This section shall not apply to the furnishing of cereal malt beverage by a parent or legal guardian to such parent's child or such guardian's ward at a location other than upon premises licensed to sell cereal malt beverage or any other location where possession of such cereal malt beverage would be prohibited by law. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to host a minor who is consuming or possessing alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage. Unlawfully hosting minors consuming or possessing alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage is recklessly permitting a person's residence or any land, building, structure or room owned, occupied or procured by such person to be used by an invitee of such person or an invitee of such person's child or ward, in a manner that results in the unlawful possession or consumption therein of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages by a minor. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee or permit holder, or the owner, officer or employee thereof, to permit, whether knowingly or unknowingly, any person under the age of 21 to possess or consume alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage upon the premises where the alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages are sold by such licensee or permit holder. There shall be a rebuttable presumption that any person possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage upon the premises has been permitted to possess or consume such alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage by the owner, officer and employee of said establishment. This section shall not apply to the dispensing of cereal malt beverage or the serving of alcoholic liquor as set forth in subparagraphs 4-3(b)(2) and 4-3(b)(3) above. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or manager of any establishment licensed as an on-premises cereal malt beverage retailer to allow or permit any person under the age of 18 to enter or remain upon such premises between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. if cereal malt beverages are available for sale or being consumed on the premises, unless: 
(1)  Such person under the age of 18 is accompanied by a parent or guardian; or 
(2)  Such person under the age of 18 is an employee of such establishment, and is not involved in the dispensing or selling of cereal malt beverages. 
    There shall be a rebuttable presumption that any person located within such premises has been permitted and allowed to enter and remain there by the owner, operator and manager of such establishment. 
(g)  Penalties. 
(1)  The penalty for a violation of subsection 4-3(a) or 4-3(b) shall be a minimum fine of $200.00, not to exceed $500.00, or a term of imprisonment not to exceed one month, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(2)  The penalty for a violation of subsection 4-3(c) or 4-3(f) shall be a minimum fine of $200.00, not to exceed $500.00, or a term of imprisonment not to exceed six months, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(3)  The penalty for a violation of subsection 4-3(d) shall be a minimum fine of $1,000.00, not to exceed $2,500.00, or a term of imprisonment not to exceed one year, or both such fine and imprisonment. If the court sentences the offender to perform community service or public service work as a condition of probation or parole, the court shall consider ordering the offender to serve the community or public service at an alcohol treatment facility. 
(4)  The penalty for a violation of subsection 4-3(e) shall be a minimum fine of $100.00, not to exceed $250.00, or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(h)  In addition to any other penalty provided, under a violation of subsection (a) or (b) of this section: 
(1)  The court may order the offender to do either or both of the following: 
(i)  Perform 40 hours of community service; or 
(ii)  Attend and satisfactorily complete a suitable educational or training program dealing with the effects of alcohol or other chemical substances when ingested by humans; and 
(2)  The court shall order the following: 
(i)  Upon a first conviction, the court shall order the division of vehicles to suspend the offender's driving privileges for 30 days. Upon receipt of the court order, the division shall notify the violator and suspend the driving privileges of the violator for 30 days whether or not that person has a driver's license. 
(ii)  Upon a second conviction, the court shall order the division of vehicles to suspend the offender's driving privileges for 90 days. Upon receipt of the court order, the division shall notify the violator and suspend the driving privileges of the violator for 90 days whether or not that person has a driver's license. 
(iii)  Upon a third or subsequent conviction, the court shall order the division of vehicles to suspend the driving privileges of such offender for one year. Upon receipt of the court order, the division shall notify the violator and suspend the driving privileges of the violator for one year whether or not that person has a driver's license. 
(3)  For the purposes of determining whether a conviction is a first, second, third or subsequent conviction: 
(i)  "Conviction" includes being convicted of a violation of subsections (a) or (b) of this section, or being convicted of a violation of a law of any state or any ordinance of any city, or resolution of any county, which prohibits the acts that subsections (a) or (b) prohibit. 
(ii)  "Conviction" shall not include entering into a diversion agreement in lieu of further criminal proceedings for a violation of subsections (a) or (b), or a violation of a law of any state or any ordinance of any city, or resolution of any county, which prohibits the acts that subsections (a) or (b) prohibit. 
(iii)  Any convictions occurring during a person's lifetime shall be taken into account when determining the sentence to be imposed. 
(iv)  It is irrelevant whether an offense occurred before or after conviction for a previous offense. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 3, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-4. - Restrictions upon the possession and consumption of alcoholic liquor and cereal malt beverages upon premises and fundraising locations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator, manager, or employee of any premises, or any location where complimentary alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages are provided pursuant to K.S.A. 41-104(h) and amendments thereto, to permit or allow any person to possess or consume either alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages upon the premises or the fundraising location, except as follows: 
(1)  Within the confines of a building located upon the premises or the fundraising location; or 
(2)  Within an outdoor area upon the premises or fundraising location, if such area is fenced or screened such that access from outside of said fenced or screened area can only be gained through the building upon the premises, or through specific gates or doors. Access to such outdoor areas shall provide the proper egress required by the applicable fire codes. Such outdoor area shall be contiguous to the building on the premises or fundraising location, and shall not include any parking areas. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator, manager or employee of any premises or fundraising location to permit or allow any person to exit the areas described in subparagraph 4-4(a) while in possession of an open container of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage, except an exit directly to another area as described in subparagraph 4-4(a). 
(c)  There shall be a rebuttable presumption that any person possessing an open container of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage upon a premises, a fundraising location, or while exiting an area as described in subparagraph 4-4(a), has been permitted to do so by the owner, operator, manager and employee of said premises or fundraising location. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 4, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-5. - Sale to certain persons forbidden. 
(a)  No person shall knowingly sell, give away, dispose of, exchange or deliver, or permit the sale, gift or procuring of any alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage to or for any person who is an incapacitated person, or any person who is physically or mentally incapacitated by the consumption of such alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage. 
(b)  Violation of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not exceeding $250.00 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 6758, § 5, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-715. 
Secs. 4-6-4-10. - Reserved. 
Article II - ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR RETAILERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate sales, K.S.A. 41-208. 

Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-11. - Hours of sale. 
    No person shall sell at retail any alcoholic liquor in the city on the following days and hours: 
(1)  On any day, Monday through Saturday, before 9:00 a.m. or after 11:00 p.m. 
(2)  On any Sunday when sale is permitted, before 12:00 noon and after 8:00 p.m.; or 
(3)  On Easter Sunday, Thanksgiving Day, or Christmas Day. 
(Code 1973, § 3-105; Ord. No. 4893, § 2, 11-1-94; Ord. No. 6783, § 1, 9-15-09; Ord. No. 6815, § 1, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-712; K.S.A. 41-2911. 
Sec. 4-12. - Retailers: Mixing drinks on premises; employment of certain persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for a retailer of alcoholic liquor: 
(1)  To permit any person to mix drinks in or on the licensed premises; 
(2)  To employ any person under the age of 21 years in connection with the operation of such retail establishment; or 
(3)  To employ any person in connection with the operation of such retail establishment who has been adjudged guilty of a felony. 
(Code 1973, § 3-106) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-713. 
Sec. 4-13. - Reserved. 
Secs. 4-14, 4-15. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-16. - Restrictions on location. 
(a)  No person shall sell at retail any alcoholic liquor in its original unopened containers within 200 feet of any public or parochial school. 
(b)  No person shall sell at retail any alcoholic liquor in its original unopened containers within 200 feet of any college. 
(c)  No person shall sell at retail any alcoholic liquor in its original unopened containers within 200 feet of a church. 
(d)  No alcoholic liquor shall be sold at retail upon any premises which have an inside entrance or opening which connects with any other place of business. 
(e)  The restrictions of subsections 4-16(a)-(c) shall not apply if the school, college, or church is established within 200 feet of the licensed premises after the premises have already been licensed. 
(f)  The distances set forth in this section shall be measured from the property line of the school, college, or church to the nearest entrance or exit of the establishment selling alcoholic liquor, which is available to, and normally used by, the public, by the shortest route which a pedestrian would normally walk. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 8, 8-14-12) 
Secs. 4-17-4-20. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR RETAILER'S LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference- Licensing and related provisions, K.S.A. 41-301 et seq. 

Sec. 4-21. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is obligated to have in such person's possession an alcoholic liquor retailer's license issued by the State of Kansas to sell, keep for sale, offer for sale, or expose for sale any alcoholic liquor unless he or she also has in his or her possession a valid, unexpired license issued by the city for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 10, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-22. - Application; issuance; term. 
(a)  Any person desiring to secure a license under this division shall make and file an application on a form provided by the city clerk. The application and the fee for new or renewal city licenses shall be submitted to the city clerk, along with a copy of a valid license, issued to the applicant by the State of Kansas, for the same activity to be licensed by the city. 
(b)  The city clerk shall issue a city license if the applicant has met the application requirements set forth in subsection (a), and if the proposed location complies with all code and zoning requirements of the city. 
(c)  The term of the city license shall coincide with the term of the license issued by the State of Kansas, and the city license shall expire at the same time the license issued by the State of Kansas expires. No license issued under this division shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 11, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-23. - Revocation or suspension, appeal. 
(a)  The city manager, upon five days written notice to the person holding a license under this division, may permanently revoke, or cause to be suspended, such license for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The licensee fraudulently obtained the license by giving false information in the application therefor or any hearing thereon; 
(2)  The licensee violated any provisions of the Kansas Liquor Control Act, K.S.A. 41-101 et seq., and amendments thereto, or any rules or regulations adopted thereunder; 
(3)  There has been a violation of a provision of the laws of Kansas, or of the United States, or the City of Manhattan, pertaining to the sale of intoxicating or alcoholic liquors, or any crime involving a morals charge, on premises where alcoholic liquor is sold by such licensee; 
(4)  The licensee has become ineligible to obtain a license or permit under this division; 
(5)  There has been a violation of K.S.A. 21-4106 or 21-4107, and amendments thereto, on premises where alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages are sold by such licensee. 
(b)  Within 20 days after the order of the city manager revoking or suspending any license, the licensee may appeal such order to the district court; provided, that such appeal shall not suspend the order of revocation or suspension during the pendency of the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 12, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-24. - Fee. 
(a)  The license fee for an alcoholic liquor retailer's license shall be $600.00. 
(b)  Any person to whom a license has been issued under this division may surrender such license to the city clerk at such time as the license is no longer necessary, and may at such time request a prorated refund of the license fee paid hereunder. The city clerk shall refund a prorated amount of the license fee based upon the number of unexpired whole months remaining in the license term from the date of surrender. No such refund shall be applicable to any license that is revoked or withdrawn pursuant to the provisions of this chapter or state laws regulating the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 13, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-25. - Display. 
    Every licensee shall cause his license to be framed and hung in plain view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 14, 8-14-12) 
Secs. 4-26-4-32. - Reserved. 
Article III - PRIVATE CLUBS, DRINKING ESTABLISHMENTS, CATERERS AND TEMPORARY ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR PERMIT HOLDERS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Licensing, regulation of clubs, K.S.A. 41-2601 et seq. 

Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-33. - Business regulations. 
(a)  No club, drinking establishment, or caterer licensed hereunder, or temporary alcoholic liquor permit holder shall allow the serving, mixing, or consumption of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage on its premises between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any day. 
(b)  No club membership shall be sold to any person under 21 years of age, nor shall alcoholic beverages or cereal malt beverages be given, sold, or traded to any person under 21 years of age, by any licensee, temporary alcoholic liquor permit holder, their agents, or employees. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 17, 8-14-12; Ord. No. 7376, § 1, 9-18-18) 
Sec. 4-34. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-35. - Entry; inspection. 
    The right of immediate entry to, and inspection of, any premises licensed as a club or drinking establishment or any premises where alcoholic liquor is sold by a holder of a temporary alcoholic liquor permit, or any premises subject to the control of any licensee or temporary alcoholic liquor permit holder, by any duly authorized officer or agent of the director of alcoholic beverage control, or by any law enforcement officer, shall be a condition on which every license or temporary alcoholic liquor permit is issued, and the application for, and acceptance of, any license or temporary permit shall conclusively be deemed to be the consent of the applicant and licensee or permit holder to such immediate entry and inspection. Such right of immediate entry and inspection shall be at any time when the premises are occupied and is not limited to hours when the club or drinking establishment is open for business. Such consent shall not be revocable during the term of the license or temporary alcoholic liquor permit. Refusal of such entry shall be grounds for revocation of the license or temporary alcoholic liquor permit. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 19, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2613) 
Division 2 - LICENSE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 19. 

Sec. 4-36. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is obligated to have in such person's possession a drinking establishment license, club license, or caterers license issued by the State of Kansas to sell or serve any alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage authorized by such license within the city unless they also have in their possession a valid, unexpired license issued by the city for such purpose. No license shall be issued by the city until such time as the State of Kansas has issued its appropriate licenses. In addition, no city license shall be issued hereunder until the premises to be used by said licensee complies with all codes and ordinances of the City of Manhattan, Kansas. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 21, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2620. 
Sec. 4-37. - Application; issuance; term. 
(a)  Any person desiring to secure a license under this division shall make and file an application on a form provided by the city clerk. The application and the fee for new or renewal city licenses shall be submitted to the city clerk, along with a copy of a valid license, issued to the applicant by the State of Kansas, for the same activity to be licensed by the city. 
(b)  The city clerk shall issue a city license, if the applicant has met the application requirements set forth in subsection 4-37(a), and if the proposed location complies with all code and zoning requirements of the city. 
(c)  The term of the city license shall coincide with the term of the license issued by the State of Kansas and the city license shall expire at the same time the license issued by the State of Kansas expires. If the license issued by the State of Kansas is revoked or withdrawn for any reason, the license issued by the city shall be deemed to be revoked and withdrawn as of the date of revocation or withdrawal of the state license. Every licensee shall cause their license to be placed in plain view on the licensed premises or, in the case of a caterer, where such caterer is serving or mixing alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 22, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-38. - Fee. 
(a)  The license fee for all licenses under this division shall be as follows: 
(1)  Class A clubs ..... $500.00 
(2)  Class B clubs ..... $500.00 
(3)  Caterers ..... $500.00 
(4)  Drinking establishments ..... $500.00 
(b)  Any person to whom a license has been issued under this division may surrender such license to the city clerk at such time as the license is no longer necessary, and may at such time request a prorated refund of the license fee paid hereunder. The city clerk shall refund a prorated amount of the license fee based upon the number of unexpired whole months remaining in the license term from the date of surrender. No such refund shall be applicable to any license that is revoked or withdrawn pursuant to the provisions of this chapter or state laws relating to the sale and consumption of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 23, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Authority for fee, K.S.A. 41-2622. 
Sec. 4-39. - Restrictions on location. 
(a)  No license under the terms of this division shall be issued to any person for a location unless it complies with all relevant zoning regulations and other ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Any premises licensed under this division prior to August 19, 2012, shall be exempt from the restrictions set forth in subsection 4-39(a) above. The exemption granted by reason of this subsection shall terminate if the premises cease to be licensed for a period of more than 120 consecutive days. Any bona fide purchaser from a licensee covered hereunder shall likewise succeed to the exemption granted in this subparagraph; provided, that the exemption granted by reason of this subparagraph shall terminate if the premises cease to be licensed for a period of more than 120 consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 24, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-40. - Transfer. 
    No license issued under the provisions of this division shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 25, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-41. - Records. 
    Every person holding a license to operate an establishment under this division shall at all times maintain in the place of the establishment a current list of all officers, directors, stockholders, owners and members and the name of the manager, if any, subject to inspections by any authorized officer or agent. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 26, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-42. - Revocation or suspension, appeal. 
(a)  The city manager, upon five days written notice to the person holding a license under this division, may permanently revoke, or cause to be suspended, such license for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The licensee fraudulently obtained the license by giving false information in the application therefor or any hearing thereon; 
(2)  The licensee violated any provisions of the Kansas Club and Drinking Establishment Act, K.S.A. 41-2601 et seq., and amendments thereto, or any rules or regulations adopted thereunder; 
(3)  The licensee has become ineligible to obtain a license or permit under this division; 
(4)  There has been a violation of a provision of the laws of Kansas, or of the United States, or the City of Manhattan, pertaining to the sale of intoxicating or alcoholic liquors or cereal malt beverages, or any crime involving a morals charge, on premises where alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages are sold by such licensee; 
(5)  There has been a violation of K.S.A. 21-4106 or 21-4107, and amendments thereto, on premises where alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages are sold by such licensee. 
(b)  At any time, the governing body may request the director of alcoholic beverage control of the state department of revenue to hold a hearing on whether any state license issued pursuant to the K.S.A. 41-2601 et seq., and amendments thereto, should be revoked or suspended. 
(c)  Within 20 days after the order of the city manager revoking or suspending any license, the licensee may appeal from such order to the district court; provided, that such appeal shall not suspend the order of revocation or suspension during the pendency of the appeal. In case of the revocation of a license of any licensee, no new license shall be issued to such person or to any person acting for or on his behalf for a period of two years after the revocation becomes effective. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 27, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2611. 
Sec. 4-43. - Caterers, notice to Riley County Police Department. 
    At least two days prior to any event at which a caterer will sell or serve alcoholic liquor by the individual drink, the caterer shall provide written notice to the director of the Riley County Police Department. The notice shall contain the location, name of the group sponsoring the event, and the exact date and times the caterer will be serving alcoholic liquor. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 28, 8-14-12) 
Division 3 - TEMPORARY PERMIT 

Sec. 4-44. - Temporary alcoholic liquor permits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, sell and serve any alcoholic liquor for consumption on unlicensed premises at any event within the city without first obtaining a local temporary alcoholic liquor permit from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 30, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-45. - Same, application. 
(a)  An application for a temporary alcoholic liquor permit to be issued by the city shall be made at least ten days before the event. 
(b)  Written application for the permit shall be made on a form provided by the city clerk. In addition to any other information required, the applicant shall provide the following: 
(1)  The name and residence of the applicant; 
(2)  The length of time that the applicant has resided within the state of Kansas; 
(3)  The premises for which the permit is to be issued; 
(4)  The group for which the event is planned; 
(5)  The date and time of the event; 
(6)  The duration of the event; 
(7)  Any anticipated need for police, fire, or other municipal services; 
(8)  A statement that the applicant is a citizen of the United States, not less than 21 years of age, and that the applicant has not within two years immediately preceding the date of making application been convicted of a felony, any crime involving moral turpitude, drunkenness, driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, or violation of any other intoxicating liquor law of any state, municipality, or of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 31, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-46. - Same, standards for issuance. 
(a)  Upon presentation of a state temporary alcoholic liquor permit, payment of the city's temporary alcoholic liquor permit fee, and a written application as provided for hereinbefore, the city clerk shall issue a local temporary alcoholic liquor permit to the applicant, if there are no conflicts with any zoning or other ordinances of the city. 
(b)  No temporary alcoholic liquor permit shall be issued for an event that requires a special event permit pursuant to chapter 31, article IV of this Code. 
(c)  No more than four temporary alcoholic liquor permits may be issued to any one applicant in a calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 32, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-47. - Same, permit fee. 
    The fee for a temporary alcoholic liquor permit shall be $25.00 per day, which shall be paid at the time the application is submitted. Such fee shall be in addition to any fee due to the State of Kansas, whether collected by the city or the state. No fee paid pursuant to this division shall be refundable. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 33, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-48. - Same, permit term, transfer. 
(a)  The term of the temporary alcoholic liquor permit shall coincide with the term of the temporary permit issued by the State of Kansas. The temporary alcoholic liquor permit shall expire at the same time the temporary permit issued by the State of Kansas expires. If a temporary permit issued by the State of Kansas is revoked or withdrawn for any reason, the temporary alcoholic liquor permit issued by the city shall be deemed to be revoked and withdrawn as of the date of revocation or withdrawal of the state temporary permit. 
(b)  No temporary alcoholic liquor permit issued hereunder shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 34, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-49. - Same, regulations. 
(a)  Every temporary alcoholic liquor permit holder shall cause the permit to be placed in plain view at the event entrance along with the name of the permit holder, and a diagram of the premises covered by the permit; 
(b)  No temporary alcoholic liquor permit holder may allow anyone under the age of 21 to possess, purchase or consume alcoholic liquor upon the permitted premises; 
(c)  Every temporary alcoholic liquor permit holder must allow immediate entry and inspection by the alcoholic beverage control agents or other law enforcement officers; 
(d)  No temporary alcoholic liquor permit holder shall allow the consumption of alcoholic liquor between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m.; 
(e)  All local ordinances and state statutes for the sale, serving and consumption of alcoholic liquor apply to holders of temporary alcoholic liquor permits. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 35, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-50. - Same, revocation. 
(a)  The city clerk or the Riley County Police Department, upon written notice to the permit holder, delivered to the permit holder's address as listed on the application for such permit or personally delivered to the permit holder at the permitted premises, may revoke or suspend a temporary alcoholic liquor permit for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The permit holder violated any regulation in section 4-49; 
(2)  The permit holder violated any state law or city ordinance pertaining to the sale, serving or consumption of alcoholic liquor on the premises during the term of the permit; 
(3)  The permit holder violated a condition or restriction placed upon the permit; 
(4)  Criminal activity has occurred on the premises during the term of the permit, for which a citation is issued or an arrest made, that is reasonably likely to cause injury or threat to persons or property or to create an unreasonable disturbance. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 36, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-51. - Same, appeal. 
    Within 20 days after the order of the city clerk or Riley County Police Department revoking, suspending, or denying a temporary alcoholic liquor permit, the permit holder may file a written appeal to the city manager. Any appeal taken from an order revoking or suspending the permit shall not suspend the order of revocation or suspension. If the city manager upholds the order revoking, suspending, or denying a temporary alcoholic liquor permit, the appellant may appeal such order to the district court; provided, that such appeal shall not suspend the order of revocation or suspension during the pendency of the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 37, 8-14-12) 
Secs. 4-52--4-62. - Reserved. 
Article IV - CEREAL MALT BEVERAGES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Cereal malt beverages, K.S.A. 41-2701 et seq., 79-3817 et seq. 

Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-63. - Hours and days of sale, consumption. 
(a)  No off-premises cereal malt beverage retailer, or any agent or any employee of any off-premises cereal malt beverage retailer, shall sell or provide cereal malt beverages on the licensed premises: 
(1)  On Sunday before 12:00 noon or after 8:00 p.m.; 
(2)  On Easter Sunday; or 
(3)  On any day, Monday through Saturday, before 6:00 a.m. or after 12:00 midnight. 
(b)  No on-premises cereal malt beverage retailer, or any agent or any employee of such on-premises cereal malt beverage retailer, shall sell, provide, or otherwise dispense cereal malt beverages on the licensed premises: 
(1)  On any day before 6:00 a.m. or after 12:00 midnight; 
(2)  On Sunday, except if the on-premises cereal malt beverage retailer derives not less than 30 percent of its gross receipts from the sale of food for consumption on the licensed premises. 
(c)  No on-premises cereal malt beverage retailer's place of business shall be open to the public or otherwise occupied by any person other than the licensee's agents, employees, or personnel between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(d)  Nothing contained in this section shall restrict or prevent the sale of cereal malt beverages on premises which are licensed pursuant to this article and K.S.A. 41-2601, et seq., and amendments thereto, at any time when alcoholic liquor is allowed by law to be served on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 40, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2704. 
Sec. 4-64. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-65. - Possession of alcoholic liquor at place of business. 
    No person shall have any alcoholic liquor in such person's possession while in any place of business, as defined in this chapter, unless the premises are currently licensed as either a club or a drinking establishment by the State of Kansas and the city. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 42, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2704. 
Sec. 4-66. - Closed booths, private rooms. 
    No private rooms or closed booths shall be operated in a place of business. This provision shall not apply if the licensed premises also are licensed as a club by the State of Kansas and the city. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 43, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2704. 
Sec. 4-67. - Access. 
    A place of business shall be open to the public and to law enforcement officers at all times during business hours, except that a premises licensed as a club pursuant to K.S.A. 41-2601, et seq., and amendments thereto, shall be open to law enforcement officers and not to the public. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 44, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2704. 
Sec. 4-68. - State license for wholesalers and/or distributors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any wholesaler or distributor, his or its agents or employees, to sell or deliver cereal malt beverages within the city to persons authorized under this division to sell the same within the city unless such wholesaler or distributor has first secured a license from the State of Kansas authorizing such sales. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 45, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Wholesalers', distributors' license, K.S.A. 79-3837. 
Sec. 4-69. - Relationship of on-premises and off-premises cereal malt beverage retailer to wholesalers and distributors. 
    No wholesaler or distributor shall sell any cereal malt beverage to any person who has not secured a license as provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 46, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2705. 
Sec. 4-70. - Penalties for violation of this article. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00, or by imprisonment for not more than one year, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  Such penalties may be assessed in addition to any license or permit revocation process provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 47, 8-14-12) 
Division 2 - ON-PREMISES AND OFF-PREMISES CEREAL MALT BEVERAGE RETAILER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 4-71. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall sell any cereal malt beverage without having first secured a license for each place of business as herein provided. 
(b)  The application for a license to sell cereal malt beverages shall be on a form provided by the city, submitted to the city clerk and approved by the governing body. Each application shall be accompanied by the required fee. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 49, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2620. 
Sec. 4-72. - License qualification and issuance. 
(a)  After examination of an application for a cereal malt beverage retailer's license, the governing body shall deny a license to: 
(1)  A person who has not been a resident in good faith of the State of Kansas for at least one year immediately preceding application and a resident of the county where the premises is located for at least six months prior to filing of such application; 
(2)  A person who is not a citizen of the United States; 
(3)  A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which the person resides; 
(4)  A person who, within two years immediately preceding the date of application approval, has been convicted of, released from incarceration for, or released from probation or parole for a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude, drunkenness, driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, or the violation of any other intoxicating liquor law of any state or of the United States; 
(5)  A partnership, unless all the members of the partnership shall otherwise be qualified to obtain a license; 
(6)  A corporation, if any manager, officer or director thereof, or any stockholder owning in the aggregate more than 25 percent of the stock of such corporation, would be ineligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residency requirements; 
(7)  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless the manager or agent possesses all the qualifications of a licensee; 
(8)  A person whose spouse would be ineligible to receive a retailer's license for any reason other than citizenship, residence requirements or age, except that this subsection (a)(8) shall not apply in determining eligibility for a renewal license; 
(9)  A person whose spouse has been convicted of a felony or other crime which would disqualify a person from licensure under this section and such felony or other crime was committed during the time that the spouse held a license under this chapter; 
(10)  A person who has had a cereal malt beverage retailer's license revoked under K.S.A. 41-2708 and amendments thereto. 
(b)  After examination of an application for a cereal malt beverage retailer's license, the governing body may deny a license to a firm, partnership, corporation, or association if any manager, officer or director thereof, or any stockholder owning in the aggregate more than 25 percent of the stock of such corporation, has been an officer, manager, director, or a stockholder owning in the aggregate more than 25 percent of the stock of a corporation which has had a license revoked under K.S.A. 41-2708 and amendments thereto. 
(c)  After examination of an application for a cereal malt beverage retailer's license, the governing body may deny a license to a person, partnership, or corporation if any manager, officer or director thereof, or any stockholder owning in the aggregate more than 25 percent of the stock of such corporation, has been an officer, manager, director, or a stockholder owning in the aggregate more than 25 percent of the stock of a corporation which has been convicted of a violation of K.S.A. 41-2601 et seq. and amendments thereto, otherwise known as the Club and Drinking Establishment Act, or the cereal malt beverage laws of this state. 
(d)  No license shall be issued for a place of business located or to be located in a prohibited zone, as defined in section 4-73. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 50, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-2623. 
Sec. 4-73. - Restrictions on location. 
(a)  No license shall be issued under the terms of this division to any person for any location unless it complies with all relevant zoning regulations and other ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Any premises licensed under this division prior to August 19, 2012, shall be exempt from the restrictions set forth in subsection 4-73(a) above. The exemption granted by reason of this subsection shall terminate if the premises cease to be licensed for a period of more than 120 consecutive days. Any bona fide purchaser from a licensee covered hereunder shall likewise succeed to the exemption granted in this subparagraph; provided, that the exemption granted by reason of this subparagraph shall terminate if the premises cease to be licensed for a period of more than 120 consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 51, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-74. - Approval; issuance; fee. 
(a)  If the application for a license required by the provisions of this division is in proper form and accompanied by cash in the amount of the license fee, the governing body shall examine the application and if the applicant is qualified as provided by law, the governing body shall approve the issuance of the license to the applicant. 
(b)  The journal of the governing body shall show the action taken upon each application filed for a license as herein provided, and if a license be approved, the city clerk shall issue to such person a license. 
(c)  The annual fee for a license issued under this division shall be as follows: 
(1)  On-premises cereal malt beverage retailer ..... $200.00 
(2)  Off-premises cereal malt beverage retailer ..... $50.00 
    The above license fees shall be in addition to any fee due to the State of Kansas whether collected by the city or the state. 
(d)  Any person to whom a license has been issued under this division may surrender such license to the city clerk at such time as the license is no longer necessary, and may at such time request a prorated refund of the city license fee paid hereunder. The city clerk shall refund a prorated amount of the license fee based upon the number of unexpired whole months remaining in the license term from the date of surrender. No such refund shall be applicable to any license that is revoked pursuant to the provisions of this chapter or state laws regulating the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages. Any fee due to the State of Kansas shall not be refundable. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 52, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-75. - Transfer; term. 
    No license issued under the provisions of this division shall be transferable or assignable. The term of the license shall be for one year and shall be renewed on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 53, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-77. - Display. 
    Each license issued under the provisions of this division shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the place of business for which the same was issued. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 54, 8-14-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 41-325. 
Sec. 4-78. - License suspension or revocation by governing body. 
(a)  The governing body, upon five days written notice to a person holding a license to sell cereal malt beverages, shall permanently revoke or suspend such license for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The licensee fraudulently obtained the license by giving false information in the application therefor; 
(2)  The licensee has become ineligible to obtain a license under K.S.A. 41-2701 et seq., and amendments thereto, or this Division; 
(3)  The nonpayment of any license fees; 
(4)  Permitting any gambling in or upon the licensee's place of business; however, gambling shall not include the term lottery as defined by state law, if the premises are licensed by the state for such lottery; 
(5)  The employment of persons under 18 years of age in dispensing or selling cereal malt beverages; 
(6)  The employment or continuation of employment of a person in connection with the sale, serving, or dispensing of cereal malt beverages if the licensee knows such person has been, within the preceding two years, adjudged guilty of a felony or of any violation of the intoxicating liquor laws of the state, another state, or the United States; or 
(7)  There has been a violation of K.S.A. 21-6204, and amendments thereto, in or upon the licensee's place of business. 
(b)  The governing body, upon five days written notice to a person holding a license to sell cereal malt beverages, may permanently revoke or suspend such license for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The licensee has violated any of the provisions of K.S.A. 41-2701 et seq., and amendments thereto, for which violation the city is authorized by law to revoke the license, or any provisions of this article, or any other rules or regulations of the city relating to cereal malt beverages, or any codes of the City of Manhattan relating to the premises; 
(2)  Drunkenness of the licensee, or permitting any intoxicated person to remain in or upon the licensee's place of business; 
(3)  The sale of cereal malt beverages to any person under the legal age for consumption of cereal malt beverages; 
(4)  Permitting any person to mix drinks with materials purchased in or upon any premises licensed under this article or brought into the licensed premises for this purpose; 
(5)  The sale or possession of, or permitting any person to use or consume on the licensed premises, alcoholic liquor; 
(6)  The licensee has been convicted of a violation of K.S.A. 41-2901 et seq., and amendments thereto. 
(c)  The provisions of subsections 4-78(b)(4) and (b)(5) shall not apply if such place of business is also currently licensed as a club or drinking establishment by the State of Kansas and the city. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 55, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-79. - Appeal. 
    Within 20 days after the court order of the governing body revoking, suspending, or denying any license, the licensee may appeal to the district court and the district court shall proceed to hear such appeal as though such court had original jurisdiction in the matter. Any appeal taken from an order revoking or suspending the license shall not suspend the order of revocation or suspension during the pendency of any such appeal. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 56, 8-14-12) 
Division 3 - TEMPORARY PERMIT 

Sec. 4-80. - Temporary cereal malt beverage permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, sell and serve any cereal malt beverage for consumption on unlicensed premises at any event within the city without first obtaining a local temporary cereal malt beverage permit from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 58, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-81. - Same, application. 
(a)  An application for a temporary cereal malt beverage permit shall be submitted to the city clerk at least 30 days before the event. 
(b)  Written application for the permit shall be made on a form provided by the city clerk. In addition to any other information required, the applicant shall provide the following: 
(1)  The name and residence of the applicant; 
(2)  The length of time that the applicant has resided within the state of Kansas; 
(2)  The premises for which the permit is to be issued; 
(3)  The group for which the event is planned; 
(4)  The date and time of the event; 
(5)  The duration of the event; 
(6)  Any anticipated need for police, fire or other municipal services; 
(7)  A statement that the applicant is a citizen of the United States and not less than 21 years of age and that the applicant has not within two years immediately preceding the date of making application been convicted of a felony, any crime involving moral turpitude, drunkenness, driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or violation of any other intoxicating liquor law of any state, municipality, or of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 59, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-82. - Same, standards for issuance. 
(a)  Upon meeting the requirements to obtain a temporary cereal malt beverage permit, the governing body, by ordinance or resolution, shall issue a permit to the applicant if there are no conflicts with any zoning or other ordinances of the city. 
(b)  The licensing qualifications set forth in section 4-72 shall be met for the issuance of a temporary cereal malt beverage permit. 
(c)  No more than four temporary cereal malt beverage permits may be issued in a calendar year to the same applicant. 
(d)  No temporary cereal malt beverage permit shall be issued for an event that requires a special event permit pursuant to chapter 31, article 4, of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 60, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-83. - Same, permit fee. 
    The fee for a temporary cereal malt beverage permit shall be $25.00 per day, not to exceed $200.00 per event, which shall be paid at the time the application is submitted. Such fee shall be in addition to any fee due to the State of Kansas whether collected by the city or the state. No fee paid pursuant to this division shall be refundable. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 61, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-84. - Same, permit term, transfer. 
(a)  A temporary cereal malt beverage permit shall be issued for a period of time not to exceed 30 consecutive days, the dates and hours of which shall be specified in the permit. 
(b)  No temporary cereal malt beverage permit issued hereunder shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 62, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-85. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-86. - Same, permit regulations. 
(a)  Every temporary cereal malt beverage permit holder must allow immediate entry and inspection by alcoholic beverage control agents or other law enforcement officers; 
(b)  No cereal malt beverages shall be given, sold or traded to any person under 21 years of age; 
(c)  No temporary cereal malt beverage permit holder shall allow the sale or serving of cereal malt beverages between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. at any event for which a temporary cereal malt beverage permit has been issued; 
(d)  All local ordinances and state statutes for the sale, serving and consumption of cereal malt beverages apply to holders of temporary cereal malt beverage permits. However, a temporary cereal malt beverage permit holder shall not be subject to the provisions of the Beer and Cereal Malt Beverage Keg Registration Act, K.S.A. 41-2901 et seq., and amendments thereto. 
(e)  Every temporary cereal malt beverage permit holder shall cause the permit to be placed in plain view at the event entrance along with the name of the permit holder, and a diagram of the premises covered by the permit. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 64, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-87. - Same, revocation. 
(a)  The city clerk or the Riley County Police Department, upon written notice to the permit holder, delivered to the permit holder's address as listed on the application for such permit or personally delivered to the permit holder at the premises, may revoke or suspend a temporary cereal malt beverage permit for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The permit holder violated any regulation in section 4-86; 
(2)  The permit holder violated any state law or city ordinance pertaining to the sale, serving or consumption of cereal malt beverages, while on the premises and during the term of the permit; 
(3)  The permit holder violated a condition or restriction placed upon the permit; 
(4)  Criminal activity has occurred on the premises during the term of the permit, for which a citation is issued or an arrest made, that is reasonably likely to cause injury or threat to persons or property or to create an unreasonable disturbance. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 65, 8-14-12) 
Sec. 4-88. - Same, appeal. 
    Within 20 days after the order of the city clerk or Riley County Police Department revoking, suspending, or denying a temporary cereal malt beverage permit, the permit holder or applicant may file a written appeal to the city manager. Any appeal taken from an order revoking or suspending the permit shall not suspend the order of revocation or suspension. If the city manager upholds the order revoking, suspending, or denying a temporary cereal malt beverage permit, the permit holder or applicant may appeal such order to the district court; provided, that such appeal shall not suspend the order of revocation or suspension during the pendency of the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 6958, § 66, 8-14-12) 
Secs. 4-89-4-95. - Reserved. 
Chapter 5 - AMUSEMENTS 
Article I - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 5-1-5-10. - Reserved. 
Article II - AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENT DEVICES 
Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-11. - Defined. 
    An automatic amusement device is hereby defined for the purposes of this article as a machine or device which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug or similar object, operates or may be operated or used for game, contest or amusement and shall include such devices as marble machines, pinball machines, shuffle boards, bowling, electric shooting and similar amusement devices under whatever name they may be indicated. 
(Code 1973, § 10-301) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-21 et seq. 
Sec. 5-12. - Prohibited locations. 
    No automatic amusement device shall be set up or operated at any place in the city within a distance of 500 feet from any school ground in the city owned by or under the control of the board of education of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 10-304) 
Secs. 5-13-5-20. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - LICENSE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 19. 

Sec. 5-21. - Required. 
    Any person displaying for public patronage or keeping for operation any automatic amusement device shall be required to obtain a license from the city as provided in this division. 
(Code 1973, § 10-302) 
Sec. 5-22. - Fee. 
    The fee for a license required under the provisions of this division shall be as prescribed in section 19-30. 
(Code 1973, § 10-303) 
Sec. 5-23. - Issuance for gambling devices prohibited; revocation when devices used for gambling. 
    No license shall be issued under this division to operate any gambling device or any game machine that is illegal and when any amusement device for which a license has been issued is thereafter used or operated for gambling or illegal purposes, the license shall be revoked. 
(Code 1973, § 10-305) 
Secs. 5-24-5-30. - Reserved. 
Article III - BILLIARD AND POOLHALLS 
Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-31. - Minors prohibited; exception.
