Sec. 15-51. - Rights granted. 
(a)  The Kansas Gas Service, a division of ONEOK, Inc., its successors and assigns, is granted the nonexclusive right, privilege and authority to occupy and use the streets, alleys and public ways of the city for a period of 20 years from the first day of January, 2007, to place and maintain the equipment and property necessary for the purpose of transmitting and distributing natural gas to the city and its inhabitants, through the city and beyond the limits thereof, at the sole expense of Kansas Gas Service, for the full term of this franchise, and to do all things necessary or proper to carry on the business of selling and distributing natural gas thereto. 
(b)  Kansas Gas Service shall not use, or allow any other person to use, its facilities or the city's right-of-way for any purpose other than the provision of natural gas. Kansas Gas Service shall not permit a subsidiary, affiliate, or a third party to acquire rights to occupy right-of-way under this franchise, except that Kansas Gas Service may allow the use of its facilities when the city receives prior written notification of such use, and such use is compensated to the city under the provisions of this franchise or a franchise granted by the city to any such third party. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 1, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 15-52. - Consideration. 
(1)  As consideration for granting this franchise, and in lieu of any city occupation, license or permit fees, or revenue taxes, Kansas Gas Service shall pay to the city during the term of this franchise, four percent of its gross cash receipts from the sale of natural gas for consumption in the city, for all purposes within the corporate limits of the city. Gross cash receipts shall not include other operating revenues received by Kansas Gas Service that are not related to the "sale of natural gas," including, but not limited to, connection fees, disconnection and reconnection fees, temporary service charges, delayed or late payment charges, collection fees and returned check charges as such terms are used in tariffs or in the natural gas industry. 
(2)  Kansas Gas Service shall make such payments monthly for the preceding monthly period. 
(3)  Notwithstanding subsection (1), Kansas Gas Service shall be required to pay the usual general property taxes and special ad valorem property assessments, sales and excise taxes or charges made for privileges that are not connected to the natural gas business, and the gross cash receipts payments required by subsection (1) shall not apply to such taxes, assessments, fees, taxes, or charges. 
(4)  For the term of this franchise, any permit fees relating to the excavation of, or adjacent to any street, alley, or other public place shall be deemed a part of the compensation paid in subsection (1). Provided that, Kansas Gas Service shall notify the city, submit application for and obtain approval of any required permits for excavation or any other work in the city's streets, avenues, bridges, parks, parking areas, alleys, public areas, or rights-of-way. In the event of an emergency, Kansas Gas Service shall have the right to commence work without having first provided such form(s). 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 2, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 15-53. - Installations. 
    All mains, services and pipe which shall be laid or installed under this grant shall be so located and laid so as not to obstruct or interfere with any water pipes, drains, sewers or other structures or facilities already installed. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 3, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 15-54. - Street excavations. 
    Kansas Gas Service shall, in the doing of any work in connection with its gas mains, pipes and services, avoid, so far as may be practicable, interfering with the use of any street, alley, avenue or other public thoroughfare. Kansas Gas Service shall, at its own expense and without expense to the city, restore and replace the paving or surface in a good condition to the satisfaction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 4, 1-9-07) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 30. 
Sec. 15-55. - Supply of gas. 
    It is recognized that the natural gas delivered by Kansas Gas Service is supplied from a pipeline system transporting natural gas from distant sources of supply; and Kansas Gas Service, by its acceptance of this franchise, obligates itself to furnish natural gas in such quantity and for such length of time required by the franchise, to the extent that such distant sources and pipelines are reasonably capable of supplying. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 5, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 15-56. - Protection of city. 
    Kansas Gas Service, its successors and assigns, in the construction, maintenance and operation of its natural gas system, shall use all reasonable and proper precaution to avoid damage or injury to persons and property. Kansas Gas Service, its successors and assigns, shall hold and save the city, its officers, employees, agents and authorized contractors harmless from any and against all claims, damages, expense, liability, and costs, including reasonable attorney fees, caused by the negligence, in whole or in part, of Kansas Gas Service employees, agents, or servants, related to Kansas Gas Service's occupancy of the rights-of-way. In the event a claim shall be made or an action shall be instituted against the city arising from Kansas Gas Service's occupancy of the rights-of-way, then upon notice by the city to Kansas Gas Service, Kansas Gas Service shall assume responsibility for the defense of such actions at the cost of Kansas Gas Service, subject to the option of the city to appear and defend. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 6, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 15-57. - Binding contract. 
(a)  This article shall become a binding contract between the parties and be in force and effect from and after its passage, and upon approval by the city, written acceptance by Kansas Gas Service to the city clerk, and publication in the official city newspaper. Within 20 days after the passage and approval of this article, Kansas Gas Service shall file a copy of the article with the Kansas Corporation Commission. 
(b)  If any clause, sentence, or section of this article shall be held to be invalid, it shall not affect the remaining provisions of this article. 
(c)  This article shall constitute the entire franchise agreement between the City of Manhattan and Kansas Gas Service. This article shall supersede and cancel prior understandings, agreements, or representations, whether written or oral, relating to the franchise. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 7, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 15-58. - Subject to state law. 
    The city has the authority to grant this franchise to Kansas Gas Service pursuant to the provisions of K.S.A. 12-2001, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 8, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 15-59. - Amendment. 
(1)  Upon 60 days' advance written notice by the city, the franchise fee percentage rate may be changed on the fifth, tenth or fifteenth anniversary of the effective date of this article, provided that the franchise fee percentage rate shall not exceed five percent. 
(2)  If the Kansas Corporation Commission takes action with respect to this franchise agreement, as amended, which precludes Kansas Gas Service from recovering from its customers any costs or fees provided for, the parties shall renegotiate accordingly. 
(3)  Upon written request of either the City of Manhattan or Kansas Gas Service, and upon mutual agreement of the other party, the franchise may be reopened and renegotiated at any time upon the occurrence of any of the following events: 
(a)  Change in federal, state, or local law, regulation, or order which materially affects any rights or obligations of either the city or Kansas Gas Service, including, but not limited to, the scope of the grant to Kansas Gas Service or the compensation to be received by the city. 
(b)  Change in the structure or operation of the natural gas industry which materially affects any rights or obligations of either the city or Kansas Gas Service, including, but not limited to, the scope of the grant to Kansas Gas Service or the compensation to be received by the city. 
(c)  Any other material and unintended change or shift in the economic benefit to the city or the company relied upon and anticipated upon entering into this franchise. 
(4)  The compensation provision of this franchise shall be reopened and renegotiated at any time if energy consumers within the city have access to alternative natural gas suppliers or other suppliers of energy through pipelines, and use the public rights-of-way or public property of the city without paying a franchise fee or other payment substantially equivalent to the franchise fee established herein, which results in a material and unfair disadvantage to Kansas Gas Service. The use of the right-of-way provision of this franchise shall be reopened and renegotiated if energy consumers within the city have access to alternative natural gas suppliers or other suppliers of energy through pipelines which use the public rights-of-way or public property of the city, and do not have requirements on the use of the public ways substantially equivalent to the requirements of this franchise, which results in a material and unfair disadvantage to Kansas Gas Service. Upon any such event, the city shall have up to 120 days after written request from Kansas Gas Service to restore competitive neutrality, provided that any adjustment in compensation resulting from the renegotiations under this subsection shall be effective no later than 120 days after the receipt of such notice by the city. 
(5)  Any amendments pursuant to this section shall be made by ordinance as required by state law. The franchise shall remain in effect according to its terms until any review or renegotiation is complete and such amendments are adopted. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 9, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 15-60. - Use of the city's right-of-way. 
    Kansas Gas Service shall comply with the city's rules, regulations, policies, resolutions and ordinances in effect now or hereafter adopted that relate to the use of the city's right-of-way. Kansas Gas Service shall comply with the city's rules, regulations, policies, resolutions and ordinances in effect now or hereafter adopted that relate to permits, sidewalk and pavement cuts, utility location, construction coordination, and other requirements on the use of the right-of-way. Provided however, that Kansas Gas Service retains its right to oppose, challenge, or seek judicial review of any such rules, regulations, policies, resolutions, or ordinances proposed, adopted, or promulgated by the city, as provided by law. Further, other than the fee required by section 15-52, such rules, regulations or policies shall not require the payment of additional fees or additional costs for the use of the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 10, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 15-61. - Transport fees. 
    The city may by separate ordinance provide for the assessment and collection of franchise fees on all natural gas transported (transport gas) by Kansas Gas Service or by others, but not sold by Kansas Gas Service, to any consumer or user within the city through the facilities of Kansas Gas Service located in the public right-of-way. Such ordinance shall provide that the customer transporting gas through Kansas Gas Service facilities shall be solely responsible for the payment of any applicable franchise fee, but said franchise may grant to Kansas Gas Service the authority to collect on behalf of the city the total compensation to be made to the city by other parties using Kansas Gas Service facilities for distribution of transport gas. Such franchise assessment shall be compatible with the Kansas Gas Service billing system. To the extent any transporter using Kansas Gas Service facilities fails to pay any amounts owed by transporters under the separate ordinance, Kansas Gas Service shall notify the city of such amount and city shall be solely responsible for collecting any sums owed. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 11, 1-9-07) 
Article V. - WESTERN UNION TELEGRAPH COMPANY 

Sec. 15-71. - Rights granted. 
    The Western Union Telegraph Company, its successors and assigns, are authorized to erect and maintain, on the streets, alleys and public ways of the city, the poles and fixtures and wires necessary for the purpose of supplying the citizens of the city and to the public communication by telegraph, or other improved electrical device, such use to be and continue upon the terms and conditions hereinafter stated. 
(Code 1973, § 8-401) 
Sec. 15-72. - Location of poles and lines. 
    The location of the poles and the lines now in use, is hereby approved; and the location of all poles and lines hereafter to be erected and any change in the location of the poles and lines now in use or extensions thereof shall be under the direction and control of the governing body. 
(Code 1973, § 8-402) 
Sec. 15-73. - Not to interfere with traffic. 
    Poles and wires shall be placed and maintained so as not to interfere with travel on the highways and the company shall hold the city free and blameless from all damages arising by reason of any abuse of such occupancy. This grant is made and is to be enjoyed subject to such reasonable regulations and ordinances of a police nature, as the governing body is authorized and sees proper at any time to adopt, not destructive to the rights herein granted. 
(Code 1973, § 8-403) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles generally, Ch. 31. 
Sec. 15-74. - Not exclusive. 
    The right of use herein given shall not be exclusive, and the city reserves the power to grant a like right-of-way to any other telegraph company; the same however not to interfere with the reasonable and proper exercise of the privileges herein granted. 
(Code 1973, § 8-404) 
Sec. 15-75. - Consideration. 
    In consideration whereof the Western Union Telegraph Company shall and by the acceptance of this article does agree to allow the governing body, to attach at any time to the top crossarm of any of the poles, where practicable, the city fire alarm and police wires and such poles are hereby made a municipal instrumentality for that purpose; provided, that the attachment shall be made so as not to interfere with the company's use and the attachment shall be made and maintained under the direction of the company's manager in the city. The company shall furnish for the city the use of its poles for the attachment thereto of its fire alarm boxes, without charge to the city. 
(Code 1973, § 8-405) 
Sec. 15-76. - Removal of lines and poles. 
    Whenever the company ceases to operate a telegraph line in the city, and ceases to use the poles and lines herein provided for in the operation of its line of telegraph, then the company shall remove such lines and poles from the streets and alleys of the city within 60 days from date that the company ceases to use and operate such lines. 
(Code 1973, § 8-407) 
Secs. 15-77-15-80. - Reserved. 
Article VI. - SOUTHWESTERN BELL TELEPHONE COMPANY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 6340, adopted June 17, 2003, repealed Ord. No. 5024, from which Art. VI, §§ 15-81-15-98, derived. Section 1 of said ordinance enacted similar provisions to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 15-81. - Definitions. 
    [For purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings given herein:] 
    Access line shall mean and be limited to retail billed and collected residential lines; business lines; ISDN lines; PBX trunks and simulated exchange access lines provided by a central office based switching arrangement where all stations served by such simulated exchange access lines are used by a single customer of the provider of such arrangement. "Access line" may not be construed to include interoffice transport or other transmission media that do not terminate at an end user customer's premises, or to permit duplicate or multiple assessment of access line rates on the provision of a single service or on the multiple communications paths derived from a billed and collected access line. "Access line" shall not include the following: Wireless telecommunications services, the sale or lease of unbundled loop facilities, special access services, lines providing only data services without voice services processed by a telecommunications local exchange service provider or private line service arrangements. 
    Access line count means the number of access lines serving consumers within the corporate boundaries of the city on the last day of each month. 
    Access line fee means the fee determined by the city, up to a maximum as set out in Kansas Statutes Annotated 12-2001 (Supplemental 2002) (K.S.A.) and amendments thereto, to be used by SBC Kansas in calculating the amount of access line remittance. 
    Access line remittance means the amount to be paid by SBC Kansas to the city, the total of which is calculated by multiplying the access line fee, as determined by the city, by the number of access lines served by SBC Kansas as a telecommunications local exchange service provider within the city for each month in that calendar quarter. 
    Communications system or system means the cables, wires, lines, optic fiber, and any associated converters, equipment, or other facilities designed, constructed or occupied by a provider or others for the purpose of producing, receiving, amplifying or distributing telecommunications service to or from locations within the city. 
    City means the City of Manhattan, Kansas. 
    Facilities means any portion of a system located in, along, over, upon, under, or through the public right-of-way. 
    Franchise fee means the access line fee or fee on gross receipts established under this article. 
    Gross receipts means only those receipts collected from within the corporate boundaries of the city and which are derived from the following: 
(a)  Recurring local exchange service for business and residence, which includes basic exchange service, touch tone, optional calling features and measured local calls; 
(b)  Recurring local exchange access line services for pay phone lines provided by a telecommunications local exchange service provider to all pay phone service providers; 
(c)  Local directory assistance revenue; 
(d)  Line status verification/busy interrupt revenue; 
(e)  Local operator assistance revenue; and 
(f)  Nonrecurring local exchange service revenue which shall include customer service for installation of lines, reconnection of service and charge for duplicate bills. 
All other revenues, including, but not limited to, revenues from extended area service, the sale or lease of unbundled network elements, nonregulated services, carrier and end user access, long distance, wireless telecommunications services, lines providing only data service without voice services processed by a telecommunications local exchange service provider, private line service arrangements, internet, broadband and all other services not wholly local in nature are excluded from gross receipts. Gross receipts shall be reduced by bad debt expenses. Uncollectible and late charges shall not be included within gross receipts. If a telecommunications local exchange service provider offers additional services of a wholly local nature which if in existence on or before July 1, 2002, would have been included with the definition of gross receipts, such services shall be included from the date of the offering of such services in the city. 
    Local exchange service means local switched telecommunications service within any local exchange service area approved by the state corporation commission, regardless of the medium by which the local telecommunications service is provided. The term local exchange service shall not include wireless communication services. 
    Provider means a local exchange carrier as defined in subsection (h) of K.S.A. 66-1,187, and amendments thereto, or a telecommunications carrier as defined in subsection (m) of K.S.A. 66-1,187, and amendments thereto. 
    Public right-of-way means only the area of real property in which the city has a dedicated or acquired right-of-way interest in the real property. It shall include the area on, below or above the present and future streets, alleys, avenues, roads, highways, parkways or boulevards dedicated or acquired as right-of-way. The term does not include the airwaves above a right-of-way with regard to wireless telecommunications or other nonwire telecommunications or broadcast service, easements obtained by utilities or private easements in platted subdivisions or tracts. 
    SBC Kansas or Company means Southwestern Bell Telephone L.P., the franchisee herein. 
    Telecommunications local exchange service provider means a local exchange carrier as defined in subsection (h) of K.S.A. 66-1,187, and amendments thereto, and a telecommunications carrier as defined in subsection (m) of K.S.A. 66-1187, and amendments thereto, which does, or in good faith intends to, provide local exchange service. The term telecommunications local exchange service provider does not include an interexchange carrier that does not provide local exchange service, competitive access provider that does not provide local exchange service or any wireless telecommunications local exchange service provider. 
    Telecommunications services means providing the means of transmission, between or among points specified by the user, of information of the user's choosing, without change in the form or content of the information as sent and received. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-82. - Grant. 
(a)  This contract franchise ordinance hereby grants to SBC Kansas, a telecommunications local exchange service provider providing local exchange service within the city, the nonexclusive contract, right, privilege, and franchise to construct, maintain, and operate facilities along, across, upon and under the public right-of-way for the purpose of providing telecommunications services. Nothing in this franchise is intended to preclude the city from seeking or authorize the city to seek, a franchise from any subsidiary, affiliate or third party providing telecommunications services. 
(b)  This contract franchise ordinance shall not convey title, equitable or legal, in the public right-of-way, and gives only the right to occupy public right-of-way, for the purposes and for the period stated herein. 
(c)  This contract franchise ordinance does not provide SBC Kansas the right to provide "cable service" to the city and inhabitants thereof. For purposes of this ordinance, "cable service" is defined as the one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or other programming services, and subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection of such video programming or other programming service; but "cable service" does not include point to point, point to multipoint, and switched video services that SBC Kansas has historically offered or other similar services that SBC Kansas may in the future offer. Nothing in this contract franchise ordinance is intended to preclude the city from seeking, or authorize the city to seek, a franchise from any subsidiary, affiliate, or third party providing "cable services." SBC Kansas and city agree that nothing in this franchise is intended to authorize the city to seek from SBC Kansas nor to require SBC Kansas to obtain a franchise to offer "open video systems" as that term is used in section 653 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 (codified at 47 U.S.C. 573). SBC Kansas and city further agree, however, that this ordinance does not authorize SBC Kansas to offer "open video systems" without paying a franchise fee on the gross revenues of the system operator for the provision of cable service in lieu of a franchise fee, pursuant to and in the manner described in 47 U.S.C. 573(c)(2)(b) and without complying with Federal Communication Commission (FCC) regulations promulgated pursuant to 47 U.S.C. 573. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec 15-83. - Term. 
(a)  This contract franchise ordinance shall be effective for a term of one year from the effective date of this contract franchise ordinance. Thereafter, this contract franchise ordinance will renew for one additional one year term, unless either party notifies the other party of its intent to terminate the contract franchise ordinance prior to 180 days before the termination of the then current term. The term of this franchise shall be deemed a continuation of the franchise that became effective on July 1, 2003, and not a new franchise. The additional term provided for herein shall also be deemed a continuation of this franchise and not a new franchise or amendment. 
(b)  Upon written request of either the City or Grantee, this contract franchise ordinance shall be renegotiated at any time in accordance with the requirements of K.S.A. 12-2001, as amended, upon any of the following events: Changes in federal, state, or local laws, regulations, or orders that materially affect any rights or obligations of either the city or grantee, including but not limited to the scope of the contract franchise ordinance granted to the grantee or the compensation to be received by the city hereunder. 
(c)  Amendments under this section, if any, shall be made by contract ordinance as prescribed by statute. The contract franchise ordinance shall remain in effect according to its terms pending completion of any review or renegotiation provided by this section. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03; Ord. No. 6554, § 1, 7-11-06; Ord. No. 6711, § 1, 7-15-08) 
Sec. 15-84. - Compensation. 
(a)  In consideration of this contract franchise ordinance, SBC Kansas agrees to remit to the city a franchise fee of $1.20 per access line. Thereafter, compensation for each calendar year of the remaining term of the contract franchise ordinance shall continue to be based on a sum equal to $1.20 per access line, unless the city notifies SBC Kansas at least 90 before the end of the calendar year, that it intends to switch to a gross receipts fee in the following calendar year. In the event the city elects compensation based on a gross receipts fee, nothing herein precludes the city from switching back to a access line fee provided the city notifies SBC Kansas at least 90 before the end of the calendar year. 
(b)  Beginning January 1, 2004, and every 36 months thereafter, the city, subject to the public notification procedures set forth in K.S.A. 12-2001 (l) and (m), as amended, may elect to adopt an increased access line fee or gross receipts fee subject to the provisions and maximum fee limitations contained in K.S.A. 12-2001, as amended, or may choose to decline all or any portion of any increase in the access line fee. 
(c)  The franchise fee shall be due and payable on a monthly basis within 45 calendar days after the end of the remittal period. If any franchise fee, or any portion thereof, is not postmarked or delivered on or before the due date, interest thereon shall accrue from the due date until received, at the applicable statutory interest rate. 
(d)  Franchise fee payments shall be accompanied by a 9K2 statement showing the manner in which the franchise fee was calculated on a quarterly basis. No acceptance by the city of any franchise fee shall be construed as an accord that the amount paid is in fact the correct amount, nor shall acceptance of any franchise fee payment be construed as a release of any claim of the city. Any dispute concerning the amount due under this section shall be resolved in the manner set forth in K.S.A. 12-2001, as amended. 
(e)  The city or its designated representatives shall have the right to examine, upon written notice to SBC Kansas no more often than once per calendar year, those records necessary to verify the correctness of the franchise fees. 
(f)  Within 60 days of the effective date of this contract franchise ordinance, SBC Kansas shall pay to the city a one-time application fee of $1,000.00. The parties agree that such fee reimburses the city for its reasonable, actual and verifiable costs of reviewing and approving this contract franchise ordinance. SBC Kansas shall additionally pay the publication costs of this ordinance. 
(g)  The franchise fee required herein shall be in addition to, not in lieu of, all taxes, charges, assessments, licenses, fees, and impositions otherwise applicable that are or may be imposed by the city under K.S.A. 12-2001 and 17-1902, as amended. The franchise fee is compensation for use of the public right-of-way and shall in no way be deemed a tax of any kind. 
(h)  SBC Kansas shall remit a franchise fee to the city on those access lines that have been resold to another telecommunications local exchange service provider, but in such case the city shall not collect a franchise fee from the reseller telecommunications local exchange service provider and shall not require the reseller to enter a contract franchise ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-85. - Use of public right-of-way. 
(a)  Pursuant to K.S.A. 17-1902, as amended, SBC Kansas shall have the right to construct, maintain, and operate poles; conduit; cable; switches and related appurtenances; and facilities along, across, upon, and under the public right-of-way. Such appurtenances and facilities shall be so constructed and maintained as not to obstruct or hinder the usual travel or public safety on such public ways or obstruct the legal use by other utilities. 
(b)  Nothing in this contract franchise ordinance shall be interpreted as granting SBC Kansas the authority to construct, maintain or operate any facility or related appurtenance on property owned by the city outside of the public right-of-way. 
(c)  The authority of SBC Kansas to use and occupy the public right-of-way shall always be subject and subordinate to the reasonable public health, safety, and welfare requirements and regulations of the city. The city may exercise its home rule powers in its administration and regulation related to the management of the public right-of-way provided that any such exercise must be competitively neutral and may not be unreasonable or discriminatory. Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the authority of the city to require a competitive infrastructure provider to enter into a contract franchise ordinance. SBC Kansas shall comply with all laws and lawful city regulations governing the use of public right-of-way. 
(d)  The city shall have the authority to prohibit the use or occupation of a specific portion of public right-of-way by SBC Kansas due to a reasonable public interest necessitated by public health, safety and welfare so long as the authority is exercised in a competitively neutral manner and is not unreasonable or discriminatory. A reasonable public interest shall include the following: 
(1)  The prohibition is based upon a recommendation by the city engineer, is related to public health, safety, and welfare and is nondiscriminatory among providers, including incumbent providers; 
(2)  SBC Kansas has rejected a reasonable, competitively neutral and nondiscriminatory justification offered by the city for requiring an alternate method or alternate route that will result in neither unreasonable additional installation expense nor a diminution of service quality; 
(3)  The city reasonably determines, after affording the provider reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard, that a denial is necessary to protect the public health and safety and is imposed on a competitively neutral and nondiscriminatory basis; or 
(4)  The specific portion of the public right-of-way for which SBC Kansas seeks use and occupancy is environmentally sensitive as defined by state or federal law or lies within a previously designated historic district as defined by local, state or federal law. 
(e)  If there is an emergency necessitating response work or repair, SBC Kansas may begin that repair or emergency response work or take any action required under the circumstances, provided that SBC Kansas notifies the city promptly after beginning the work and timely thereafter meets any permit or other requirement had there not been such an emergency. 
(f)  SBC Kansas shall repair all damage to the public right-of-way caused by the activities of SBC Kansas, or of any agent affiliate, employee, or subcontractor of SBC Kansas, while occupying, installing, repairing or maintaining facilities in a public right-of-way and to return the public right-of-way to its functional equivalence before the damage pursuant to the reasonable requirements and specifications of the city. If SBC Kansas fails to make the repairs required by the city, the city may affect those repairs and charge SBC Kansas the cost of those repairs. If the city incurs damages as a result of a violation of this subsection, then the city shall have a cause of action against SBC for violation of this subsection, and may recover its damages, including reasonable attorney fees, if SBC is found liable by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(g)  When requested by the city, in order to accomplish construction and maintenance activities directly related to improvements for the health, safety and welfare of the public, SBC Kansas promptly shall remove its facilities from the public right-of-way or shall relocate or adjust its facilities within the public right-of-way at no cost to the city. Such relocation or adjustment shall be completed as soon as reasonably possible within the time set forth in any request by the city for such relocation or adjustment. Any damages suffered by the city or its contractors as a result of SBC Kansas' failure to timely relocate or adjust its facilities shall be borne by SBC Kansas. 
(h)  SBC Kansas shall coordinate the placement of its facilities in the public right-of-way in a manner that minimizes adverse impact on public improvements, as reasonably determined by the city engineer. 
(i)  In granting this contract franchise ordinance the city makes no express or implied representation or warranty regarding its rights to authorize the installation or construction of facilities on any particular segment of the public right-of-way. The burden and responsibility for making all such determinations in advance of construction or installation shall be entirely upon SBC Kansas. 
(j)  Except as may otherwise be provided by other applicable ordinances of the city, where reasonable and appropriate and where adequate public right-of-way exist, SBC Kansas shall place aboveground facilities underground in conjunction with city capital improvement projects and/or at specific locations requested by the city provided that such placement is practical, efficient, and economically feasible. 
(k)  When SBC Kansas is allowed to place facilities above ground under this section, SBC Kansas may attach its facilities to an existing utility pole pursuant to a properly executed agreement with the pole owner provided; however, that any necessary replacement of the pole in order to accommodate the attachment shall be subject to the proper exercise of the city's police powers, and in no instance shall a franchisee erect a new pole within an existing aerial pole line absent the city's prior authorization. 
    Aboveground pedestals, vaults, or other aboveground facilities, may be installed only if approved by the city where alternative underground facilities are not feasible or where underground requirements are otherwise waived pursuant to this section, and shall generally be located behind the sidewalk where feasible and shall be screened from public view. Facilities in rear lot easements shall be exempt from the screening requirements except when they are within 50 feet of a street or highway. 
    The underground requirements of this subsection shall not apply to the maintenance and repair of existing facilities, as determined by the city engineer. 
(l)  SBC Kansas shall take all reasonable measures necessary to maintain accurate as completed records in electronic format, of all facilities constructed, reconstructed, or relocated in the public right-of-way of arterial streets after the date hereof. Such facilities shall be horizontally and vertically located at least every 100 feet and at any other alignment change. All points of facilities shall be horizontally located from street centerline, or section or quarter section lines or corners. Vertical locations on all points of facilities shall consist of elevations in United States Geological Survey datum. SBC Kansas shall cooperate promptly and fully with the city and take all reasonable measures necessary to provide accurate and complete information regarding the nature and horizontal and vertical location of its facilities located within right-of-way when requested by the city or its authorized agents for a public project. Such location and identification shall be at the sole expense of SBC Kansas without expense to the city, its employees, agents, or authorized contractors. 
(m)  Permission is hereby granted to SBC to trim trees upon any overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks, and public places of said city so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with SBC's facilities; all the said trimming shall comply with all applicable laws, statutes, and/or city regulations. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-86. - Indemnity and hold harmless. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of SBC Kansas to take adequate measures to protect and defend its facilities in the public right-of-way from harm or damage. If SBC Kansas fails to accurately or timely locate facilities when requested, it has no claim for costs or damages against the city and its authorized contractors unless such party is responsible for the harm or damage by its negligence or intentional conduct. The city and its authorized contractors shall be responsible to take reasonable precautionary measures including calling for utility locations and observing marker posts when working near SBC Kansas' facilities. 
(b)  SBC Kansas shall indemnify and hold the city and its officers and employees harmless against any and all claims, lawsuits, judgments, costs, liens, losses, expenses, fees (including reasonable attorney fees and costs of defense), proceedings, actions, demands, causes of action, liability and suits of any kind and nature, including personal or bodily injury (including death), property damage or other harm for which recovery of damages is sought, to the extent that it is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be caused by the negligence of the provider, any agent, officer, director, representative, employee, affiliate or subcontractor of the provider, or their respective officers, agents, employees, directors or representatives, while installing, repairing or maintaining facilities in a public right-of-way. 
    The indemnity provided by this subsection does not apply to any liability resulting from the negligence of the city, its officers, employees, contractors or subcontractors. If SBC Kansas and the city are found jointly liable by a court of competent jurisdiction, liability shall be apportioned comparatively in accordance with the laws of this state without, however, waiving any governmental immunity available to the city under state law and without waiving any defenses of the parties under state or federal law. This section is solely for the benefit of the city and SBC Kansas and does not create or grant any rights, contractual or otherwise, to any other person or entity. 
    SBC Kansas or the city shall promptly advise the other in writing of any known claim or demand against SBC Kansas or the city related to or arising out of the SBC Kansas' activities in a public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-87. - Insurance requirement and performance bond. 
(a)  During the term of this franchise, SBC Kansas shall obtain and maintain insurance coverage at its sole expense, with financially reputable insurers that are licensed to do business in the State of Kansas. Should SBC Kansas elect to use the services of an affiliated captive insurance company for this purpose, that company shall possess a certificate of authority from the Kansas Insurance Commissioner. SBC Kansas shall provide not less than the following insurance: 
(1)  Workers' compensation as provided for under any workers' compensation or similar law in the jurisdiction where any work is performed with an employers' liability limit equal to the amount required by law. 
(2)  Commercial general liability, including coverage for contractual liability and products completed operations liability on an occurrence basis and not a claims made basis, with a limit of not less than $2,000,000.00 combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, personal injury, and property damage liability. The city shall be included as an additional insured with respect to liability arising from SBC Kansas' operations under this ordinance. 
(b)  As an alternative to the requirements of subsection (a), SBC Kansas may demonstrate to the satisfaction of the city that it is self-insured and as such SBC Kansas has the ability to provide coverage in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence and $2,000,000.00 in aggregate, to protect the city from and against all claims by any person whatsoever for loss or damage from personal injury, bodily injury, death or property damage occasioned by SBC Kansas, or alleged to so have been caused or occurred. 
(c)  SBC Kansas shall, as a material condition of this franchise, prior to the commencement of any work and prior to any renewal thereof, deliver to the city a certificate of insurance or evidence of self-insurance, satisfactory in form and content to the city, evidencing that the above insurance is in force and will not be cancelled or materially changed with respect to areas and entities covered without first giving the city 30 days prior written notice. SBC Kansas shall make available to the city on request the policy declarations page and a certified copy of the policy in effect, so that limitations and exclusions can be evaluated for appropriateness of overall coverage. 
(d)  SBC Kansas shall, as a material condition of this franchise, prior to the commencement of any work and prior to any renewal thereof, deliver to the city a performance bond in the amount of $50,000.00, payable to the city to ensure the appropriate and timely performance in the construction and maintenance of facilities located in the right-of-way. The required performance bond must be with good and sufficient sureties, issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in the State of Kansas, and satisfactory to the city attorney in form and substance. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-88. - Nondiscrimination. 
    SBC Kansas will not, on the grounds of race, color, sex, religion, national origin, ancestry, disability, or age, discriminate or permit discrimination against any person in the use of the public right-of-way or in activities under this franchise. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-89. - Transfer and assignment. 
    This franchise shall be assignable in accordance with the laws of the State of Kansas. SBC Kansas shall provide the city written notice of any transfer or assignment within 30 days, including notice of the name and address of the assignee and contact information. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-90. - Expiration or termination of contract franchise ordinance. 
    Upon expiration of this contract franchise ordinance, whether by lapse of time, by agreement between SBC Kansas and city, or by forfeiture thereof, SBC Kansas shall have the right to remove any and all of its facilities within a reasonable time after such expiration or termination or to transfer any and all of its facilities to another entity authorized to place facilities in the public right-of-way. It shall be the duty of the company, immediately upon any such removal, to restore the public right-of-way from which said facilities are removed to as good a condition as the same were before said removal was effected. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-91. - Notices. 
    Except in emergencies, all notices by either the city or the company to the other shall be made by personal delivery, depositing such notice in the U.S. mail, certified mail, return receipt requested, or by facsimile. any notice served by certified mail, return receipt requested, shall be deemed delivered five calendar days after the date of such deposit in the U.S. mail unless otherwise provided. Any notice given by facsimile is deemed received by the next business day. "Business day", for purposes of this section, shall mean Monday through Friday, city and SBC Kansas observed holidays excepted. Emergency notices shall be provided by telephone, with written notice immediately following by facsimile. 
    Notices shall be addressed to the city as follows: 
City Clerk 
1101 Poyntz Avenue 
Manhattan, Kansas 66502 
    Notice to SBC Kansas shall be addressed to the Company as follows: 
SBC Kansas 
Director-Municipal Affairs 
220 E. 6 th Street, Room 505 
Topeka, Kansas 66603 
    Notice shall be given as required by the terms of this contract franchise ordinance. Notice shall be provided to the above-named addressees unless directed otherwise in writing by city or SBC Kansas. Both SBC Kansas and the city shall provide to the other contact information with telephone and facsimile numbers for use in emergencies. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-92. - Confidentiality. 
    Information provided to the city by SBC Kansas under K.S.A. 12-2001 and/or this contract franchise ordinance shall be governed by confidentiality procedures in compliance with K.S.A. 45-215 and 66-1220a et seq., and amendments thereto. In the event the city is required by law to disclose such information, the city shall provide SBC Kansas ten days advance notice of its intent to disclose such information and shall take such action as may be reasonably necessary to cooperate with SBC Kansas to safeguard such information. SBC Kansas agrees to indemnify and hold the city harmless from any and all penalties or costs, including attorney's fees, arising from the actions of SBC Kansas, or of the city at the written request of SBC Kansas, in seeking to safeguard the confidentiality of information provided by SBC Kansas to the city under this contract franchise ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-93. - Conditions of franchise. 
    This contract franchise ordinance is granted and accepted under and subject to all applicable laws and under and subject to all of the orders, rules, and regulations now or hereafter adopted by governmental bodies now or hereafter having jurisdiction, including all permit requirements, fee payments, and all other city codes and ordinances in effect as of the date of this ordinance or hereinafter adopted to the extent not in contravention of state or federal law. Each and every provision hereof shall be subject to acts of God, fires, strikes, riots, floods, war, and other causes beyond SBC Kansas or the city's control. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-94. - Acceptance. 
    Prior to the effective date of the continuation of this franchise, pursuant to the terms hereof, grantee shall file with the city clerk of the City of Manhattan its acceptance in writing of the provisions, terms and conditions of this ordinance, which acceptance shall be duly acknowledged before an officer authorized by law to administer oaths. When so accepted, the ordinance and acceptance shall constitute a contract between the city and grantee subject to the provisions of the laws of the State of Kansas. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03; Ord. No. 6554, § 1, 7-11-06; Ord. No. 6711, § 1, 7-15-08) 
Sec. 15-95. - Reservation of rights. 
(a)  The city specifically reserves its right and authority as a customer of the company and as a public entity with responsibilities towards its citizens, to participate to the full extent allowed by law in proceedings concerning the company's rates and services to ensure the rendering of efficient telecommunications service at reasonable rates, and the maintenance of the company's property in good repair. 
(b)  In granting its consent hereunder, the city does not in any manner waive its regulatory or other rights and powers under and by virtue of the laws of the State of Kansas as the same may be amended, its home rule powers under the Constitution of the State of Kansas, nor any of its rights and powers under or by virtue of present or future ordinances of the city. 
(c)  In granting its consent hereunder, SBC Kansas does not in any manner waive its regulatory or other rights and powers under and by virtue of the laws of the State of Kansas as the same may be amended, or under the Constitution of the State of Kansas, nor any of its rights and powers under or by virtue of present or future ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-96. - Failure to enforce. 
    The failure of either party to insist in any one or more instances upon the strict performance of any one or more of the terms or provisions of this contract franchise ordinance shall not be construed as a waiver or relinquishment for the future of any such term or provision, and the same shall continue in full force and effect. No waiver or relinquishment shall be deemed to have been made by either party unless said waiver or relinquishment is in writing and signed by the parties. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-97. - Severability. 
    If any clause, sentence, or section of this contract franchise ordinance, or any portion thereof, shall be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remainder, as a whole or any part thereof, other than the part declared to be invalid; provided, however, the city or SBC Kansas may elect to declare that the entire agreement is invalidated if the portion declared invalid is, in the judgment of the city or SBC Kansas, an essential part of this contract franchise ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-98. - Governing law and venue. 
(a)  As a condition of this contract franchise ordinance, SBC Kansas is required to obtain and is responsible for any necessary permit, license, certification, grant, registration or any other authorization required by any appropriate governmental entity, including, but not limited to, the city, the FCC or the Kansas Corporation Commission (KCC), subject to SBC's right to challenge in good faith such requirements as established by the FCC, KCC or other city regulations. SBC Kansas shall also comply with all applicable laws, statutes and/or city regulations, subject to SBC Kansas' right to challenge in good faith such laws, statutes, and/or city regulations. 
(b)  The obligations and undertakings of both parties hereto shall be performed at Manhattan, Riley County, Kansas. In the event that any legal proceeding is brought to enforce the terms of this franchise, the same shall be brought in state or federal courts, as appropriate, having jurisdiction for Riley County, Kansas. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 15-99. - Effective date of franchise. 
    The effective date of the continuation of this franchise shall be August 1, 2008. 
(Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 6-17-03; Ord. No. 6554, § 1, 7-11-06; Ord. No. 6711, § 1, 7-15-08) 
Article VII - KANSAS STATE UNIVERSITY TELECOMMUNICATION SYSTEM 

Sec. 15-100. - Rights granted. 
    Kansas State University is hereby granted the right to construct, maintain and operate a communication cable in, through and along that right-of-way which is approved by action of the governing body of the city, for the purpose of supplying telecommunication service to facilities owned and operated by Kansas State University, and others as set forth herein. Said grant is to be nonexclusive and subject to the terms and conditions set forth hereinafter. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-101. - Use of right-of-way. 
    In the use of right-of-way under this article, Kansas State University shall be subject to all rules, regulations, policies, resolutions, and ordinances now or hereafter adopted or promulgated by the city in the reasonable exercise of its police power and is subject to all applicable laws, orders, rules and regulations adopted by governmental bodies now or hereafter having jurisdiction. In addition, Kansas State University shall be subject to all rules, regulations, policies, resolutions, and ordinances now or hereafter adopted or promulgated by the city relating to permits and fees, sidewalk and pavements cuts, utility location, construction coordination, beautification, and other requirements on the use of the right-of-way and shall comply with the following: 
(a)  Kansas State University's use of right-of-way shall in all matters be subordinate to the city's use of the right-of-way for any public purpose. Kansas State University shall coordinate the placement of its cable in a manner which minimizes adverse impact on public improvements, as reasonably determined by the city. Where placement is not otherwise regulated, the facility shall be placed with adequate clearance from such public improvements so as not to impact or be impacted by such public improvement. 
(b)  All earth, materials, sidewalks, paving, crossings, utilities, public improvements of any kind, injured or removed by Kansas State University in its activities under this article, shall be fully repaired by Kansas State University in its activities under this article, shall be fully repaired or replaced promptly by Kansas State University at its sole expense and to the reasonable satisfaction of the city or owner thereof. 
(c)  All facilities constructed, reconstructed, or relocated in the right-of-way after the date hereof shall be placed underground unless otherwise agreed to by the city. 
(d)  Kansas State University shall keep and maintain accurate records and as-built drawings depicting accurate horizontal and vertical location of all facilities constructed, reconstructed, or relocated in the right-of-way after the date hereof. All points of facilities shall be horizontally located from street center line, or section or quarter-section lines or corners. Vertical locations or all points of facilities shall consist of elevations in either city datum or United States Geological Survey Datum. 
(e)  Prior to construction, reconstruction or relocation of any facilities in the right-of-way, Kansas State University shall submit to the city engineer for approval plans and specifications of the proposed installation. Such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, delayed or conditioned. 
(f)  Kansas State University shall cooperate promptly and fully with the city and take all measures necessary to provide accurate and complete information regarding the nature and locations, both horizontal and vertical, of its facilities located within right-of-way when requested by the city or its authorized agents for a public project. Such location and identification shall be a the sole expense of Kansas State University without expense to the city, its employees, agents, or authorized contractors. Kansas State University shall have a person familiar with the facilities, who is responsible for timely satisfying information needs of the city and other uses of the right-of-way. 
(g)  Kansas State University shall promptly relocate, or adjust any facilities located in right-of-way for a public project. Such relocation or adjustment shall be performed by Kansas State University at its sole expense without expense to the city, its employees, agents, or authorized contractors and shall be specifically subject to rules and regulations of the city not inconsistent with this article pertaining to such. 
(h)  It shall be the sole responsibility of Kansas State University to take adequate measures to protect and defend its facilities in the right-of-way from harm or damage. If Kansas State University fails to accurately or timely locate facilities when requested, it has no claim for costs or damages against the city and its authorized contractors or any other party authorized to be in the right-of-way unless such party is solely responsible for the harm or damage by its negligence or intentional conduct. 
(i)  Kansas State University shall notify the city not less than three working days in advance of any construction, reconstruction, repair or relocation of facilities which would require any street closure which reduces traffic flow to less than two lanes of moving traffic. Except in the event of an emergency, as reasonably determined by Kansas State University, no such closure shall take place without such notice and prior authorization from the city. The city shall follow its policies in the grant or denial of such authority, which shall not be unreasonably delayed. In addition, all work performed in the traveled way or which in any way impacts vehicular or pedestrian traffic shall be properly signed, barricaded, and otherwise protected. Such signing shall be in conformance with the latest edition of the Federal Highway Administration's Standards and Guideline for Work Zone Traffic Control, unless otherwise agreed to by the city. 
(j)  All technical standards governing construction, reconstruction, installation, operation, testing, use, maintenance, and dismantling of the facilities in the right-of-way shall be in accordance with applicable present and future federal, state and city law and regulation, including but not limited to the most recent editions of the National Electrical Code, the National Electrical Safety Code, and the Fiber Optic Cable Installation Standard of the Telecommunications Industry Committee, or such substantive equivalents as may hereafter be adopted or promulgated. It is understood that the standards established in this paragraph are minimum standards and the requirements established or referenced in this article may be additional to or stricter than such minimum standards. Nothing in this section is intended or shall be interpreted to eliminate Kansas State University's right to use the right-of-way for the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95; Ord. No. 6011, § 1, 6-2-98) 
Sec. 15-102. - City's right to use cable. 
    As partial consideration for this article, Kansas State University agrees that the city shall have the right to use any communication cable installed by the University under the terms of this article, for the city's own public purposes, including the transmission/reception of data from other governmental entities, so long as it does not interfere with the utilization of the medium by Kansas State University. 
    Kansas State University shall notify the city as far in advance as possible of all scheduled maintenance that would discontinue or disrupt the use, even temporarily. Kansas State University shall notify the city immediately of any malfunction of disruption of the medium and shall provide an estimated repair time as soon as practical. Kansas State University shall take whatever steps are necessary to immediately repair or replace the medium whenever necessary to insure its continued operation. Should Kansas State University decide to discontinue its own use of the medium, the medium shall revert to the ownership of the city, if the city so desires. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-103. - Indemnity and hold harmless. 
    Kansas State University shall hold and save the city, its officers, employees, agents, and authorized contractors on public improvements, harmless from and against all claims, damages, expense, liability, and costs including attorney fees, which may be occasioned by Kansas State University in any manner, solely or in part by Kansas State University's occupancy of right-of-way, except to the extent otherwise specified in section 5-101(h). In the event a claim shall be made or an action shall be instituted against the city growing out of such occupancy of the right-of-way by facilities of Kansas State University, then upon notice by the city to Kansas State University, Kansas State University will assume liability for the defense of such actions at the cost of Kansas State University, subject to the option of the city to appear and defend, at its own costs, any such case. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-104. - Payments and charges. 
    The payments herein provided shall be in lieu of all other licenses, taxes, charges, fees or impositions, except that the usual general property taxes and special ad valorem property taxes, permits and fees including charges for pavement cuts or other charges based on restoring premises to their same condition, or charges outside the scope of this article which are not in any way connected with telecommunication business, as such, will be imposed on Kansas State University, and are not covered by the payments herein. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-105. - Compensation to city. 
    Kansas State University shall pay to the city as compensation for the right and privilege granted in this article the amount of $5,000.00, effective the date of this Ordinance No. 4936. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-106. - Forfeiture of grant and privilege. 
    In case of failure on the part of Kansas State University, its successors and assigns, to comply with any of the provisions of this article, or if Kansas State University, its successors and assigns, should do or cause to be done any act or thing prohibited by or in violation of the terms of this article, Kansas State University, its successors and assigns, shall forfeit all rights and privileges granted by this article and all rights hereunder shall cease, terminate and become null and void, provided that said forfeiture shall not take effect until the city shall carry out the following proceedings. Before the city proceeds to forfeit said article, as in this section prescribed, it shall first serve a written notice upon Kansas State University, setting forth in detail in such notice the neglect or failure complained of, and Kansas State University shall have 90 days thereafter in which to comply with the conditions of this grant and privilege. If at the end of such 90-day period the city deems that the conditions have not been complied with and that the article is subject to cancellation by reason thereof, the city shall enact a repealing ordinance setting out the grounds upon which said grant and privilege is to be cancelled or terminated. If within 30 days after the effective date of said repealing ordinance Kansas State University shall not have instituted an action, either in the District Court of Riley County, Kansas, or some other court of competent jurisdiction to determine whether or not Kansas State University has violated the terms of this article and that the article is subject to cancellation by reason thereof, this article shall be cancelled and terminated at the end of such 30-day period. If within such 30-day period Kansas State University does institute an action, as above provided, to determine whether or not Kansas State University has violated the terms of this article and that the article is subject to cancellation by reason thereof and prosecutes such action to final judgment with due diligence, then, in that event, in case the court finds that the article is subject to cancellation by reason of the violation of its terms, this article shall terminate 30 days after such final judgment is rendered. Provided, however, that the failure of Kansas State University to comply with any of the provisions of this article or the doing or causing to be done by Kansas State University of anything prohibited by or in violation of the terms of this article shall not be a ground for the forfeiture thereof when such act or omission on the part of Kansas State University is due to any cause or delay beyond the control of Kansas State University, its successors and assigns, or to bona fide legal proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-107. - Rights and duties of grantee upon expiration of ordinance. 
    Upon expiration of this article, whether by lapse of time, by agreement between Kansas State University and the city, or by forfeiture thereof, Kansas State University shall have the right to remove from public property any and all of its facilities used in its said business within a reasonable time after such expiration, but in such event, it shall be the duty of Kansas State University immediately upon such removal, to restore the right-of-way from which said facilities are removed to as good condition as the same were before said removal was effected. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-108. - Terms and termination date. 
    This article shall be and remain in full force and effect for a period of ten years from the effective date hereof, unless sooner terminated as herein provided. Kansas State University is granted the option to renew the rights granted in this ordinance for one additional ten year term subject to the renegotiation of the provisions of this ordinance, except for the compensation provided for in section 15-105. Kansas State University shall not be obligated to pay any additional compensation for any extension under this section. Kansas State University shall give notice of the exercise of the option at least nine months prior to the expiration of the term. The renewal is subject to the provision of section 15-113. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-109. - Right to assign. 
    The rights granted by this article inure to the benefit of Kansas State University. Such rights shall not be assignable without the expressed written consent of the governing body of the city, except that Kansas State University may contract with others to install or maintain such cable on behalf of Kansas State University. Any required consent is to be evidenced by an ordinance or resolution of the governing body of the city that fully recites the terms and conditions, if any, upon which consent is given. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-110. - Participation in utility location. 
    Kansas State University agrees to participate in the one call damage prevention system serving the area where it has, or will have, facilities installed. The system is presently known as Kansas One Call. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-111. - Force majeure. 
    Each and every provision hereof shall be subject to acts of God, fires, strikes, riots, floods, war and other causes beyond Kansas State University's control. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-112. - Invalidity. 
    If any clause, sentence, or section of this article shall be held to be invalid, it shall not affect the remaining provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Sec. 15-113. - Effectiveness and acceptance. 
    This ordinance shall not take effect or become in force until it shall have been read in full at three regular meetings of the governing body of the city nor until and immediately after its final passage it shall be published in the official city paper once each week for three consecutive weeks, and such ordinance shall not take effect or be in force until and after the expiration of 60 days from the date of its final passage, nor if, pending the final passage and taking effect of said ordinance, an election shall be called as provided by law, in which event said ordinance shall not take effect or become in force until the same shall have been duly approved by the electorate. 
    Within 60 days after the final passage and approval of this ordinance, Kansas State University shall file with the city clerk of the City of Manhattan its acceptance in writing of the provisions, terms and conditions of this ordinance, which acceptance shall be duly acknowledged before some officer authorized by law to administer oaths; and when so accepted the ordinance and acceptance shall constitute a contract between the city and Kansas State University subject to the provisions of the laws of the State of Kansas. 
(Ord. No. 4936, § 1, 9-9-95) 
Secs. 15-114, 15-115. - Reserved. 
Article VIII - RIGHT-OF-WAY PERMIT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4971, § 2, adopted May 7, 1996, added provisions designated as Art. VII, §§ 15-100-15-106; in-as-much there already exists an Art. VII, §§ 15-100-15-113, the editor has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. 4971, § 2, as a new Art. VIII, §§ 15-116-15-122 and retained the originally assigned section numbers as part of the history note. 

Sec. 15-116. - Right to apply for permit. 
    Any person, other than public utilities which are eligible to obtain a franchise from the city, desiring to place within any street, alley or other public right-of-way within the city, any cable, pipe, conduit, transmission line, wire or any other such similar device or structure, may apply to the city, for a permit for such purpose as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 4971, § 2(15-100), 5-7-96) 
Sec. 15-117. - Permit application. 
    The application for a permit under this article shall be submitted to the city clerk along with a fee of $250.00. Such application shall be on a form provided by the city, containing, as a minimum, the following information: 
(a)  The name and address of the person making the application. 
(b)  The nature of the device or structure proposed to be placed within the public right-of-way. 
(c)  All proposed public rights-of-way within which such devices or structures are to be located. 
(d)  The location, ownership and use of any and all properties that are to be served by, or connected to, the device or structure. 
(e)  Such additional information as shall be reasonably requested by the city manager, or his designee, such as, construction drawings and/or specifications. 
(Ord. No. 4971, § 2(15-101), 5-7-96) 
Sec. 15-118. - Issuance of permit; requirements. 
    The city manager, or his designee, may issue a permit for the purposes set forth in this article, if the city manager, or his designee, finds that such use of the public right-of-way will not be detrimental to the public use of such right-of-way, and if the following requirements are met: 
(a)  The applicant has executed a document which indemnifies, and holds the city harmless from any and all loss, damages, claims, demands, actions, causes of action, costs and expenses of whatever nature, which may result from injury to, or death of, persons, or from loss of, or damage to, property (including damage to the devices or structures owned by the applicant) when such injury, death, loss or damage is due to, or arises in connection with, or as a result of, the use of the public right-of-way by the applicant, regardless of any negligence of the city; 
(b)  The applicant has executed a document which obligates the applicant to remove or relocate, the structures or devices, at the sole cost of the applicant, if such removal, or relocation, is necessitated by a valid public purpose, as determined by the city; 
(c)  The applicant has executed a document which provides that the devices and structures will only be used by the applicant, to serve the locations provided in the application, and that the applicant will not allow any third party to connect to such structures or devices; and 
(d)  The applicant has agreed to participate in the one call damage prevention system serving the area where it has, or will have, facilities installed for the duration of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 4971, § 2(15-102), 5-7-96) 
Sec. 15-119. - Obligation to maintain. 
    The installation, maintenance and repair of any structure or device authorized by this article shall be at the sole cost and expense of the applicant, and shall be accomplished pursuant to all applicable codes and ordinances, and shall also be accomplished pursuant to such other reasonable requirements, as established by the city manager, or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 4971, § 2(15-103), 5-7-96) 
Sec. 15-120. - Nontransferable. 
    Any permit issued under this article shall be valid only to the person to whom it is issued, and shall not be deemed to run with any tract of real estate. Such permit may not be transferred, or assigned, without the written consent of the city. Once the permit is delivered, the applicant shall not be released from the requirements of such permit, nor from the requirements of this article, except in writing from the city. 
(Ord. No. 4971, § 2(15-104), 5-7-96) 
Sec. 15-121. - Revocation. 
    Any violation of the terms or conditions of the permit shall be grounds for its revocation. The city manager, or his designee, may revoke a permit, based upon such grounds, upon 30 days written notice to the holder of such permit. 
(Ord. No. 4971, § 2(15-105), 5-7-96) 
Sec. 15-122. - Appeal. 
    Any person denied a permit hereunder, or whose permit has been revoked, may appeal such decision to the governing body by filing a written notice of such appeal with the city clerk within ten days of the notice denying or revoking such permit. 
(Ord. No. 4971, § 2(15-106), 5-7-96) 
Secs. 15-123-15-129. - Reserved. 
Article IX - OCCUPATION TAX FOR PROVIDERS OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 5025, adopted March 4, 1997, added a new Art. VII, §§ 15-100-15-107. Inasmuch as there already exists an Art. VII, said provisions have been redesignated Art. IX, §§ 15-130-15-137. 

Sec. 15-130. - Definitions. 
    Access lines shall mean and be limited to retail billed and collected residential lines; business lines; ISDN lines; PBX trunks and simulated exchange access lines provided by a central office based switching arrangement where all stations served by such simulated exchange access lines are used by a single customer of the provider of such arrangement. Access line may not be construed to include interoffice transport or other transmission media that do not terminate at an end user customer's premises, or to permit duplicate or multiple assessment of access line rates on the provision of a single service or on the multiple communications paths derived from a billed and collected access line. Access line shall not include the following: Wireless telecommunications services, the sale or lease of unbundled loop facilities, special access services, lines providing only data services without voice services processed by a telecommunications local exchange service provider or private line service arrangements. 
    Franchise shall mean a current franchise granted by the City of Manhattan for any telecommunications services under the procedures and provisions of K.S.A. 12-2001 et seq., as amended. 
    Local exchange service means local switched telecommunications service within any local exchange service area approved by the state corporation commission, regardless of the medium by which the local telecommunications service is provided. The term local exchange service shall not include wireless communication services. 
    Provider means a local exchange carrier as defined in K.S.A. 66-1187(h), and amendments thereto, or a telecommunications carrier as defined in K.S.A. 66-1187(m), and amendments thereto. 
    Telecommunications local exchange service provider means a local exchange carrier as defined in K.S.A. 66-1187(h), and amendments thereto, and a telecommunications carrier as defined in K.S.A. 66-1187(m), and amendments thereto, which does, or in good faith intends to, provide local exchange service. The term telecommunications local exchange service provider does not include an interexchange carrier that does not provide local exchange service, competitive access provider that does not provide local exchange service or any wireless telecommunications local exchange service provider. 
    Telecommunications service means providing the means of transmission, between or among points specified by the user, of information of the user's choosing, without change in the form or content of the information as sent and received. 
(Ord. No. 5025, § 1, 3-4-97; Ord. No. 6375, § 1, 11-18-03) 
Sec. 15-131. - Telecommunications service occupations tax. 
    There is hereby imposed an occupation tax on the privilege of engaging in the business of furnishing local exchange services. This tax is levied upon providers in the amount of $1.20 per month for each access line served by the provider for local telecommunication service within the City of Manhattan. The occupation tax shall be paid to the city by the provider based upon the number of access lines served on the last day of the month for which the occupation tax is imposed. 
(Ord. No. 5025, § 1, 3-4-97; Ord. No. 6375, § 2, 11-18-03) 
Sec. 15-132. - Payment and reporting. 
(a)  Each provider that is obligated to pay the occupation tax imposed hereunder shall report the amount of access lines served and such other information deemed necessary by the city treasurer on forms to be established and furnished by the city treasurer. The provider shall pay the occupation tax due on a monthly basis within 30 days of the last day of the month for which the occupation tax is imposed. The governing body shall be authorized to adopt by resolution rules and regulations deemed necessary from time to time to account for and collect the occupation tax. 
(b)  For each and every month, or any part thereof, that the tax provided for by this article remains unpaid after the same becomes due and payable by the provider, there shall be added to such tax, as a late charge, the sum of one and one-half percent per month. 
(Ord. No. 5025, § 1, 3-4-97) 
Sec. 15-133. - Credit for franchise payments. 
(a)  A provider who is operating under a franchise shall receive credit on the occupation tax due to be paid hereunder to the extent that such payment would be duplicative of payments such provider is making under its franchise. 
(b)  Any provider that makes payment to the holder of a franchise in a monthly sum equal to or greater than the occupation tax imposed by this article shall receive a credit on the occupation tax due to be paid hereunder, provided that the holder of franchise remits such payment to the city pursuant to its obligations under the franchise. 
(Ord. No. 5025, § 1, 3-4-97) 
Sec. 15-134. - Franchise rights not waived. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to preclude the city from requiring a franchise from any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or entity who uses the streets and right-of-way of the city for the purpose of constructing and operating a telecommunications system. Any tax payment received by the city under this article shall not be deemed to waive or diminish the city's rights under K.S.A. 12-2001 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 5025, § 1, 3-4-97) 
Sec. 15-135. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for a provider to fail or refuse to pay the occupation tax imposed by this article. In addition, it shall be unlawful for a provider to engage in the business of furnishing telecommunications service within the city during the times that the occupation tax is unpaid and past due. 
(Ord. No. 5025, § 1, 3-4-97) 
Sec. 15-136. - Penalties.
