    There is hereby created in and for the city an advisory board to be known as the arts and humanities advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 6883, § 2, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-111. - Purposes. 
    The arts and humanities advisory board shall make reports and recommendations to the governing body on all matters referred to it, and as the board deems advisable, shall make recommendations related to the promotion and support of arts and humanities in the city. 
(Ord. No. 6883, § 2, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-112. - Composition. 
    The members of the advisory board shall consist of nine members appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the governing body. The board membership shall consist of at least three members who have professional experience in arts and humanities. The mayor shall also make a reasonable and good faith effort to ensure that the board membership consists of some members who are architects, graphic designers, historians, artists, or in similar fields. If the mayor is unable to find such members, the mayor may appoint other citizens to serve, with the advice and consent of the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 6883, § 2, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-113. - Terms. 
(a)  Each member of the advisory board shall serve for a period of three-year terms, for a maximum of two consecutive terms. Provided that, at the board's initial creation, three members shall be appointed for three years, three members shall be appointed for two years, and three members appointed for one year. 
(b)  Whenever a person is appointed to fill a position on the board that has become vacant because of a resignation, termination or other vacation, such appointment shall be only for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 6883, § 2, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-114. - Removal. 
    Any member of the arts and humanities advisory board may be removed by the governing body without notice or hearing. 
(Ord. No. 6883, § 2, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 23-115. - Bylaws; quorum. 
    The arts and humanities advisory board shall establish bylaws which provide for the election of officers for the board and establish guidelines for meetings as well as the frequency of those meetings and such other matters as the board may deem necessary. The adoption and amendment of the bylaws shall be approved by the governing body. The bylaws shall establish that five members of the board shall constitute a quorum and be necessary for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 6883, § 2, 3-22-11) 
Chapter 24 - CANVASSERS, PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 6895, adopted June 7, 2011, amended Ch. 24 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 24 consisted of §§ 24-1-24-6, 24-21, 24-22, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the original codification of this Code. 
Cross reference- Soliciting funds at the airport, § 7-57; secondhand goods generally, Ch. 29. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms as used in this chapter shall be deemed to mean and be construed as follows: 
    Canvass shall mean noncommercial activities such as opinion sampling, poll-taking, campaigning, proselytizing, or other similar activities that are conducted from dwelling to dwelling. 
    Canvasser shall mean any person who engages in canvassing for himself or for any other person or organization, but such term shall not include a government census taker. 
    Dwelling shall mean a building or portion thereof, including residential-design manufactured homes, mobile homes and manufactured homes, designed or used for a residential occupancy. For the purposes of this chapter, this term shall include common areas of multifamily residential structures. 
    Peddle shall mean traveling by foot, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance, from dwelling to dwelling, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, or merchandise for the purpose of offering or exposing the same for sale. 
    Peddler shall mean any person who peddles, except the term shall not include a person who has been specifically invited by an occupant of a dwelling to peddle at the dwelling. 
    Solicit shall mean traveling by foot, automobile, motor truck, or any other type of conveyance, from dwelling to dwelling, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries, or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he or she is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. 
    Solicitor shall mean any person who solicits, except the term shall not include a person who has been specifically invited by an occupant of a dwelling to solicit at the dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 6895, § 1, 6-7-11) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-21 et seq. 
Sec. 24-2. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, solicitor, or peddler to occupy or use the public streets, sidewalks, plazas or other city property to sell, or offer for sale, any goods, wares, merchandise, food or services, except as permitted by a city license or as authorized by the parks and recreation department in parks and recreation facilities. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any canvasser, solicitor, or peddler: 
(1)  To canvass, solicit or peddle within the city between the hours of one-half hour before sunset and 8:00 a.m. the following morning, or at any time on Sundays. 
(2)  To enter upon the private premises of any dwelling when the premises are posted with a sign stating "No Peddling", "No Solicitations" or any other words to such effect. 
(3)  To canvass, solicit or peddle upon, or to refuse to leave, any premises after having been asked by the owner or occupant thereof to leave the premises. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or peddler to make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality or nature of the peddler's or solicitor's goods, wares, merchandise or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the same. 
(Ord. No. 6895, § 1, 6-7-11; Ord. No. 6920, § 1, 9-20-11) 
Secs. 24-3-24-20. - Reserved. 
Article II - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 19. 

Sec. 24-21. - When required; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit or peddle within the city without having first obtained a license as required in this article. 
(b)  A license shall not be required for a person who solicits or peddles within the city on behalf of charitable, educational or religious organizations if the organization submits a letter to the city clerk certifying the organization's status as a charitable, educational, or religious organization and describing the dates and nature of activities that primarily benefit such organization. 
(Ord. No. 6895, § 2, 6-7-11) 
Sec. 24-22. - License application; criminal background check; fees. 
(a)  The application for a license to solicit or peddle shall be on a form provided by the city clerk, and a complete application shall be submitted to the city clerk, accompanied by the appropriate fees. The application form shall obtain the information necessary to conduct a criminal background check on each person listed as a solicitor or peddler on the application to ensure compliance with this section. 
(b)  No license shall be issued under this chapter to any person who: 
(1)  Is required to register pursuant to the Kansas Offender Registration Act, K.S.A. 22-4901 et seq., or pursuant to an offender registration act of any state; or 
(2)  Has been convicted of a felony; or 
(3)  Has been convicted in the past five years of a misdemeanor or ordinance violation involving force, violence, deceit, or fraud; or 
(4)  Has been convicted of any law regulating the act of soliciting within the past five years. 
(c)  The fees for the license and criminal background checks shall be as prescribed in section 19-40. 
(Ord. No. 6895, § 2, 6-7-11) 
Sec. 24-23. - Conditions of licensure. 
    The city clerk, or an officer of the Riley County Police Department, may suspend or revoke a license if the solicitor or peddler: 
(a)  Fails to carry, at all times while engaging in peddling or soliciting, a copy of the city license issued under this chapter. 
(b)  Fails to produce the city-issued license upon the request of the city, any law enforcement officer, or any person to whom the licensee is soliciting or peddling. 
(c)  Fails to prominently display on his/her person the city-issued badge at all times while engaging in peddling or soliciting. 
(d)  Fails to provide, at the request of the purchaser, a written receipt for purchases exceeding $5.00 in cash or tangible property, which receipt shall be signed by the person making the sale and shall set forth a brief description of the goods or services sold, the total purchase price thereof, amount of cash payment, if any, and the balance due and terms of payment. 
(e)  Commits any unlawful act described in section 24-2 or any other violation of the law while soliciting or peddling. 
    If the solicitor or peddler is notified, in person or in writing, that he or she has violated a condition of licensure resulting in a suspension or revocation, the solicitor or peddler shall immediately cease soliciting or peddling upon the receipt of such notification. 
(Ord. No. 6895, § 2, 6-7-11) 
Sec. 24-24. - Right to appeal. 
    The applicant or solicitor shall have the right to appeal the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license issued under this article to the city manager. The applicant or solicitor shall file a written notice of appeal with the city manager within five business days following the notification that the license has been denied, suspended, or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 6895, § 2, 6-7-11) 
Sec. 24-25. - Reserved. 
Article III - MOBILE ICE CREAM VENDING 
Division 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms as used in this chapter shall be deemed to mean and be construed as follows: 
    Mobile ice cream vending operation shall mean any person, firm, partnership or corporation who conducts or engages in the business of selling or offering for sale any prepackaged ice cream novelties, intended for immediate consumption, from a vehicle that travels from house to house, street to street, or place to place. Provided that, this definition shall not include any person, firm, partnership or corporation who conducts or engages in the business of selling or offering for sale prepackaged ice cream novelties that are sold or delivered to the ultimate consumer on a prearranged date that is scheduled with the consumer. 
    Mobile ice cream vendor shall mean a person who drives a vehicle used for a mobile ice cream vending operation, or who assists the driver from within such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 3, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-27. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a mobile ice cream vending operation unless such person has obtained the license required by this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be a mobile ice cream vendor unless such person has obtained the license required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 3, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-28. - Reserved. 
Division 2. - MOBILE ICE CREAM VENDING OPERATION LICENSE 

Sec. 24-29. - License application; term; fees; exemption. 
(a)  The application for a mobile ice cream vending operation license shall be on a form provided by the city clerk, and a complete application shall be submitted to the city clerk, accompanied by the appropriate fee. The application shall include a photograph of, and the vehicle identification number (VIN) for, each vehicle used for the mobile ice cream vending operation in the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  The license shall expire on December 31 of the calendar year for which it was issued. 
(c)  The annual license fee shall be $150.00. The license fee shall not be prorated and is nontransferable and nonrefundable. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 4, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-30. - Standards of issuance. 
(a)  The mobile ice cream vending operation shall comply with all food safety laws and requirements of the State of Kansas. The mobile ice cream vending operation must have a valid Kansas food license for the mobile ice cream vending operation, and/or for each vehicle used by the operation, as required by the State of Kansas. 
(b)  The applicant must provide a Kansas Retail Sales Tax Number for the mobile ice cream vending operation. 
(c)  The applicant must secure and maintain commercial general liability insurance for the mobile ice cream vending operation, written by an insurance carrier licensed to do business in Kansas, with minimum limits of $500,000.00 combined, single limit for bodily and property damage, each occurrence and $500,000.00 in the general aggregate. Evidence of compliance with the insurance requirements shall be in the form of a certificate of insurance that shall be submitted with the application. Such insurance certificate shall include coverage for premises/operations liability, products/completed operations, and personal/advertising injury. 
(d)  The applicant must provide proof that each vehicle used for the mobile ice cream vending operation complies with the vehicle regulations listed in subsections 24-31(a) through (e). 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 4, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-31. - Motor vehicle regulations. 
(a)  Each motor vehicle used for the mobile ice cream vending operation must be equipped with the following: 
(1)  Prominent signs, visible from the front and the rear of the vehicle, with the wording "Caution - Children", or similar language, in letters at least six inches tall; 
(2)  Flashing amber yellow caution lights on the vehicle, visible from the front and rear, which may include a swinging arm equipped with such lights; 
(3)  Left and right outside rearview mirrors, as well as two additional outside wide-angle mirrors on the front and back of the vehicle to enable to driver to see around the entire vehicle; and 
(4)  A serving window that is located on the curbside of the vehicle only. 
(b)  Each motor vehicle used for the mobile ice cream vending operation must be in good working order and kept in a safe and clean condition. 
(c)  Each motor vehicle must have a valid registration. 
(d)  Each motor vehicle must be insured with business automobile liability insurance, written by an insurance carrier licensed to do business in Kansas, with minimum limits of insurance of $50,000.00 for bodily injury or death to any one person; $100,000.00 for injury or death of any number of persons; and $10,000.00 for property damage in any one accident. Evidence of compliance with the insurance requirements shall be in the form of a certificate of insurance that shall be submitted with the application for a mobile food vending operation license. 
(e)  No vending vehicle attached to a motor vehicle by means of a hatch or any other connecting device shall be permitted. 
(f)  When used for the mobile ice cream vending operation, each motor vehicle must be driven by a licensed mobile food vendor, and occupied by no more than one additional person, who shall also be a licensed mobile food vendor. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 4, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-32. - Conditions of licensure. 
    The city clerk, or an officer of the Riley County Police Department, may deny, suspend or revoke a license in the following circumstances: 
(a)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or any false statement contained in any application, including attachments, for such license; 
(b)  Failure to comply with the standards of issuance and maintain such compliance throughout the license term; 
(c)  Failure to comply with the motor vehicle requirements for each motor vehicle used for the mobile ice cream vending operation; and 
(d)  Fails to display, at all times while operating any motor vehicle for the mobile ice cream vending operation, a copy of the city license issued under this article and a copy of the licensee's Kansas food license. The copies of such licenses shall be prominently displayed on, or in close proximity to, the serving window of each motor vehicle, so that they can be clearly and easily viewed by a customer at the serving window. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 4, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-33. - Right to appeal. 
    The applicant or licensee shall have the right to appeal the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license issued under this article to the city manager. The applicant or licensee shall file a written notice of appeal with the city manager within five business days following the notification that the license has been denied, suspended, or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 4, 9-20-11) 
Secs. 24-34, 24-35. - Reserved. 
Division 3. - MOBILE ICE CREAM VENDOR LICENSE 

Sec. 24-36. - License application; term; fees; exemption. 
(a)  The application for a mobile ice cream vendor license shall be on a form provided by the city clerk, and a complete application shall be submitted to the city clerk, accompanied by the appropriate fee. 
(b)  The license shall expire on December 31 of the calendar year for which it was issued. 
(c)  The annual license fee shall be $25.00; provided that the license fee shall be waived for up to four mobile ice cream vendors working for a mobile ice cream vending operation with a valid, current license. The mobile ice cream vending operation licensee shall pay the license fee for each mobile ice cream vendor if it licenses more than four in a calendar year. 
(d)  The license fee shall not be prorated and is nontransferable and nonrefundable. 
(e)  Every application for a mobile ice cream vendor license shall include a nonrefundable $20.00 fee for the criminal background check required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 5, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-37. - Standards of issuance. 
(a)  No license shall be issued under this division to any person unless that person has a current and valid driver's license issued by the State of Kansas. 
(b)  No license shall be issued under this chapter to any person who: 
(1)  Is required to register pursuant to the Kansas Offender Registration Act, K.S.A. 22-4901 et seq., as amended, or pursuant to an offender registration act of any state; or 
(2)  Has been convicted of a felony; or 
(3)  Has been convicted in the past five years of a misdemeanor or ordinance violation involving force, violence, deceit, or fraud; or 
(4)  Has been convicted in the past three years of any law prohibiting leaving the scene of an accident; driving under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs; reckless driving; fleeing or alluding a police officer; driving while license is suspended or revoked; failure to report an accident; or five or more traffic violations (not including parking violations). 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 5, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-38. - Regulations. 
(a)  The licensee shall only engage in mobile ice cream food vending between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and sunset. 
(b)  The licensee shall remain mobile, which means that the licensee shall only stop when summoned by a customer, and that such stop shall be for a maximum duration of ten minutes. 
(c)  The licensee shall not vend on any street at a location where the speed limit is greater than 30 miles per hour. In no case shall the licensee's speed exceed 15 miles per hour in a residential zoning district when soliciting customers. 
(d)  The licensee shall comply with all traffic regulations. The licensee shall not stop, stand, or park at any location prohibited by the most recent version of the standard traffic ordinance. Further, the licensee shall not vend from any location marked where official signs or yellow-painted curb markings prohibit stopping, standing, or parking. The licensee shall not obstruct or interfere with traffic, nor shall the licensee stop or vend in any location that creates a danger to pedestrians or other drivers. 
(e)  The licensee shall not operate within alleys or public parking lots, nor can the licensee vend within 50 feet of an intersection. The licensee shall only vend from the curbside window to individuals standing on the curb or on private property. The licensee shall not vend to individuals standing or located within city streets. 
(f)  The licensee shall not solicit or conduct any transaction within two blocks from the property lines containing any public or private school property for a period beginning 30 minutes before the regular school day of any such school and continuing until 30 minutes after the adjournment of the regular school day. 
(g)  A licensee shall not operate within city parks and recreation facilities without first receiving the permission of the city parks and recreation department. If the licensee receives permission from the city parks and recreation department, the licensee shall comply with the requirements imposed by the parks and recreation department, including limitations on hours and location of operation. 
(h)  Any sound equipment used by the licensee shall be limited to music or human speech and can only be used between 10:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. The sound emitted from such equipment shall not be played in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the vehicle. The sound must be turned off when the vehicle is stopped for vending. 
(i)  When occupying a motor vehicle used for the mobile ice cream vending operation, the licensee shall not allow anyone to occupy such vehicle other than one other licensed mobile food vendor. 
(j)  The licensee shall not operate a vehicle that does not meet the vehicle regulations set forth in section 24-31. 
(k)  The licensee shall comply with all food safety laws and requirements of the State of Kansas. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 5, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-39. - Conditions of licensure. 
    The city clerk, or an officer of the Riley County Police Department, may deny, suspend or revoke a license in the following circumstances: 
(a)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or any false statement contained in any application, including attachments, for such license; 
(b)  Failure to comply with the standards of issuance and maintain such compliance throughout the license term; 
(c)  Failure to comply with the license regulations; 
(d)  Violation of any law while acting as a mobile ice cream vendor. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 5, 9-20-11) 
Sec. 24-40. - Right to appeal. 
    The applicant or licensee shall have the right to appeal the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license issued under this article to the city manager. The applicant or licensee shall file a written notice of appeal with the city manager within five business days following the notification that the license has been denied, suspended, or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 6920, § 5, 9-20-11) 
Chapter 26 - PLANNING AND ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; mobile homes and trailers, Ch. 20; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 30; utilities, Ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Planning and zoning, K.S.A. Ch. 12, Art. 7. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Zoning application fees. 
    Whenever any application is submitted requesting any of the following zoning changes, amendments, or considerations, said application shall be accompanied by the corresponding fee: 
(a)  A change in the text of the zoning regulations ..... $75.00 
(b)  Appeals of the zoning administrator's decision. (This is a deposit which will be refunded to the applicant if the appeal is sustained.) ..... 90.00 
(c)  Variance of zoning regulations ..... 120.00 
(d)  Exception of zoning regulations ..... 120.00 
(e)  Request for a conditional use permit ..... 120.00 
(f)  Request zoning or rezoning of a tract of ground to any residential, commercial or industrial designation, except a PUD, Planned Unit Development ..... 160.00 
(g)  Request zoning or rezoning a tract of ground to PUD, Planned Unit Development (preliminary development plan) ..... 300.00 
(h)  Request a final Planned Unit Development approval ..... 100.00 
(i)  Request an amendment to a final Planned Unit Development ..... 85.00 
(j)  Request an amendment or revisions to a floodplain as shown on adopted FEMA maps ..... 200.00 
(k)  Request for a letter of opinion on a nonconforming use ..... 75.00 
(l)  Request for a floodplain development permit ..... 50.00 
(m)  Request for authority to construct or expand a state or municipally owned and operated public utility and facility ..... 160.00 
(Ord. No. 3661, § 1, 11-21-78; Ord. No. 4008, § 1, 12-7-82; Ord. No. 4470, § 1, 11-3-87; Ord. No. 5041, § 1, 6-17-97) 
Sec. 26-2. - Approval of subdivision regulations. 
(a)  The Manhattan Urban Area Subdivision Regulations, as adopted by the Manhattan Urban Area Planning Board, on October 3, 1983, are hereby approved, and hereby incorporated by reference into this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with the provision of said Manhattan Urban Area Subdivision Regulations. 
(c)  Three copies of said Manhattan Urban Area Subdivisions Regulations shall be on file in the city clerk's office during office hours for public inspection. Said copies shall be marked "Official copy as incorporated by Ordinance No. 4130." 
(Ord. No. 4130, §§ 1-3, 4-17-84) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4130, §§ 1-3, adopted Apr. 17, 1984, did not specifically amend this Code, but such provisions have been included herein as § 26-2 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 26-3. - Subdivision application fees. 
    Whenever any of the following subdivision requests are filed with the city, a fee shall be submitted therewith in the amount indicated below: 
(a)  A change in the text of the regulations ..... $ 75.00 
(b)  Preliminary plats ..... 150.00 
(c)  A final plat, an amendment to a preliminary plat, or replat of an existing plat of record ..... 150.00 
(d)  A combined preliminary and final plat (small tract procedure) ..... 200.00 
(Ord. No. 4008, § 2, 12-7-82; Ord. No. 4470, § 2, 11-3-87) 
Secs. 26-4-26-15. - Reserved. 
Article II - URBAN AREA PLANNING BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; boards, agencies and commissions, § 2-191 et seq. 
State Law reference- Joint cooperation in area planning, K.S.A. 12-716 et seq. 

Sec. 26-16. - Creation; agreement between county and city. 
    Pursuant to K.S.A. 12-744, the City does hereby adopt, approve and make effective, the Agreement, dated the sixth day of February, 2001, set forth hereinafter, between Riley County and the City of Manhattan, related to joint cooperation in area planning and zoning. An original of such Agreement, along with Exhibit A attached thereto, after it has been signed by all parties, and has been approved by the Attorney General, shall be placed on file with the City Clerk. The body of such Agreement reads, as follows: 
"AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, AND RILEY COUNTY, KANSAS, RELATING TO JOINT COOPERATION IN PLANNING AND ZONING 
    "THIS AGREEMENT is hereby entered into, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-744, this 6th day of February, 2001, by and between the City of Manhattan, Kansas, a Municipal Corporation, hereinafter sometimes referred to as the "City"; and the Board of County Commissioners of Riley County, Kansas, hereinafter sometimes referred to as the "County". 
    "WHEREAS, the City and the County have previously entered into an agreement (the "Original Agreement"), pursuant to K.S.A. 12-716, which was effective on May 1, 1976; and, 
    "WHEREAS, the Original Agreement created a Joint Planning Commission (The Manhattan Urban Area Planning Board, hereinafter sometimes referred to as "MUAPB"), to exercise planning functions, both within the corporate limits of the City, and within a designated area outside the City, but within Riley County; and, 
    "WHEREAS, the Original Agreement was amended by the parties several different times, including, on November 6, 1979, to modify the designated area outside the City; and, 
    "WHEREAS, the Original Agreement was again amended by the parties in 1981 to provide for a different method of appointing members of MUAPB; and, 
    "WHEREAS, the City and the County have adopted the Original Agreement and the amendments thereto, by ordinance and resolution respectively; and, 
    "WHEREAS, the Kansas Legislature has repealed K.S.A. 12-716 and replaced it with K.S.A. 12-744, which now provides the authority for cities and counties to cooperate, by written agreement, in the exercise and performance of planning powers, duties and functions and to establish a joint planning commission; and, 
    "WHEREAS, the parties hereto desire to amend, and replace, in their entirety, the Original Agreement and the amendments thereto. 
    "NOW THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual promises contained herein, the parties hereto agree as follows: 
"1.  That the Original Agreement, and all amendments thereto, are hereby amended and replaced, in their entirety, by the provisions set forth hereinafter. 
"2.  The City and the County hereby agree to cooperate in the exercise and performance of planning powers, duties and functions within the Urban Area, all as more specifically set forth hereinafter. 
"3.  That the Joint Planning Commission known as the MUAPB, as created by the Original Agreement, and amendments thereto, is hereby continued, as more specifically set forth hereinafter. The MUAPB shall consist of seven (7) members, with three (3) being appointed by the City, pursuant to its own adopted procedure governing the appointment of members to its Boards, and three (3) being appointed by the County, pursuant to its adopted procedures governing the appointment of members to its boards, and one (1) being alternately appointed by the County and the City, again pursuant to the procedures of the appointing body. The members of the MUAPB shall be appointed for three (3) year terms and the members previously appointed pursuant to the Original Agreement shall continue to serve, and their term shall expire at the same time as it would have expired under their original appointment. The alternating appointment between the City and the County shall continue in the same order as it was previously established under the Original Agreement. The members of the MUAPB, while appointed for a term for the convenience of the jurisdiction appointing them, shall serve in that term at the pleasure of the governing body of the jurisdiction appointing them. In order to qualify for service as a member of the MUAPB, a person must reside within the area of the jurisdiction of the MUAPB. 
"4.  The MUAPB is hereby empowered to carry into effect the provisions of Kansas law delegated to planning commissions, all as set forth in K.S.A. 12-741, et seq., pertaining to matters within the corporate limits of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, and also pertaining to matters within the Urban Area. For the purposes of this Agreement, the Urban Area shall consist of an area lying outside the corporate limits of the City of Manhattan, but within Riley County, the boundaries of which shall be specifically agreed to, in writing, by the governing bodies of the City of Manhattan and Riley County. At the outset of this Agreement, and until modified by written agreement of the parties, the boundaries of the Urban Area are set forth on Exhibit A, attached hereto. The parties hereto agree to review, and modify if necessary, such boundaries on an annual basis, or more frequently, when events occur that cause the administrative staffs of either, or both, governing bodies, to recommend such review and/or modification. 
"5.  (a)  The parties hereto agree to cooperate with each other, and with the MUAPB, in the creation of a single Comprehensive Plan for the City and surrounding Urban Area that is consistent with the City's growth policies and plans. 
"(b)  The parties further agree to cooperate with each other, and the MUAPB, in the creation, and maintenance, of sub-division regulations that are consistent for both the Urban Area and the City of Manhattan. 
"(c)  Any Comprehensive Plan created pursuant to this Agreement shall not be effective until it has been adopted by the MUAPB, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-747, and approved by the governing body of the City, and the Board of the Riley County Commissioners, also pursuant to K.S.A. 12-747. 
"6.  In addition to those duties proscribed by K.S.A. 12-741, et seq., the MUAPB shall continually, when time and priorities permit, make specific recommendations to the governing bodies regarding any matters that might facilitate cooperation between the parties in the providing of governmental services within the Urban Area. Such matters include, by way of example, but are not limited to, the following: 
"(a)  The adoption of codes relating to minimum standards of housing, building, electrical work, plumbing work, and other related areas. 
"(b)  The staffing for administration, inspection and enforcement of all of such codes, as well as sub-division regulations and zoning regulations within the Board's jurisdiction. 
"(c)  The division of cost between the City and the County related to such cooperation. 
"7.  Until such time as plans or regulations provided for herein, or recommendations by the MUAPB, are adopted by the City and the County, the separate regulations of the City shall apply within the corporate limits of the City, and the separate regulations of the County shall apply in the unincorporated area. Further, until the City and the County have adopted joint regulations which provide otherwise, the City and the County shall continue to have separate administrative staffs and personnel for administration, inspection and enforcement; however, these separate staffs are directed to work diligently, and cooperatively, in connection with the efforts of the MUAPB and in furtherance of the purposes of this Agreement. 
"8.  The duration of this Agreement is perpetual unless terminated on January 1 of any given year, by either the City or the County. The party desiring termination shall provide written notice to the other party on, or before, March 1 of the year preceding the effective date of termination. 
"9.  The parties agree to adopt this Agreement, by official action of their governing bodies, pursuant to law." 
(Ord. No. 3396, 3-16-76, Ord. No. 3525, 10-4-77; Res. No. 102180-D, 11-4-80; Ord. No. 6200, 2-20-01) 
Sec. 26-17. - Appointed to function as municipal airport zoning commission. 
    Pursuant to K.S.A. 3-705(2) the governing body appoints the urban area planning board to be the municipal airport zoning commission and to carry out the functions and duties of the same as set out in K.S.A. 3-701 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 3185, § 1, 9-4-73) 
Cross reference- Aviation generally, Ch. 7. 
Secs. 26-18-26-28. - Reserved. 
Article III - BIG LAKES REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; boards, agencies and commissions, § 2-191 et seq. 
State Law reference- Joint cooperation in area planning, K.S.A. 12-716 et seq. 

Sec. 26-29. - Participation; agreement. 
    The city, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-716 et seq., as amended, does elect to participate in the expanded Big Lakes Regional Commission. The city does approve and adopt by reference the By-Laws of the Big Lakes Regional Planning Commission which read as follows: 
"BIG LAKES REGIONAL COUNCIL 
BY-LAWS 
AS AMENDED, JANUARY, 1979 
"PROVIDING FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT, OPERATION, POWER, DUTIES, JURISDICTION, AND THE SHARING OF THE EXPENSES OF OPERATION OF THE BIG LAKES REGIONAL COUNCIL. 
    "WHEREAS, the Board of County Commissioners of counties with adjoining jurisdictions in an area defined as the Big Lakes Region together with cities in the region recognize the need for unified development and coordination of programs affecting the area, these By-Laws are formulated to establish the Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments. The purpose of the Council shall include but not be limited to the coordination of community improvement and development programs, the identification and elimination of planning duplication, the promotion of economy and efficiency in the development of the region, and the support of programs to improve the general welfare and prosperity of the people in the region. Programs and policies will be developed to reflect the trends and needs of the physical, social, economic and governmental conditions in the region. The Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments shall assist in the development and implementation of programs and shall serve in an advisory capacity to all governmental units in the region. 
"BE IT RESOLVED BY THE BOARD OF COUNTY COMMISSIONERS OF MEMBER COUNTIES TO ESTABLISH THE BIG LAKES REGIONAL COUNCIL OF LOCAL GOVERNMENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FOLLOWING ARTICLES. 
"ARTICLE I. NAME 
    "Section 1. NAME. The name of the association shall be the Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments. 
"ARTICLE II. MEMBERSHIP AND DIRECTORS 
    "Section 1. MEMBERSHIP. Membership in the Council will be limited to governmental jurisdictions within counties whose Board of County Commissioners adopt these By-Laws by ordinance and contribute to the budget of Council in accordance with provisions in Article VI. Each governmental jurisdiction within the boundaries of contributing counties is considered a member of the Council and entitled to participate in programs and services provided by the Regional Council. 
    "Section 2. MEMBERSHIP REQUESTS. Any county commission having adjoining jurisdiction with any member county of the Big Lakes Regional Council may petition the Council for active membership. New members will be accepted upon majority vote by the Council and upon signifying their acceptance of the terms of the By-Laws and other memorandum or agreements adopted by the Council. 
    "Section 3. BOARD OF DIRECTORS. The Board of County Commissioners from member counties in the Big Lakes Regional Council shall appoint three members to the Board of Directors to the Big Lakes Regional Council based on the following selection procedures: 
"A.  A member of the Board of County Commissioners from each member county shall be designated as a member of the Board of Directors of the Big Lakes Regional Council. 
"B.  The Board of County Commissioners of member counties shall appoint two residents of their county to serve as at-large members of the Board of Directors of the Council who shall serve as representatives of local units of government within the county. 
"C.  Appointments to the Board of Directors shall be for two-year terms. Terms shall be staggered to assure a continuity of membership on the Board of Directors and on the Executive Committee of the Council. Appointments of less than two years shall be made to fill unexpired terms on the Board of Directors or to make adjustments as determined necessary by the Board of Directors. 
    "Section 4. EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE. An Executive Committee shall be established. The Executive Committee shall include one representative from each member county designated by the respective Board of County Commissioners and the elected Chairperson of the Council. Executive Committee members shall be members of the Board of Directors of the Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments. Committee responsibilities shall include the development of recommendations of policies and programs of the Council and on other matters as directed by the Board of Directors. 
    "Section 5. EX OFFICIO MEMBERS. Elected or appointed representatives of federal, state, or local governmental entities or representatives of other public or private organizations or agencies may be appointed to serve as ex officio nonvoting members of the Council. The appointments of ex officio members on the Council shall be determined by the voting members of the Board of Directors of the Big Lakes Regional Council. 
    "Section 6. COMPENSATION. Board of Director members of the Council shall serve without compensation. 
    "Section 7. REMOVAL OR SUSPENSION. Officers of the Council shall not be removed or suspended from office except for cause and after a hearing held before the Council Board of Directors. The removal or suspension of a member of the Board of Directors shall be the exclusive jurisdiction of the Board of County Commissioners by whom the member was appointed. 
"ARTICLE III. OFFICERS 
    "Section 1. COUNCIL OFFICERS. The Board of Directors of the Council shall elect from its membership a Chairperson and a Vice-Chairperson. A Secretary-Treasurer for the Council shall also be elected, who need not be a member of the Council. 
"A.  Officers of the Council shall be elected at the annual meeting of the Council which shall be held in January of each year. Elected officers shall assume office on the first day of February and shall serve a term of 12 calendar months. 
"B.  Unscheduled vacancies in an office of the Council shall be filled for the unexpired term by special election at the first regular meeting of the Council following receipt of notification of the vacancy. 
    "Section 2. RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES. The responsibilities and duties of officers shall be those normally pertaining to their office, and shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
"A.  Chairperson-The Chairperson shall preside at all meetings of the Council and the Executive Committee. The Chairperson shall be the designated officer authorized to sign contracts, agreements, and other documents on behalf of the Big Lakes Regional Council. The Chairperson shall appoint, with approval of the Council and the Director of the Cooperative Extension Service at Kansas State University an Executive Director to the Council. 
"B.  Vice-Chairperson-The Vice-Chairperson shall perform all duties of the Chairperson in the absence or incapacity of the Chairperson and perform other functions determined necessary for the normal conduct of the Council's program. 
"C.  Secretary-Treasurer-The Secretary-Treasurer shall be responsible for maintenance of a record of proceedings and financial affairs of the Council. Responsibility for the day-to-day duties of the Secretary-Treasurer may be delegated to the Executive Director of the Council. 
"ARTICLE IV. MEETINGS AND QUORUMS 
    "Section 1. MEETINGS. The Big Lakes Regional Council shall hold a minimum of ten regular meetings during each calendar year. Meetings shall generally be scheduled for a specific day during a specific week of the month at a time and place designated by the Council or its Chairperson. The meeting in January of each year shall be the annual meeting of the Council. 
"A.  Special meetings of the Council may be called by the Chairperson or upon request from a majority of the members of the Board of Directors of the Council. 
"B.  Special meetings shall require a minimum of seventy-two (72) hour notice to each member of the Council, unless the required notice is waived in writing by a majority of the Board of Directors of the Council. 
"C.  The maximum period of time between meetings of the Council shall not exceed sixty-five (65) calendar days. 
    "Section 2. QUORUM. A quorum shall be required to conduct the formal business of the Council. A quorum shall be defined as a majority of the Board of Directors officially appointed and serving as a member of the Big Lakes Regional Council. 
"ARTICLE V. ANNUAL BUDGET AND SHARING COSTS 
    "Section 1. BUDGET. The Big Lakes Regional Council shall adopt annually a budget for its operation. This budget will be submitted to the Board of County Commissioners of member counties on or about June 1, of each year. Such annual budget is to be for the fiscal year commencing January 1, subsequent to the adoption thereof. The annual budget so prepared by the Council shall be subject to approval by the Board of County Commissioners of member counties of the Council. Thereafter, and upon such approval, each of said public bodies shall appropriate funds to implement said budget. 
    "Section 2. PRORATION OF BUDGET. The local cost of operating the program of the Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments shall be allocated among its member county governments by a mill levy, to be determined in the annual budget, on the assessed valuation of each county. 
    "Section 3. TRANSFER OF FUNDS. Upon approval of the annual budget by the County Commissioners of each member county, the treasurer of each member county shall be directed to make payment to the depository of the Big Lakes Regional Council. The initial payment for each budget year shall be made prior to February 1, of each year. 
"ARTICLE VI. FUNCTIONS, DUTIES, AND POWERS 
    "Section 1. LEGISLATIVE AUTHORITY. The Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments shall have all the functions, duties and powers as provided in K.S.A. Sections 12-716 to 12-721 inclusive, as amended and as provided in K.S.A. Section 12-2904 et seq. 
    "Section 2. DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS. Duties and functions of the Council shall include: 
"A.  The gathering and assimilation of economic, technical, and social information. 
"B.  Providing educational assistance in identifying problems, determining priorities, setting goals and solving problems. 
"C.  Identifying and organizing resources to meet the needs of people. 
"D.  Providing assistance to community leaders in the development and improvement of their leadership ability. The Council shall use educational programs in community and resource development as a source of information and as a demonstration of application of the decision making process. 
    "Section 3. FISCAL RESPONSIBILITIES. The fiscal responsibilities and functions pertaining to the Council shall include: 
"A.  Authority to approve expenditures by voucher or check executed by designated officers or employees of the Council from appropriated funds. 
"B.  Designation of a depository or depositories for the total budget of the Council. Proposed changes in the depository for the operating budget of the Council shall be considered by the Council at the regular meeting immediately preceding the beginning of a new fiscal year and a depository change shall be effective with the beginning of the fiscal year. The depository or depositories for federal grants, special programs or special purposes with definite termination dates shall be designated for the complete term of the grant, special program or special purposes. 
"C.  Authority to accept, receive and expend funds, grants and services from the United States Government or its agencies and from instrumentalities of state and local governments. 
"D.  Authority to accept, receive and expend funds, grants and services from private persons or organizations, including business or non-profit organizations. 
"E.  Development and approval of rules of fiscal management necessary for proper reporting of receipt and expenditure of public and private funds. 
"ARTICLE VII. TERMINATION OF COUNCIL 
    "Section 1. TERMINATION. The termination of the Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments shall require a vote of three-fourths of the voting members of the Council. The termination of the Big Lakes Regional Council shall become effective 90 days following such a vote to allow adequate time for transfer of responsibilities and pertinent data to the proper agencies and for preparation of reports and materials for final consideration. The termination shall be effected in the following manner: 
"A.  All equipment and property of the Big Lakes Regional Council shall be sold at auction and proceeds deposited in the depository of the Big Lakes Regional Council. 
"B.  Balances in the account or accounts of the Big Lakes Regional Council after payment of all bills and obligations, including the proceeds from the sale of equipment and other property, shall be distributed by check to the county treasurer of all contributing counties in the year of the termination vote. The amount of this distribution will be established by the percentage of the local contribution provided by each county during the year of the termination vote. 
"ARTICLE VIII. AMENDMENTS 
    "Section 1. AMENDMENTS. Amendments to these By-Laws shall be approved by two-thirds vote of the Board of Directors of the Council. Written notice shall be given of proposed By-Law amendments to all members by depositing such notice in the U.S. Postal Service at least ten days prior to its consideration by the Council following completion of required public notice of proposed changes. 
"ARTICLE IX. USE OF FUNDS 
    "Section 1. USE OF FUNDS. Funds shall not be used to the benefit of or be distributable to, its members, trustees, officers, or other private persons, except that the Council shall be authorized and empowered to pay reasonable compensation for services rendered and to make payments and distributions in furtherance of the purposes established by the Council. The Council shall not participate in, or intervene in (including the publishing or distribution of statements) any political campaign on behalf of any candidate for public office. Notwithstanding any other provision of these Articles, the Council shall not carry on any other activities not permitted to be carried on (a) by the Council exempt from Federal Income Tax under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 (or the corresponding provision of any future United States Internal Revenue Law), or (b) by a Council, contributions to which are deductible under Section 170(c)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 (or the corresponding provision of any future United States Internal Revenue Law.) 
"ARTICLE X. RULES AND POLICIES 
    "Section 1. RULES AND POLICIES. The Council shall adopt other rules and policies as determined necessary by the Board of Directors including rules for the transaction of Council business. Rules and policies shall be adopted for functions including but not limited to: 
"A.  Membership 
"B.  Officers 
"C.  Meetings and voting 
"D.  Staff and budget 
"E.  Sharing of costs 
"F.  Agreements with the Cooperative Extension Service at Kansas State University and other cooperating agencies. 
"ARTICLE XII. EFFECTIVE DATE 
    "Section 1. SEPARABILITY. If these By-Laws or any part thereof, shall be held or determined to be unconstitutional, illegal, ultravires or void, the same shall not be held or construed to change or annul any provision hereof which may be legal or lawful; and in the event these By-Laws or any part thereof, shall be held unconstitutional, illegal, ultravires or void, the same shall not affect any action heretofore taken by the Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments heretofore established and constituted. 
"ARTICLE XII. EFFECTIVE DATE 
    "Section 1. EFFECTIVE DATE. The By-Laws of the Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments shall become effective following approval by a two-thirds vote of the voting members of the Board of Directors of the Council and adoption by the Board of County Commissioners of each member county contributing to the budget of the Big Lakes Regional Council of Local Governments." 
(Ord. No. 3335, 1-4-75) 
Chapter 27 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; offenses, Ch. 22; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 31. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 27-1-27-15. - Reserved. 
Article II - MERCHANT GUARD OR MERCHANT PATROL 
Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 27-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Agents and employees shall mean all persons employed by a merchant guard or merchant patrol, in the conduct of his business, except stenographic and clerical employees whose duties are confined entirely to stenographic and clerical duties in the business office of the merchant guard or merchant patrol or other employees not directly engaged in providing protection or preserving the peace. 
    Merchant guard or merchant patrol shall mean any person who conducts or is engaged in the business of providing protection or preserving the peace of the property of another for a fee. 
    Property shall mean either personal or real property, and shall include property used for commercial, residential or industrial purposes. 
    Providing protection and preserving the peace shall mean any service designed and intended to prevent the injury or damage to, or commission of a crime upon, the property of another, and shall include the routine surveillance of such property for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 1, 7-5-77; Ord. No. 4296, § 1, 2-18-86) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-21 et seq. 
Sec. 27-17. - Uniforms. 
    Uniforms shall be worn by agents or employees of merchant guards or merchant patrols while employed within the city and will be of a color different and distinctive from that worn by officers of the Riley County police department. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 12, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-18. - Vehicles. 
    The vehicles used in the conduct of the merchant guard or merchant patrol business within the city by any licensee shall be of a color different from that of the vehicles of the Riley County police department and the fire department; once determined, the color shall not be changed except by mutual agreement between the director and the business licensee. In addition, such vehicles shall not be equipped with any rotating roof lights, or siren, nor shall any insignias be painted on the sides thereof which are similar to or which could be confused with that painted on the sides of the vehicles of the police department and the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 13, 7-5-77) 
State Law reference- Merchant or security police licensed by municipality must have state licensed vehicles, K.S.A. 12-1679. 
Sec. 27-19. - Use of flashing, blinking or rotating lights or sirens prohibited. 
    The licensee shall not operate or permit the operation of any flashing, blinking, or rotating lights on its vehicles other than as may be permitted under the Standard Traffic Ordinance as adopted by the city. Sirens of any type shall not be used or permitted to be used on the licensee's vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 14, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-20. - Use of words "police officer", prohibited. 
    The words "police officer" shall not be used in any advertising or upon the premises within the limits of the city occupied by the merchant guard or merchant patrol, nor on any of its vehicles or equipment. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 15, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-21. - Firearms. 
    Agent or employee licensees may have the right to carry firearms only after completion of a firearm proficiency program under the direction and control of the Riley County police department and the certification by the director or his designee that the licensee has completed the program and has demonstrated his proficiency in the use and safety of a firearm. The authority to carry a firearm will be extended only while the licensee is performing the required duties of his employment and while in route to or from his place of business. The right to carry a firearm may be suspended or revoked by the director if the right has been abused. Such decision by the director shall be effective immediately, provided however that appeal from the decision may be made to the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 16, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-22. - Change in personnel. 
(a)  Whenever an agent or employee of a merchant guard or merchant patrol is discharged for any reason, his employer shall immediately notify the city clerk of such fact. The city clerk shall forward a copy of the notification to the director of the Riley County police department. The employer shall notify the police department of the reasons for dismissal; such information shall be confidential. 
(b)  When an agent or employee of a merchant guard or merchant patrol is dismissed, he shall forthwith surrender the identification card to the director of the Riley County police department. If the person surrendering the identification card is reemployed during the remainder of the year, the identification card may be reissued to him without change. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 17, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-23. - Changing place of business or vehicle. 
(a)  Any licensee changing place of business or abode shall immediately notify the city clerk of such fact, together with the address of the new place of business or abode; provided, however, that if a licensee changes his place of abode, this shall not be deemed to be a transfer of license, or require the payment of any additional fees. The city clerk shall forward a copy of the notification to the director of the Riley County police department. 
(b)  Whenever a new vehicle is acquired by a licensee for use in the conduct of his business, the type and description of the vehicle shall be immediately reported to the city clerk who shall forward a copy to the director of the Riley County police department. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 18, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-24. - Unlawful acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this article to: 
(1)  Hinder or interfere with any investigation under the jurisdiction of the Riley County police department; 
(2)  Fail to report immediately to the Riley County police department violations of city, state or federal laws which constitute felonies or breach of the peace coming to his attention; 
(3)  Draw or fire a firearm in the performance of his duties except when necessary to protect himself from great bodily harm or to prevent the commission of a felony involving force or violence; 
(4)  Fail to notify the Riley County police department of any arrests and to fail to turn such person over to the Riley County police department; provided the licensee, upon refusal of the Riley County police department to take custody of the subject, may turn the individual over to any competent law enforcement agency; 
(5)  Represent himself to be an officer of the Riley County police department; 
(6)  Willfully suppress facts that pertain to any violation of city, state or federal laws under investigation by the Riley County police department. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 19, 7-5-77) 
Secs. 27-25-27-30. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 19. 

Sec. 27-31. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or conduct a merchant guard or merchant patrol business without obtaining a license as provided in this division. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any merchant guard or merchant patrol to employ any agent or employee unless the person to be employed has obtained a license as provided in this division. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to accept employment as an agent or employee of a merchant guard or merchant patrol without obtaining a license as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 2, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-32. - Application. 
(a)  Applicants for a license as a merchant guard or merchant patrol, or agent or employee of a merchant guard or merchant patrol, shall file an application with the city clerk on forms to be provided by him for that purpose and shall contain the following: 
(1)  If an applicant for a license as a merchant guard or merchant patrol: The applicant's name, address and social security number; a description of the nature and type of business to be conducted; the services to be offered, and the area expected to be covered in the conduct of the business; a statement as to the number of persons to be employed as agents or employees; a statement as to the number and type of vehicles to be used in conduct of the business and a description thereof; a description of all weapons registered to that applicant. 
(2)  If an applicant for a permanent license as an agent or an employee of a merchant guard or merchant patrol: The applicant's name, address and social security number; the name of the person by whom the applicant is employed. 
(b)  Each applicant as designated in subsection (a) also shall file with his application: 
(1)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any felony, misdemeanor or ordinance violation, the nature of the offense, the penalty or punishment imposed, and the date and place where such offense occurred; 
(2)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever had a judgement or conviction for fraud, deceit or misrepresentation entered against him, and if so, the details thereof; 
(3)  A statement as to the business or employment record of the applicant for the five years immediately preceding the date of application; 
(4)  Three letters certifying to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant. 
(c)  The director is hereby instructed to prepare appropriate application forms to be supplied to the city clerk, at the city's expense. 
(Ord. No. 3501, §§ 3, 4, 7, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-33. - Fee. 
    The fee for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 19-37. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 5, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-34. - Investigation. 
    Upon receipt of the application fee under this division, the city clerk shall direct the applicant to complete the forms given to him. The applicant shall return the completed original forms to the city clerk who shall forward the original and a copy of the completed documents to the office of the director of the Riley County police department who shall within 21 days investigate the applicant's qualifications and forward to the city clerk the original documents and a statement of his recommendation of approval or disapproval of the application. The director shall accompany any application which he disapproves with a summary of all reasons why the application should be disapproved. The original statements of approval or disapproval of the director as well as any summaries of reasons for disapproval shall be maintained in the original by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3501, §§ 6, 7, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-35. - Mandatory causes for denial. 
    No license shall be issued under this division to any of the following persons: 
(1)  Any person under 18 years of age; 
(2)  Any person whose character and reputation and record of sobriety is not satisfactory to the governing body; 
(3)  Any person convicted of a felony, misdemeanor or violation of a municipal ordinance pertaining to moral turpitude within ten years immediately preceding the date of application; or, in the case of a corporation, if any officer, director, or principal stockholder has been convicted as above; 
(4)  Any person against whom a judgment or conviction for fraud, deceit or misrepresentation has been entered within ten years immediately preceding the date of application; 
(5)  Any person who has a record of drug addiction, or a record of violent acts against persons or property, within ten years immediately preceding the date of application; provided, this section shall not apply to violent acts against persons or property while the applicant was under the age of 18. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 20, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-36. - Insurance prerequisite to issuance. 
    All merchant guard or merchant patrol business licensees shall carry insurance for the purpose of indemnifying third persons for bodily injury, in amounts not less than $100,000.00 for each bodily injury and $300,000.00 aggregate limit; and further, to indemnify third persons for any damage to property as the result of the action of the merchant guard or merchant patrol agent or employee, in an amount of not less than $100,000.00 per claimant and $300,000.00 aggregate limit. The insurance shall be with companies licensed to do business in the state. It shall be the business licensee's responsibility to determine that its insurance carrier has notified the city clerk of any lapse or cancellation in coverage within ten days of notification to the insured. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 8, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-37. - Bond prerequisite to issuance. 
    All merchant guard or merchant patrol business licensees shall file with the city clerk a surety bond issued by a corporation authorized to do business in the state in the sum of $10,000.00 running to any and all employers of the principal of the bond, conditioned that the principal of the bond shall well and faithfully perform the services he engaged to perform. Action on the bond may be brought by any employer of the principal in the bond. Such bond shall be approved as to form and surety by the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 9, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-38. - Issuance. 
    The city clerk shall issue a license under this division for persons employed by a merchant guard or merchant patrol upon approval of the application by the director. The city clerk shall issue a license under this division for any persons engaged in the business of providing merchant guards or merchant patrols upon approval of the application by the governing body and the filing of insurance as provided in this division. The director, upon display of a license duly executed by the city clerk, shall issue the identification card as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 7, 7-5-77; Ord. No. 4038, § 1, 2-2-83) 
Sec. 27-39. - In addition to other permits. 
    This article is intended to be in addition to all other permits, licenses, or other law enforcement authority vested in persons by the state, county or city, and it shall not be a defense to the failure to secure a license to protect or preserve the peace of one or more establishments that the person had such authority. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 21, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-40. - Identification cards. 
(a)  In addition to the license issued under this division, the director of the Riley County police department shall issue an identification card to each licensee which shall be carried by the licensee at all times while on duty as a merchant guard. The identification card shall be approximately two and one-half inches by four inches and shall include the following information: 
(1)  The type of license and expiration date thereof; 
(2)  Name, address, physical description and picture of the licensee; 
(3)  The name of the employer if the licensee is an agent or employee of a merchant guard or merchant patrol; 
(4)  The signature of the licensee and that of the director; 
(5)  A statement as to whether or not the licensee is authorized to carry a firearm; 
(6)  Such other information as the director may deem advisable. 
(b)  The director of the Riley County police department is hereby authorized to charge the sum of $3.00 per identification card to cover expenses of printing etc. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 10, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-41. - Renewal. 
    The director of the Riley County police department is authorized to prepare rules and regulations if necessary concerning the renewal of licenses under this division; the rules and regulations so prepared shall then be examined and adopted, or adopted as amended by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 11, 7-5-77) 
Sec. 27-42. - Revocation or suspension. 
    The governing body shall have the authority to revoke or suspend any license granted pursuant to this division for violation of any federal or state statute, city ordinances, for falsification of application documents, for violation of any of the provisions of this division, or for any act committed by a licensee which is deemed by the governing body to make the licensee unfit to handle the responsibilities of such a license upon request. Suspension periods shall be for the maximum of 60 days. In cases of revocation or suspension of the license of a merchant guard or merchant patrol business, a hearing shall be held by the governing body, and the licensee may present any evidence or be heard with respect to the allegations contained in the request for revocation. 
(Ord. No. 3501, § 22, 7-5-77) 
Chapter 29 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 24; sales, Ch. 28. 

Articles I, II - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4119, § 1, adopted Feb. 21, 1984, repealed the substantive sections of Ch. 29, being §§ 29-16, 29-17, 29-26-29-29, which pertained to junkyards and wrecking yards and the licensing thereof. Prior to repeal, such sections had been derived from the 1973 Code, §§ 10-801 and 10-802. 

Secs. 29-1-29-40. - Reserved. 
Article III - PAWNBROKERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of pawnbrokers, K.S.A. 16-706 et seq. 

Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 29-41. - Defined. 
    As used in this article, the word "pawnbroker" shall mean any person who loans money on deposit or pledge of personal property or valuable thing, other than intangible personal property, or a person that deals in the purchase of personal property on condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated price, but such term shall not include any person operating under the supervision of the state banking commissioner, credit union commissioner or the consumer credit commissioner of this state. 
(Code 1973, § 10-901) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-21 et seq. 
State Law reference- Similar definition, K.S.A. 16-706. 
Sec. 29-42. - Loans secured by pledged goods. 
(a)  Every loan made by a pawnbroker for which goods are received in pledge as security shall be evidenced by a written contract, in ink, a copy of which shall be furnished to the borrower. The loan contract shall set forth the loan period, which shall be one month, the date on which the loan is due and payable and the charges, and it shall clearly inform the borrower of his right to redeem the pledge during the redemption period of two months after due date. Except as otherwise provided herein, the holder of any such contract shall be presumed to be the person entitled to redeem the pledge, and the pawnbroker shall deliver the pledge to the person presenting the contract, upon payment of the principal and charges. 
(b)  Every pawnbroker shall retain in his possession, after the date on which the loan became due and payable, every article pledged to him for a redemption period of two months. During such period, the borrower may redeem the pledged articles, upon payment of the principal and charges. It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to sell or transfer title or possession of any pledged property until the expiration of such period of redemption. 
(c)  If any pledged article is not redeemed within such redemption period, the pawnbroker shall become vested with all right, title and interest of the pledgor, or his assigns, to such pledged article, to hold and dispose of as his own property. Any other provision of law relating to the foreclosure and sale of pledges shall not be applicable to any pledge, the title to which is transferred in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1973, § 10-905) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-714. 
Sec. 29-43. - Report of description of property received in pawn or purchased as secondhand merchandise. 
    Every pawnbroker shall report to the director of the Riley County police department the description of all property received in pawn or purchased as secondhand merchandise, in whatever quantity received, including property purchased as secondhand merchandise at wholesale, secondhand merchandise taken in for sale or possessed on consignment for sale and secondhand merchandise taken in trade; provided, that no such report need be made concerning property or merchandise acquired from another pawnbroker licensed in the state in a transaction involving the purchase or other acquisition from the other pawnbroker of his stock in trade, or a substantial part thereof in bulk, where the other pawnbroker has made the reports required by this section with respect to such property or merchandise. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-715. 
Sec. 29-44. - Record of transactions. 
    At the time of any transaction, a pawnbroker shall enter in a pawnbroker kept by him for that purpose, the date, duration, amount and charges of every loan made by him an accurate description of the property pledged and the name and residence address of the pledgor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-716. 
Sec. 29-45. - Secured loans to minors prohibited. 
    No person shall receive in pawn, or as security for any loan, transfer, service, undertaking or advantage, anything of value from any person under the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1973, § 10-906) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-717. 
Sec. 29-46. - Inspection and examination of premises and contents by law enforcement officers; search and seizure. 
    Every pawnbroker, and every person employed by a pawnbroker in the conduct of his business, shall admit to any and every part of the premises designated in the license, at any time, any law enforcement officer of the city or county to examine any goods, articles, things, pledges, pawns, books or other records on the premises, and to search for and to take into possession any article known or believed by such officer to have been stolen. Such law enforcement officer may make any such search or seizure as is provided for in this section, and property so seized shall be receipted for by such officer who shall adequately describe the seized property and sign the receipt. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-718. 
Sec. 29-47. - Interest and charges on pawnbroker transactions; applicability of other laws; maximum charges; terms of loans. 
(a)  No pawnbroker shall contract for, charge, or receive directly or indirectly on or in connection with any pawnbroker transaction any charges, whether for interest, storage, insurance, service fee, handling, compensation, consideration or expense which in the aggregate are greater than the charges provided and authorized by this article. Any other provisions of law relating to interest, storage and such charges shall not be applicable to any pawnbroker transaction made in accordance with this article. 
(b)  Whenever any loan is made by a pawnbroker for which goods are received in pledge, the following maximum amounts may be charged: 
(1)  On any amount a charge may be added in an amount not to exceed ten percent per month or 120 percent per annum of the amount advanced to the borrower; and 
(2)  The maximum amount of a loan authorized by this article shall not exceed $300.00 per transaction. 
(c)  The term of any loan made under the provisions of this article shall be one month. Loans may be extended or renewed by the payment of the charges herein provided monthly. The charges authorized herein shall be deemed to be earned at the time the loan is made and shall not be subject to refund. On loans under this article, no insurance charges or any other charges of any nature whatsoever shall be permitted. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-719. 
Sec. 29-48. - Person selling personal property to give identification. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person selling or pledging personal property to a pawnshop hereunder to knowingly give a false or incorrect name or address. Further, any person selling or pledging personal property to a pawnshop shall produce documentary evidence sufficient to identify such person before any owner or employee of such pawnshop may undertake to transact any business with such person. Sufficient documentary evidence for the purpose of this provision shall mean: Driver's license, military identification card, social security number, or other documentary evidence of a comparable nature. An owner or employee of a pawnshop may transact business with any person with whom they are personally acquainted without requiring the production of such documentary evidence. 
(Code 1973, § 10-907) 
Sec. 29-49. - Receipt of stolen property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, owner or employee of a pawnshop to purchase, take or receive any item of personal property from any person while knowing the same to have been stolen or having reason to believe that the item of personal property has been stolen. It shall be the duty of such person to whom such personal property is offered, to immediately advise the Riley County police department of the city in order to facilitate a prompt investigation into the circumstances thereof. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or pledge any item of personal property to any pawnshop licensed hereunder if the personal property is subject to a financing statement which has been previously recorded with the register of deeds in any county of the state. Any sale or pledge of personal property subject to such mortgage indebtedness shall be null and void and the secured party named in said financing statement shall be entitled to immediate possession of the personal property involved. The owner or employee of any pawnshop which has received personal property subject to such a valid financing statement shall forthwith return said personal property to the secured party named in the financing statement, its successors or assigns. 
(Code 1973, § 10-908) 
Sec. 29-50. - Refusal to redeliver converted or stolen property received in pawn to rightful owner. 
    When converted or stolen property has been pawned and the pawnbroker refuses to redeliver such property to the rightful owner upon demand and presentation of a bill of sale or other proper indicia of ownership by the owner, and legal action by the rightful owner to recover the property becomes necessary, the court may assess the pawnbroker for reasonable attorney's fees incurred by the rightful owner, if the court finds that the pawnbroker wrongfully withheld the converted or stolen property. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-720. 
Sec. 29-51. - Examination of books, accounts and records. 
    Each licensee shall keep and use in his business such books, accounts and records as will enable the city to determine whether such licensee is complying with the provisions of this article, and any such city or county may examine or cause to be examined the books, accounts, records and files used by any such licensee or by any other person engaged in the pawnbroking business, irrespective of whether such person, partnership or corporation shall act or claim to act as principal, agent or broker, or under or without authority of this article. The duly designated representatives of the city shall have and be given free access to all such books, accounts, papers, records, files, safes and vaults. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-712. 
Secs. 29-52-29-60. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - LICENSE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 19. 

Sec. 29-61. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish or conduct the business of a pawnbroker unless the owner shall have first procured a license to conduct such business in the city in accord with this division. 
(Code 1973, § 10-902) 
Sec. 29-62. - Application.
