(a)  Application for a license under this division shall be in writing and shall state the full name and place of residence of the applicant or if the applicant be a partnership, of each member thereof, or, if a corporation or association, of each officer, shareholder or member thereof, together with the address of the place or places where the business is to be conducted and the hours of the day and days of the week during which the applicant proposes to engage in the business of pawnbroking at each such place, and such other information as may be necessary to determine the applicant's qualifications for a license in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Each applicant also shall submit with his application: 
(1)  A statement that he is the holder of a valid registration certificate issued by the director of revenue pursuant to K.S.A. 79-3608 for each place of business for which application for a license is made; and 
(2)  A detailed inventory and description of all goods, wares, merchandise or other property held in pawn or for sale at the time of the application at each place of business stated therein, indicating whether the same was received in pawn or purchased as secondhand merchandise. 
The application shall be in a form approved by the attorney general. 
(Code 1973, § 10-904) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-707 
Sec. 29-63. - Qualifications. 
    No license or any renewal thereof under this division shall be granted to: 
(1)  Any person who is not a citizen of the United States; 
(2)  Any person who has not been an actual resident of the state for at least two years immediately preceding the date of his application; 
(3)  Any person who has been convicted of or has pleaded guilty to a felony under the laws of this state, or any other state, or of the United States, or shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such offense within the ten years immediately prior to such person's application for a license; 
(4)  Any person who has had his license revoked for cause under the provisions of this division; 
(5)  Any person who is not at least 21 years of age; 
(6)  Any person who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first application; 
(7)  Any person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought, unless he has a written lease therefor for at least three-fourths of the period for which the license is to be issued; 
(8)  Any person whose spouse would be ineligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than the age, citizenship and residence requirements; 
(9)  Any partnership, unless all of the partners shall be eligible to receive a license as an individual; and 
(10)  A corporation, if any officer, manager, director or stockholder would be ineligible to receive a license as an individual. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-708. 
Sec. 29-64. - Fee. 
    The fee for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 19-39. 
(Code 1973, § 10-903) 
Sec. 29-65. - Transfer of stock by stockholder of corporate licensee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any shareholder of a corporate licensee to transfer any stock in the corporation to any person who would be ineligible to receive a license as an individual, and any such transfer shall be null and void; provided, that if any such stockholder of a corporate licensee shall become deceased and his heirs or devisees to whom the stock descends by descent and distribution or by will shall be ineligible to receive a license hereunder, then the legal representatives of the deceased stockholder's estate, his heirs and devisees shall have 14 months from the date of the death of the stockholder within which to sell the stock to a person eligible to receive a license hereunder, with such sale to be made in accordance with the provisions of the state probate code and any amendments thereto. If the legal representatives, heirs and devisees shall fail, refuse or neglect to so convey the stock within the time hereinbefore prescribed, then the stock shall revert to and become the property of the corporation, for which the corporation shall pay to the legal representatives, heirs or devisees the book value of such stock. If the stock in any corporation shall be the subject of any trust heretofore or hereafter created, the trustee or trustees and the beneficiaries of each trustee and beneficiary of the trust who is 21 years of age or older must be a person who would be eligible to receive a license or the trustee shall be and he is hereby authorized and required, within 14 months after the effective date of the trust to sell the stock to a person eligible to receive a license under this act, and he shall hold and disburse the proceeds thereof in accordance with the terms of the trust, or the license of the corporation shall be forfeited. 
(b)  During the 14-month periods hereinbefore mentioned a corporation shall not be denied a license or have its license revoked if it meets all of the other requirements necessary to have a license as provided in this division. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-709. 
Sec. 29-66. - Contents; display; restrictions on issuance. 
    The document or other instrument evidencing the license of a pawnbroker shall state the address at which the business is to be conducted and shall state fully the name of the licensee, and if the licensee is a partnership, the names of the members thereof, and if a corporation, the date and place of its incorporation, and the names of all shareholders thereof. Such license shall be kept conspicuously posted in the place of business of the licensee and shall not be transferable or assignable. Not more than one place of business shall be maintained under the same license, but more than one license may be issued to the same licensee upon compliance with all the provisions of this division governing the issuance of an initial license. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-710. 
Sec. 29-67. - Change in location of place of business; notice; duplicate license; restrictions. 
    Whenever a licensee shall change his place of business to another location within the same political subdivision by which he is licensed, he immediately shall give written notice thereof to the clerk of such subdivision who then shall issue a duplicate license which shall show in addition to all of the information appearing on the old license, a record of the change of location and the date thereof, which new license shall be authority for the operation of such business under such license at such location. The licensee shall return the old license to the appropriate clerk as soon as the new license has been received and the change in location has taken place. No change in the place of business of a licensee to a location outside of the licensing subdivision shall be permitted under the same license. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-711. 
Sec. 29-68. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Any license issued under this division may be suspended or revoked, after due notice and public hearing, if the licensee: 
(1)  Has failed to pay the annual license fee; 
(2)  Has violated any provision of this article; or 
(3)  Has been convicted of or has pleaded guilty to a felony under the laws of this state, or any other state, or of the United States, or shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such offense, if such conviction or plea occurred subsequent to or within the ten years immediately prior to the date of the licensee's application for the license. 
(b)  Any license issued under this division shall be revoked, after due notice and hearing thereon if it shall be proved at the hearing that the licensee sold any handgun to a minor. 
(c)  The hearing herein provided shall be held within 30 days after notice thereof, and the alleged violation determined by written order of the city within 60 days after such hearing is concluded; but no revocation or suspension or surrender of any license shall impair or affect the obligation of any preexisting lawful contract between the licensee and any borrower. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 16-713. 
Chapter 30 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances opening, dedicating, widening, vacating or narrowing streets, avenues, alleys and boulevards saved from repeal, § 1-2(3); ordinances establishing and changing grades of streets, avenues, alleys and boulevards saved from repeal, § 1-2(4); ordinances naming or changing the names of streets, avenues and boulevards saved from repeal, § 1-2(5); distribution of handbills restricted in public places, § 3-22; livestock running at large prohibited, § 6-1; fowl running at large prohibited, § 6-2; dogs and cats running at large prohibited, § 6-22; aviation, Ch. 7; use of roads or walks at airports, § 7-53; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; cemeteries, Ch. 9; franchises, Ch. 15; street excavations by Kansas Power and Light Company for natural gas, § 15-54; library, Ch. 18; use of streets by businesses, § 19-7; mobile homes and trailers, Ch. 20; curfew for minors, § 22-81 et seq., parks and recreation, Ch. 23; planning and zoning, Ch. 26; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 31; utilities, Ch. 32; vegetation, Ch. 33; permit required for planting, trimming, removal of vegetation on public grounds, § 33-1; protection of public trees, § 33-2; vehicles for hire, Ch. 34; public improvements, App. A, Nos. 12 and 13. 

Article I - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Obstructing. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic on any street, alley, sidewalk, public place, public plaza or right-of-way. For the purposes of this section, "to obstruct" includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  To walk, stand, sit, or lie in a manner that blocks the lawful passage by another person or vehicle or that requires another person or driver in the normal course of travel to take action to avoid physical contact; 
(2)  To place any object in a manner that blocks the lawful passage by another person or vehicle or that requires another person or driver in the normal course of travel to take action to avoid physical contact; 
(3)  To block, in any way, the entrance of any public or private structure from the street, alley, sidewalk, public place, public plaza, or right-of-way; 
(4)  To conduct any activity on a street, alley, sidewalk, public place, public plaza, or right-of-way without a city permit, if such activity requires a city permit. 
(b)  It shall not be a violation of subsection (a) to do the following: 
(1)  To conduct, engage in, or attend any activity on the street, alley, sidewalk, or public plaza allowed by a city permit issued for such activity. 
(2)  To place newsstands, news racks, and other devices for the distribution or sale of newspapers, pamphlets and handbills. 
(3)  To exercise a person's constitutional right to picket, or to legally protest, provided that, if required, such person has obtained a city permit for such activity. 
(Code 1973, § 17-401; Ord. No. 6435 § 1, 11-2-04; Ord. No. 6692, § 2, 4-15-08) 
Sec. 30-2. - Barbed wire and electric fences prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain a wire fence with barbs or a wire fence that is mounted on insulators that is capable of being electrically charged when either are less than 30 feet from a public right-of-way within the city limits. This section shall not apply to the city zoo grounds, Riley County Police Department jail grounds, or to fences where the only barbs or only electrical charge would be more than seven feet above the ground. 
(Code 1973, § 17-403; Ord. No. 4055, § 1, 5-3-83) 
Sec. 30-3. - Petroleum products in street unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or throw any waste oil, fuel oil, kerosene, gasoline or other products of petroleum or any acids into or upon any street or public grounds of the city, or willfully to permit the same to be spilled, dripped or otherwise to come into contact with the surface of any street, alley or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 17-405) 
Sec. 30-4. - Junk deposit unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to store or deposit, or to accumulate or abandon any old iron, machinery, vehicles of any kind, vehicle bodies or parts thereof or any junk of any kind in or upon any sidewalk, street, parking, alley or public grounds within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 17-406) 
Sec. 30-5. - Requirements for paving projects to be turned over to city. 
    Concerning all street paving projects that are built by persons that intend to turn the improvement over to the city for ownership and maintenance, the following requirements must be satisfied: 
(1)  The improvement must be designed by a professional engineer registered by the state and according to established city specifications and practices. 
(2)  Plans and specifications must be approved by the city engineer prior to initiating any construction and must be submitted along with a construction cost estimate. 
(3)  Inspection will be performed by the city engineer or his authorized representative to assure compliance with the plans and specifications. The inspector shall have full authority to make appropriate engineering judgements and construction changes in the field to insure such compliance. He shall have the right to enter upon the construction scene at any time. 
(4)  As-built plans on mylar paper must be submitted at the end of the project and will be made a permanent record in the city engineer's office. 
(5)  The "as-builts" shall be accompanied by a maintenance bond, good for one year from the date of completion, in the amount of the total construction cost. The bond shall be issued by a corporate surety and payable to the city and shall state the amount for which it has been written. 
(6)  A fee of three percent of actual construction cost will be charged, payable by the owner of the property being served upon final approval of the project by the city engineer, to the city, for inspection and administrative costs associated with the project. The fee shall be deposited in the engineering projects fund. 
(7)  All construction will be done within public easements or rights-of-way. The obtaining of all such rights, if they do not exist prior to planning the improvement, will be the sole responsibility of the person having the project done. 
Secs. 30-6-30-20. - Reserved. 
Article II - CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR OF SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 30-21. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, reconstruct or repair any sidewalk without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city engineer. Such work shall be done in accord with the plans and specifications set forth in this article. Such sidewalk shall be built under the inspection and direction of the city engineer. 
(Code 1973, § 17-101) 
Sec. 30-22. - Plans and specifications. 
    All sidewalks constructed, reconstructed or repaired in the city shall be constructed, reconstructed or repaired in accord with the plans and specifications for the construction, repair and reconstruction of sidewalks, including width and location, a copy or copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk and in the office of city engineer, which plans and specifications are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference. 
(Code 1973, § 17-102) 
State Law reference- Authority for this section, K.S.A. 12-1802. 
Sec. 30-23. - Sidewalk construction required. 
(a)  Whenever sidewalks are required to be constructed within the city as a part of a street improvement project, such sidewalks may either be constructed at the same time the street is constructed, or on a schedule as set forth in the remainder of this section. 
(b)  If sidewalks required as a part of a street project are not constructed at the same time as the street, the city engineer, at the time of the street project shall designate the location of the sidewalks required as a part of such project and the description of property which abuts said location. Notice of such designation shall be filed with the appropriate register of deeds in substantially the following form: 
NOTICE 
    You are hereby notified that owners of the following described property are hereby required to construct sidewalks on the public right-of-way adjacent to such property pursuant to Section 30-23 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, to wit: 
(here describe the property). 
_____
City Engineer 
STATE OF KANSAS       )       ) SS: COUNTY OF RILEY       )  
    BE IT REMEMBERED that on this _______ day of _______, 19_______, before me the undersigned, a notary public in and for the state and county aforesaid, came _______, City Engineer, for the City of Manhattan, Kansas, and duly acknowledged his execution of the above Notice. 
    IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed my notarial seal on the day and year last above written. 
_____
Notary Public 
    My commission expires:_______ 
(c)  The failure of the city engineer to file the notice required by subsection (b), or the erroneous, filing of such notice, shall not affect the property owners responsibilities as set forth hereinafter. 
(d)  The owner of property, which abuts the location of sidewalks designated by the city engineer, shall construct such sidewalk at the time any improvement requiring a building permit is placed upon such property. No building permit shall be issued for any improvement upon such property without requiring the construction of such sidewalk as a part thereof. In the event no building permit has been applied for within two years of the date of the city accepted the street improvement project, as complete, such owner shall construct such sidewalk no later than 30 days after the expiration of such two years. Such time may be extended by the city engineer for just cause. 
(e)  In the event any owner or property fails to comply with subsection (d), the city may send such owner written notice of such failure. Such notice may be sent to the address of the owner, as reflected in the tax records concerning the subject property. If no address for such owner is known, the notice may be posted on the property itself. If said owner continues to fail to comply with subsection (d) for 30 days after the mailing of said notice, or the posting of such notice, the city may proceed to construct the sidewalk and assess all costs therefore against the subject property pursuant to K.S.A. 12-6a17. 
(Ord. No. 4792, § 1, 2-2-93) 
Secs. 30-24-30-35. - Reserved. 
Article III - CURB CUTS AND DRIVEWAY ENTRANCES 

Sec. 30-36. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Corner shall mean a point of intersection of the lines of two street curb faces extended into the street intersection. 
    Curb parking space shall mean the length of the curb equal to 20 feet where an automobile or other vehicle can park parallel thereto. 
    Curb return shall mean the portion of a curb nearest to a driveway entrance which includes the radius of curvature, or the ramp-type lug or commercial or industrial type pavements and which connects the driveway entrance to the street curb. 
    Driveway shall mean a place on private property for the operation of automobiles and other vehicles. 
    Driveway entrance shall mean an area, construction or facility between the roadway of the public street and private property intended to provide access for vehicles from the roadway of a public street to private property and the entrance must provide access to something definite on private property such as a parking area, a driveway or a door at least seven feet wide, intended and used for the entrance of vehicles. 
    Outside sidewalk line shall mean a line parallel to the property line along the edge of the sidewalk nearest the street, roadway or curb; or where no sidewalk exists, a line in the street parking parallel to and not less than five feet from the property line of adjacent lots. 
    Parcel of land shall mean a lot or tract of land officially recorded under one ownership. 
(Code 1973, § 17-201) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-21 et seq. 
Sec. 30-37. - Crossing, cutting or breaking curbs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to drive or cause or permit to be driven, any vehicle or machinery over or across any curb or sidewalk in any street or avenue of the city, or to damage, break or cut any curb, gutter or sidewalk, except as may be authorized under a permit from the city engineer issued in accordance with ordinances of the city relating to street parking, curbs and gutters, and as provided in this article for the construction of driveway entrances. 
(Code 1973, § 17-202) 
Sec. 30-38. - Bridging curbs; interference with gutters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bridge across any curb and gutter or fill any gutter with concrete, asphalt or other material for purpose of gaining access to or egress from any driveway or private property, or to obstruct or interfere with the drainage of any gutter or drain at the edge of a roadway by placing therein any concrete, asphalt, planks, stones, earth or other material or substance for such purpose except by written permit of the city engineer; provided, that building material may be stored in or along side of any curb and gutter or any street parking in accordance with a permit issued by the city engineer as provided by ordinance relating to the encumbering of streets for certain purposes; provided further, that the street department may remove any existing material or any material hereafter placed across any curb or in any gutter or drain in violation of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 17-203) 
Sec. 30-39. - Extension of driveway entrances unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, alter or extend, or permit or cause to be constructed, altered or extended any driveway entrance which can be used only as a parking space or area between the curb and adjacent property line, except in connection with a permit authorized by ordinance for the location and construction of parking areas by cutting and removal of curbs and widening the street upon the issuance of a permit therefor by the governing board. 
(Code 1973, § 17-204) 
Sec. 30-40. - Construction of driveway entrances. 
(a)  The construction of driveway entrances by the cutting and removal of curbs or gutters shall be authorized upon the issuance of a permit by the city engineer upon application in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  No driveway entrance shall be constructed which will interfere with public facilities including street lighting poles, traffic signal standards, signs, catchbasins, hydrants, crosswalks, loading zones, utility poles, fire alarm supports, underground pipes or ducts or other necessary street structures. 
(2)  Not more than one driveway entrance may be constructed for access to one parcel of ground less than 50 feet in width, except that one entrance shall be permitted to any lot of lesser width under separate ownership; provided, that there may be one entrance from each street of a corner lot, and more than one entrance may be constructed to gain access to commercial and industrial occupancies from a single street front. 
(3)  No driveway entrance in a residential district of the city shall exceed 24 feet in width; and in a commercial district of the city, more than 40 feet in width. 
(4)  No curb cutting width shall exceed the driveway entrance at the sidewalk line by more than ten feet for an entrance of 30 feet or less in width, or 12 feet for an entrance of more than 30 feet in width. 
(5)  The sides, edges or curbs of driveway entrances shall be at right angles to the street curb except for the curb return. 
(6)  No driveway entrance shall be constructed across any sidewalk unless such sidewalk be constructed or reconstructed in accordance with specifications pertaining to the construction of sidewalks to be used as driveway entrances. 
(7)  No driveway entrance shall be constructed in a manner to change or interfere with the gutter flow line or sidewalk grade where such driveway entrance crosses any such gutter or sidewalk. 
(8)  The sidewalk and curb shall, insofar as possible, be cut and removed at the nearest joint and upon replacement and reconstruction of a sidewalk as an entrance, the construction of the curb return and any pavement in connection with an entrance or driveway, suitable joints shall be provided in all such work where the same come into contact, all such spaces shall be filled by a bituminous fiber or compound in accordance with the specifications of the city engineer. 
(9)  The cost of construction of all driveway entrances and necessary appurtenances thereto shall be borne by the permittee. 
(b)  In those cases where it is proposed to construct a driveway entrance to parking lots and similar facilities for the storage of vehicles and machinery, the regulations of subsection (a), insofar as practicable, shall apply to such construction, except that the permittee shall be required to construct and maintain, adjacent to and within the interior lot lines of his premises, a suitable curb or fencing so designed and constructed as to prevent vehicles, machinery or other equipment stored thereon to encroach upon or obstruct the sidewalk, street parking or adjacent parcels of land. 
(Code 1973, §§ 17-205, 17-206) 
Sec. 30-41. - Conditions of article permits. 
    All permits granted for the use of public property under the provisions of this article shall be granted on condition that the same are revocable at the discretion of the governing body and no such permit shall be deemed to permit or authorize any violation of other provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city. Any permit issued hereunder shall be granted on the further condition that the permittee or his successors in title will, upon the abandonment of any driveway entrance, restore and reconstruct the curb and gutter to its original condition upon notice from the city manager, and the city reserves the right to close any abandoned driveway entrance, reconstruct the curb and charge the cost thereof against the owner; provided, that this article shall not be construed to deny or abridge the right of egress and ingress of property owners. 
(Code 1973, § 17-207) 
Sec. 30-42. - Variance from strict application of this article. 
    The city engineer is hereby authorized, subject to the approval of the governing body, to grant, in writing, as a part of any permit issued by him, variances from the strict application of the provisions of this article, upon determining that the following conditions are present: 
(1)  Exception or variance desired arises from peculiar physical conditions not ordinarily existing in similar districts in the city or is due to the nature of business and operations on the abutting property. 
(2)  Exception or variance desired is not against the public interest, safety, convenience and general welfare. 
(3)  The granting of the permit for the exception or variance will not adversely affect the right of adjacent property owners or tenants. 
(4)  The strict application of the provisions of this article will work unnecessary hardship on the property owner or tenant. 
(Code 1973, § 17-208) 
Sec. 30-43. - Standard plans and specifications. 
    The city engineer is authorized to prepare standard plans and specifications for the construction of driveway entrances, sidewalk crossings and interior curbs which shall be furnished to any permittee upon application. 
(Code 1973, § 17-209) 
Sec. 30-44. - Enforcement by city engineer. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer to enforce the provisions of this article and to supervise all work authorized by a permit. Upon completion of any such work, his approval shall be entered on the permit and he shall preserve a permanent file of all permits issued and agreements entered into under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 17-209) 
Sec. 30-45. - Fees. 
    Any person, firm or corporation desiring a permit which is required under the provisions of this article shall pay a fee of $15.00 per permit. 
(Ord. No. 4465, § 1, 11-3-87) 
Secs. 30-46-30-55. - Reserved. 
Article IV - PAVEMENT CUTS AND EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 30-56. - Permit required. 
    No person shall make or cause to be made any cuts or excavations in, through or under any street, alley, curbing, gutter, parking or public place without a permit therefor from the city engineer. 
(Code 1973, § 17-301) 
Sec. 30-57. - Replacement of pavement; costs. 
    The work of replacing and restoring all pavement cut or damaged by persons operating under a permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be done by the city and the holder of such permit shall pay the cost of time and material therefor plus 15 percent administrative costs to the city. 
(Code 1973, § 17-302) 
Sec. 30-58. - Duty to guard excavations. 
    Any person making excavations in any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks or public grounds of the city shall at all times during the work, maintain proper barricades, safety guards and lights for the protection of the traveling public. 
(Code 1973, § 17-303) 
State Law reference- Warning lights required for street improvements, K.S.A. 68-2102. 
Sec. 30-59. - Backfilling; removal of surplus material. 
    All trenches, ditches and excavations shall be backfilled and properly tamped by the person holding a permit issued under this article and such person shall remove all surplus materials from the streets, alleys and public grounds. Such work shall be subject to the supervision, direction and approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1973, § 17-304) 
Secs. 30-60-30-70. - Reserved. 
Article V - SNOW AND ICE ON SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Emergency snow routes, § 31-201 et seq. 

Sec. 30-71. - Snow and ice to be removed from sidewalks by abutting property owner or occupant. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the owner or the occupant of any lot abutting upon any sidewalk used by the general public to keep such sidewalk free from the accumulation of snow and ice. It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of such property to fail to remove all accumulated snow and ice from such sidewalks within 36 hours of the cessation of any measurable precipitation which has so accumulated. 
(Code 1973, § 17-501; Ord. No. 3765, § 1, 12-4-79) 
Sec. 30-72. - Obstructing streets prohibited. 
    No person shall place snow that has been removed from property upon any public street, alley, sidewalk, or parking lot, unless the person has received prior approval of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 17-502; Ord. No. 6934, § 2, 1-24-12) 
Sec. 30-73. - City may clean sidewalks and assess costs. 
    If any owner or occupant of any lot shall refuse or neglect to clean or remove all snow and ice from sidewalks abutting such lot, the city may abate such condition and assess such costs pursuant to section 21-18 of the city code. 
(Code 1973, § 17-503; Ord. No. 6934, § 2, 1-24-12) 
Secs. 30-74-30-85. - Reserved. 
Article VI - RAILROAD CROSSINGS 

Sec. 30-86. - Suitable crossings required. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning or operating any railroad within the city to construct and maintain suitable and safe crossings over the tracks of such railroad at all street or alley crossings to the full width of the street and alley, and to construct and maintain proper culverts and waterways along and across such tracks; and such crossings shall be maintained in a passable condition so that vehicles can cross such railroad tracks with ease and facility. 
(Code 1973, § 17-601) 
Sec. 30-87. - Paving and macadamizing. 
    It shall be the duty of every person constructing, owning, maintaining or operating any railroad within the city to pave between the tracks and between the rails of such railroad and for a distance of three feet outside of such rails, in the street, avenue or alley upon which such tracks are located, with the same kind and quality of material with which such street, avenue or alley is paved or with such other material as may be approved by the city engineer; and on all unpaved streets, avenues or alleys, it shall be the duty of such person to macadamize between the rails of such railroad and for a distance of three feet outside of such rails in the street, avenue or alley upon which such railroad is located, with good, broken stone to the depth of 12 inches. 
(Code 1973, § 17-602) 
Sec. 30-88. - Obstructing crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any engineer or conductor or other person in charge of a railway train to leave any locomotive or car standing upon the railroad track at the crossings at Fourth Street, Fifth Street, Sixth Street, Juliette Avenue, Ninth Street, Tenth Street, Manhattan Avenue, Fifteenth Street, Delaware Avenue, Colorado Street and Poyntz Avenue longer than five minutes at any one time, or at any other crossing in the city longer than 30 minutes at one time. It shall be the duty of any person in charge of the railroad trains while switching, to at no time use such crossing longer than the time aforesaid in such manner as to prevent persons with teams or vehicles of any kind or foot passengers from crossing such tracks in safety. 
(Code 1973, § 17-603) 
Sec. 30-89. - Poyntz Avenue crossing. 
    It shall be the duty of the Union Pacific Railroad Company to provide at the crossing of its tracks over Poyntz Avenue, at all times during the switching of cars back and forth and across the avenue, either some trainman, or other suitable person for the purpose of safeguarding the public against danger of such switching of cars; provided, that all trains while passing over and across the avenue shall reduce their speed to not exceed three miles per hour. 
(Code 1973, § 17-604) 
Sec. 30-90. - Bluemont Avenue crossing. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the Union Pacific Railroad Company to provide at the crossing of its tracks over Bluemont Avenue prior to entering the crossing from either direction, a trainman or other suitable person for the purpose of safeguarding the public against the danger of such activity across the crossing. It is understood that once the unit is on the crossing that the trainman or other person providing the safeguarding may be relieved from that duty to perform other necessary switching functions. It shall also be the duty of the Union Pacific Railroad Company to reduce the speed of all trains passing over and across Bluemont Avenue to ten miles per hour. 
(b)  The crossing of the Union Pacific Railroad tracks in the 200 block of Bluemont Avenue is hereby designated as "exempt," according to section 8B-6 of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(Ord. No. 4201, §§ 1, 2, 5-7-85; Ord. No. 4219, §§ 1, 2, 7-2-85) 
Sec. 30-91. - Leavenworth Street crossing. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the Union Pacific Railroad Company to reduce the speed of all trains passing over and across Leavenworth Street near Tuttle Creek Boulevard to ten miles per hour. 
(b)  The crossing of the Union Pacific Railroad tracks in the 200 block of Leavenworth Street is hereby designated as "exempt," according to Section 8B-6 of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(Ord. No. 4359, §§ 1, 2, 10-7-86) 
Sec. 30-92. - Certain crossings designated as exempt. 
    The crossings of the Union Pacific Railroad tracks in the following locations are hereby designated as "exempt," according to Section 8B-6 of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices: 
(1)  East Poyntz Avenue crossing at the intersection with Tuttle Creek Boulevard (east entrance to Manhattan Town Center Parking Lot); 
(2)  Fort Riley Boulevard crossing, 600 feet south of the intersection with U.S. 24; 
(3)  East Pierre Street crossing (southeast entrance to Manhattan Town Center Parking Lot). 
(Ord. No. 4439, § 1, 9-15-87) 
Secs. 30-93-30-100. - Reserved. 
Article VII - NUMBERING SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6918, adopted Sept. 20, 2011, amended art. VII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. VII consisted of §§ 30-101-30-106, pertained to the same subject matter and derived from the 1973 Code. 

Sec. 30-101. - Address number required. 
(1)  All buildings within the corporate limits of the city shall have a permanent address number, assigned by the city engineer in accordance with The City of Manhattan Address Numbering Standards. 
(2)  The city engineer shall adopt The City of Manhattan Address Numbering Standards that describe how address numbers are assigned to buildings within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 6918, § 1, 9-20-11) 
Secs. 30-102-30-109. - Reserved. 
Article VIII - TEMPORARY USE OF CITY SIDEWALK OR PUBLIC PLAZA[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 3-9 of Ord. No. 6692, adopted Apr. 15, 2008, amended art. VIII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. VIII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 4501, adopted Apr. 19, 1988. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; department of parks and recreation, § 2-181 et seq.; advertising, Ch. 3; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 4; fire prevention, Ch. 13; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 16; nuisances, Ch. 21; parks and recreation, Ch. 23; park regulations, § 23-86 et seq.; peddlers and solicitors, Ch 24; utilities, Ch. 32. 

Sec. 30-110. - Permit for temporary uses required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use a city sidewalk or public plaza as described in this article without the required permit. For the purposes of this article, "public plaza" shall mean the area located directly east of Third Street at the western entrance of Manhattan Town Center in the Poyntz Avenue right-of-way. 
(a)  Display permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain a display on a city sidewalk or public plaza without a valid temporary use permit. "Display" includes, but is not limited to, the placement of any table, rack, machine, or other device or object relating to the storage, advertising, exhibition, or sale of merchandise or services, but does not include freestanding signs. Provided that, no permit shall be required to place newsstands, news racks, and other devices for the distribution or sale of newspapers, pamphlets and handbills. 
(b)  Sidewalk café permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, permit or allow a sidewalk café on a city sidewalk or public plaza without a valid temporary use permit. "Sidewalk café" includes, but is not limited to, the placement of any table, chair, vending station, food stand or other device or object relating to the sale of food or beverages or sidewalk dining, but does not include freestanding signs. 
(c)  Sidewalk sign permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain a sidewalk sign, as defined in the Manhattan Zoning Regulations, on a city sidewalk or public plaza without a valid temporary use permit. 
(Ord. No. 6692, § 4, 4-15-08; Ord. No. 7116, § 1, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 30-111. - Temporary use permit application; fee; term. 
(a)  Permit application. 
(1)  The owner of the establishment in front of which the display, sidewalk café or sidewalk sign will be located shall submit the temporary use permit application to the city clerk on the form provided by the city, along with the appropriate fee. If the applicant does not own the property, the permit application must include written permission from the property owner. The application shall be submitted no later than 14 days prior to the commencement of the temporary use. 
(2)  The applicant shall submit a site plan for the temporary use that shall include elevation drawings. The site plan shall state the square footage of sidewalk or public plaza proposed for such use, and shall detail the dimensions, size, location and type of the temporary use objects relating to the permit request. If, in the city's opinion, the use or location requires railing(s) or barrier(s), whether temporary or permanent, to be placed upon city property, the site plan shall detail the railing or barrier's style, design and color. 
(b)  Permit fee. The temporary use permit fee shall be $100.00, except that the fee for a sidewalk sign shall be $25.00 and the fee for a sidewalk café in which alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages shall be served shall be $250.00. 
(c)  Permit term. Each temporary use permit issued shall terminate December 31 of the year in which it is issued, and a new application and fee shall be submitted at least 14 days prior to the end of the calendar year to continue the use into the following calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 6692, § 5, 4-15-08; Ord. No. 7116, § 2, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 30-112. - Temporary use permit requirements. 
(a)  To obtain and maintain any temporary use permit, the following requirements must be met: 
(1)  The establishment for which the permit is issued must be sited adjacent to a public sidewalk or public plaza located within the C-3, Aggieville business district, C-4, central business district, or within a planned unit development (PUD) that allows or authorizes temporary uses on a city sidewalk or public plaza within or adjacent to the PUD. 
(2)  The temporary use shall be located only in front of the adjoining establishment holding the permit, and shall not extend into abutting or adjacent properties. 
(3)  The temporary use objects shall not be placed in, or protrude into, any street or alley, and the temporary use objects shall be designed, constructed and securely placed to prevent danger to the public and to prevent being blown over or knocked over. 
(4)  The temporary use shall not create a fire hazard or interfere with ingress or egress from any building. 
(5)  The temporary use shall not interfere with the area's compliance with the American with Disabilities Act, as amended. At a minimum, the temporary use must allow five feet of clear and unobstructed passageway on the sidewalk or public plaza between the outermost edge of the permitted displays, café tables, chairs, sidewalk signs or other objects and the curb, street lamps, lamp posts, sign posts or other fixtures or obstructions. The director of public works may impose additional requirements to ensure compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act or to protect traffic safety or pedestrian safety or passage. 
(6)  The temporary use shall be located a minimum of five feet from driveways and alleys, and ten feet from intersections of public streets, except the director of public works may modify these requirements where the only public entrance to the establishment is on the corner of the building adjoining such intersection and the modification(s) maintain traffic safety and pedestrian safety and passage. The director of public works may impose additional requirements to protect traffic safety or pedestrian safety or passage. 
(7)  The display or sidewalk café shall be limited to food, beverages, or merchandise that is sold, displayed, or provided inside the permit holder's adjoining establishment. The sidewalk sign shall be limited to referencing or advertising food, beverages, or merchandise that is sold, displayed, or provided inside the permit holder's adjoining establishment. 
(8)  The temporary use object may only be placed within the permit area during the normal business hours of the permit holder's establishment, but in no case shall such items be located in the permit area between 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(9)  Use of the permitted area must conform with applicable laws, city ordinances, and zoning regulations. 
(10)  The city and the permit holder shall execute a temporary use of city property agreement for the use of the sidewalk or public plaza that shall include all conditions of this article and other conditions based upon the particular location and/or use. The agreement shall provide that the temporary use is subordinate to the city's use of the sidewalk or public plaza. The agreement shall provide that the permit holder agrees to at all times save and hold harmless the city from all liability, costs, damages, and expenses of any kind, for the payment of which the city may become liable to any person, firm or corporation by reason of any claim or damages arising from the failure of the permit holder, its employees, agents, servants, invitees, and patrons to exercise due care and diligence in the use of the sidewalk or public plaza. 
(11)  The permit holder shall purchase and maintain an insurance policy issued by a company licensed to issue insurance in the State of Kansas, insuring the licensee, and the city as an additionally named insured, in an amount not less than $500,000.00 per single incident, for any liability associated with the failure of the permit holder, its employees, agents, servants, invitees, and patrons to exercise due care and diligence in the use of the sidewalk or public plaza. The permit holder shall provide a certificate of insurance to the city upon permit issuance. 
(12)  The permit shall be conspicuously displayed at all times at the business for the permit area and shall be available for inspection by the city. 
(13)  The permit shall apply to the permit holder only and is non-assignable and non-transferable. 
(b)  In addition to the requirements set forth in subsection (a), to obtain and maintain a temporary use permit for a sidewalk sign, the following requirements must be met: 
(1)  Only one sidewalk sign shall be permitted per establishment. 
(2)  The sidewalk sign must be a movable sign not secured or attached to the ground or surface upon which it is located and placed upon a sidewalk within a public right-of-way that is supported by its own frame and shall be no more than nine square feet in total surface area and no more than five and one-half feet tall as measured from the sidewalk surface. 
(Ord. No. 6692, § 6, 4-15-08; Ord. No. 7116, § 3, 12-2-14; Ord. No. 7217, § 1, 6-7-16) 
Sec. 30-113. - Permit suspension, denial, and revocation. 
(a)  Permits applied for, or issued, under this article may be denied, suspended or revoked by the city, at any time, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Failure to furnish a completed application or required permit fee. 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or any false statement contained in the application for a permit. 
(3)  Failure to comply with the permit requirements, this article or the temporary use of city property agreement with the city. 
(4)  Failure to maintain the temporary use objects in good repair, in a safe and neat condition. 
(5)  Any violation of city codes, state statutes pertaining to alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages, or the zoning regulations. 
(b)  In addition to subsection (a), the director of public works may suspend a temporary use permit for a period not to exceed 14 days, if the public interest requires the use of the permitted area for a special event or construction or repair, or as otherwise necessary to protect the public health, safety, or welfare. 
(c)  Written notice of a denial, suspension or revocation shall be made in writing, stating the cause(s) therefore, and shall be delivered to the applicant or permit holder personally, or mailed to the applicant or permit holder's address as provided in the permit application. 
(d)  Any person whose permit has been denied, suspended or revoked, shall have the right to request a hearing before the city manager by filing a written request with the city clerk within five days following the delivery or mailing of the written notice of denial, suspension or revocation. The written appeal request shall state the grounds upon which appeal is made and the mailing address of the appellant. The city clerk shall schedule an appeal hearing before the city manager within ten business days following the receipt of the written appeal, and the city clerk shall provide written notice of the appeal hearing to the appellant by mail to the address provided in the written appeal request. The decision of the city manager shall become final within five days after mailing notice to the appellant. Failure to timely and properly file an appeal shall result in the decision of the director of public works becoming final. 
(e)  If a permit is revoked or expired, the permit holder shall remove the temporary use objects from city property, at the permit holder's expense, within 30 days of the date of expiration or the date of the notice of revocation. The permit holder shall restore the city property, at the permit holder's expense, to its public use and in a safe and neat condition. If the permit holder fails to remove any object, or to restore the city property, the city may remove and dispose of the object and restore the city property to its public use and in a safe and neat condition. The permit holder, or the property owner, shall reimburse the city for the costs of removal or relocation and for the restoration of the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 6692, § 7, 4-15-08; Ord. No. 7116, § 4, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 30-114. - Sidewalk cafe regulations. 
    The permit holder for a sidewalk cafe shall comply with the following regulations: 
(a)  The sidewalk cafe area and adjoining sidewalk areas shall remain clear of litter, food scraps, grease, and soiled dishes. All flooring areas must be cleaned daily, including adjacent sidewalk areas. 
(b)  The sidewalk cafe shall be continuously supervised by employees of the licensed establishment. 
(c)  Alcohol or cereal malt beverages may not be served within the permitted area, unless the following conditions are met: 
(1)  Pursuant to Chapter 4 of the City Code, the governing body approves an ordinance granting an exemption for the possession and consumption of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages on the specified city property upon which the sidewalk cafe will be located. The permit holder shall pay for the publication costs of an ordinance granting exemption for the possession and consumption of alcoholic liquor on such property. 
(2)  The permit holder possesses and maintains all required licenses relating to alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages, and the permit holder complies with all laws relating to the service of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages within establishment and the permitted area. If the permit holder, or an employee therefor, fails to comply with any law relating to the service of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages, the city may suspend or revoke the sidewalk cafe permit. 
(3)  The permitted area shall be designated with a permanent railing or barrier. Upon making application for a sidewalk cafe permit, the applicant shall submit a site plan detailing the style, design and color of the railing or barrier, which shall be at least 36 inches high. The city may require modification of the applicant's plan to increase safety, to improve passage, to prevent damage to the city's right-of-way, or to maintain a style consistent with the surrounding area. The permit holder, and the employees therefor, shall not serve or sell, or permit the service, sale, possession or consumption of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages, outside of the permitted area designated by the barrier. 
(4)  Alcohol may not be served, sold or consumed within the permitted area after 11:00 p.m. or before 8:00 a.m. 
(d)  The sidewalk cafe shall meet the requirements of the Riley County Heath Department, and all other state and local laws pertaining to the service of food. The permit holder shall possess and maintain a valid license for food service as required by state and local laws. 
(e)  All required building modifications shall be completed prior to the commencement of the operation of the sidewalk cafe. 
(Ord. No. 6692, § 8, 4-15-08) 
Sec. 30-115. - Exceptions. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to activities that require a permit pursuant to section 30-110 when such activities are part of an event conducted on an area-wide basis, if the event requires and has been granted the appropriate city permit for such event. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to activities authorized and supervised by the appropriate authority of any government agency, federal, state or local, acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Ord. No. 6692, § 9, 4-15-08) 
Secs. 30-116-30-119. - Reserved. 
Article IX - PUSHCARTS WITHIN CITY SIDEWALKS OR PUBLIC PLAZAS 

Sec. 30-120. - License, when required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a pushcart on city property without having first obtained a license as required in this article. "Pushcart" shall mean and include a manually propelled vehicle designed for the mobile service of food, that is of a size and nature that can be moved by one person and that will not obstruct pedestrian passage on city property. 
(Ord. No. 6900, § 3, 6-21-11) 
Sec. 30-121. - License application; term; fees; exemption. 
(a)  The application for a pushcart license shall be on a form provided by the city clerk, and a complete application shall be submitted to the city clerk, accompanied by the appropriate fee. The application shall include a photograph of the pushcart. 
(b)  The term of the license shall be from January 1 through December 31 of each calendar year. 
(c)  The annual license fee shall be $300.00. The license fee shall not be prorated and is nontransferable and nonrefundable. The license fee shall be waived for an applicant who applies for a license on behalf of a food establishment with premises in the city limits that have been licensed by the State of Kansas as a food establishment, as such term is defined by the state. 
(d)  The applicant shall pay a nonrefundable $20.00 fee for a criminal background check required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 6900, § 3, 6-21-11) 
Sec. 30-122. - Standards of issuance. 
(a)  A license shall only be issued to an applicant who meets the following requirements: 
(1)  The applicant has a valid Kansas food license for the pushcart. The applicant shall submit a copy of the applicant's valid Kansas food license for the pushcart with such city license application. 
(2)  The applicant has provided proof that the applicant has a Kansas Retail Sales Tax Number for the licensed activity. 
(3)  The applicant shall purchase and maintain an insurance policy, issued by a company licensed to issue insurance in the state of Kansas, insuring the licensee and the city as an additionally named insured, in an amount not less than $500,000.00 per single incident, for any liability associated with the failure of the licensee, its employees, agents, servants, invitees and patrons, to exercise due care and diligence in the use of the sidewalk or public plaza. 
(b)  No license shall be issued under this chapter to any person who: 
(1)  Is required to register pursuant to the Kansas Offender Registration Act, K.S.A. 22-4901 et seq., as amended, or pursuant to an offender registration act of any state; or 
(2)  Has been convicted of a felony; or 
(3)  Has been convicted in the past five years of a misdemeanor or ordinance violation involving force, violence, deceit, or fraud; or 
(4)  Has been convicted of any law regulating the act of soliciting within the past five years. 
(Ord. No. 6900, § 3, 6-21-11) 
Sec. 30-123. - Regulations. 
(a)  The licensees shall only operate the pushcart within the city sidewalks and public plazas between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and sunset. 
(b)  The licensee shall only operate within zoning districts in which restaurants are permitted uses, pursuant to the Manhattan Zoning Regulations. 
(c)  The licensee shall solicit only within a city sidewalk or public plaza. The licensee shall not vend to individuals or vehicle occupants standing or located within city streets, alleys, parking lots, or other city rights-of-way. A licensee shall not operate within city parks and recreation facilities without first receiving the permission of the city parks and recreation department. If the licensee receives permission from the city parks and recreation department, the licensee shall comply with the requirements imposed by the parks and recreation department, including limitations on hours and location of operation. 
(d)  No licensee shall solicit at any one location for more than two hours of any four-hour period of time. One side of one city block, or one public plaza, is considered one location. There shall be no more than one licensee located per one side of each city block or within one public plaza. The first licensee to locate on a particular block or within a public plaza shall have the right to occupy the location, subject to the time limitations set forth in this subsection. 
(e)  The licensee, nor anyone on the licensee's behalf, shall shout or use any sound device or sound reproducing or amplifying device to attract attention to the licensee's pushcart or to solicit. 
(f)  The licensee shall not obstruct pedestrian passage on the sidewalk or within the public plaza, nor shall the licensee obstruct or prevent access to any public or private structure. The licensee's use of the sidewalk or public plaza shall allow five feet of clear and unobstructed passageway on the sidewalk or in the public plaza. 
(g)  The licensee shall not solicit from within an area designated as a special event, sidewalk dining, sidewalk display or similar area, or to individuals within such areas, without prior written approval from the special event permit holder. 
(h)  If the licensee will operate within an area that has been designated as a business improvement district, the licensee shall be required to pay the annual business fee assigned to each district under the smallest retail business classification in the fee schedule. The licensee shall pay the fee(s) when the license is issued. A licensee who is licensed on behalf of a state-licensed food establishment with premises in a business improvement district shall not be required to pay an additional business fee to operate a pushcart within such district. 
(i)  The licensee shall comply with all food safety laws and requirements of the State of Kansas. 
(Ord. No. 6900, § 3, 6-21-11) 
Sec. 30-124. - Conditions of licensure. 
    The city clerk, or an officer of the Riley County Police Department, may suspend or revoke a license if the licensee: 
(a)  Fails to display, at all times while operating the pushcart, a copy of the city license issued under this article and a copy of the licensee's Kansas food license; 
(b)  Fails to comply with the regulations described in section 30-123; 
(c)  Fails to maintain his/her Kansas food license for the pushcart, a Kansas Retail Sales Tax Number, or liability insurance required by this article; 
(d)  Has been convicted of any crime during the license year that would disqualify the licensee from licensure pursuant to section 30-122; or 
(e)  Violates any law while operating the pushcart. 
(Ord. No. 6900, § 3, 6-21-11) 
Sec. 30-125. - Right to appeal. 
    The applicant or licensee shall have the right to appeal the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license issued under this article to the city manager. The applicant or licensee shall file a written notice of appeal with the city manager within five business days following the notification that the license has been denied, suspended, or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 6900, § 3, 6-21-11) 
Secs. 30-126-30-129. - Reserved. 
Article X - SUBDIVISION AND DEVELOPMENT SIGNS IN CITY RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 30-130. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain a subdivision or development identification sign in a city right-of-way without a valid permit. A "subdivision identification sign" or "development identification sign" is a sign identifying a residential subdivision, recognized residential neighborhood or a unified commercial or industrial development, and located in the city right-of-way near the entrance to a residential subdivision, recognized residential neighborhood, or a unified commercial or industrial development. 
(Ord. No. 7117, § 2, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 30-131. - Permit application and fee. 
(a)  The permit application must be submitted by the developer or the owner of, or the homeowners' association for, the residential subdivision, recognized residential neighborhood, or a unified commercial or industrial development. The applicant shall include a detailed site plan for the subdivision identification or development identification sign that shall include elevation drawings. The site plan shall state and illustrate the square footage of city right-of-way proposed for such use, and shall detail the dimensions, size, illumination, location and type of the identification sign within the city right-of-way. 
(b)  The completed application for any permit required in this article shall be submitted to the city clerk, on the form provided by the city, and shall be accompanied by the permit fee of $100.00 per sign. 
(Ord. No. 7117, § 3, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 30-132. - Subdivision identification or development identification sign requirements. 
    The subdivision identification or development identification sign must meet the following requirements: 
(a)  The sign must only be located in the city right-of-way adjacent to a vehicular entrance of the residential subdivision, recognized residential neighborhood, or unified commercial or industrial development. 
(b)  The sign must be located, designed, installed and maintained in a manner approved by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 7117, § 4, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 30-133. - Permit issuance. 
    The director of public works shall issue a permit if the application and the subdivision identification or development identification sign meet the requirements of this article, in consideration of the following factors: 
(a)  Whether the proposed sign's design and location creates driver distraction or negatively impacts traffic, pedestrian and bicycle safety; 
(b)  Whether the proposed sign may contribute to a vehicular, pedestrian or bicycle accident and the potential impact if the proposed sign is struck in an accident; and 
(c)  Whether the sign's materials and design will have long-term durability, and whether the sign is consistent and compatible with the aesthetics of the area. 
(Ord. No. 7117, § 4, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 30-134. - Permit suspension, denial, and revocation. 
(a)  The permit holder's right to use the right-of-way is subordinate at all times to the city's use of the right-of-way. The director of public works may require the temporary or permanent relocation of the sign to accommodate a public improvement or to protect the public health, safety or welfare. If the director of public works determines that the sign cannot be adequately relocated, in compliance with this article, to accommodate a public improvement or to protect the public health, safety or welfare, the director of public works may revoke the permit in accordance with this section. 
(b)  In addition to subsection (a), permits applied for, or issued, under this article may be denied, suspended or revoked by the city, at any time, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Failure to furnish a completed application or required permit fee. 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or any false statement contained in the application for a permit. 
(3)  Failure to comply with the permit standards or this article. 
(4)  Failure to maintain the sign in good repair, in a safe and neat condition. 
(c)  Written notice of a denial, suspension or revocation shall be made in writing, stating the cause(s) therefor, and shall be delivered to the applicant or permit holder personally, or mailed to the applicant or permit holder's address as provided in the permit application. 
(d)  Any person whose permit has been denied, suspended or revoked, shall have the right to request a hearing before the city manager by filing a written request with the city clerk within five days following the delivery or mailing of the written notice of denial, suspension or revocation. The written appeal request shall state the grounds upon which appeal is made and the mailing address of the appellant. The city clerk shall schedule an appeal hearing before the city manager within ten business days following the receipt of the written appeal, and the city clerk shall provide written notice of the appeal hearing to the appellant by mail to the address provided in the written appeal request. The decision of the city manager shall become final within five days after mailing notice to the appellant. Failure to timely and properly file an appeal shall result in the decision of the director of public works becoming final. 
(e)  If a permit is revoked, the permit holder shall remove the sign from the city right-of-way, at the permit holder's expense, within 30 days of the date of the notice of revocation. The permit holder shall restore the city right-of-way, at the permit holder's expense, to its public use in a safe and neat condition. If the permit holder fails to remove the sign, or to restore the city right-of-way, the city may remove and dispose of the sign and restore the city property to its public use and in a safe and neat condition. The permit holder shall reimburse the city for the costs of removal and disposal of the sign and restoration of the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 7117, § 5, 12-2-14) 
Secs. 30-135-30-139. - Reserved. 
Article XI - DUMPSTERS UPON CITY PROPERTY 

Sec. 30-140. - Definitions. 
    Dumpster shall mean and include a bin, receptacle or container for the collection and storage of refuse, trash, garbage, solid waste, construction materials, and similar items and which is then hoisted onto a specially equipped truck to be removed and emptied of its contents at a dumpsite by a city-licensed refuse collector. 
    Dumpster owner shall be the person who owns or controls the dumpster. If the dumpster owner is an entity, then any officer, partner, member, or other person responsible for the dumpster may be considered the dumpster owner. 
    No practical alternative shall mean that the parcel that is served by the dumpster does not have adequate space to accommodate the dumpster, and that the use of such dumpster is necessary for a temporary activity occurring upon such parcel. 
    "No practical alternative" shall not include circumstances of mere inconvenience or protection of grass or landscaping. In the event of a dispute about whether no practical alternative exists, the opinion of the city engineer shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 7339, §§ 1, 2, 2-6-18) 
Sec. 30-141. - Unlawful placement or maintenance of a dumpster upon city property; penalty. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to direct the placement of, or to place or maintain a dumpster upon, a city street, alley, sidewalk or other city-owned property. Each person who has directed the placement of, or placed or maintained, a dumpster in violation of this subsection may be held jointly and severally liable for such violation with respect to enforcement. 
(2)  It shall not be a violation of subsection (a) for a person to direct the placement of, or to place or maintain a dumpster upon a city street or alley in the C-3, Aggieville business district, or C-4, downtown business district, if a dumpster permit has been issued for the dumpster's location and the dumpster is placed and maintained in full compliance with the permit requirements. 
(3)  It shall not be a violation of subsection (a) for a person to direct the placement of, or to place or maintain a dumpster upon a city street or alley in a zoning district other than the C-3 or C-4 districts, if there is no practical alternative to the dumpster's location upon the city street or alley, and the dumpster is in full compliance with the requirements set forth in section 30-144. 
(4)  The penalty for each violation of subsection (a) shall be a fine of at least $100.00, but not exceeding $500.00, or by imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment as may be just for any one offense. Each day a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 7339, §§ 1, 2, 2-6-18) 
Sec. 30-142. - Declaration of nuisance. 
    Any dumpster that is placed in violation of this article is hereby declared to be and constitute a nuisance. In addition to any other civil or criminal penalties imposed by law, the city may pursue abatement of the nuisance condition pursuant to chapter 21 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 7339, §§ 1, 2, 2-6-18) 
Sec. 30-143. - Dumpster permit required for the C-3, Aggieville business district, or C-4, downtown business district. 
(a)  Dumpster permit required. A dumpster permit shall be issued prior to the placement of any dumpster upon a city street or alley in the C-3, Aggieville business district, or C-4, downtown business district. 
(b)  Application. The application for a dumpster permit shall be submitted to the city engineer on the form provided by the city, with a site plan and other required attachments. Such application must be submitted prior to the placement of the dumpster at the desired location. 
(c)  Fees. The fee for a dumpster permit is $75.00. The fee for a dumpster permit's renewal is $75.00. In addition to all other penalties, any person failing to obtain the permit or renewal, or failing to pay the fee, prior to conducting the activity allowed by the permit, shall pay double the fee when the permit is obtained or renewed. The fee is non-refundable. 
(d)  Issuance. The dumpster permit shall be issued or renewed if the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The applicant has submitted a complete application with the required fee. 
(2)  The requested location is upon a street or alley located in either the C-3 or C-4 zoning district. 
(3)  The city engineer finds that there is no practical alternative for the placement of the dumpster upon the parcel that the dumpster will serve. 
(4)  The city engineer finds that the placement of the dumpster upon the street or alley can maintain safety for vehicular and pedestrian traffic, with or without special requirements. 
(e)  Permit requirements. The permit is subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  The dumpster must be placed and maintained in accordance with section 30-144. 
(2)  The dumpster must be placed and maintained as approved in the permit. 
(3)  The dumpster must be placed and maintained in accordance with any special site conditions that the city deems to be reasonable and necessary. Such special site conditions may include requiring the permit holder to temporarily remove or relocate the dumpster if safety or special circumstances arise, at the permit holder's expense. 
(4)  The permit holder agrees to reimburse the city for the costs to repair any damage to the city street or alley caused by the dumpster. 
(f)  Term. Each permit or renewal permit shall be valid for the specific days and/or time period stipulated therein, as determined by the city engineer, but in no case shall the term of the permit or renewal exceed 60 days. If the time limit on the permit expires without approval of a renewal, the permit shall be considered expired and the permit holder shall immediately remove the dumpster from the city street or alley. 
(Ord. No. 7339, §§ 1, 2, 2-6-18) 
Sec. 30-144. - Requirements for each dumpster placed upon a city street or alley pursuant to this article. 
    Any dumpster that is placed or maintained upon a city street or alley in accordance with this article shall meet the following requirements at all times: 
(a)  The dumpster shall not block or obstruct a city sidewalk. 
(b)  The public right-of-way surrounding the dumpster shall be kept in a neat and slightly condition and free of debris. 
(c)  The exterior of dumpsters/containers located in the streets or alleys shall be marked with reflective tape, at least one-inch wide, along the side edge of both ends of the dumpster located perpendicular to vehicular or pedestrian traffic. Minimum amount of reflective tape for each edge in red and white pattern is 20 square inches mounted at minimum height of 30 inches above the bottom of the container on both ends on all four corners. 
(d)  The dumpster shall be placed upon appropriate runners or similar devices if placed upon asphalt-paved surfaces. 
(e)  The dumpster must be clearly labeled with the dumpster owner's name and current phone number. 
(f)  The dumpster must be placed and maintained immediately adjacent to the parcel it serves. 
(g)  Except as provided in a city dumpster permit or renewal permit, the dumpster shall not be placed or maintained upon the city street or alley adjacent to the parcel the dumpster serves for more than 60 days of any calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 7339, §§ 1, 2, 2-6-18) 
Sec. 30-145. - Permit suspension, denial or revocation. 
    The city engineer may suspend, deny or revoke a dumpster permit for any of the following reasons: 
(a)  Failure to submit a complete application and/or the appropriate fee; 
(b)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement in the application; 
(c)  Failure to comply with any law or city ordinance related to the placement of a dumpster upon a city street or alley; or 
(d)  Failure to comply with any dumpster permit condition or requirement. 
(Ord. No. 7339, §§ 1, 2, 2-6-18) 
Sec. 30-146. - Appeals. 
    An applicant or permit holder may appeal a decision of the city engineer, by filing a written appeal with the director of public works within ten days of the city engineer's decision. An applicant or permit holder may appeal a decision of the director of public works, by filing a written appeal with the city manager within ten days of the director's decision. The city manager's decision shall be issued in writing and shall be considered final. 
(Ord. No. 7339, §§ 1, 2, 2-6-18) 
Secs. 30-147-30-149. - Reserved. 
Article XII - STANDARDS FOR SMALL CELL FACILITIES AND WIRELESS SUPPORT STRUCTURES 
Division 1 - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-150. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings: 
    Accessory equipment means any equipment serving or being used in conjunction with a wireless facility or wireless support structure including, but not limited to, antennas, utility or transmission equipment, power supplies, generators, batteries, cables, equipment buildings, enclosures and storage sheds, shelters or similar structures. 
    Alley means a dedicated right-of-way, other than a street, that affords a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    Antenna means communications equipment that transmits or receives radio frequency signals in the provision of wireless service. 
    Application means a request submitted by a franchisee to the city for: 
(a)  The construction of a new wireless support structure or new wireless facility; 
(b)  The substantial modification of a wireless support structure or wireless facility; or 
(c)  Collocation of a wireless facility or replacement of a wireless facility. 
    Cantenna means a structural, weatherproof enclosure that protects an antenna. The cantenna is constructed of material that minimally attenuates the electromagnetic signal transmitted or received by the antenna. Cantennas protect antenna surfaces from weather and/or conceal antenna accessory equipment from public view. 
    City means the City of Manhattan, Kansas. 
    Collocation, collocate means to install, mount, modify, or replace wireless facilities on a wireless support structure. 
    Enclosure means a cabinet, box, or shroud for antennas or accessory equipment intended to conceal its contents, prevent electrical shock to users, and protect the contents from the environment. 
    Facility or facilities means any portion or component of the network located in, along, over, upon, under, or through the public right-of-way. 
    Franchisee means a natural person, corporation, partnership or governmental entity which has entered into a franchise agreement with the city for authorizing the construction, maintenance and operation of wireless facility within the right-of-way. 
    Network means a wireless service provider's wireless facilities or small cell facilities, including the antenna, poles, accessory equipment, enclosures, wireless support structures, underground and aboveground fiber optic cable, wires, lines, fiber enclosures, fiber repeaters and related equipment and appurtenances, and similar facilities and appurtenances, designed, constructed or occupied for the purpose of producing, receiving, amplifying or distributing wireless services to or from locations within the city. 
    Right-of-way means only the area of real property in which the city has a dedicated or acquired right-of-way interest in the real property. It shall include the area on, below or above the present and future streets, alleys, avenues, roads, highways, parkways or boulevards dedicated or acquired as right-of-way. The term does not include the airwaves above a right-of-way with regard to wireless services, easements obtained by utilities or private easements in platted subdivisions or tracts. 
    Small cell facility means a wireless facility that meets both of the following qualifications: 
(a)  Each antenna is located inside an enclosure of not more than six cubic feet in volume or, in the case of an antenna that has exposed elements, the antenna and all of its exposed elements could fit within an imaginary enclosure of not more than six cubic feet, and 
(b)  All other accessory equipment associated with the small cell facility is cumulatively not more than 28 cubic feet in volume, or 50 cubic feet in volume if the equipment was ground-mounted before the effective date of this section. The following types of associated ancillary equipment are not included in the calculation of equipment volume pursuant to this subdivision: 
i.  Electric meters. 
ii.  Concealment elements. 
iii.  A telecommunications demarcation box. 
iv.  Grounding equipment. 
v.  A power transfer switch. 
vi.  A cut-off switch. 
vii.  Vertical cable or the connection of power and other services. 
    Small cell network means a collection of interrelated small cell facilities designed to deliver wireless service. 
    Street means a public thoroughfare used, or intended to be used, for passage or travel by motor vehicles. 
    Substantial modification means a proposed modification to an existing wireless support structure that will substantially change the physical dimensions of the wireless support structure under the objective standard for substantial change, established by the FCC in 47 C.F.R. § 1.40001(b)(7), as may be amended, and as applicable to facilities in the public right-of-way. 
    Wireless facility means equipment at a fixed location that enables wireless communications between user equipment and a communications network, including all of the following: 
(a)  Equipment associated with wireless communications;
