(1)  Refused to submit and complete any test of blood, breath, or urine requested by law enforcement excluding the preliminary screening test as set forth in K.S.A. 8-1012, and amendments thereto; 
(2)  Was convicted of violating the provisions of K.S.A. 40-3104, and amendments thereto, relating to motor vehicle liability insurance coverage; 
(3)  Was convicted of vehicular homicide, K.S.A. 21-3405, prior to its repeal or K.S.A. 21-5406, and amendments thereto, involuntary manslaughter while driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, K.S.A. 21-3442, prior to its repeal or or K.S.A. 21-5405, and amendments thereto, or any other murder or manslaughter crime resulting from the operation of a motor vehicle; or, 
(4)  Was convicted of being a habitual violator, K.S.A. 8-287, and amendments thereto. 
(c)  The person convicted shall not be eligible for release on probation, suspension or reduction of sentence or parole until the person has served at least 90 days' imprisonment. The 90 days' imprisonment mandated by this subsection may be served in a work release program only after such person has served 48 consecutive hours' imprisonment, provided such work release program requires such person to return to confinement at the end of each day in the work release program. The court may place the person convicted under a house arrest program or any municipal ordinance to serve the remainder of the minimum sentence only after such person has served 48 consecutive hours' imprisonment. 
(d)  For the purposes of determining whether a conviction is a first, second, third or subsequent conviction in sentencing under this section, conviction includes a conviction of a violation of any ordinance of any city or resolution of any county or a law of any state, which is in substantial conformity with this section. (K.S.A. Supp. 8-262) 
(Code 1973, § 18-102; Ord. No. 3737, § 2, 9-18-79; Ord. No. 4083, §§ 2-11, 8-2-83; Ord. No. 4112, §§ 1, 2, 1-3-84; Ord. No. 4149, §§ 1-4, 9-4-84; Ord. No. 4197, §§ 2-15, 4-16-85; Ord. No. 4216, § 1, 6-18-85; Ord. No. 4441, §§ 2-15, 9-15-87; Ord. No. 4497, § 1, 2-16-88; Ord. No. 4664, §§ 3-16, 10-16-90; Ord. No. 4763, §§ 3-15, 9-15-92; Ord. No. 4802, § 1, 7-6-93; Ord. No. 4819, §§ 3-15, 10-5-93; Ord. No. 6097, §§ 3-14, 10-19-99; Ord. No. 6214, § 1, 6-19-01; Ord. No. 6228, §§ 3-14, 8-21-01; Ord. No. 6301, §§ 3-16, 11-5-02; Ord. No. 6366, §§ 3-17, 10-21-03; Ord. No. 6438 §§ 3-18, 11-2-04; Ord. No. 6511, §§ 3-19, 11-15-05; Ord. No. 6556, §§ 1, 2, 7-18-06; Ord. No. 6585, §§ 3-21, 10-17-06; Ord. No. 6671, §§ 3-22, 11-6-07; Ord. No. 6731, § 3, 10-21-08; Ord. No. 6812, §§ 3-18, 2-16-10; Ord. No. 6830, §§ 3-19, 7-6-10; Ord. No. 6853, §§ 3-16, 10-12-10; Ord. No. 6924, §§ 3-14, 10-18-11; Ord. No. 6967, §§ 3-16, 10-2-12; Ord. No. 7040, §§ 3-15, 10-1-13; Ord. No. 7113, §§ 3-17, 12-2-14; Ord. No. 7174, §§ 3-16, 11-3-15; Ord. No. 7255, §§ 3-16, 10-18-16; Ord. No. 7303, § 1, 7-18-17; Ord. No. 7312, §§ 3-19, 9-5-17; Ord. No. 7375, §§ 3-19, 9-4-18) 
Sec. 31-18. - Unsafe, inattentive, negligent driving. 
    Every driver operating a motor vehicle on the streets, alleys or public ways of the city shall give full attention to the safe operation of his vehicle while it is in motion. No driver of a motor vehicle in the city shall engage in any activity or do any act which interferes with the safe control of his vehicle. Any driver of a motor vehicle, whose vehicle collides with another vehicle, person, or a fixed object, because of his driving error which act is not otherwise prohibited by ordinances of this city, shall be deemed guilty of unsafe, inattentive or negligent driving and subject to penalty. 
(Code 1973, § 18-218) 
Sec. 31-19. - Noise from motor vehicles. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to establish standards regulating noise from motor vehicles in the city. 
(b)  Definitions. Unless otherwise expressly stated, or the content clearly indicates a different intention, the following terms shall have the meaning shown: 
(1)  dBA means the composite abbreviation for A-weighted sound level, and the unit of sound level, the decibel. 
(2)  Gross combination weight rating or GCWR means the value specified by the manufacturer as the maximum loaded weight of a combination vehicle. 
(3)  Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled other than a motorized bicycle. 
(4)  Gross vehicle weight rating or GVWR means the value specified by the manufacturer as a loaded weight of a single vehicle. 
(5)  Sound level means the A-weighted sound pressure level measured with a fast response using an instrument complying with specifications for sound level meters of the American. 
National Standards Institute, Inc., (ANSIS 1.4-1971 or the latest approved revision thereof) or its successor bodies, except that only A-weighting and fast dynamic response need be provided. 
(6)  Sound level meter will mean an apparatus or instrument including a microphone, amplifier, attenuator, output meter and frequency weighting networks for the measurement of sound levels. 
(c)  Operating noise limits. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle, or accessories attached thereto, within the city at any time in such a manner that the sound level emitted by the motor vehicle, or the accessory, exceeds the level set forth in the table below, for the speed limit zone, regardless of the actual speed of the motor vehicle. If the vehicle is stationary or in an area where no speed limit is applicable, the sound level for 35 miles per hour or less shall apply. 
Motor vehicle sound limit measured at 15 meters (50 feet). In the event the distance is less than 50 feet, such listed noise limit will be corrected to reflect the equivalent noise limits for the actual distance. 
Sound Level in dBAVehicle Class Speed limit, 35 mph or less Speed limit, over 35 mph Motor carrier vehicle engaged in interstate commerce of GVWR or GCWR of 10,000 lbs. or more 86 90 All other motor vehicles of GVWR or GCWR of 10,000 lbs. or more 86 90 Any other motor vehicle or any combination of vehicles towed by any motor vehicle 80 84  
(d)  Adequate mufflers or sound dissipative devices. Every motor vehicle shall be equipped, maintained, and operated so as to prevent excessive or unusual noise. Every motor vehicle at all times shall be equipped with a muffler or other effective noise suppression system and no person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass, or similar device. 
(e)  Standing motor vehicles. No person shall operate the engine providing motive power, or an auxiliary engine of a motor vehicle with a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating of 10,000 pounds or more for a consecutive period longer than 20 minutes which such vehicle is standing and located within 150 feet of property zoned and used for residential purposes except where the vehicle is standing within a completely enclosed structure. This section shall not apply to delivery or pickup vehicles that require the operation of the engine to unload their vending loads. 
(f)  Exempt vehicles. The following are exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(1)  Authorized emergency vehicles, as defined in K.S.A. 81-1404. 
(2)  Construction or agricultural equipment and street maintenance equipment. 
(g)  Penalty for violation. Upon conviction of a violation of any provision herein, the violator shall be fined in any sum not to exceed $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 3870, §§ 1-6, 8, 7-21-81) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3870, adopted July 21, 1981, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-6 and 8 as § 31-19 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 31-20-31-30. - Reserved. 
Article III - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING 
Division 1 - GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Sec. 1 of Ord. No. 7144, adopted June 16, 2015, repealed and replaced divs. 1-5 of art. III. Said divs. 1-5, pertained to similar provisions, consisted of §§ 31-31-31-37, 31-51, 31-62-31-65, 31-71-31-75, 31-86-31-94, 31-101. See the Code Comparative Table for amendatory history. 

Sec. 31-31. - Loading zones. 
(a)  Loading zones are hereby designated and established in the locations along the streets and highways of the city specified in this section. Parking, standing and stopping for the loading or unloading of property or passengers shall only be allowed in the following zones for the following maximum periods of time: 
Houston Street 
30 Minute Loading Zone: The south side of Houston Street between a point 44 feet east of the east back-of-curb of the intersection of the south side of Houston Street and 5 th Street and a point 90 feet east of said east back-of-curb of 5 th Street. 
30 Minute Loading Zone: The south side of Houston Street between a point 164 feet west of the west back-of-curb of the intersection of the south side of Houston Street and 3 rd Street and a point 208 feet west of said west back-of-curb of 3 rd Street. 
Pine Drive 
15 Minute Loading Zone: The east side of Pine Drive between a point 35 feet south of the south back-of-curb of the intersection of the east side of Pine Drive and Poyntz Avenue and a point 100 feet south of said south back-of-curb of Poyntz Avenue. 
Pioneer Lane 
30 Minute Loading Zone: The north side of Pioneer Lane between a point 61 feet west of the west back-of-curb of the intersection of the north side of Pioneer Lane and McCain Lane and a point 101 feet west of said west back-of-curb of McCain Lane. 
Vattier Street 
30 Minute Loading Zone: The south side of Vattier Street between Juliette Street and 8 th Street. 
5 th Street 
15 Minute Loading Zone: The west side of 5 th Street between a point 56 feet north of the centerline of Pierre Street at the intersection of the west side of 5 th Street and Pierre Street and a point 156 feet north of said centerline of Pierre Street. 
30 Minute Loading Zone: The east side of 5 th Street between a point 80 feet south of the south back-of-curb of the intersection of the east side of 5 th Street and Poyntz Avenue and a point 136 feet south of said south back-of-curb of Poyntz Avenue. 
6 th Street 
30 Minute Loading Zone: The east side of 6 th Street between a point 108 feet north of the north back-of-curb of the intersection of the east side of 6 th Street and Poyntz Avenue and a point 156 feet north of said north back-of-curb of Poyntz Avenue. 
12 th Street 
15 Minute Loading Zone: The west side of 12 th Street between a point 50 feet south of the centerline of Laramie Street at the intersection of the west side of 12 th Street and Laramie Street and a point 90 feet south of said centerline of Laramie Street. 
30 Minute Loading Zone: The east side of 12 th Street between a point 14 feet north of the north back-of-curb of the intersection of the east side of 12 th Street and the alley between Bluemont Avenue and Moro Street and a point 62 feet north of said north back-of-curb of the alley between Bluemont Avenue and Moro Street. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked within a loading zone except for the purpose of loading or unloading the vehicle and then only for such length of time as is reasonably necessary to load or unload the vehicle which shall not under any circumstances exceed the maximum period of time listed for such loading zone in this section. The city traffic engineer shall mark loading zones with appropriate signs and other indicators. 
(c)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not exceeding $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 31-32. - Parking and standing of buses. 
    Notwithstanding any provision in the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, or any code adopted by said Manhattan Code to the contrary, it shall be lawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any bus registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked upon any street for the purpose of immediate loading or unloading of passengers. Nevertheless, it is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any bus registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked upon any street in any location where parking is prohibited for any period of time unless actively engaged in the loading or unloading of passengers. Furthermore, it is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any bus registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked for any period of time in a location that obstructs the ability of other drivers to observe oncoming traffic or in violation of subsection (a) of Section 85 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities, as adopted and amended by the city. Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not exceeding $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 31-33. - Parking and standing of school buses. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any school bus registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be parked upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop zone or a school bus stop zone. 
(b)  School bus stop zones for the loading or unloading of school bus passengers are hereby designated and established along the following streets and highways of the city: 
Browning Avenue 
The east side of Browning Avenue between a point 320 feet south of the centerline of Hobbs Drive at the intersection of Hobbs Drive and the east side of Browning Avenue and a point 520 feet south of said centerline of Hobbs Drive. 
Canfield Drive 
The east side of Canfield Drive beginning at the north back-of-curb of Anderson Avenue and a point north 250 feet. 
Griffith Drive 
The north side of Griffith Drive between the eastern intersection of Griffith Drive and Griffith Terrace and the western intersection of Griffith Drive and Griffith Terrace. 
Westbaker Street 
The west side of Westbaker Street between a point 350 feet south of the south back-of-curb of the intersection of the west side of Westbaker Street and Churchill Street and a point 550 feet south of said south back-of-curb of Churchill Street. 
8 th Street 
The east side of 8 th Street between a point 50 feet south of the centerline of Vattier Street at the intersection of Vattier Street and the east side of 8 th Street and a point 250 feet south of said centerline of Vattier Street. 
9 th Street 
The west side of 9 th Street between Poyntz Avenue and Pierre Street. 
10 th Street 
The east side of 10 th Street between Poyntz Avenue and Pierre Street. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any school bus registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked within a school bus stop zone except for the purpose of loading or unloading the school bus and then only for such length of time as is reasonably necessary to load or unload the school bus which shall not under any circumstances exceed 45 minutes. It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person that is not a school bus to be stopped, stood or parked within a school bus stop zone except for the purpose of immediate loading or unloading of passengers. The city traffic engineer shall mark school bus stop zones with appropriate signs and other indicators. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15; Ord. No. 7190, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 31-34. - Procedure for impounding motor vehicles. 
(a)  The Riley County Police Department may impound and dispose of vehicles pursuant to and in compliance with K.S.A. 8-1101 et seq. or otherwise request for a vehicle to be moved as provided in K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq. pursuant to and in compliance with K.S.A. 8-1102. The governing body of the city hereby finds and determines that the absence of an engine in a vehicle in no way mitigates the effects of abandoning a vehicle or leaving a vehicle unattended in such a manner as to interfere with public highway operations and as a result the same public health, public safety and public welfare justifications which support and make necessary the motor vehicle impoundment and disposition authority and procedures set forth within K.S.A. 8-1101 et seq. support and make necessary the impoundment and disposition of any vehicle, as that term is defined in the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities as adopted and amended by the city, under the circumstances and for the reasons described for the impoundment and disposition of motor vehicles in K.S.A. 8-1101 et seq. These public health, public safety and public welfare justifications include the public's interest in the safe and orderly flow of traffic and the efficient and predictable removal of vehicles that have been abandoned or left on a public highway or other property open to use by the public or on other real property which is not owned or leased by the person abandoning or leaving the vehicle or by the owner or lessee of such vehicle. Therefore, the Riley County Police Department is hereby additionally empowered to impound and dispose of vehicles that are not motor vehicles under the circumstances described and pursuant to and in compliance with the procedures set forth within K.S.A. 8-1101 et seq. for motor vehicles. In the alternative, the Riley County Police Department may also, under the circumstances described and pursuant to and in compliance with the procedures set forth within K.S.A. 8-1102, request for such vehicles to be moved by a wrecker or towing service under the circumstances described and pursuant to and in compliance with the procedures set forth within K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq. The removal, recovery, release, transportation, protection, storage and safekeeping of a vehicle, including the personal property contained therein, that is requested to be removed by a wrecker or towing service pursuant to this section shall only be accomplished pursuant to and in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq. 
(b)  The governing body of the city hereby finds and determines that unattended vehicles which are stopped, stood or parked in violation of the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities, as adopted and amended by the city, interfere with public highway operations in several ways, including: 
(1)  Negatively affecting the safe and lawful use of the public sidewalks and highways of the city by pedestrians and impeding the safe and orderly flow of traffic alongside or opposite street excavations and obstructions, upon bridges and other elevated structures, within highway tunnels and over or near railroad tracks, railroad crossings and fire stations; 
(2)  Preventing firefighting and emergency medical equipment, including vehicles used for firefighting or emergency medical purposes, from being maneuvered, parked, located and stood to maximize safe and orderly vehicular traffic upon the public highways or other property open to use by the public while maintaining the safety of emergency response personnel and other persons which may be present during an incident; 
(3)  Causing an unusual delay to traffic that impedes the travel of persons, vehicles and emergency response personnel and equipment; 
(4)  Preventing or otherwise frustrating the use of public highways or other property open to use by the public by adjacent private property owners and other users of such public highways and other property open to use by the public; 
(5)  Creating a potentially hazardous condition; and 
(6)  Endangering the safety and welfare of persons and property by forcing drivers or operators of vehicles which are empowered to stand and park in certain locations to seek other locations to stand and park such vehicles that may not offer the same safety and accommodation of surrounding traffic for the loading or unloading of merchandise or passengers. 
    Therefore, unattended vehicles which are stopped, stood or parked in violation of the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities, as adopted and amended by the city, are subject to immediate removal and impoundment pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1101 et seq. 
(c)  The governing body of the city hereby finds and determines that unattended vehicles which are stopped, stood or parked in violation of section 31-203 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, interfere with public highway operations in several ways, including preventing the safe and orderly removal and remediation of snow upon the streets of the city which may cause a delay to traffic that impedes the travel of persons, vehicles and emergency response personnel and equipment thereby endangering the safety and welfare of persons and property. Therefore, unattended vehicles which are stopped, stood or parked in violation of section 31-203 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas are subject to immediate removal and impoundment pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1101 et seq. 
(d)  If an impounded vehicle is registered in another state or bears no registration plates and the Riley County Police Department impounds such vehicle, the Riley County Police Department shall, in addition to any and all procedures set forth in K.S.A. 8-1102, take prompt action that is reasonably calculated to apprise the owner and lienholder, if any, of the vehicle's location and potential disposition. Such action may include, but is not limited to, contacting the department of motor vehicles of other states to learn to whom the vehicle is registered, performing a check with the Federal Bureau of Investigation's National Crime Information Center to determine whether the vehicle has been stolen or obtaining a report from CARFAX or an equivalent entity which shows the state in which the vehicle is titled and/or registered and the presence of any liens. If a report from CARFAX or an equivalent entity is obtained, the Riley County Police Department shall subsequently inquire with the appropriate employees and officials of the state in which the vehicle is titled and/or registered to determine the names and addresses of its owner(s) and any lienholders. If the Riley County Police Department is unsuccessful in determining the name and address of the owner or any lienholder of the vehicle, they shall publish a notice once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper describing the vehicle by name of maker, model, color and serial number (if any), and shall further state the reasons for the impoundment, information regarding the rights of the owner/lienholder in the recovery of the vehicle and a statement that unless the owner/lienholder takes action within ten days of the date of the second publication, the vehicle will be sold at public auction to cover the removal and storage costs and publication costs incurred by the Riley County Police Department. If the Riley County Police Department is successful in locating the name and address of the owner or any lienholder, they shall be afforded the same notice by certified mail as set forth in K.S.A. 8-1102(a)(2) for owners registered with the Kansas Department of Revenue Division of Vehicles. 
(e)  Whenever the Riley County Police Department has complied with the foregoing provisions of K.S.A. 8-1102 and this section with respect to any impounded vehicle, and the owner or lienholder does not exercise any of his rights as set forth in K.S.A. 8-1102 and this section within the time stated in the notice, the Riley County Police Department may, pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1102 and this section, directly or through its designated agent sell the vehicle at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. 
(f)  Once any vehicle has been impounded pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1102 and this section or moved as provided in K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq. in response to a request from an officer of the Riley County Police Department, the owner or lienholder may: 
(1)  Immediately pay the accrued wrecker or towing service fees and storage fees, and thereby regain possession of the vehicle; 
(2)  Provide a surety bond in the amount of the accrued wrecker or towing service fees and storage fees, and thereby immediately regain possession of the vehicle. Upon the posting of a surety bond, the clerk of the municipal court shall schedule a hearing on the validity of the removal or impoundment to be held before the municipal court on a regularly scheduled court day not more than ten calendar days following the posting of the surety bond. If the judge of the municipal court finds that there was no probable cause that the traffic violation attendant with the removal or impoundment occurred and the removal or impoundment was not otherwise justified pursuant to this section and K.S.A. 8-1102, the vehicle shall be immediately released to its lawful owner or possessor without the payment of wrecker or towing service fees and storage fees or any other costs, and the bond posted shall be returned. Upon such a finding, the city shall pay the wrecker or towing service fees and storage fees to the wrecker or towing service which had been in possession of the vehicle; or 
(3)  Demand a hearing on the validity of the removal and impoundment, to be held before the municipal court on the next regularly scheduled court day following the demand. If the judge of the municipal court finds that there was no probable cause that the traffic violation attendant with the removal or impoundment occurred and the removal and impoundment was not otherwise justified pursuant to this section and K.S.A. 8-1102, the vehicle shall be immediately released to its lawful owner or possessor without the payment of wrecker or towing service fees and storage fees or any other costs. Upon such a finding, the city shall pay the wrecker or towing service fees and storage fees to the wrecker or towing service which had been in possession of the vehicle. 
(g)  No vehicle shall be returned until the owner/lienholder provides proof of valid registration (if the vehicle is required to be registered by law) and ownership of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 31-35. - Parking on private property without authority prohibited; procedure for removal described. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), it is unlawful for any person to park, store, leave or abandon a vehicle or cause a vehicle to be parked, stored, left or abandoned on real property without authority from the owner or occupant of such real property. 
(b)  It shall not be a violation of this section to park a vehicle on public property, as long as such parking is in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. It shall not be a violation of this section to park a vehicle on private property, which is both open to use by the public for such purpose and is designed and intended for the parking of motor vehicles. For the purposes of this section, private property is not "open to use by the public", if it is: 
(1)  Being used as either single-family residential or two-family residential; or 
(2)  Restricted to parking for a particular purpose, or to certain vehicles or users, and the public is notified of such restrictions by signs erected on the property in compliance with subsection (c) hereinafter. 
    Nothing contained within this section shall be deemed to permit the parking of motor vehicles at any location where such parking is otherwise prohibited by law. 
(c)  Signs restricting parking pursuant to subsection (b)(2) shall comply with the following: 
(1)  All such signs shall be at least 18 inches wide, and 24 inches tall, and shall be posted on a pole or other structure between four feet and eight feet above the ground. 
(2)  The signs shall reasonably inform the users of the parking area of the restrictions as to its use. In addition to wording informing the users of such restrictions, such signs shall contain wording at the top stating "RESTRICTED PARKING" and shall contain wording at the bottom stating "VIOLATORS WILL BE TOWED AT VEHICLE OWNERS EXPENSE". 
(3)  At least one sign shall be placed at all entrances to the parking area and positioned so that the operator of a vehicle entering the parking area can observe the sign. A minimum number of signs, equal to one for each ten parking spaces within the parking area, shall be located uniformly throughout the parking area. The requirements set forth in this subparagraph (3) shall not apply to parking areas that contain more than 50 parking spaces. In parking areas that contain more than 50 parking spaces, the number, and location, of such signs shall be established by the director of the Riley County Police Department, or his designee. The number and location of such signs shall be determined in a manner to reasonably notify the users of such parking area of the restrictions. 
(d)  In any prosecution charging a violation of this section, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was in violation of this section, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of the violation a registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute a prima facie presumption that said registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked such vehicle. In addition to all other penalties which are applicable to a conviction of this section, the judge of the municipal court may require a person convicted of this offense to reimburse any person who has incurred costs related to the removal and impoundment of such vehicle. 
(e)  After issuing a citation for a violation of this section, the Riley County Police Department may request for a wrecker or towing service to remove the vehicle for which the citation was issued from the property. The removal, recovery, release, transportation, protection, storage and safekeeping of a vehicle, including the personal property contained therein, that is requested to be removed by a wrecker or towing service pursuant to this section shall only be accomplished pursuant to and in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq. 
(f)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not exceeding $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 31-36. - Parking of vehicles by owners of leasing services on streets, alleys prohibited; fine for violation. 
(a)  The governing body of the city finds that the parking of trucks, trailers, and automobiles by owners or operators of truck, trailer and automobile leasing services along the streets and alleys of the city can and does create traffic hazards and unduly inconveniences the citizens of the city. 
(b)  The parking of commercial trucks, trailers, and automobiles by owners or operators of truck, trailer or automobile leasing services along the streets and alleys of the city is prohibited. 
(c)  The said parking of each individual commercial truck, trailer, or automobile above described shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not exceeding $100.00, or be imprisoned not to exceed 30 days or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 31-37. - Parking longer than 48 hours on city streets or other public property declared unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to park or leave a vehicle or allow a vehicle to be parked or left on the streets of the City of Manhattan, Kansas or on any other public property of the City of Manhattan, Kansas continuously in one location for a period in excess of 48 hours. Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not exceeding $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 31-38. - Wrecker or towing service fees, reports and procedures. 
(a)  As required by K.S.A. 8-1103, any wrecker or towing service which moves a vehicle as provided in K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq. in response to a request from an officer of the Riley County Police Department shall not charge wrecker or towing service fees and storage fees in excess of the following amounts for the following types of vehicles: 
Tow Classification Tow Fee Storage Fee Vehicle towed weighs 10,000 pounds or less $200.00 $30.00 for each day after the day on which the vehicle is towed Vehicle towed weighs more than 10,000 pounds and less than 26,000 pounds $350.00 $40.00 for each day after the day on which the vehicle is towed Vehicle towed weighs 26,000 pounds or more $450.00 $50.00 for each day after the day on which the vehicle is towed  
(b)  The owner of any vehicle moved as provided in K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq. in response to a request from an officer of the Riley County Police Department shall have access to personal property in such vehicle for 48 hours after such vehicle has been towed and such personal property shall be released to the owner. 
(c)  Any wrecker or towing service which moves a vehicle as provided in K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq. in response to a request from an officer of the Riley County Police Department shall report the location of such vehicle to the Riley County Police Department within two hours of such tow. Such report shall be made either orally or in writing according to the policies and procedures of the Riley County Police Department and shall include, at a minimum, a description of the vehicle, its tag number (if any), the location from which the vehicle was moved, the name of any owner or occupant of real property or agent of the same who requested removal, the location at which the vehicle is stored, and any other information required by the Riley County Police Department. 
(d)  If any wrecker or towing service moves a vehicle as provided in K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq. in response to a request from an officer of the Riley County Police Department when said vehicle is registered in another state or bears no registration plates, in addition to any and all procedures set forth in K.S.A. 8-1103 et seq., the wrecker or towing service shall take the action that is reasonably calculated to apprise the owner and lienholder, if any, of the vehicle's location and potential disposition that is described in subsection (d) of section 31-34 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 31-39. - Angle parking. 
    Angle parking is permitted on and adjacent to any street in stalls that have been authorized by and marked pursuant to the instruction of the city's traffic engineer. Angle parking shall not be permitted on any federal-aid or state highway, unless the Kansas Secretary of Transportation has determined that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. The stopping, standing or parking of any vehicle within any area where angle parking is permitted shall be subject to all ordinances, laws, regulations and provisions of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas governing the stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle which apply to the portion of the street adjacent to such area or upon which such area is located. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 31-40. - Stall parking on public parking lots and garages. 
    Where parking stalls or spaces are marked or designated on the pavement or curb of any parking lot or parking garage owned by the city or any other publicly owned parking lot or parking garage within the city, vehicles shall be parked or stopped within such stalls or spaces at the angle indicated by the markings. 
(Ord. No. 7173, § 2, 11-3-15; Ord. No. 7183, § 2, 12-1-15) 
Secs. 31-41-31-50. - Reserved. 
Division 2 - LIMITED TIME PARKING ZONES AND LOTS AND NO PARKING ZONES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- See editor's note at div. 1. 

Sec. 31-51. - Limited time parking zones. 
(a)  In any 24-hour period, it is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on the same side of any street in the same block for a period or periods of time, the total of which is greater than the maximum period of time allowed by this section for parking on such block of such street. Parking, standing or stopping of a vehicle in any limited time parking zone shall only be allowed if such parking, standing or stopping is not in violation of any other provisions of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas and other applicable laws. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection for longer than two hours. 
Downtown District 
All streets within the area described as beginning at the intersection of the north right-of-way of Humboldt Street and the east right-of-way of 2 nd Street; thence south along the east right-of-way of 2 nd Street to the south right-of-way of Houston Street; thence west along Houston Street to the east right-of-way of 4 th Street; thence south to the south right-of-way of Pierre Street; thence west to the west right-of-way of 5 th Street; thence north to the south right-of-way of Poyntz Avenue; thence west to the east right-of-way of 6 th Street; thence north to the north right-of-way of Poyntz Avenue; thence east to the west right-of-way of 5 th Street; thence north to the north right-of-way of Humboldt Street; thence east to the east right-of-way of 2 nd Street and the point of beginning. 
Laramie Street 
The north and south sides of Laramie Street between 11 th Street and 14 th Street. 
Manhattan Avenue 
The east side of North Manhattan Avenue between Laramie Street and Bluemont Avenue. 
Moro Street 
The north and south sides of Moro Street between 11 th Street and North Manhattan Avenue. 
Old Anderson Avenue 
The south side of Old Anderson Avenue, which is located in Aggieville and referred to as the Old Anderson Avenue cutoff, between North Manhattan Avenue and Anderson Avenue. 
Poyntz Avenue 
The north side of the 600 block of Poyntz Avenue. 
12 th Street 
The east and west sides of North 12 th Street between Laramie Street and Bluemont Avenue. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection for longer than two hours except that this limitation shall not apply on Sundays. 
5 th Street 
The east and west sides of North 5 th Street between Humboldt Street and the alley between Humboldt Street and Poyntz Avenue. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection for longer than 30 minutes. 
Humboldt Street 
The south side of Humboldt Street between a point 130 feet east of the east back-of-curb of the intersection of the south side of Humboldt Street and 5 th Street and a point 160 feet west of the west back-of-curb of the intersection of the south side of Humboldt Street and 4 th Street. 
Leavenworth Street 
The north and south sides of Leavenworth Street between 5 th Street and 6 th Street. 
(e)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection for longer than 15 minutes except that this limitation shall only apply on Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
Poyntz Avenue 
The north side of Poyntz Avenue between a point 120 feet east of the east back-of-curb of the intersection of the north side of Poyntz Avenue and 8 th Street and a point 285 feet east of said east back-of-curb of 8 th Street. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15; Ord. No. 7355, § 1, 6-5-18) 
Sec. 31-52. - Limited time parking lots and no parking during designated times lots. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any parking lot owned by the city or other publicly owned parking lot within the city in the following locations in excess of the periods of time allowed for parking prescribed herein or during the periods of time prescribed herein when parking a vehicle is unlawful: 
The public parking lot south of the Library on the northeast corner of Juliette Avenue and Houston Street 
This entire lot will be designated as free parking with a three-hour time limit, except for the 11 stalls on the west side of said parking lot next to Juliette Avenue, which will have a 30-minute time limit. These parking time limits shall only be applicable on Monday through Saturday between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. and on Sunday from 1:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m., provided that such restrictions shall not apply on any holidays. 
The public parking lot on the south side of Humboldt Street between Third and Fourth Streets 
Except as set forth hereinafter, this entire lot will be designated as free parking and the south two parking rows shall be restricted with a two-hour time limit. All remaining parking rows shall be unrestricted as to the amount of time a vehicle can remain parked therein. The time limits on this parking lot shall apply on Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. The city manager is hereby authorized to designate up to eight parking stalls within this public lot for reserved use by public vehicles only. Such public vehicles may be owned and operated by public law enforcement, community corrections, the United States Government, or any similar public agency or entity. Once designated, the city manager shall place signs within each such parking stall, clearly setting forth the public use to which such stall is reserved. Such reservation shall apply 24 hours a day, each and every day of the week, and such stalls shall not be subject to the time restrictions set forth herein. Once posted, it shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in violation of the reservation noted thereon. 
The public parking lot on the north side of Houston Street, west of, and adjacent to, Third Street 
This entire lot shall be designated as free parking with the north two parking rows restricted with a two-hour time limit. All remaining parking rows shall be unrestricted as to the amount of time a vehicle can remain parked therein. The time limits on this lot shall only be applicable on Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
The public parking lots on the north side of Laramie Street, west of, and adjacent to, 12 th Street 
These entire lots shall be designated as free parking with a two-hour time limit. The time limits on this lot shall only apply on Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
The public parking lot on the west side of North Manhattan Avenue, north of, and adjacent to, Laramie Street 
This entire lot shall be designated as free parking with a two-hour time limit. The time limits on this lot shall only apply on Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
The public parking lot on the south side of the 1200 Block of Bluemont Avenue 
The entire lot shall be designated as free parking with a two-hour time limit. The time limits on this lot shall only apply on Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
The public parking lot on the north side of the 1100 Block of Moro Street 
The entire lot shall be designated as free parking with a two-hour time limit. The time limits on this lot shall only apply on Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
The public parking lot on the south and east sides of 227 Blue Earth Place 
The 34 parking stalls in the center aisle on the south side and eight parking stalls immediately east of the drive thru lane of 227 Blue Earth Place shall be designated as free parking with a two-hour time limit. The time limits on this lot shall only apply on Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
The public parking lot adjacent to Town Center Mall 
The entire lot is designated as free parking and shall not be restricted as to the amount of time within which a vehicle may be parked. However, it is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on this parking lot between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. except for government vehicles, vehicles making deliveries to the stores located in Town Center Mall, vehicles used in cleaning, snow removal or maintenance of the parking lot or Town Center Mall, or vehicles with lawful permits issued and displayed pursuant to section 31-70 of this Code. 
The public parking lot at the Manhattan Municipal Court Building 
It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on this parking lot between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. except for government vehicles and other vehicles authorized by the city. 
(b)  The city engineer or his/her designee is hereby authorized to post stop signs, yield signs, signs and other markers denoting no parking areas, reduced speed zone signs and markers and such other traffic control devices at all locations as he/she may deem necessary and appropriate within the boundaries of any parking lot owned by the city or other publicly owned parking lot within the city. From and after the placement of such traffic control devices, it shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked in violation of such posted traffic control devices and any violation thereof and the penalty therefore shall be as prescribed for such violation by the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities, as adopted and amended by the city. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15; Ord. No. 7334, § 1, 1-8-18; Ord. No. 7355, § 2, 6-5-18) 
Sec. 31-53. - No parking during designated times zones. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection except that this prohibition shall not apply on Sundays. 
Browning Avenue 
The east side of Browning Avenue between a point 150 feet north of the centerline of Claflin Road at the intersection of Claflin Road and the east side of Browning Avenue and a point 200 feet south of the centerline of Dickens Avenue at the intersection of Dickens Avenue and the east side of Browning Avenue. 
College Avenue 
The west side of College Avenue between Dickens Avenue and Hobbs Drive. 
College Heights Road 
The northerly side of College Heights Road beginning at a point 75 feet westerly of the west back of curb of the intersection of the northerly side of College Heights Road and College Avenue thence westerly 225 feet to a point 300 feet westerly of said west back of curb of College Avenue. 
Dickens Avenue 
The south side of Dickens Avenue beginning at the west back of curb at its intersection with Beechwood Terrace west to its intersection with Seth Child Road. 
Juliette Avenue 
The east side of Juliette Avenue between Leavenworth Street and Humboldt Street. 
The west side of Juliette Avenue between Houston Street and Colorado Street. 
Poyntz Avenue 
The north side of Poyntz Avenue between North 9 th Street and North 10 th Street. 
The south side of the 900 block of Poyntz Avenue. 
Sunset Avenue 
The east side of Sunset Avenue between Sunset Lane and Delaware Avenue. 
Yuma Street 
The south side of Yuma Street between South 8 th Street and South 10 th Street. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection from 3:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. 
Laramie Street 
The north and south sides of Laramie Street between North 11 th Street and North 12 th Street. 
Old Anderson Avenue 
The south side of Old Anderson Avenue, which is located in Aggieville and referred to as the Old Anderson Avenue cutoff, between North Manhattan Avenue and Anderson Avenue. 
Poyntz Avenue 
The north and south sides of Poyntz Avenue between 3 rd Street and 6 th Street. 
12 th Street 
The east and west sides of North 12 th Street between Laramie Street and Bluemont Avenue. 
The east side of North 12 th Street beginning at the south back-of-curb of the intersection of the east side of North 12 th Street and Laramie Street thence south 180 feet to the north back-of-curb of the intersection of the east side of North 12 th Street and the alley between Laramie Street and Fremont Street. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection from 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. 
Manhattan Avenue 
The east side of North Manhattan Avenue between Laramie Street and Bluemont Avenue. 
Moro Street 
The north and south sides of Moro Street between 11 th Street and North Manhattan Avenue. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
Stratton Circle 
The entire south side of Stratton Circle. 
(e)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection from 12:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. 
Pioneer Lane 
The north and west side of Pioneer Lane between Sunnyslope Lane and a point 145 feet north of the extended south property line of Lot 7 of the Revised Plat of the Campus View Addition to the City of Manhattan, Riley County, Kansas. 
(f)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. on any day when school is in session. 
Hobbs Drive 
The north side of Hobbs Drive between Browning Avenue and Vaughn Drive. 
8 th Street 
The west side of 8 th Street between Vattier Street and Bluemont Avenue. 
(g)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. 
14 th Street 
The west side of North 14 th Street between Poyntz Avenue and Fairchild Avenue. 
(h)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday. 
Legore Lane 
The east and west sides and northern terminus of Legore Lane between the northern terminus of Legore Lane and Claflin Road. 
(i)  It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked on any street in the locations specified in this subsection from 12:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. on Sunday. 
Poyntz Avenue 
The north side of Poyntz Avenue between the east back-of-curb of the intersection of the north side of Poyntz Avenue and 8 th Street and a point 120 feet east of said east back-of-curb of 8 th Street. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15; Ord. No. 7271, § 1, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 31-54. - No parking at any time zones. 
    It is unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or owned or operated by such person to be stopped, stood or parked at any time on any street in the following locations: 
Allen Road 
Both sides of Allen Road between Casement Road and Tuttle Creek Boulevard. 
Allison Avenue 
Both sides of Allison Avenue between its northernmost intersection with North Dondee Drive and its easternmost intersection with Stagg Hill Road near the intersection of Kansas Highway 18 and Kansas Highway 113. 
The west side of Allison Avenue between its northernmost intersection with North Dondee Drive and its southernmost intersection with Stagg Hill Road. 
Amherst Avenue 
The entire north and west side of Amherst Avenue. 
The south and east side of Amherst Avenue between the intersection of the south and east side of Amherst Avenue with Miller Parkway and a point 75 feet southeasterly of the centerline of E.J. Frick Drive at the intersection of E.J. Frick Drive and the south and east side of Amherst Avenue. 
The south and east side of Amherst Avenue between points 160 feet westerly and 50 feet easterly of the centerline of Notre Dame Circle at the intersection of Notre Dame Circle and the south and east side of Amherst Avenue. 
The south and east side of Amherst Avenue between points 100 feet westerly and 70 feet easterly of the centerline of Harvard Place at the intersection of Harvard Place and the south and east side of Amherst Avenue. 
The south and east side of Amherst Avenue between points 250 feet westerly and 325 feet northeasterly of the centerline of Yale Circle at the intersection of Yale Circle and the south and east side of Amherst Avenue. 
The south and east side of Amherst Avenue between points 155 feet southwesterly and 90 feet northeasterly of the centerline of South Dartmouth Drive at the intersection of South Dartmouth Drive and the south and east side of Amherst Avenue. 
The south and east side of Amherst Avenue between a point 110 feet southwesterly of the centerline of Research Drive at the intersection of Research Drive and the south and east side of Amherst Avenue and the eastern terminus of Amherst Avenue. 
Anderson Avenue 
Both sides of Anderson Avenue between North Manhattan Avenue and the west city limits, except diagonal parking is allowed on the south side of Old Anderson Avenue, which is located in Aggieville and referred to as the Old Anderson Avenue cutoff, and parallel parking is allowed on the north side of Old Anderson Avenue, which is located in Aggieville and referred to as the Old Anderson Avenue cutoff. 
Ardmore Drive 
The west side of Ardmore Drive beginning at the intersection of Players Terrace and Players Circle proceeding south and east to the cul-de-sac. 
Back Nine Circle 
The entire west side of Back Nine Circle except for that portion contained within the circular cul-de-sac. 
Bakers Way Avenue 
The south side of Bakers Way Avenue between the east back-of-curb of its intersection with North Manhattan Avenue and a point 428 feet east of said east back of curb of North Manhattan Avenue. 
The north side of Bakers Way beginning 604 feet east of its intersection with North Manhattan Avenue and a point 180 feet east if said east back of curb of North Manhattan Avenue.

The east side of Beechwood Terrace between the north back-of-curb of its intersection with Claflin Road and a point 475 feet north of said north back-of-curb of Claflin Road. 
The west side of Beechwood Terrace between the north back-of-curb of its intersection with Claflin Road and a point 118 feet north of said north back-of-curb of Claflin Road. 
The west side of Beechwood Terrace beginning 230 feet north of the intersection with Claflin proceeding north 50 feet. 
Bellerive Drive 
The west side of Bellerive Drive between Tobacco Road and Players Terrace. 
Bent Wood Drive 
The entire north side of Bent Wood Drive. 
Bertrand Street 
The south side of Bertrand Street between North Manhattan Avenue and Juliette Avenue.

The east side of Blueline Circle between the south back-of-curb of its intersection with Buttonwood Drive and a point 220 feet south of said south back-of-curb of Buttonwood Drive. 
Bluemont Avenue 
Both sides of Bluemont Avenue between Hayes Drive and North Manhattan Avenue. 
Bluemont Drive 
The east side of Bluemont Drive between Ehler Road and Bluemont Circle. 
Bluemont Scenic Drive 
The south side of Bluemont Scenic Drive between Ehlers Road and Spring Hill Lane.

Brianna Court 
The entire inside radius of Brianna Court. 
Brook Lane 
The entire inside northerly radius of Brook Lane between both of the intersections of Brook Lane and Butterfield Road. 
The west side of Brook Lane between the intersection of Brook Lane and Butterfield Road and the intersection of Brook Lane and Brooklawn Drive.

The east side of Brookhaven Drive between Brookmont Drive and Brooklawn Drive.

The entire southerly side of Brooklawn Drive between Brook Lane and Brookmont Drive.

The east side of Brookpark Drive between Northfield Road and Walters Drive.

The south side of Brookmont Drive between the intersection of Brookmont Drive and Brook Lane and the intersection of Brookmont Drive and Brooklawn Drive.

The south side of Brookridge Drive between Brookville West Drive and Brookville Drive.

The south side of Brookstone Circle between the east back-of-curb of its intersection with Brookville Drive and a point 165 feet east of said east back of curb of Brookville Drive. 
Brookstone Drive 
The north side of Brookstone Drive between Brookpark Drive and Brookville Drive. 
Brookville Drive and Brookville West Drive 
The east side of Brookville West Drive between the intersection of Brookville West Drive and Walters Drive and the transition of Brookville West Drive to Brookville Drive and continuing thence along the south and westerly side of Brookville Drive between the transition of Brookville West Drive to Brookville Drive and the intersection of Brookville Drive and Northfield Road.

The north side of Brookway Drive between Brookville West Drive and Brookpark Drive.

The west side of Browning Avenue between Claflin Road and Kimball Avenue.

Sec. 31-55. - Fine for parking violations and appearance procedure; administrative processing fee. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of sections 31-51, 31-52, 31-53 or 31-54 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, including any violation of Article 13 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities, as adopted and amended by the city, that is based upon the parking restrictions contained within and signage erected pursuant to said sections 31-51, 31-52, 31-53 or 31-54, shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined $15.00. If a violator of sections 31-51, 31-52, 31-53 or 31-54 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, including any violator of the provisions of Article 13 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities referenced above, does not appear in court in response to a traffic citation affixed to such motor vehicle within five business days following the issuance of the citation, an administrative processing fee of $10.00 shall become due and payable accompanying the citation and the clerk of the court shall send to the owner of the motor vehicle to which the traffic citation was affixed a letter informing the owner of the violation and administrative fee, and warning the owner that an additional administrative processing fee of $25.00 shall be applied to the citation if the violator does not appear in court on or before the date stated in the letter and a warrant for their arrest shall be issued. If a violator of this sections 31-51, 31-52, 31-53 or 31-54 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, including any violator of the provisions of Article 13 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities referenced above, does not appear in court in response to a traffic citation affixed to such motor vehicle within ten days following the issuance of the letter informing the owner of the violation and administrative fees, an additional administrative processing fee of $25.00 shall become due and payable accompanying the citation. As provided in K.S.A. 8-2118, payment of the fine and any administrative processing fee shall be deemed an appearance before the court, waiver of right to trial and plea of no contest. A fine established by this section may be paid by depositing an envelope that contains information identifying the citation and violator, payment of the total fine and any other documentation required by the court in any box marked for such purposes established by the city upon public property within the city. However, payment of any fine and administrative processing fee established by this section must be made directly to the clerk of the court after the initial administrative processing fee of $10.00 shall become due and payable accompanying the citation pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15; Ord. No. 7367, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 31-56. - Failure to appear regarding parking citation; fine. 
    It is unlawful for any person issued a citation for a violation of the provisions of this division of chapter 31 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas or Article 13 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities, as adopted and amended by the city, to fail to comply with that citation. Failure to comply with a citation means failure either to: 
(1)  Appear before the municipal court in response to a citation and pay in full any fine, administrative fee and/or court costs imposed; or 
(2)  Otherwise comply with a citation as provided in K.S.A. 8-2118, and amendments thereto. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined $25.00. However, because this section is part of the city's ordinances prohibiting or restricting the parking of motor vehicles within the city no court costs for the administration of justice shall be assessed regarding any violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Secs. 31-57-31-69. - Reserved. 
Division 3 - PUBLIC PARKING LOT PERMITS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- See editor's note to div. 1. 

Sec. 31-70. - "Purple zone" parking permits for city parking lots in the C-4 zoning district. 
(a)  Any person leasing or owning residential real estate within the C-4 zoning district, as defined in the City of Manhattan Zoning Regulations, is eligible to apply for one or more resident parking permits. Each resident parking permit allows and shall be used only for the parking of the vehicle identified in the permit overnight between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. in any parking lot owned and operated by the City of Manhattan, Kansas located in the C-4 zoning district even if it is otherwise unlawful to continuously park vehicles overnight between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. in any such parking lot. 
(b)  Applications for resident parking permits under this section shall be submitted to the city clerk's office or his/her designee on a form provided by the city clerk or his/her designee and shall be accompanied by a fee of $5.00 per permit and proof of the ownership of or the lease agreement for real estate within the C-4 zoning district. 
(c)  The granting of all permits under this section depends upon available parking lot space. Each resident parking permit issued under this section shall be issued for a specific vehicle. Each resident parking permit shall expire on December 31 of the year for which it is issued, but it shall expire earlier than December 31 when the user of the vehicle identified in the residential parking permit no longer resides at, or owns, the property for which the permit is issued. All permits issued prior to January 1, 2010 shall expire on December 31, 2009, except for 2010 permits issued in advance. 
(d)  Any person who is eligible to obtain a resident parking permit under the terms of this section may also obtain up to two guest parking permits depending on available parking lot space. A guest parking permit shall be requested on an application form provided by the city clerk or his/her designee, and such form shall be accompanied by a $5.00 fee per permit. Any guest parking permit granted under the terms of this section allows and shall be used only for the parking of any one vehicle by temporary bona fide guests of the property for which the permit is issued overnight between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. in any parking lot owned and operated by the City of Manhattan, Kansas, located in the C-4 zoning district even if it is otherwise unlawful to continuously park vehicles overnight between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. in any such parking lot. Each guest permit shall expire on December 31 of the year for which it is issued, but it shall expire earlier than December 31 when the person who obtained the permit no longer resides at, or owns, the property for which the permit is issued. All guest permits issued prior to January 1, 2010, shall expire on December 31, 2009, except for 2010 permits issued in advance. 
(e)  Each permit granted pursuant to this section shall be in a form designed by the city clerk or his/her designee and shall be prominently displayed on the vehicle parked as required by the city clerk or his/her designee. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to continue to use a permit after its validity has expired. It shall further be unlawful for any person to fraudulently obtain or use a permit or to allow another person to fraudulently obtain or use a permit. 
(g)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than $15.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 6-16-15)
