NO. 15. PLUMBERS' EXAMINING BOARD, FEES [17] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-1503 AND K.S.A. 12-1504 IN ITS ENTIRETY AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT RELATING TO PLUMBING REGULATIONS. 
NO. 16. CEREAL MALT BEVERAGES RETAILER'S LICENSE [18] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 41-2702, AS AMENDED. 
NO. 17. PAWNBROKERS AND PRECIOUS METAL DEALERS [19] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 16-707(c), AS AMENDED. 
NO. 18. COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS OF GOVERNING BODY [20] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-1008, WHICH LIMITS THE COMPENSATION PAID TO MEMBERS OF THE GOVERNING BODY, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVE PROVISIONS THEREFORE. 
NO. 19. PAWNBROKERS AND PRECIOUS METAL DEALERS 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE REPEALING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 17. OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, AND EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K. S. A. 16-707(c), AS AMENDED. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. That Charter Ordinance No. 17 of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, be and the same is hereby repealed. 
    Section 2. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself, from, and makes inapplicable to it, Section 16-707(c) of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, which is not applicable uniformly to all cities. 
    Section 3. In place of K. S. A. 16-707(c), the governing body of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, hereby enacts the following: 
The license application shall be in a form approved by the Attorney General. Each application shall be accompanied by a fee of $25.00 for a precious metal dealer's license or $100.00 for a pawnbroker's license or $100.00 for a combination precious metal dealer's and pawnbroker's license which shall be paid annually upon renewal of the license. The full amount of the license fee shall be paid regardless of the time of year the application is made and the licensee shall only operate under the license for the remainder of the calendar year for which the license is issued. All such fees received by the City Clerk shall be deposited in the city general fund. 
    Section 4. That Section 19-39 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Manhattan is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    Section 19-39. Pawnbrokers and Precious Dealers. 
    The annual license fee for pawnbrokers and a combination pawnbroker/precious metal dealer shall be $100.00. The annual license fee for precious metal dealers shall be $25.00. 
    Section 5. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 6. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after the final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAT [THAN] TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 1ST DAY OF NOVEMBER, 1983. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS 
/s/       
BY: Wanda L. Fateley, Mayor 
(SEAL) 
ATTEST: 
/s/ Gregg W. Gibson, City Clerk 
NO. 20. TAX LEVIES 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE REPEALING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 14. OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, AND EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K. S. A. 79-1951 REGARDING MILL LEVY LIMITATION FOR LIBRARY PURPOSES AND PROVIDING A SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISION ON THE SAME SUBJECT. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. That Charter Ordinance No. 14 of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, be and the same is herby repealed. 
    Section 2. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, a city of the first class of less than 50,000 population, by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt and exempts itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, that portion of K. S. A. 79-1951 regarding a mill levey limitation for library purposes, said statute not being applicable uniformly to all cities of the first class and the legislature not having established classes of cities for the purpose of imposing tax limitations and prohibitions. 
    Section 3. The Governing Body of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, hereby provides the following substitute and additional provisions to that portion of K. S. A. 79-1951 regarding mill levy limitation for library purposes: The Governing Body of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is hereby authorized and empowered to levy taxes each year of [for] Library Purposes at a rate not in excess of six (6.00) mills on each dollar of assessed tangible valuation of the said city. 
    Section 4. The Governing Body of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, does not exempt itself from the remaining provisions of said K. S. A. 79-1951. 
    Section 5. This Ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city paper, the Manhattan Mercury. 
    Section 6. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after the final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED by the Governing Body, not less than two-thirds of the members elect voting in favor thereof, on the fifteenth day of May, 1984. 
/s/ _____
David J. Fiser, Mayor 
(SEAL) 
ATTEST: 
/s/ Gregg W. Gibson, City Clerk 
NO. 21. CEREAL MALT BEVERAGE 
RETAILER'S LICENSE [21] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K. S. A. 41-2702, AS AMENDED. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, Section 41-2702 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, which is not applicable uniformly to all cities of the first class. 
    Section 2. Charter Ordinance No. 16 of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is hereby repealed. 
    Section 3. In place of K. S. A. 41-2702, the governing body of the City of Manhattan, hereby enacts the following ordinance: 
A.  No retailer shall sell any cereal malt beverage within the City of Manhattan, without having first secured a license for each place of business as herein provided. The application for said license shall be made to the City Clerk and shall be approved by the governing body. 
B.  An application for a retailer's license shall be verified and upon a form prepared by the Attorney General of the State and shall contain: 
(1)  The name and residence of the applicant; 
(2)  The length of time that the applicant has resided within the State of Kansas; 
(3)  The particular place of business for which a license is desired; 
(4)  The name of the owner of the premises upon which the place of business is located; 
(5)  A statement that the applicant is a citizen of the United States and not less than twenty-one (21) years of age, and that the applicant has not within two years immediately preceding the date of making application been convicted of a felony, any crime involving moral turpitude, drunkenness, driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or violation of any other intoxicating liquor law of any state or of the United States. 
C.  Each application for a retailer's license shall be accompanied by a fee as follows: 
(1)  For licensure of a place of business to sell cereal malt beverage for consumption on the premises: $250.00. 
(2)  For licensure to sell only cereal malt beverages in original and unopened containers and not for consumption on the premises: $100.00. 
(3)  The full amount of the license fee shall be paid regardless of the time of the year the application is made and the licensee shall only operate under the license for the remainder of the calendar year for which the license is issued. No rebate or return of any portion of the license fee shall be made in case the license is revoked for any cause provided for by law. 
    Section 4. The City Clerk may, upon presentation of a regular and complete application for a cereal malt beverage license by a fully qualified applicant and payment of the license fee, issue a temporary license to the applicant, said temporary license being valid as a regular license until the completion of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the governing body of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, or twenty-one (21) days, whichever period is shorter. Said temporary license shall only be issued by the City Clerk if all codes of the City of Manhattan concerning the proposed licensed premises have been complied with. 
    Section 5. All ordinances of the City of Manhattan governing the issuance, suspension or revocation of cereal malt beverage licenses, except those in conflict with this ordinance, shall remain in full force and effect. 
    Section 6. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper, The Manhattan Mercury. 
    Section 7. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after the final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 2ND DAY OF OCTOBER, 1984. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS 
/s/ _____
BY: David J. Fiser, Mayor 
(SEAL) 
ATTEST: 
/s/ Gregg W. Gibson, City Clerk 
NO. 22. PLUMBERS' EXAMINING BOARD, FEES 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K. S. A. 12-1503 AND K. S. A. 12-1504 IN ITS ENTIRETY AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT RELATING TO PLUMBING REGULATIONS. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, the provisions of K. S. A. 12-1503 and K. S. A. 12-1504 in its entirety which applies to this city, but not uniformly to all cities in the State of Kansas. 
    Section 2. That in place of K. S. A. 12-1503, the City hereby adopts the following and hereby amends Section 8-116 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, to read as follows: 
    Sec. 8-116. Plumbers' examining board. 
    The board shall be comprised of the plumbing members from the code appeals board and the Building Official. This board shall designate the type of examination of all applicants desiring to engage in or work at plumbing or drainlaying work within their jurisdiction. 
    Section 3. That in place of K. S. A. 12-1504, the City hereby adopts the following and amends Section 8-119 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Manhattan, Kansas, to read as follows: 
    Section 8-119. Fees. 
    (a) The following fees for examinations and renewal of certificates under this division shall apply: 
(1)  Master plumber: 
a.  Certification or renewal, per year ..... $20.00 
b.  Examination (without certification fee), per exam ..... 20.00 
(2)  Journeyman plumber: 
a.  Certification or renewal, per year ..... $10.00 
b.  Examination (without certification fee), per exam ..... 20.00 
(3)  Master drainlayer: 
a.  Certification or renewal, per year ..... $20.00 
b.  Examination (without certification fee), per exam ..... 20.00 
(4)  Journeyman drainlayer: 
a.  Certification or renewal, per year ..... $10.00 
b.  Examination (without certification fee), per exam ..... 20.00 
    (b) All such fees shall be paid to the building official and shall become a part of the general fund. The master and journeyman plumber on the board shall each receive five dollars ($5.00) for each test that they shall grade. 
    Section 4. Charter Ordinance No. 15 is hereby repealed. 
    Section 5. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 6. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, THIS 7TH DAY OF JANUARY, 1986. 
/s/ _____

Suzanne Lindamood, Mayor 
(SEAL) 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 

Heide Clark, City Clerk 
NO. 23. TRANSIENT GUEST TAX 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM CERTAIN PORTIONS OF K.S.A. 12-1697. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself, from, and makes inapplicable to it, that portion of K.S.A. 12-1697, which authorizes the levy of a transient guest tax at not to exceed the rate of two percent (2%) upon the gross receipts derived from or paid by transient guests for sleeping accommodations exclusive of charges for incidental services or facilities in any hotel, motel or tourist court. Said statute not being uniformly applicable to all cities in Kansas. 
    Section 2. In place of that portion of K.S.A. 12-1697 referred to above, the governing body of the city of Manhattan, Kansas, is hereby authorized to levy a transient guest tax at not to exceed the rate of three percent (3%) upon the gross receipts derived from or paid by transient guests for sleeping accommodations exclusive of charges for incidental services or facilities in any hotel, motel, or tourist court. 
    Section 3. All other provisions of K. S. A. 12-1697 shall remain the same. 
    Section 4. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 5. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 7TH DAY OF JANUARY, 1986. 
/s/ _____

Susanne Lindamood, Mayor 
(SEAL) 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 

Heide Clark, City Clerk 
NO. 24. COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS OF GOVERNING BODY [22] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K. S. A. 12-1008, WHICH LIMITS THE COMPENSATION PAID TO MEMBERS OF THE GOVERNING BODY, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVE PROVISIONS THEREFOR. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, Section 12-1008 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, which is not applicable uniformly to all cities of the first class. 
    Section 2. The members of the governing body of the City of Manhattan shall, from and after the effective date of this ordinance, receive salaries in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month, payable in monthly installments. 
    Section 3. Charter Ordinance No. 18 is hereby repealed. 
    Section 4. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 5. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after the final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon.

NO. 25. COURT COSTS IN MUNICIPAL COURT 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-4112, CONCERNING COURT COSTS IN MUNICIPAL COURT, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVES THEREFOR. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, the provisions of K.S.A. 12-4112. 
    Section 2. Whenever a defendant, in a case before the municipal court of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is either convicted of a violation of a municipal ordinance or ordinances or enters into a diversion agreement concerning a violation thereof, said defendant shall be assessed court costs in the sum of twenty-eight dollars ($28.00). Said sum shall be in addition to any fine that is imposed by the court for said violations. 
    Section 3. The provisions of section 2 of this ordinance shall not apply to convictions for the violation of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting the parking of motor vehicles within the city. 
    Section 4. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 5. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 2ND DAY OF SEPTEMBER, 1986. 
/s/ _____

J. Eric (Rick) Mann, Mayor 
(SEAL) 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 

Heide Clark, City Clerk 
NO. 26. PUBLIC BUILDING COMMISSION 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM VARIOUS SECTIONS OF THE PUBLIC BUILDING COMMISSION ACT. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, certain sections of the Public Building Commission Act (K.S.A. 12-1757 et seq.), hereinafter referred to as the "Act." Said Act not being applicable uniformly to all cities of the first class. 
    Section 2. That the city does hereby exempt itself from the following sections of said Act: 
K.S.A. 12-1758; K.S.A. 12-1759; K.S.A. 12-1760; K.S.A. 12-1763; K.S.A. 12-1764; and K.S.A. 12-1767. 
The balance of the Act shall remain in full force and effect as to the City of Manhattan, except that when the word "Act" is used in the statute it shall also mean and refer to this ordinance where applicable. 
    Section 3. In place of K.S.A. 12-1758; K.S.A. 12-1759; K.S.A. 12-1760; K.S.A. 12-1763; K.S.A. 12-1764; and K.S.A. 12-1767, the governing body of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, hereby enacts the following ordinance: 
A.  The city, by ordinance, may create a public building commission as defined in the Act. Said building commission shall be for the purposes of acquiring a site or sites for, and constructing, reconstructing, equipping and furnishing a building or buildings or other facilities of a revenue-producing character, including parking facilities, or for purchasing or otherwise acquiring said building or buildings or facilities. Such building or buildings or facilities shall be maintained and operated for city offices, a county courthouse, county correctional facilities or jails, the housing and accommodation of county offices or county businesses, or such other purposes as are commonly carried on in connection with such facilities or in county courthouses or general city buildings, including administrative offices for school districts and housing, accommodations and parking facilities for offices of state and federal agencies. In addition to the above, the public building commission may acquire land and facilities, including leasehold interests therein, adjacent to or near Kansas State University, and may construct, reconstruct, equip and furnish such facilities on such land, and lease or sublease such land and facilities to any board of trustees of Kansas State University or to the official governing body of said university. 
B.  The ordinance creating the building commission shall specify the purposes and functions of said public building commission and shall specify the number of members for the governing body of such commission, which shall not be fewer than three nor more than nine. 
C.  The public building commission created by the city shall have the power to do all things necessary or incidental to the purpose of constructing or acquiring or enlarging, furnishing and equipping and operating and maintaining buildings to be made available for use by governmental agencies. In addition, the public building commission shall have authority to transfer fee simple title to the real estate, once all bonds issued pursuant to the Act have been retired, to the city or such other governmental entity that requested construction of the facility in the first place. 
D.  The public building commission created by the city shall have the authority to rent all or any part of its buildings or other facilities to any federal, state or county governmental agency, or any municipal corporation, quasi municipal corporation, political subdivision or body politic, or agency thereof doing business, maintaining an office or rendering a public service in the county seat or county in which the commission was organized and to rent any space as may be needed by such governmental agencies for such service facilities as such public building commission may determine will primarily service the comfort and convenience of the occupants of its buildings or other facilities. In addition, if the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a tenant of any building or facility owned by the public building commission, the city shall have the authority to sublease all or any portion of such building or facility to any other governmental agency or to any private entity. However, if the City of Manhattan, Kansas, chooses to sublease all or any part of such building to a private entity, the governing body of the city shall determine that the portion so subleased to a private entity is not needed for any public purpose of the city. The public building commission established by the city shall have the power to acquire the fee simple title to real property, or a leasehold interest in real property, including easements and reversionary interest in the streets, alleys and other public places and personal property required for its purposes, by purchase, gift, devise or by exercise of the power of eminent domain of the state, and the title thereto shall be taken in the corporate name of the commission. The corporate name of the commission so created shall be the Manhattan Public Building Commission. 
E.  Any revenue bonds authorized by the Act shall be issued as provided in K.S.A. 10-1201 et seq., and amendments thereto, except to the extent that such statutes are in conflict with the Act. 
    Section 4. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 5. This is a Charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after the final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (C)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 20th DAY OF October, 1987. 
/s/ _____

E. A. Klingler, Mayor 
(SEAL) 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 

Heide Clark, City Clerk 
NO. 27. TRANSIENT GUEST TAX [23] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM CERTAIN PORTIONS OF K.S.A. 12-1697 AND FROM K.S.A. 12-1698(d). 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and, by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, that portion of K.S.A. 12-1697 which authorizes the levy of a transient guest tax at not to exceed the rate of two percent upon the gross receipts derived from or paid by transient guests for sleeping accommodations, exclusive of charges for incidental services or facilities, in any hotel, motel or tourist court. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, also hereby elects to exempt and does hereby exempt itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, K.S.A. 12-1698(d). Said statutes not being uniformly applicable to all cities in Kansas. 
    Section 2. In place of that portion of K.S.A. 12-1697 referred to above, the governing body of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is hereby authorized to levy a transient guest tax at not to exceed the rate of five percent upon the gross receipts derived from or paid by transient guests for sleeping accommodations, exclusive of charges for incidental services or facilities, in hotel, motel or tourist court. 
    Section 3. In place of K.S.A. 12-1698(d), the following shall apply to the City of Manhattan, Kansas: 
All such monies received by the city treasurer from disbursements from the city transient guest tax fund shall be credited to the tourism and convention promotion fund of the city and shall be used for all or any portion of programs, projects, activities, municipal services or public improvements which the governing body of the city has determined are related to the promotion, enhancement, advancement or retention of tourism and conventions to the City of Manhattan, Kansas, including the payments of principal and interest on bonds issued for such purposes. 
    Section 4. All other provisions of K.S.A. 12-1697 and K.S.A. 12-1698 shall remain the same. 
    Section 5. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 6. This is a Charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 18TH DAY OF APRIL, 1989. 
/s/ ;hg; _____
Kent Glasscock, Mayor 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 
Curt Wood, Acting City Clerk 
(SEAL) 
NO. 28. MUNICIPAL COURT COSTS 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-4112, CONCERNING COURT COSTS IN MUNICIPAL COURT, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVES THEREFORE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself, from, and makes inapplicable to it, the provisions of K.S.A. 12-4112. 
    Section 2. Whenever a defendant, in a case before the Municipal Court of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is either convicted of a violation of a municipal ordinance or ordinances, or enters into a diversion agreement concerning a violation thereof, said defendant shall be assessed court costs in the sum of twenty-nine dollars and fifty cents ($29.50). Said sum shall be in addition to any fine that is imposed by the court for said violations. 
    Section 3. The provisions of Section 2 of this ordinance shall not apply to convictions for the violation of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting the parking of motor vehicles within the city. 
    Section 4. The amount of court costs set forth in Section 2 may be amended by ordinary ordinance from and after the effective date of this charter ordinance. 
    Section 5. All prior charter ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
    Section 6. This ordinance shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 7. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 4TH DAY OF JUNE, 1991.

NO. 30. MUNICIPAL COURT COSTS 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-4112, CONCERNING COURT COSTS IN MUNICIPAL COURT, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVES THEREFORE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself from, and makes inapplicable to it the provisions of K.S.A. 12-4112. 
    Section 2. Whenever a defendant, in a case before the Municipal Court of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is either convicted of a violation of a municipal ordinance, or ordinances, or enters into a Diversion Agreement concerning a violation thereof, said defendant shall be assessed court costs in the sum of forty-five dollars ($45.00), or such sum as shall be established by ordinary ordinance adopted after the effective date of this charter ordinance. Said sum shall be in addition to any fine that is imposed by the court for said violations. 
    Section 3. The provisions of Section 2 of this ordinance shall not apply to convictions for the violation of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting the parking of motor vehicles within the city. 
    Section 4. All previous charter ordinances, or ordinary ordinances, in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
    Section 5. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 6. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case, the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 1ST DAY OF OCTOBER, 1996. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN,

SYDNEY CARLIN, Mayor

RICHARD L. DOAN, City Clerk 
(SEAL) 
NO. 31. SEWER SYSTEM(S) 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF THE WATER POLLUTION ACT, K.S.A. 12-3101 THROUGH K.S.A. 12-3107, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE ESTABLISHMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SEWER SYSTEMS, AND TO THE ESTABLISHMENT OF CERTAIN FEES RELATED THERETO, AND TO THE ISSUANCE OF BONDS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PAYING FOR THE GROUNDS AND IMPROVEMENTS NECESSARY FOR THE OPERATION OF SUCH SYSTEMS. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, by virtue of the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt itself and hereby makes inapplicable to it Section 12-3101, 12-3102, 12-3103, 12-3104, 12-3105, 12-3106 and 12-3107, Kansas Statutes Annotated, which apply to said city and the city provides further substitute and additional provisions as set forth herein. 
    Section 2. Definitions. For the purpose of this charter ordinance, the words and phrases "sewer", "sewer system" or "sewer systems" shall mean sanitary and/or storm sewers that exist at the time this charter ordinance is adopted or that are hereafter established and all appurtenances necessary in the maintenance and operation of the same, including, but not limited to, pumping stations, sewage treatment plants, main sewers, intercepting sewers, outfall sewers, surface drains, channels, rivers, streams and other flood control facilities and works for the collection, transportation, pumping, treating, and disposing of water carried wastes or storm of surface waters. 
    Section 3. Sewer systems; powers of municipality. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, shall have all the powers necessary or convenient to plan, alter, enlarge, extend, improve, construct, reconstruct, develop, redevelop, operate and maintain a sewer system or sewer systems, including such powers as the City of Manhattan may, from time to time, establish by way of ordinances adopted by the governing body of the city and including, but not by way of limitation, the following powers: 
(a)  To impose service charges and connection fees on property served by the city's sewer system or sewer systems. The method of calculating and fixing such service charges and connection fees shall be as established by ordinances, rules or regulations heretofore or hereafter adopted, except that any fee related to storm water drainage shall be as established by this charter ordinance, and the city shall not alter or amend such fee except by charter ordinance. 
(b)  To provide that sewer service charges and connection fees authorized in subparagraph (a) above, or in subsequent sections of this charter ordinance, when delinquent, be certified by the clerk of the city to the county clerk of Riley or Pottawatomie County to be placed on the tax roll for collection, subject to the same penalties and to be collected in like manner as other taxes, and such charges shall, thereafter, constitute a lien upon the real estate served by the sewer system or sewer systems and against which such charges were made; 
(c)  To use the proceeds of the sewer service charges and connection fees authorized in subparagraph (a) above to plan, alter, enlarge, extend, improve, construct, reconstruct, develop, redevelop, operate and maintain a sewer system or sewer systems; 
(d)  To issue general obligation bonds or revenue bonds, as authorized by law, and to use the proceeds of the same to plan, alter, enlarge, extend, improve, construct, reconstruct, develop and redevelop a sewer system or sewer systems; 
(e)  To use the proceeds of the sewer service charges and connection fees authorized in subparagraph (a) above, or in subsequent sections of this charter ordinance, to pay the principal and interest on bonds heretofore or hereafter issued for the planning, altering, enlarging, extending, improving, constructing, reconstructing, developing, redeveloping, operating and maintaining of a sewer system or sewer systems; 
(f)  To contract with agencies of the federal government, public bodies of this state or other states, or with any private person or body for jointly planning, altering, enlarging, extending, improving, constructing, reconstructing, developing, redeveloping, operating and maintaining a sewer system or sewer systems; 
(g)  To contract with agencies of the federal government, public bodies of this state or other states or with any private person or body for receiving and treating sewage or stormwater from outside of the city limits of the city; 
(h)  To plan, alter, enlarge, extend, improve, construct, reconstruct, develop, redevelop, operate and maintain a sewer system or sewer systems outside of the city limits of the city and to have the right of eminent domain both inside and outside the city limits of the city in order to acquire land and right-of-way for a sewer system or sewer systems; 
(i)  To borrow money and to apply for and accept advances, loans, grants, contributions or any other form of financial assistance from the federal government, the state, county or any other public body for the purposes of this ordinance, and the city may, when contracting with the federal government for any such financial assistance, include in any such contract such conditions imposed pursuant to federal law as the city may deem reasonable and appropriate; 
(j)  To, under authority granted herein, establish a sanitary sewer system utility, a storm sewer system utility, and to combine its sanitary sewer system utility and storm sewer system utility and its water utility, into one or more utilities; and 
(k)  To establish a unified and consolidated billing system for its sanitary sewer system utility, its storm sewer system utility and its water utility, whether or not the same are combined as provided for in subparagraph (j) above. 
    Section 4. Same; rules and regulations authorized; billing and collection of sewer service charges; discontinuance of water service, when. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, shall have the power by ordinance or resolution to adopt rules and regulations that shall include, but not be limited to, providing for the management and operating of its sewer system or sewer systems, prohibiting the discharge into such sewer system or sewer systems of matter deleterious to the proper operation of the sewer system or sewer systems and the general health, safety and welfare of the community, establishing the types and characteristics of sewage and stormwater that may be discharged into the sewer system or sewer systems, establishing the method for calculating and fixing the service charges and connection fees for property served by the city's sewer system or sewer systems, requiring security for the payment thereof, and providing methods and rules of collection, and providing for the disposition of the revenue therefrom, except any fee related to storm water drainage shall be as established by this charter ordinance. In the event any person, firm, corporation, political unit or organization living or operating on property served by the city's sewer system or sewer systems shall neglect, fail or refuse to pay the service charges fixed by the governing body of the city, the city may, as authorized by rules and regulations adopted under the authority of this section and if a unified and consolidated billing system has been established, refuse the delivery of water through the pipes and mains of its publicly owned waterworks until such time as such charges are fully paid. 
    Section 5. Issuance of sewer system revenue bonds; requirements. 
(a)  The City of Manhattan, Kansas, shall have the power to issue revenue bonds from time to time in its discretion to finance the planning, altering, enlarging, extending, improving, constructing, and reconstructing of a sewer system or sewer systems under this ordinance. Such bonds shall be made payable, as to both principal and interest, solely from the income, proceeds, revenues, and funds of the city derived from or held in connection with its sewer system or sewer systems; provided, however, that payment of such bonds, both as to principal and interest, may be further secured by a pledge of any loan, grant or contribution from the federal government. 
(b)  Bonds issued under this section shall not constitute an indebtedness within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory debt limitation or restriction, and shall not be subject to the provisions of any other law relating to the authorization, issuance or sale of bonds. Bonds issued under the provisions of this charter ordinance are declared to be issued for an essential public and governmental purpose and, together with interest thereof and income therefrom, shall be exempted from all taxes. 
(c)  Bonds issued under this section shall be authorized by ordinance or resolution of the governing body and may be issued in one or more series and shall bear such date or dates, be payable on demand or mature at such time or times, bear interest at such rate or rates, not exceeding the maximum rate of interest prescribed by K.S.A. 10-1009, be in such denomination or denominations, be in such form, have such rank or priority, be executed in such manner, and be subject to such terms of redemption (with or without premium), be secured in such manner, and have such other characteristics as may be provided by such ordinance or resolution issued pursuant thereto. 
    Section 6. Same; powers supplemental and additional. The powers herein granted to plan, alter, enlarge, extend, improve, construct, reconstruct, develop, redevelop, operate and maintain a sewer system or sewer systems and to issue bonds shall be supplemental to and not amendatory of the provisions of all other laws and shall not be construed to limit the city's authority under the provisions of any other laws. 
    Section 7. Code amendment. That the Code of Ordinances of the City of Manhattan, Kansas is hereby amended, by amending, and replacing, in its entirety, Article IV of Chapter 32, as follows: 
ARTICLE IV. STORMWATER MANAGEMENT SYSTEM 
    Section 32-184. Creation of Storm Water Management System. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Charter Ordinance No. 31, the City of Manhattan does hereby establish a stormwater management system and declares its intention to operate, construct, maintain and repair such stormwater management system. It is hereby found, determined, and declared that the elements of the stormwater management system which provide for the collection, treatment and disposal of stormwater are of benefit, and provide services, to property within the incorporated City limits. The beneficiaries of the system include all real properties within the City which benefit by the provisions, operation and improvement of the system. Such benefits may include, but are not limited to, the provision of adequate systems of collection, conveyance, detention, treatment and release of stormwater, the reduction of hazard to property and life resulting from stormwater runoff, improvement in general health and welfare through reduction of undesirable stormwater conditions, and improvement to the water quality in the storm and surface water system and its receiving waters. 
    Section 32-185. Storm Drainage Fee. 
A.  There is hereby assessed against all property within the City that is connected to either the water or sanitary sewer systems, or both, of the City a monthly storm drainage fee. Such fee is based upon a determination, using accepted engineering principals, of a comparable amount of impervious area for uses within each rate category, as set forth hereinafter. The owner, occupant and any person who is responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall all be jointly and severally responsible for the payment of said fee. Persons responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall include the person responsible for payment for water provided to a master meter that is then distributed to multiple users, whether or not said users are located on the same property as the master meter. The fee shall be calculated as follows: 
1.  All property devoted to a residential use shall be assessed the sum of One Dollar and Ten Cents ($1.10) per month per living unit. The term "residential" shall include single family homes, mobile homes and mobile home parks, duplexes and apartment units. The term "residential" shall not include rooming and boarding houses, fraternities, sororities and similar facilities. The term "living unit" shall mean one or more rooms in a residential building which are arranged, designed, used or intended for use by one family, and which includes cooking space and lawful sanitary facilities reserved for the occupants thereof. 
2.  Property devoted to any use other than residential, as set forth above, shall be assessed a monthly fee based upon the number of square feet developed for that particular use, as follows: 
Less than or equal to 20,000 square feet ..... $ 5.20 
20,001 to 100,000 square feet ..... 25.00 
100,001 to 200,000 square feet ..... 50.00 
200,001 to 400,000 square feet ..... 100.00 
400,001 to 1,000,000 square feet ..... 208.00 
1,000,001 to 2,000,000 square feet ..... 390.00 
2,000,001 to 4,000,000 square feet ..... 710.00 
4,000,001 to 6,000,000 square feet ..... 870.00 
6,000,001 to 8,000,000 square feet ..... 1,000.00 
8,000,001 to 10,000,000 square feet ..... 1,100.00 
10,000,001 to 12,000,000 square feet ..... 1,160.00 
For all properties in excess of 12,000,000 square feet (275 acres) the fee shall be $4.23 multiplied by the number of acres in the property. 
3.  In determining the area of property developed for a particular use, the area measured shall include all property contiguous to the particular use, and under the same ownership, except that portion of said property that is both unimproved and legally subject to being subdivided from that portion actually devoted to the primary use. In situations where property is used in common with more than one use, the common area shall be included with each use in the same proportions as the area of each use bears to the area of the total of all uses. In situations where property is devoted to uses on more than one level, the area of the property shall be proportionately divided among the levels. 
B.  The revenue generated by this fee shall be set aside in a special fund to be used only for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of stormwater system facilities, including the acquisition, and related costs thereof, of real estate for such use. In addition, said fund may be used to pay fees to study and prepare documents related to such facilities, and to make payments of principal and interest on bonds issued for such improvements. Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to limit or restrict the City's ability to use and obtain other sources of funds for the same or similar purposes. 
C.  The monthly fees set forth above may be included as part of the monthly bill for water and sanitary sewer service, but shall be identified separately on said billing, said fees shall be due at the same time as water charges are due and the failure to pay said fees shall be considered a failure to pay water charges and enforceable pursuant to Section 32-51 of this Code. If the monthly fees are not included as part of a water or sewer bill, they shall be billed at least annually. In addition, anytime water service is established, or reestablished, to a property, all fees hereunder shall be paid current, as of the date such water service is established, or re-established. 
D.  1.  Any person who disagrees with the calculation of their storm drainage fee or, who believes that the actual amount of impervious area located upon their property justifies a reduction in the square footage of their property used to calculate the fee, in order to make their fee consistent with other uses with a similar amount of impervious area, may appeal the determination of their fee to the City Engineer. The appeal shall be in writing. The City Engineer shall thereafter hold an informal hearing. The City Engineer, prior to such hearing, may request that the appealing party provide information concerning the basis of the appeal, including a land survey showing dwelling units, total property area, and impervious area, as appropriate, if such information is deemed to be material by the City Engineer. Based upon information provided, the City Engineer shall make a determination of the storm drainage fee for such property. The City Engineer shall notify parties in writing of his/her decision. 
2.  A person shall have the right to appeal the decision of the City Engineer to a board comprised of the City Manager, or his designee, the Director of Public Works, and the Director of Community Development. Such appeal shall be made within 15 days of the date of the written decision of the City Engineer. Such appeal shall be in writing and filed with the City Engineer. A hearing on such appeal shall be held within 30 days from the date of filing and the applicant shall be given seven days advance notice of the time and date of such hearing. Within seven days after the conclusion of such hearing, the Board shall render a decision in writing that sets forth findings that support its decision. The decision of the Board shall be final and any further appeal of such decision shall be to the District Court pursuant to K.S.A. 60-2101(d). 
    Section 8. Nothing contained within this charter ordinance shall prohibit the governing body from the exercising authority granted hereunder by the adoption of simple ordinances enacted after the date hereof, including amendments to Article IV of Chapter 32 of the Code of Ordinances, except that no amendment to the storm drainage fee, as established by this charter ordinance shall occur except by a subsequent charter ordinance. 
    Section 9. This charter ordinance shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 10. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, or on July 1, 1997, whichever date is later, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed requiring a referendum to be held on this ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of the State of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective on July 1, 1997, or on the first day of the month following approval by a majority of the electors voting thereon, whichever date is later. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 17TH DAY OF DECEMBER, 1996. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN, 
/s/ _____

SYDNEY CARLIN, Mayor 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 

RICHARD L. DOAN, City Clerk 
(SEAL) 
NO. 32. CEREAL MALT BEVERAGES RETAILER'S LICENSE [24] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 41-2702, AS AMENDED. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, Section 41-2702 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, which is not applicable uniformly to all cities of the first class. 
    Section 2. Charter Ordinance No. 21 of the City of Manhattan, Kansas is hereby repealed. 
    Section 3. In place of K.S.A. 41-2702, the Governing Body of the City of Manhattan, hereby enacts the following ordinance: 
A.  No retailer shall sell any cereal malt beverage within the City of Manhattan, without having first secured a license for each place of business as herein provided. The application for said license shall be made to the City Clerk and shall be approved by the Governing Body. 
B.  An application for a retailer's license shall be verified and upon a form prepared by the Attorney General of the State and shall contain: 
1)  The name and residence of the applicant; 
2)  The length of time that the applicant has resided with the State of Kansas; 
3)  The particular place of business for which a license is desired; 
4)  The name of the owner of the premises upon which the place of business is located; 
5)  Statement that the applicant is a citizen of the United States and not less than twenty-one (21) years of age, and that the applicant has not within two (2) years immediately preceding the date of making application be convicted of a felony, any crime involving moral turpitude, drunkenness, driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or violation of any other intoxicating liquor law of any state or of the United States. 
C.  Each application for a retailer's license shall be accompanied by a fee as follows: 
1)  For licensure of a place of business to sell cereal malt beverage for consumption on the premises: $250.00. 
2)  For licensure to sell only cereal malt beverages in original and unopened containers and not for consumption on the premises: $100.00. 
D.  The term of such retailer's license shall be for a period of one (1) year from the date of issuance. Any person to whom a license has been issued may surrender such license to the City Clerk at such time as the license is no longer necessary, and may at such time request a prorated refund of the license fee paid hereunder. The City Clerk shall refund a prorated amount of the license fee paid hereunder. The City Clerk shall refund a prorated amount of the license fee based upon the number of unexpired whole months remaining in the license term from the date of surrender of the license. No such refund shall be applicable to any license that is revoked. 
    Section 4. The City Clerk may, upon presentation of a regular and complete application for a cereal malt beverage license by a fully qualified applicant and payment of the license fee, issue a temporary license to the applicant, said temporary license being valid as a regular license until the completion of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the governing body of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, or twenty-one (21) days, whichever period is shorter. Said temporary license shall only be issued by the City Clerk if all codes of the City of Manhattan concerning the proposed license premises have been complied with. 
    Section 5. All ordinances of the City of Manhattan governing the issuance, suspension or revocation of cereal malt beverage licenses, except those in conflict with this ordinance, shall remain in full force and effect. 
    Section 6. This ordinance shall be published once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper, The Manhattan Mercury. 
    Section 7. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after the final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THIS 6TH DAY OF JANUARY, 1998. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN, 
/s/ _____

BRUCE SNEAD, Mayor 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 

RICHARD L. DOAN, City Clerk 
NO. 33. QUORUM OF THE GOVERNING BODY 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 13-1810, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. Exemption. The City of Manhattan, by virtue of the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to and does exempt itself, and make inapplicable to it, K.S.A. 13-1810 which applies to this City, but does not apply uniformly to all Cities. 
    Section 2. Quorum. The quorum necessary for the transaction of business shall be either three (3) or four (4) members-elect of the governing body and shall be established by the governing body by ordinary ordinance; however, in the absence of a duly adopted ordinary ordinance, the quorum shall be four (4) members-elect of the governing body. 
    Section 3. Publication. This Charter Ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official City newspaper. 
    Section 4. Effective Date. This Charter Ordinance shall take effect sixty one (61) days after final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed, requiring a referendum to be held on the Ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case this Charter Ordinance shall become effective upon approval by majority of electors voting thereon. 
PASSED AND ADOPTED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, THIS 21st DAY OF APRIL, 1998. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN, 
/s/ _____
STEVE HALL, Mayor 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 
RICHARD L. DOAN, City Clerk 
NO. 34. JURISDICTION OF MUNICIPAL COURT AND ISSUANCE OF SEARCH WARRANTS FOR DANGEROUS DOG(S) 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A 12-4104, CONCERNING THE JURISDICTION OF MUNICIPAL COURT AND THE ISSUANCE OF SEARCH WARRANTS, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. Exemption. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself from, and makes inapplicable to it the provisions of K.S.A. 12-4104. 
    Section 2. Municipal Court; jurisdiction; search warrants. The Municipal Court of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine cases involving violations of the ordinances of the City. Search warrants shall not issue out of Municipal Court, except when the judge of the Municipal Court determines there is probable cause to believe that a violation of Section 6-25 of the Manhattan Code of Ordinances has occurred, said judge shall have jurisdiction to issue a search warrant to seize the dangerous dog, or dogs, that are the subject of such violation. 
    Section 3. Issuance of search warrants. 
(a)  A search warrant shall be issued only upon the oral or written statement of any person under oath or affirmation which states facts sufficient to show probable cause that a violation of Section 6-25 of the Manhattan Code of Ordinances has been or is being committed and which particularly describes a person, place or means of conveyance to be searched and identifies the dog, or dogs, to be seized. Any statement which is made orally shall be either taken down by a certified shorthand reporter, sworn to under oath and made a part of the application for a search warrant, or recorded before the Municipal Court Judge from whom the search warrant is requested and sworn to under oath. Any statement orally made shall be reduced to writing as soon thereafter as possible. If the Judge is satisfied that grounds for the application exist or that there is probable cause to believe that they exist, the Judge may issue a search warrant for the seizure of the dangerous dog or dogs. 
(b)  Before ruling on a request for a search warrant, the Judge may require the affiant to appear personally, and may examine under oath the affiant and any witnesses that the affiant may produce. Such proceeding shall be taken down by a certified shorthand reporter or recording equipment and made part of the application for a search warrant. 
(c)  Affidavits or sworn testimony in support of the probable cause requirement of this section shall not be made available for examination without a written order of the court, except that such affidavits or testimony when requested shall be made available to the defendant or the defendant's counsel for such disposition as either may desire. 
    Section 4. Territorial limitations. Search warrants issued by a Municipal Court Judge may be executed only within the city limits of the City of Manhattan, Kansas. 
    Section 5. Time of issuance. All search warrants shall show the time and date of issuance and shall be the warrants of the Municipal Court Judge issuing the same, and such warrants need not bear the seal of the court or clerk thereof. The statement on which the warrant is issued need not be filed with the clerk of the court until the warrant has been executed or has been returned "not executed." 
    Section 6. Persons authorized to execute search warrants. A search warrant shall be issued in duplicate and shall be directed for execution to all law enforcement officers of the state, or to any law enforcement officer specifically named therein. 
    Section 7. Execution of search warrants. A search warrant shall be executed within ninety-six hours from the time of issuance. If the warrant is executed the duplicate copy shall be left with any person from whom any such dog, or dogs, are seized or if no person is available the copy shall be left at the place from which the dog, or dogs, were seized. Any warrant not executed within such time shall be void and shall be returned to the court issuing the same as "not executed." 
    Section 8. Command of search warrant. A search warrant shall command the person directed to execute the same to search the person, place or means of conveyance particularly described in the warrant and to seize the dog, or dogs, particularly described in the warrant. 
    Section 9. Use of force in execution of search warrant. All necessary and reasonable force may be used to effect an entry into any building or part thereof to execute a search warrant. 
    Section 10. Detention and search of persons on premises. In the execution of a search warrant the person executing the same may reasonably detain and search any person in the place at the time; 
(a)  To protect himself from attack, or 
(b)  To prevent the disposal or concealment of any dog, or dogs, particularly described in the warrant. 
    Section 11. When search warrant may be executed. A search warrant may be executed at any time of any day or night. 
    Section 12. No warrant quashed for technicality. No search warrant shall be quashed or evidence suppressed because of technical irregularities not affecting the substantial rights of the accused. 
    Section 13. Custody and disposition of property seized. Dogs seized under a search warrant shall be delivered to, and maintained by, the Manhattan Animal Shelter unless otherwise directed by the Municipal Court Judge. The officer seizing the dog shall give a receipt to the person from whom the dog was seized, and shall file a copy of such receipt with the Judge before whom the warrant was issued. When the dog is no longer needed as evidence, it shall be disposed of pursuant to the order of the Municipal Court Judge. 
    Section 14. Publication. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official City newspaper. 
    Section 15. Effective Date. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c) (3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case, the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 21ST DAY OF JULY, 1998. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN, 
/s/ _____
STEVE HALL, Mayor 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 
RICHARD L. DOAN, City Clerk 
NO. 35. APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL 
OF COMMISSIONERS TO THE 
HOUSING AUTHORITY 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K. S. A. 17-2341 AND K.S.A. 17-2343, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT, RELATING TO THE APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL OF COMMISSIONERS TO THE HOUSING AUTHORITY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, the provisions of K. S. A. 17-2341 and K.S.A. 17-2343, which both apply to this City, but not uniformly to all cities of the State of Kansas. 
    Section 2. When the governing body of the City of Manhattan adopts, or has adopted, a resolution pursuant to K.S.A. 12-2340, creating a Housing Authority for the City of Manhattan, it shall promptly notify the mayor of its adoption. Upon receiving the notice, the mayor, with the consent of the City Commission, shall appoint seven (7) persons as commissioners of the authority created for said municipality. 
    The commissioners who are first appointed pursuant to this Charter Ordinance shall be designated to serve one (1) for one (1) year, two (2) for two (2) years, two (2) for three (3) years and two (2) for four (4) years each, from the date of their appointment, but thereafter commissioners shall be appointed as aforesaid for a term of office of four (4) years except that all vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term. 
    A commissioner shall receive no compensation for his or her services, but shall be entitled to the necessary expenses, including traveling expenses, incurred in the discharge of his or her duties. Each commissioner shall hold office until his or her successor has been appointed and has qualified; however, such commissioners, while appointed for a term for the convenience of the city, shall serve in that term at the pleasure of the governing body of the City of Manhattan. 
    The powers delegated by the City of Manhattan to the Housing Authority shall be vested in the commissioners thereof in office from time to time. Four (4) commissioners shall constitute a quorum of such authority for the purpose of conducting its business and exercising its powers and for all other purposes, notwithstanding the existence of any vacancies. Action may be taken by the authority present, unless in any case the bylaws of the authority shall require a larger number. Meetings of the commissioners of the authority may be held anywhere within the boundaries of the City of Manhattan or within any additional area where the authority is authorized to undertake a project. Appointments may be made of any persons as commissioners of the authority who reside within the City of Manhattan and who are otherwise eligible for such appointments under all applicable laws, rules and regulations. The commissioners of the authority shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman from among the commissioners. 
    Section 3. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 4. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum is held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c) (3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 21ST DAY OF DECEMBER, 1999. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN 
/s/ _____
ROGER P. REITZ, M.D., Mayor 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 
RICHARD L. DOAN, CMC, City Clerk 
NO. 36. COURT COSTS IN 
MUNICIPAL COURT 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-4112, CONCERNING COURT COSTS IN MUNICIPAL COURT, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVES THEREFORE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, the provisions of K.S.A. 12-4112, which applies to this City, but not uniformly to all cities of the State of Kansas. 
    Section 2. Whenever a defendant, in a case before the Municipal Court of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is either convicted of a violation of a municipal ordinance, or ordinances, or enters into a Diversion Agreement concerning a violation thereof, said defendant shall be assessed court costs in the sum of fifty dollars ($50). Said sum shall be in addition to any fine that is imposed by the court for said violation. In addition, the judge of the Municipal Court, in cases where a defendant is placed on probation or parole following conviction of an offense in Municipal Court, shall have the authority to impose upon such defendant a probation/parole supervision fee in a sum not to exceed one hundred ($100) dollars. The City Attorney, or the Municipal Prosecutor, where a defendant enters into a diversion agreement that requires supervision of the Court Services Officer, shall have the authority to impose upon such defendant a diversion supervision fee in a sum not to exceed one hundred ($100) dollars. The supervision fees provided for herein shall be in addition to any fines or costs otherwise imposed. 
    Section 3. The provisions of Section 2 of this ordinance shall not apply to convictions for the violation of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting the parking of motor vehicles with the city. 
    Section 4. All previous charter ordinances, or ordinary ordinances, in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
    Section 5. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 6. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum is held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THIS 4TH DAY OF JANUARY, 2000. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN, 
/s/ _____
ROGER P. REITZ, M.D., Mayor 
ATTEST: 
/s/ ___________ 
RICHARD L. DOAN, CMC, City Clerk 
NO. 37 SUBPOENAS; 
WITNESSES' EXPENSES; 
ABUSE OF SUBPOENAS [25] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-4411, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT, RELATING TO SUBPOENAS; WITNESSES' EXPENSES; AND, ABUSE OF SUBPOENAS IN THE MUNICIPAL COURT OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, the provisions of K.S.A. 12-4411, which is part of an enactment that applies to this City, but not uniformly to all cities of the State of Kansas. The City provides further substitute and additional provisions, as set forth herein. 
    Section 2. All parties, including the City of Manhattan, in cases pending in the Municipal Court of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, shall be entitled to the use of subpoenas to compel attendance of witnesses within the state of Kansas. The Municipal Judge, or his/her designee, shall issue a subpoena which may be served by any law enforcement officer upon the named person. Disobedience may constitute contempt. 
    Fees and mileage of witnesses shall be ten dollars ($10) per day or any part thereof for an appearance, and ten cents ($.10) per mile actually driven over ten (10) miles. The fees and mileage for the attendance of witnesses shall be borne by the party calling the witness, except that if an accused person is found not guilty, the City shall pay all such expenses: Provided, The Municipal Judge may direct that fees and mileage of witnesses subpoenaed by the accused person be charged against such person, if the judge finds that there has been an abuse of the use of subpoenas by the accused person. 
    Section 3. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 4. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum is held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 6TH DAY OF JUNE, 2000. 
ATTEST: 
/s/ _____
KAREN McCULLOH, Mayor 
/s/ _____
BRENDA K. WOLF, Deputy City Clerk 
NO. 38. COURT COSTS IN MUNICIPAL COURT 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-4112, CONCERNING COURT COSTS IN MUNICIPAL COURT, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVES THEREFORE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, the provisions of K. S. A. 12-4112, which applies to this City, but not uniformly to all cities of the State of Kansas. 
    Section 2. Whenever a defendant, in a case before the Municipal Court of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is convicted of a violation of a municipal ordinance, or ordinances, or enters into a Diversion Agreement concerning a violation thereof, said defendant shall be assessed court costs in the following amounts, to-wit: For Class A violations, as designated by the Code of Ordinances of the City of Manhattan, or by the ordinance establishing such violation, the sum of one hundred sixteen dollars ($116.00). For all other violations, the sum of fifty-nine dollars ($59.00). When a single case involves a Class A violation, as well as other violations, the court costs for Class A violations shall apply. Said sum shall be in addition to any fine that is imposed by the court for said violation. In addition, the judge of the Municipal Court, in cases where a defendant is placed on probation or parole following conviction of an offense in Municipal Court, shall have the authority to impose upon such defendant a probation/parole supervision fee in a sum not to exceed one hundred ($100.00) dollars. The City Attorney, or the Municipal Prosecutor, where a defendant enters into a diversion agreement that requires supervision of the Court Services Officer, shall have the authority to impose upon such defendant a diversion supervision fee in a sum not to exceed one hundred ($100.00) dollars. The supervision fees provided for herein shall be in addition to any fines or costs otherwise imposed. 
    Section 3. The provisions of Section 2 of this ordinance shall not apply to convictions for the violation of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting the parking of motor vehicles with the city. 
    Section 4. Whenever a defendant is assessed court costs pursuant to this Charter Ordinance, said sum shall be deemed to include any assessments imposed by the state of Kansas, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-4116 or K.S.A. 12-4117, and the Court Services Officer of the Municipal Court shall remit the appropriate assessments received to the state treasurer, pursuant to law. 
    Section 5. All previous charter ordinances, or ordinary ordinances, in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
    Section 6. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 7. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum is held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c) (3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THIS 1ST DAY OF OCTOBER, 2002. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN 
ED KLIMEK, Mayor 
ATTEST: 
GARY S. FEES, City Clerk 
NO. 39. PREPARATION, FILING AND SERVICE OF COMPLAINTS AND NOTICES TO APPEAR IN MUNICIPAL COURT 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-4113(g), 12-4202, 12-4203, 12-4204, 12-4205a, AND 12-4207, AND ANY AMENDMENTS THERETO, WHICH RELATE TO THE PREPARATION, FILING AND SERVICE OF COMPLAINTS AND NOTICES TO APPEAR IN MUNICIPAL COURT; AND, PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas hereby elects to exempt itself and make inapplicable to it the provisions of K.S.A. 12-4113(g), 12-4202, 12-4203, 12-4204, 12-4205a and 12-4207, and any amendments thereto.
