Such referenced provisions are part of the Kansas Code of Procedure for Municipal Courts, an enactment of the legislature, which is applicable to the City of Manhattan but not uniformly applicable to all cities. 
    Section 2. Definitions. 
a.  For the purposes of this Charter Ordinance, the term "City Officer" shall mean those individuals filling positions, designated as a City Officer position by the City Manager, and the position has been confirmed as a City Officer position by resolution of the Governing Body. Said City Officers shall have the authority to investigate violations of City ordinances, order compliance with those ordinances, and issue complaints and notices to appear, pursuant to the provisions hereof. 
b.  For the purposes of this Charter Ordinance, the term "complaint" means a sworn written statement, or a written statement by a law enforcement officer or a City Officer, of the essential facts constituting a violation of a City ordinance. 
    Section 3. Complaint; requirements; form. A complaint shall be in writing and shall be signed by the complainant. More than one violation may be charged in the same complaint. A complaint shall be deemed sufficient if in substantially the following form: 
IN THE MUNICIPAL COURT OF 
MANHATTAN, KANSAS 
The City of Manhattan, Kansas, 
vs. 
___________ (Accused person) 
___________, the undersigned, complains that on or about the ___ day of ________, A.D., 20___, in the City of Manhattan, County of ________, and State of Kansas, ___________ did then and there unlawfully ___________ in violation of Section ___ of Ordinance No. ___ of the City of Manhattan. 
Complainant    
*Sworn to positively before me, this ___ day of ________, A.D., 20___. 
Officer authorized to administer oaths 
(*This complaint is not required to be sworn if it is signed by a law enforcement officer or a City Officer.) 
    Whenever a law enforcement officer or City Officer issues a complaint for the violation of any City ordinance, and such complaint includes information required by this Charter Ordinance, and is signed by the officer preparing the same, then such complaint shall be deemed lawful for purposes of prosecution under this Charter Ordinance, even though the same has not been sworn to before a Municipal Judge, Court Clerk, Assistant Court Clerk, or Notary Public. 
    Section 4. In all cases a complaint and notice to appear in Municipal Court may be set forth on a combined form, which shall be deemed sufficient if it contains the information set forth in both Section 3 and Section 5 of this Charter Ordinance, and, where applicable, the information required by subsection (b) of K.S.A. 8-2106, and amendments thereto. 
    Section 5. Notice to appear; contents; form. A notice to appear shall describe the offense charged, shall summon the accused person to appear, shall contain a space in which the accused person may agree, in writing, to appear at a time not less than five (5) days after such notice to appear is given, unless the accused person shall demand an earlier hearing. A notice to appear may be signed by a municipal judge, the clerk of the municipal court, or any law enforcement officer or City Officer. A notice to appear shall be deemed sufficient if in substantially the following form: 
IN THE MUNICIPAL COURT OF 
MANHATTAN, KANSAS 
The City of Manhattan, Kansas 
vs. 
___________, (Accused person) 
(Address)       
NOTICE TO APPEAR 
The City of Manhattan, Kansas, To The Above Named Accused Person. 
    You are hereby summoned to appear before the Municipal Court of Manhattan, Kansas, on the ___ day of ________, 20___, at ________ o'clock, ___.m., to answer a complaint charging you with _______. 
If you fail to appear a warrant will be issued for your arrest. 
    Dated ________, 20___. 
Signature of Official   
Title of Official    
I agree to appear in said Court at said time and place. 
Signature of Accused Person 
RETURN 
    The undersigned hereby certifies that on the ___ day of ________, 20___, the notice to appear was served, mailed or delivered. 
Law Enforcement Officer/City Officer 
    Section 6. Same; service; return. The notice to appear shall be served upon the accused person by delivering a copy to him or her personally, or by leaving it at the dwelling house of the accused person or usual place of abode with some person of suitable age and discretion then residing therein, or by mailing it to the last known address of said person. A notice to appear may be served by any law enforcement officer or city officer and, if mailed, shall be mailed by a law enforcement officer, city officer, or the clerk of the municipal court. Upon service by mail, the law enforcement officer, city officer or the clerk of the municipal court shall execute a verification to be filed with a copy of the notice to appear. Said verification shall be deemed sufficient if in substantially the following form: 
    The undersigned hereby certifies that on the ___ day of ________, 20___, a copy of a notice to appear was mailed to ___________ at ___________. 
Signature of Law Enforcement Officer/ 
City Officer/Clerk of Municipal Court 
    Section 7. Same; how used; issuance of warrant; refusal to issue; effect. A copy of the complaint shall be served, together with a notice to appear or a warrant, by a law enforcement officer or city officer upon the accused person, and forthwith, the complaint shall be filed with the municipal court. A complaint may also be filed initially with the municipal court, and if so filed, a copy of the complaint shall forthwith be delivered to the City Prosecutor. The City Prosecutor shall cause a notice to appear to be issued, unless he or she has good reason to believe that the accused person will not appear in response to a notice to appear, in which case the City Prosecutor may request that a warrant be issued. Such warrant will be issued if the complaint is positively sworn to and the municipal judge has probable cause to believe that (a) there has been the commission of a violation of a municipal ordinance, (b) the accused person committed such violation and (c) the accused person will not appear in response to a notice to appear. 
    If the City Prosecutor fails to cause a notice to appear to be served, and also fails to request a warrant to be issued, on a complaint initially filed with the municipal court, the municipal judge may, upon affidavits filed with him or her alleging the violation of an ordinance, order the City Prosecutor to institute proceedings against the accused person. Any such municipal judge shall be disqualified from sitting in any case wherein such order was entered and is further prohibited from communicating about such case with the municipal judge pro tem appointed to preside therein. 
    Section 8. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 9. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 18TH DAY OF NOVEMBER, 2003. 
MARK TAUSSIG, Mayor 
ATTEST: 
GARY S. FEES, City Clerk 
NO. 40 [26] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-4112, CONCERNING COURT COSTS IN MUNICIPAL COURT, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVES THEREFORE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, the provisions of K. S. A. 12-4112, which applies to this City, but not uniformly to all cities of the State of Kansas. 
    Section 2. Whenever a defendant, in a case before the Municipal Court of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is convicted of a violation of a municipal ordinance, or ordinances, or enters into a Diversion Agreement concerning a violation thereof, said defendant shall be assessed court costs in the following amounts, to-wit: For Class A violations, as designated by the Code of Ordinances of the City of Manhattan, or by the ordinance establishing such violation, the sum of one hundred sixteen dollars ($116.00). For all other violations, the sum of fifty-nine dollars ($59.00). When a single case involves a Class A violation, as well as other violations, the court costs for Class A violations shall apply. Said sum shall be in addition to any fine that is imposed by the court for said violation. In addition, the judge of the Municipal Court, in cases where a defendant is placed on probation or parole following conviction of an offense in Municipal Court, shall have the authority to impose upon such defendant a probation/parole supervision fee in a sum not to exceed one hundred ($100.00) dollars. The City Attorney, or the Municipal Prosecutor, where a defendant enters into a diversion agreement that requires supervision of the Court Services Officer, shall have the authority to impose upon such defendant a diversion supervision fee in a sum not to exceed one hundred ($100.00) dollars. The supervision fees provided for herein shall be in addition to any fines or costs otherwise imposed. 
    Section 3. The provisions of Section 2 of this ordinance shall not apply to convictions for the violation of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting the parking of motor vehicles with the city. 
    Section 4. Whenever a defendant is assessed court costs pursuant to this Charter Ordinance, said sum shall not be deemed to include any assessments imposed by the state of Kansas, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-4116, K.S.A. 12-4117, or any other applicable statute, rule or regulation. Any such assessments shall be imposed by the Court, pursuant to the applicable statute, rule or regulation, shall be in addition to the court costs assessed pursuant to this Charter Ordinance; and, the Court Services Officer of the Municipal Court shall remit the appropriate assessments received to the state treasurer, pursuant to law. 
    Section 5. All previous charter ordinances, or ordinary ordinances, in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
    Section 6. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 7. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum is held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c) (3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THIS 18TH DAY OF JULY, 2006. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN 
/s/   
      TOM PHILLIPS, Mayor Pro Tem   ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CMC, City Clerk   NO. 41 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-1008, WHICH LIMITS THE COMPENSATION PAID TO MEMBERS OF THE GOVERNING BODY, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVE PROVISIONS THEREFOR. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, Section 12-1008 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, which is not applicable uniformly to all cities of the first class. The City provides further substitute and additional provisions, as set forth herein. 
    Section 2. The members of the governing body of the City of Manhattan shall, from and after the effective date of this ordinance, receive salaries, as follows: 
a.  Commissioners, excluding the Mayor, shall receive the sum of Four Hundred Dollars ($400.00) per month. 
b.  The Mayor shall receive the sum of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) per month, commencing with the month following their election as Mayor, and ending on the month following the end of their term. 
c.  The salaries set forth herein shall automatically increase by the sum of Twenty Dollars ($20.00) per month, on the third anniversary of the effective date of this ordinance and again on each successive third anniversary thereafter, unless the Governing Body adopts a resolution before any such anniversary date eliminating such increase. Such resolution shall only pertain to the automatic increase which immediately follows the date of such resolution; and, the Governing Body may repeal such resolution, by the adoption of a subsequent resolution, at any time it chooses and reinstate the automatic increase, effective on the first day of the month following such repeal. 
d.  The salaries set forth herein may be paid in equal installments on a monthly basis, or they may be paid in equal installments on pay periods, corresponding to the pay periods established for city employees. 
    Section 3. Charter Ordinance No. 24 is hereby repealed. 
    Section 4. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 5. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect on the later of January 1, 2007, or sixty-one (61) days after final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective on the first day of the first month following such election, if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE THIRD DAY OF OCTOBER, 2006. 
(Seal) 
/s/   
      BRUCE SNEAD, Mayor   ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CMC, City Clerk   NO. 42 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 12-4501, CONCERNING TRIAL PROCEEDINGS IN MUNICIPAL COURT, AND PROVIDING ALTERNATIVES THEREFORE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, the provisions of K. S. A. 12-4501, which applies to this City, but not uniformly to all cities of the State of Kansas. 
    Section 2. Plea of not guilty; trial; time; continuance. An accused person entering a plea of not guilty in the Municipal Court of the City of Manhattan, or for whom the Municipal Court Judge entered a plea of not guilty, shall be tried on the earliest practical day set by the Municipal Court Judge, or his designee, unless trial is continued for good cause: Provided, that an accused person in custody shall be tried on the earliest day that the Municipal Court convenes, unless trial is continued upon motion of either party, or at the discretion of the Municipal Court Judge, and for good cause. 
    Section 3. Publication. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 4. Effective Date. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum is held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c) (3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THIS 21ST DAY OF NOVEMBER, 2006. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN 
/s/   
      BRUCE SNEAD, Mayor   ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CMC, City Clerk   NO. 43. SEWER SYSTEMS [27] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE AMENDING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31, WHICH EXEMPTED THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF THE WATER POLLUTION ACT, K.S.A. 12-3101 THROUGH K.S.A. 12-3107, AND PROVIDED SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE ESTABLISHMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SEWER SYSTEMS, AND WHICH ESTABLISHED CERTAIN FEES RELATED THERETO, WHICH PROVIDED THE AUTHORITY FOR THE ISSUANCE OF BONDS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PAYING FOR THE GROUNDS AND IMPROVEMENTS NECESSARY FOR THE OPERATION OF SUCH SYSTEMS. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, by virtue of the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, adopted Charter Ordinance No. 31 (the "Original Ordinance") which exempted the City, and made inapplicable to it, Sections 12-3101, 12-3102, 12-3103, 12-3104, 12-3105, 12-3106 and 12-3107, Kansas Statutes Annotated, which apply to said City, but not uniformly to all cities, and Charter Ordinance No. 31 provided further substitute and additional provisions as set forth therein. 
    Section 2. Amendment. The City of Manhattan does hereby amend a portion of Section 7 of the Original Ordinance by amending Section 32-185 of the Code of Ordinances of the City, which is set forth in Section 7 of the Original Ordinance, now amended, as follows: 
Section 32-185. Storm Drainage Fee. 
A.  There is hereby assessed against all property within the City that is connected to either the water or sanitary sewer systems, or both, of the City a monthly storm drainage fee. Such fee is based upon a determination, using accepted engineering principals [principles], of a comparable amount of impervious area for uses within each rate category, as set forth hereinafter. The owner, occupant and any person who is responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall all be jointly and severally responsible for the payment of said fee. Persons responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall include the person responsible for payment for water provided to a master meter that is then distributed to multiple users, whether or not said users are located on the same property as the master meter. The fee shall be calculated as follows: 
1.  All property devoted to a residential use shall be assessed the following sums, per month, per living unit, to-wit: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, through December 31, 2007, the sum of $2.50; b) from and after January 1, 2008, through December 31, 2008, the sum of $3.00; and c) from and after January 1, 2009, the sum of $3.50. The term "residential" shall include single-family homes, mobile homes and mobile home parks, duplexes and apartment units. The term "residential" shall not include rooming and boarding houses, fraternities, sororities and similar facilities. The term "living unit" shall mean one or more rooms in a residential building which are arranged, designed, used or intended for use by one (1) family, and which includes cooking space and lawful sanitary facilities reserved for the occupants thereof. 
2.  Property devoted to any use other than residential, as set forth above, shall be assessed a monthly fee based upon the number of square feet developed for that particular use, as follows: 
Less than or equal to 20,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, through December 31, 2007, the sum of $5.46; b) from and after January 1, 2008, through December 31, 2008, the sum of $5.63; and c) from and after January 1, 2009, the sum of $5.68. 
From 20,001 to 100,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, through December 31, 2007, the sum of $26.25; b) from and after January 1, 2008, through December 31, 2008, the sum of $27.05; and c) from and after January 1, 2009, the sum of $27.33. 
From 100,001 to 200,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, through December 31, 2007, the sum of $52.50; b) from and after January 1, 2008, through December 31, 2008, the sum of $54.10; and c) from and after January 1, 2009, the sum of $54.65. 
From 200,001 to 400,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, through December 31, 2007, the sum of $105.00; b) from and after January 1, 2008, through December 31, 2008, the sum of $108.20; and c) from and after January 1, 2009, the sum of $109.30. 
From 400,001 to 1,000,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, through December 31, 2007, the sum of $218.40; b) from and after January 1, 2008, through December 31, 2008, the sum of $225.00; and c) from and after January 1, 2009, the sum of $227.20. 
From 1,000,001 to 2,000,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, through December 31, 2007, the sum of $409.50; b) from and after January 1, 2008, through December 31, 2008, the sum of $421.80; and c) from and after January 1, 2009, the sum of $426.00. 
From 2,000,001 to 4,000,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, through December 31, 2007, the sum of $745.50; b) from and after January 1, 2008, through December 31, 2008, the sum of $767.90; and c) from and after January 1, 2009, the sum of $775.50. 
4,000,001 to 6,000,000 square feet ..... $870.00. 
6,000,001 to 8,000,000 square feet ..... 1,000.00. 
8,000,001 to 10,000,000 square feet ..... 1,100.00. 
10,000,001 to 12,000,000 square feet ..... 1,160.00. 
For all properties in excess of 12,000,000 square feet (275+ acres) the fee shall be $4.23 multiplied by the number of acres in the property. 
3.  In determining the area of property developed for a particular use, the area measured shall include all property contiguous to the particular use, and under the same ownership, except that portion of said property that is both unimproved and legally subject to being subdivided from that portion actually devoted to the primary use. In situations where property is used in common with more than one use, the common area shall be included with each use in the same proportions as the area of each use bears to the area of the total of all uses. In situations where property is devoted to uses on more than one level, the area of the property shall be proportionately divided among the levels. 
B.  The revenue generated by this fee shall be set aside in a special fund to be used only for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of stormwater system facilities, including the acquisition, and related costs thereof, of real estate for such use. In addition, said fund may be used to pay fees to study and prepare documents related to such facilities, and to make payments of principal and interest on bonds issued for such improvements. Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to limit or restrict the City's ability to use and obtain other sources of funds for the same or similar purposes. 
C.  The monthly fees set forth above may be included as part of the monthly bill for water and sanitary sewer service, but shall be identified separately on said billing, said fees shall be due at the same time as water charges are due and the failure to pay said fees shall be considered a failure to pay water charges and enforceable pursuant to Section 32-51 of this Code. If the monthly fees are not included as part of a water or sewer bill, they shall be billed at least annually. In addition, any time water service is established, or re-established, to a property, all fees hereunder shall be paid current, as of the date such water service is established, or re-established. 
D.  1.  Any person who disagrees with the calculation of their storm drainage fee or, who believes that the actual amount of impervious area located upon their property justifies a reduction in the square footage of their property used to calculate the fee, in order to make their fee consistent with other uses with a similar amount of impervious area, may appeal the determination of their fee to the City Engineer. The appeal shall be in writing. The City Engineer shall thereafter hold an informal hearing. The City Engineer, prior to such hearing, may request that the appealing party provide information concerning the basis of the appeal, including a land survey showing dwelling units, total property area, and impervious area, as appropriate, if such information is deemed to be material by the City Engineer. Based upon information provided, the City Engineer shall make a determination of the storm drainage fee for such property. The City Engineer shall notify parties in writing of his/her decision. 
2.  A person shall have the right to appeal the decision of the City Engineer to a board comprised of the City Manager, or his designee, the Director of Public Works, and the Director of Community Development. Such appeal shall be made within fifteen (15) days of the date of the written decision of the City Engineer. Such appeal shall be in writing and filed with the City Engineer. A hearing on such appeal shall be held within thirty (30) days from the date of filing and the applicant shall be given seven (7) days advance notice of the time and date of such hearing. Within seven (7) days after the conclusion of such hearing, the Board shall render a decision in writing that sets forth findings that support its decision. The decision of the Board shall be final and any further appeal of such decision shall be to the District Court pursuant to K.S.A. 60-2101(d). 
    Section 3. All portions of the Original Ordinance, not amended hereby, shall remain in full force and effect. 
    Section 4. This Charter Ordinance shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official City newspaper. 
    Section 5. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, or on April 1, 2007, whichever date is later, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed requiring a referendum to be held on this ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, subdivision (c) (3) of the Constitution of the State of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective on April 1, 2007, or on the first day of the month following approval by a majority of the electors voting thereon, whichever date is later. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 5TH DAY OF DECEMBER, 2006. 
CITY OF MANHATTAN 
/s/   
      BRUCE SNEAD, Mayor   ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CMC, City Clerk   NO. 44. PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 13-1017, REPEALING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 13; AND, PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT RELATING TO THE MAKING OF PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    SECTION 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas hereby elects to exempt itself and make inapplicable to it the provisions of K.S.A. 13-1017, and any amendments thereto, which is applicable to the City of Manhattan but not uniformly applicable to all cities. 
    SECTION 2. Estimate of cost of improvements; contracts; bids; when. 
(a)  Except as set forth hereinafter, before undertaking the construction or reconstruction of any sidewalk, curb, gutter, bridge, pavement, sewer or any other public improvement in any street, highway or public grounds, or of any public building or facility, or any other kind of public improvement, a detailed estimate of the cost of such improvement shall be made under oath by the City Engineer, the City Manager, any Department Head, or any other competent person appointed for such purposes by the Governing Body, and said estimate shall be submitted to the Governing Body for its action thereon. 
(b)  In all cases where the estimated cost of the public improvement amounts to more than Twenty Thousand Dollars ($20,000.00), sealed proposals for the public improvement shall be invited by advertisement, published by the City Clerk once in the official City newspaper, and the Governing Body shall let all such work by contract to the lowest and best responsible bidder, if there be any such whose bid does not exceed the estimate. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Governing Body reserves the right to refuse all or any part of any bid when it is felt that such action is in the best interest of the City. 
(c)  If no qualified responsible person shall propose to enter into the contract at a price not exceeding the estimated cost, all bids may be rejected and the same proceedings as before repeated. In the alternative, if all bids exceed the estimated cost, the Governing Body may accept the bid and let the work by contract to the lowest and best responsible bidder; but if that cost is greater than seven percent (7%) over the estimated cost, the Department Director of the department letting the bids or his/her designee shall give a full explanation to the Governing Body of the reason for the discrepancy. In no case shall the City be liable for anything beyond the original contract price for doing the work or making the improvement. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to: 
1.  Any repair or maintenance work not amounting to substantial alteration, addition or change in any public improvement; or 
2.  The construction, reconstruction, repair or maintenance of any public improvement by employees of the City; or 
3.  Improvements financed by economic development bonds issued pursuant to K.S.A. 12-1740, et seq. 
    SECTION 3. Alternative process. As a complete alternative to the procedures set forth in Section 2, the Governing Body may develop any method of procuring the construction, or reconstruction, of any public facility, that it deems to be in the best interests of the City. Such alternatives may include, but are not necessarily limited to: 
(a)  Direct negotiations with a prospective provider, selected by a means determined by the Governing Body, including negotiations with the lowest and best responsible bidder following the submittal of bids pursuant to Section 2, if all bids exceed the estimate; 
(b)  Selection of a provider from a Request for Quotes; 
(c)  A design/build process, as determined by the Governing Body; or 
(d)  Any other integrated comprehensive project design and/or construction process. 
    SECTION 4. Repeal. Charter Ordinance No. 13 is hereby repealed. 
    SECTION 5. Publication. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION 6. Charter Ordinance. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 2 ND DAY OF SEPTEMBER, 2008. 
ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CITY CLERK   /s/   
      MARK J. HATESOHL, MAYOR   CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 46 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM CERTAIN PORTIONS OF K.S.A. 12-1697 AND FROM K.S.A. 12-1698(e). 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, that portion of K.S.A. 12-1697 which authorizes the levy of a transient guest tax at a rate not to exceed two percent of the gross receipts derived from or paid by transient guests for sleeping accommodations, exclusive of charges for incidental services or facilities, in any hotel, motel or tourist court. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, also hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, K.S.A. 12-1698(e). Said statutes not being uniformly applicable to all cities in Kansas. 
    Section 2. In place of that portion of K.S.A. 12-1697 referred to in Section 1, the following shall be applicable to the City of Manhattan, to-wit: The governing body of the City of Manhattan, Kansas, is hereby authorized to levy a transient guest tax, at a rate not to exceed seven percent (7%), upon the gross receipts derived from or paid by transient guests for sleeping accommodations, exclusive of charges for incidental services or facilities, in any hotel, motel or tourist court located within the City of Manhattan. 
    Section 3. In place of K.S.A. 12-1698(e), the following shall be applicable to the City of Manhattan, to-wit: Except as otherwise provided in K.S.A. 12-1774, and amendments thereto, all monies received by the city treasurer from disbursements from the city transient guest tax fund shall be credited to the tourism and convention promotion fund of the city and shall be used for all, or any portion of, programs, projects, activities, municipal services or public improvements which the governing body of the city has first designated for such use, and has further determined are related to the promotion, enhancement, advancement or retention of tourism and conventions to the City of Manhattan, Kansas, including the payments of principal and interest on bonds issued for such purposes. 
    Section 4. All other provisions of K.S.A. 12-1697 and K.S.A. 12-1698, not exempted hereby, shall remain the same. 
    Section 5. Charter Ordinance No. 27, and any other Charter Ordinance in conflict with this Charter Ordinance, is hereby repealed. 
    Section 6. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 7. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum is held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c) (3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THIS 9 TH DAY OF JUNE, 2009. 
ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CITY CLERK   /s/   
      BOB STRAWN, MAYOR   CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 47 [28] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE AMENDING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31, WHICH EXEMPTED THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF THE WATER POLLUTION ACT, K.S.A. 12-3101 THROUGH K.S.A. 12-3107, AND PROVIDED SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE ESTABLISHMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SEWER SYSTEMS, AND WHICH ESTABLISHED CERTAIN FEES RELATED THERETO, WHICH PROVIDED THE AUTHORITY FOR THE ISSUANCE OF BONDS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PAYING FOR THE GROUNDS AND IMPROVEMENTS NECESSARY FOR THE OPERATION OF SUCH SYSTEMS; AND, REPEALING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 43, WHICH PREVIOUSLY AMENDED, IN PART, CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    SECTION 1. The City of Manhattan, by virtue of the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, adopted Charter Ordinance No. 31 (the "Original Ordinance") which exempted the City, and made inapplicable to it, Sections 12-3101, 12-3102, 12-3103, 12-3104, 12-3105, 12-3106 and 12-3107, Kansas Statutes Annotated, which apply to said City, but not uniformly to all cities, and Charter Ordinance No. 31 provided further substitute and additional provisions as set forth therein. In addition, by virtue of the same power, the City of Manhattan adopted Charter Ordinance No. 43, which amended a portion of Section 7 of the Original Ordinance. 
    SECTION 2. Amendment/Repeal. The City of Manhattan does hereby repeal Charter Ordinance No. 43, and does hereby amend a portion of Section 7 of the Original Ordinance by amending Section 32-185 of the Code of Ordinances of the City, which is set forth in Section 7 of the Original Ordinance, now amended, as follows: 
Section 32-185. Storm Drainage Fee. 
A.  There is hereby assessed against all property within the City that is connected to either the water or sanitary sewer systems, or both, of the City a monthly storm drainage fee. Such fee is based upon a determination, using accepted engineering principals [principles], of a comparable amount of impervious area for uses within each rate category, as set forth hereinafter. The owner, occupant and any person who is responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall all be jointly and severally responsible for the payment of said fee. Persons responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall include the person responsible for payment for water provided to a master meter that is then distributed to multiple users, whether or not said users are located on the same property as the master meter. The fee shall be calculated as follows: 
1.  All property devoted to a residential use shall be assessed the following sums, per month, per living unit, to-wit: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2010, the sum of $3.75. The term "residential" shall include single family homes, mobile homes and mobile home parks, duplexes and apartment units. The term "residential" shall not include rooming and boarding houses, fraternities, sororities and similar facilities. The term "living unit" shall mean one or more rooms in a residential building which are arranged, designed, used or intended for use by one (1) family, and which includes cooking space and lawful sanitary facilities reserved for the occupants thereof. 
2.  Property devoted to any use other than residential, as set forth above, shall be assessed a monthly fee based upon the number of square feet developed for that particular use, as follows: 
Less than or equal to 20,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2010, the sum of $6.08. 
From 20,001 to 100,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2010, the sum of $29.24. 
From 100,001 to 200,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2010, the sum of $58.48. 
From 200,001 to 400,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2010, the sum of $116.95. 
From 400,001 to 1,000,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2010, the sum of $243.10. 
From 1,000,001 to 2,000,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2010, the sum of $455.82. 
From 2,000,001 to 4,000,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, January 1, 2010, the sum of $829.79. 
4,000,001 to 6,000,000 square feet ..... $870.00. 
6,000.001 to 8,000,000 square feet ..... 1,000.00. 
8,000,001 to 10,000,000 square feet ..... 1,100.00. 
10,000,001 to 12,000,000 square feet ..... 1,160.00. 
For all properties in excess of 12,000,000 square feet (275+ acres) the fee shall be $4.23 multiplied by the number of acres in the property. 
3.  In determining the area of property developed for a particular use, the area measured shall include all property contiguous to the particular use, and under the same ownership, except that portion of said property that is both unimproved and legally subject to being subdivided from that portion actually devoted to the primary use. In situations where property is used in common with more than one use, the common area shall be included with each use in the same proportions as the area of each use bears to the area of the total of all uses. In situations where property is devoted to uses on more than one level, the area of the property shall be proportionately divided among the levels. 
B.  The revenue generated by this fee shall be set aside in a special fund to be used only for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of stormwater system facilities, including the acquisition, and related costs thereof, of real estate for such use. In addition, said fund may be used to pay fees to study and prepare documents related to such facilities, and to make payments of principal and interest on bonds issued for such improvements. Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to limit or restrict the City's ability to use and obtain other sources of funds for the same or similar purposes. 
C.  The monthly fees set forth above may be included as part of the monthly bill for water and sanitary sewer service, but shall be identified separately on said billing, said fees shall be due at the same time as water charges are due and the failure to pay said fees shall be considered a failure to pay water charges and enforceable pursuant to Section 32-51 of this Code. If the monthly fees are not included as part of a water or sewer bill, they shall be billed at least annually. In addition, any time water service is established, or re-established, to a property, all fees hereunder shall be paid current, as of the date such water service is established, or re-established. 
D.  1.  Any person who disagrees with the calculation of their storm drainage fee or, who believes that the actual amount of impervious area located upon their property justifies a reduction in the square footage of their property used to calculate the fee, in order to make their fee consistent with other uses with a similar amount of impervious area, may appeal the determination of their fee to the City Engineer. The appeal shall be in writing. The City Engineer shall thereafter hold an informal hearing. The City Engineer, prior to such hearing, may request that the appealing party provide information concerning the basis of the appeal, including a land survey showing dwelling units, total property area, and impervious area, as appropriate, if such information is deemed to be material by the City Engineer. Based upon information provided, the City Engineer shall make a determination of the storm drainage fee for such property. The City Engineer shall notify parties in writing of his/her decision. 
2.  A person shall have the right to appeal the decision of the City Engineer to a board comprised of the City Manager, or his designee, the Director of Public Works, and the Director of Community Development. Such appeal shall be made within fifteen (15) days of the date of the written decision of the City Engineer. Such appeal shall be in writing and filed with the City Engineer. A hearing on such appeal shall be held within thirty (30) days from the date of filing and the applicant shall be given seven (7) days advance notice of the time and date of such hearing. Within seven (7) days after the conclusion of such hearing, the Board shall render a decision in writing that sets forth findings that support its decision. The decision of the Board shall be final and any further appeal of such decision shall be to the District Court pursuant to K.S.A. 60-2101(d). 
    SECTION 3. All portions of the Original Ordinance, not amended hereby, shall remain in full force and effect. 
    SECTION 4. This Charter Ordinance shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official City newspaper. 
    SECTION 5. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, or on January 1, 2010, whichever date is later, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed requiring a referendum to be held on this ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, subdivision (c) (3) of the Constitution of the State of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective on January 1, 2010, or on the first day of the month following approval by a majority of the electors voting thereon, whichever date is later. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 18 TH DAY OF AUGUST, 2009. 
ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CITY CLERK   /s/   
      BOB STRAWN, MAYOR   CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 48 [29] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE AMENDING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31, WHICH EXEMPTED THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF THE WATER POLLUTION ACT, K.S.A. 12-3101 THROUGH K.S.A. 12-3107, AND PROVIDED SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE ESTABLISHMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SEWER SYSTEMS, AND WHICH ESTABLISHED CERTAIN FEES RELATED THERETO, WHICH PROVIDED THE AUTHORITY FOR THE ISSUANCE OF BONDS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PAYING FOR THE GROUNDS AND IMPROVEMENTS NECESSARY FOR THE OPERATION OF SUCH SYSTEMS; AND, REPEALING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 47, WHICH PREVIOUSLY AMENDED, IN PART, CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    SECTION 1. The City of Manhattan, by virtue of the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, adopted Charter Ordinance No. 31 (the "Original Ordinance") which exempted the City, and made inapplicable to it, Sections 12-3101, 12-3102, 12-3103, 12-3104, 12-3105, 12-3106 and 12-3107, Kansas Statutes Annotated, which apply to said City, but not uniformly to all cities, and Charter Ordinance No. 31 provided further substitute and additional provisions as set forth therein. In addition, by virtue of the same power, the City of Manhattan adopted Charter Ordinance No. 47, which amended a portion of Section 7 of the Original Ordinance. 
    SECTION 2. Amendment/Repeal. The City of Manhattan does hereby repeal Charter Ordinance No. 47, and all other ordinances in conflict herewith, and does hereby amend a portion of Section 7 of the Original Ordinance by amending Section 32-185 of the Code of Ordinances of the City, which is set forth in Section 7 of the Original Ordinance, now amended, as follows: 
Section 32-185. Storm Drainage Fee. 
A.  There is hereby assessed against all property within the City that is connected to either the water or sanitary sewer systems, or both, of the City a monthly storm drainage fee. Such fee is based upon a determination, using accepted engineering principles, of a comparable amount of impervious area for uses within each rate category, as set forth hereinafter. The owner, occupant and any person who is responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall all be jointly and severally responsible for the payment of said fee. Persons responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall include the person responsible for payment for water provided to a master meter that is then distributed to multiple users, whether or not said users are located on the same property as the master meter. The fee shall be calculated as follows: 
1.  All property devoted to a residential use shall be assessed the following sums, per month, per living unit, to wit: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2011, the sum of $3.93. The term "residential" shall include single family homes, mobile homes and mobile home parks, duplexes and apartment units. The term "residential" shall not include rooming and boarding houses, fraternities, sororities and similar facilities. The term "living unit" shall mean one or more rooms in a residential building which are arranged, designed, used or intended for use by one (1) family, and which includes cooking space and lawful sanitary facilities reserved for the occupants thereof. 
2.  Property devoted to any use other than residential, as set forth above, shall be assessed a monthly fee based upon the number of square feet developed for that particular use, as follows: 
Less than or equal to 20,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2011, the sum of $6.38. 
From 20,001 to 100,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2011, the sum of $30.71. 
From 100,001 to 200,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2011, the sum of $61.40. 
From 200,001 to 400,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2011, the sum of $122.80. 
From 400,001 to 1,000,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2011, the sum of $255.26. 
From 1,000,001 to 2,000,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2011, the sum of $478.61. 
From 2,000,001 to 4,000,000 square feet: a) from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, January 1, 2011, the sum of $871.27, and for: 
4,000,001 to 6,000,000 square feet ..... $870.00. 
6,000.001 to 8,000,000 square feet ..... 1,000.00. 
8,000,001 to 10,000,000 square feet ..... 1,100.00. 
10,000,001 to 12,000,000 square feet ..... 1,160.00. 
For all properties in excess of 12,000,000 square feet (275+ acres) the fee shall be $4.23 multiplied by the number of acres in the property. 
3.  In determining the area of property developed for a particular use, the area measured shall include all property contiguous to the particular use, and under the same ownership, except that portion of said property that is both unimproved and legally subject to being subdivided from that portion actually devoted to the primary use. In situations where property is used in common with more than one use, the common area shall be included with each use in the same proportions as the area of each use bears to the area of the total of all uses. In situations where property is devoted to uses on more than one level, the area of the property shall be proportionately divided among the levels. 
B.  The revenue generated by this fee shall be set aside in a special fund to be used only for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of stormwater system facilities, including the acquisition, and related costs thereof, of real estate for such use. In addition, said fund may be used to pay fees to study and prepare documents related to such facilities, and to make payments of principal and interest on bonds issued for such improvements. Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to limit or restrict the City's ability to use and obtain other sources of funds for the same or similar purposes. 
C.  The monthly fees set forth above may be included as part of the monthly bill for water and sanitary sewer service, but shall be identified separately on said billing, said fees shall be due at the same time as water charges are due and the failure to pay said fees shall be considered a failure to pay water charges and enforceable pursuant to Section 32-51 of this Code. If the monthly fees are not included as part of a water or sewer bill, they shall be billed at least annually. In addition, any time water service is established, or reestablished, to a property, all fees hereunder shall be paid current, as of the date such water service is established, or reestablished. 
D.  1.  Any person who disagrees with the calculation of their storm drainage fee or, who believes that the actual amount of impervious area located upon their property justifies a reduction in the square footage of their property used to calculate the fee, in order to make their fee consistent with other uses with a similar amount of impervious area, may appeal the determination of their fee to the City Engineer. The appeal shall be in writing. The City Engineer shall thereafter hold an informal hearing. The City Engineer, prior to such hearing, may request that the appealing party provide information concerning the basis of the appeal, including a land survey showing dwelling units, total property area, and impervious area, as appropriate, if such information is deemed to be material by the City Engineer. Based upon information provided, the City Engineer shall make a determination of the storm drainage fee for such property. The City Engineer shall notify parties in writing of his/her decision. 
2.  A person shall have the right to appeal the decision of the City Engineer to a board comprised of the City Manager, or his designee, the Director of Public Works, and the Director of Community Development. Such appeal shall be made within fifteen (15) days of the date of the written decision of the City Engineer. Such appeal shall be in writing and filed with the City Engineer. A hearing on such appeal shall be held within thirty (30) days from the date of filing and the applicant shall be given seven (7) days advance notice of the time and date of such hearing. Within seven (7) days after the conclusion of such hearing, the Board shall render a decision in writing that sets forth findings that support its decision. The decision of the Board shall be final and any further appeal of such decision shall be to the District Court pursuant to K.S.A. 60-2101(d). 
    SECTION 3. All portions of the Original Ordinance, not amended hereby, shall remain in full force and effect. 
    SECTION 4. This Charter Ordinance shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official City newspaper. 
    SECTION 5. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, or on January 1, 2011, whichever date is later, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed requiring a referendum to be held on this ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of the State of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective on January 1, 2011, or on the first day of the month following approval by a majority of the electors voting thereon, whichever date is later. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 24 TH DAY OF AUGUST, 2010. 
ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CITY CLERK   /s/   
      BRUCE SNEAD, MAYOR   CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 49 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 65-210. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    Section 1. The City of Manhattan, Kansas, is a city of the first class, and by the power vested in it by Article XII, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt, and does hereby exempt, itself from, and makes inapplicable to it, K.S.A. 65-210, which provides for the distribution of money remaining in the hands of the treasurer of a Joint Board of Health, upon its dissolution. Said statute being a part of an enactment which is not uniformly applicable to all cities in Kansas. 
    Section 2. In place of K.S.A. 65-210, the following shall be applicable to the City of Manhattan, to-wit: 
a.  Any money remaining in the hands of the treasurer of the Joint Board of Health established by the City of Manhattan and Riley County, upon its dissolution, shall be repaid to the respective treasurers of the City of Manhattan and Riley County in the proportion in which such municipalities contributed during the last fiscal year. 
b.  Any money received by the City of Manhattan, pursuant to the provisions of subsection (a), shall be placed in the general fund of the City and may be expended at the discretion of the Governing Body of the City for any lawful purpose. Such purpose shall include, but not be limited to, payments to the Board of Riley County Commissioners for the purpose of the operation of the Riley County Board of Health. As an alternative, the Governing Body may give written direction to the treasurer of the joint board to distribute all, or any portion, of the funds belonging to the City directly to the Board of Riley County Commissioners. 
c.  Any money received by the City of Manhattan, in the form of delinquent taxes, distributions of taxes pursuant to K.S.A. 79-5110, or any similar distribution, that would have been placed within the fund designated for distribution to the joint board of health but for its dissolution, shall be placed in the general fund of the City and may be expended at the discretion of the Governing Body of the City for any lawful purpose. 
    Section 3. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    Section 4. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after its final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum is held on the ordinance, as provided in Article XII, Section 5, Subdivision (c) (3), of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THIS 2 ND DAY OF AUGUST, 2011. 
ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CITY CLERK   /s/   
      JAMES E. SHEROW, MAYOR   CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 50 [30] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE AMENDING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31, WHICH EXEMPTED THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF THE WATER POLLUTION ACT, K.S.A. 12-3101 THROUGH K.S.A. 12-3107, AND PROVIDED SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE ESTABLISHMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SEWER SYSTEMS, AND WHICH ESTABLISHED CERTAIN FEES RELATED THERETO, WHICH PROVIDED THE AUTHORITY FOR THE ISSUANCE OF BONDS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PAYING FOR THE GROUNDS AND IMPROVEMENTS NECESSARY FOR THE OPERATION OF SUCH SYSTEMS; AND, REPEALING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 48, WHICH PREVIOUSLY AMENDED, IN PART, CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    SECTION 1. The City of Manhattan, by virtue of the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, adopted Charter Ordinance No. 31 (the "Original Ordinance") which exempted the City, and made inapplicable to it, Sections 12-3101, 12-3102, 12-3103, 12-3104, 12-3105, 12-3106 and 12-3107, Kansas Statutes Annotated, which apply to said City, but not uniformly to all cities, and Charter Ordinance No. 31 provided further substitute and additional provisions as set forth therein. In addition, by virtue of the same power, the City of Manhattan adopted Charter Ordinance No. 48, which amended a portion of Section 7 of the Original Ordinance. 
    SECTION 2. Amendment/Repeal. The City of Manhattan does hereby repeal Charter Ordinance No. 48, and all other ordinances in conflict herewith, and does hereby amend a portion of Section 7 of the Original Ordinance by amending Section 32-185 of the Code of Ordinances of the City, which is set forth in Section 7 of the Original Ordinance, now amended, as follows: 
Section 32-185. Storm Drainage Fee. 
A.  There is hereby assessed against all property within the City that is connected to either the water or sanitary sewer systems, or both, of the City a monthly storm drainage fee. Such fee is based upon a determination, using accepted engineering principals, of a comparable amount of impervious area for uses within each rate category, as set forth hereinafter. The owner, occupant and any person who is responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall all be jointly and severally responsible for the payment of said fee. Persons responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall include the person responsible for payment for water provided to a master meter that is then distributed to multiple users, whether or not said users are located on the same property as the master meter. The fee shall be calculated as follows: 
1.  All property devoted to a residential use shall be assessed the following sums, per month, per living unit, to-wit: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2012, the sum of $4.13. The term "residential" shall include single family homes, mobile homes and mobile home parks, duplexes and apartment units. The term "residential" shall not include rooming and boarding houses, fraternities, sororities and similar facilities. The term "living unit" shall mean one or more rooms in a residential building which are arranged, designed, used or intended for use by one (1) family, and which includes cooking space and lawful sanitary facilities reserved for the occupants thereof. 
2.  Property devoted to any use other than residential, as set forth above, shall be assessed a monthly fee based upon the number of square feet developed for that particular use, as follows: 
Less than or equal to 20,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2012, the sum of $6.70. 
From 20,001 to 100,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2012, the sum of $32.24. 
From 100,001 to 200,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2012, the sum of $64.47. 
From 200,001 to 400,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2012, the sum of $128.94. 
From 400,001 to 1,000,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2012, the sum of $268.02. 
From 1,000,001 to 2,000,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2012, the sum of $502.54. 
From 2,000,001 to 4,000,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, January 1, 2012, the sum of $914.84, and for: 
4,000,001 to 6,000,000 square feet ..... $1,121.06 
6,000,001 to 8,000,000 square feet ..... $1,288.58 
8,000,001 to 10,000,000 square feet ..... $1,417.43 
10,000,001 to 12,000,000 square feet ..... $1,494.75 
For all properties in excess of 12,000,000 square feet (275+ acres) the fee shall be $5.45 multiplied by the number of acres in the property. 
3.  In determining the area of property developed for a particular use, the area measured shall include all property contiguous to the particular use, and under the same ownership, except that portion of said property that is both unimproved and legally subject to being subdivided from that portion actually devoted to the primary use. In situations where property is used in common with more than one use, the common area shall be included with each use in the same proportions as the area of each use bears to the area of the total of all uses. In situations where property is devoted to uses on more than one level, the area of the property shall be proportionately divided among the levels. 
B.  The revenue generated by this fee shall be set aside in a special fund to be used only for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of stormwater system facilities, including the acquisition, and related costs thereof, of real estate for such use. In addition, said fund may be used to pay fees to study and prepare documents related to such facilities, and to make payments of principal and interest on bonds issued for such improvements. Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to limit or restrict the City's ability to use and obtain other sources of funds for the same or similar purposes. 
C.  The monthly fees set forth above may be included as part of the monthly bill for water and sanitary sewer service, but shall be identified separately on said billing, said fees shall be due at the same time as water charges are due and the failure to pay said fees shall be considered a failure to pay water charges and enforceable pursuant to Section 32-51 of this Code. If the monthly fees are not included as part of a water or sewer bill, they shall be billed at least annually. In addition, any time water service is established, or re-established, to a property, all fees hereunder shall be paid current, as of the date such water service is established, or re-established. 
D.  1.  Any person who disagrees with the calculation of their storm drainage fee or, who believes that the actual amount of impervious area located upon their property justifies a reduction in the square footage of their property used to calculate the fee, in order to make their fee consistent with other uses with a similar amount of impervious area, may appeal the determination of their fee to the City Engineer. The appeal shall be in writing. The City Engineer shall thereafter hold an informal hearing. The City Engineer, prior to such hearing, may request that the appealing party provide information concerning the basis of the appeal, including a land survey showing dwelling units, total property area, and impervious area, as appropriate, if such information is deemed to be material by the City Engineer. Based upon information provided, the City Engineer shall make a determination of the storm drainage fee for such property. The City Engineer shall notify parties in writing of his/her decision. 
2.  A person shall have the right to appeal the decision of the City Engineer to a board comprised of the City Manager, or his designee, the Director of Public Works, and the Director of Community Development. Such appeal shall be made within fifteen (15) days of the date of the written decision of the City Engineer. Such appeal shall be in writing and filed with the City Engineer. A hearing on such appeal shall be held within thirty (30) days from the date of filing and the applicant shall be given seven (7) days advance notice of the time and date of such hearing. Within seven (7) days after the conclusion of such hearing, the Board shall render a decision in writing that sets forth findings that support its decision. The decision of the Board shall be final and any further appeal of such decision shall be to the District Court pursuant to K.S.A. 60-2101(d). 
    SECTION 3. All portions of the Original Ordinance, not amended hereby, shall remain in full force and effect. 
    SECTION 4. This Charter Ordinance shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official City newspaper. 
    SECTION 5. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, or on January 1, 2012, whichever date is later, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed requiring a referendum to be held on this ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of the State of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective on January 1, 2012, or on the first day of the month following approval by a majority of the electors voting thereon, whichever date is later. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 16 TH DAY OF AUGUST, 2011. 
ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, CITY CLERK   /s/   
      JAMES E. SHEROW, MAYOR   CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 51 [31] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE AMENDING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31, WHICH EXEMPTED THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF THE WATER POLLUTION ACT, K.S.A. 12-3101 THROUGH K.S.A. 12-3107, AND PROVIDED SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE ESTABLISHMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SEWER SYSTEMS, AND WHICH ESTABLISHED CERTAIN FEES RELATED THERETO, WHICH PROVIDED THE AUTHORITY FOR THE ISSUANCE OF BONDS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PAYING FOR THE GROUNDS AND IMPROVEMENTS NECESSARY FOR THE OPERATION OF SUCH SYSTEMS; AND, REPEALING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 50, WHICH PREVIOUSLY AMENDED, IN PART, CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    SECTION 1. The City of Manhattan, by virtue of the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, adopted Charter Ordinance No. 31 (the "Original Ordinance") which exempted the City, and made inapplicable to it, Sections 12-3101, 12-3102, 12-3103, 12-3104, 12-3105, 12-3106 and 12-3107, Kansas Statutes Annotated, which apply to said City, but not uniformly to all cities, and Charter Ordinance No. 31 provided further substitute and additional provisions as set forth therein. In addition, by virtue of the same power, the City of Manhattan adopted Charter Ordinance No. 50, which amended a portion of Section 7 of the Original Ordinance. 
    SECTION 2. Amendment/Repeal. The City of Manhattan does hereby repeal Charter Ordinance No. 50, and all other ordinances in conflict herewith, and does hereby amend a portion of Section 7 of the Original Ordinance by amending Section 32-185 of the Code of Ordinances of the City, which is set forth in Section 7 of the Original Ordinance, now amended, as follows: 
Section 32-185. Storm Drainage Fee. 
A.  There is hereby assessed against all property within the City that is connected to either the water or sanitary sewer systems, or both, of the City a monthly storm drainage fee. Such fee is based upon a determination, using accepted engineering principals, of a comparable amount of impervious area for uses within each rate category, as set forth hereinafter. The owner, occupant and any person who is responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall all be jointly and severally responsible for the payment of said fee. Persons responsible for the payment of water and/or sewer service to the property shall include the person responsible for payment for water provided to a master meter that is then distributed to multiple users, whether or not said users are located on the same property as the master meter. The fee shall be calculated as follows: 
1.  All property devoted to a residential use shall be assessed the following sums, per month, per living unit, to-wit: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2013, the sum of $4.29. The term "residential" shall include single family homes, mobile homes and mobile home parks, duplexes and apartment units. The term "residential" shall not include rooming and boarding houses, fraternities, sororities and similar facilities. The term "living unit" shall mean one or more rooms in a residential building which are arranged, designed, used or intended for use by one (1) family, and which includes cooking space and lawful sanitary facilities reserved for the occupants thereof. 
2.  Property devoted to any use other than residential, as set forth above, shall be assessed a monthly fee based upon the number of square feet developed for that particular use, as follows: 
Less than or equal to 20,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2013, the sum of $6.97. 
From 20,001 to 100,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2013, the sum of $33.53. 
From 100,001 to 200,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2013, the sum of $67.05. 
From 200,001 to 400,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2013, the sum of $134.10. 
From 400,001 to 1,000,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2013, the sum of $278.74. 
From 1,000,001 to 2,000,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, from and after January 1, 2013, the sum of $522.64. 
From 2,000,001 to 4,000,000 square feet: from and after the effective date of this Charter Ordinance, January 1, 2013, the sum of $951.43, and for: 
4,000,001 to 6,000,000 square feet ..... $1,165.90 
6,000,001 to 8,000,000 square feet ..... $1,340.12 
8,000,001 to 10,000,000 square feet ..... $1,474.13 
10,000,001 to 12,000,000 square feet ..... $1,554.54 
For all properties in excess of 12,000,000 square feet (275± acres) the fee shall be $5.67 multiplied by the number of acres in the property. 
3.  In determining the area of property developed for a particular use, the area measured shall include all property contiguous to the particular use, and under the same ownership, except that portion of said property that is both unimproved and legally subject to being subdivided from that portion actually devoted to the primary use. In situations where property is used in common with more than one use, the common area shall be included with each use in the same proportions as the area of each use bears to the area of the total of all uses. In situations where property is devoted to uses on more than one level, the area of the property shall be proportionately divided among the levels. 
B.  The revenue generated by this fee shall be set aside in a special fund to be used only for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of stormwater system facilities, including the acquisition, and related costs thereof, of real estate for such use. In addition, said fund may be used to pay fees to study and prepare documents related to such facilities, and to make payments of principal and interest on bonds issued for such improvements. Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to limit or restrict the City's ability to use and obtain other sources of funds for the same or similar purposes. 
C.  The monthly fees set forth above may be included as part of the monthly bill for water and sanitary sewer service, but shall be identified separately on said billing, said fees shall be due at the same time as water charges are due and the failure to pay said fees shall be considered a failure to pay water charges and enforceable pursuant to Section 32-51 of this Code. If the monthly fees are not included as part of a water or sewer bill, they shall be billed at least annually. In addition, any time water service is established, or re-established, to a property, all fees hereunder shall be paid current, as of the date such water service is established, or re-established. 
D.  1.  Any person who disagrees with the calculation of their storm drainage fee or, who believes that the actual amount of impervious area located upon their property justifies a reduction in the square footage of their property used to calculate the fee, in order to make their fee consistent with other uses with a similar amount of impervious area, may appeal the determination of their fee to the City Engineer. The appeal shall be in writing. The City Engineer shall thereafter hold an informal hearing. The City Engineer, prior to such hearing, may request that the appealing party provide information concerning the basis of the appeal, including a land survey showing dwelling units, total property area, and impervious area, as appropriate, if such information is deemed to be material by the City Engineer. Based upon information provided, the City Engineer shall make a determination of the storm drainage fee for such property. The City Engineer shall notify parties in writing of his/her decision. 
2.  A person shall have the right to appeal the decision of the City Engineer to a board comprised of the City Manager, or his designee, the Director of Public Works, and the Director of Community Development. Such appeal shall be made within fifteen (15) days of the date of the written decision of the City Engineer. Such appeal shall be in writing and filed with the City Engineer. A hearing on such appeal shall be held within thirty (30) days from the date of filing and the applicant shall be given seven (7) days advance notice of the time and date of such hearing. Within seven (7) days after the conclusion of such hearing, the Board shall render a decision in writing that sets forth findings that support its decision. The decision of the Board shall be final and any further appeal of such decision shall be to the District Court pursuant to K.S.A. 60-2101(d). 
    SECTION 3. All portions of the Original Ordinance, not amended hereby, shall remain in full force and effect. 
    SECTION 4. This Charter Ordinance shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official City newspaper. 
    SECTION 5. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, or on January 1, 2013, whichever date is later, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed requiring a referendum to be held on this ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of the State of Kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective on January 1, 2013, or on the first day of the month following approval by a majority of the electors voting thereon, whichever date is later. 
PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, NOT LESS THAN TWO-THIRDS OF THE MEMBERS-ELECT VOTING IN FAVOR THEREOF, ON THE 21ST DAY OF AUGUST, 2012. 
ATTEST: 
/s/   
      GARY S. FEES, MMC, CITY CLERK   /s/   
      LOREN J. PEPPERD, MAYOR   CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 52 [32] 
A CHARTER ORDINANCE AMENDING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31, WHICH EXEMPTED THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF THE WATER POLLUTION ACT, K.S.A. 12-3101 THROUGH K.S.A. 12-3107, AND PROVIDED SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE ESTABLISHMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SEWER SYSTEMS, AND WHICH ESTABLISHED CERTAIN FEES RELATED THERETO, WHICH PROVIDED THE AUTHORITY FOR THE ISSUANCE OF BONDS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PAYING FOR THE GROUNDS AND IMPROVEMENTS NECESSARY FOR THE OPERATION OF SUCH SYSTEMS; AND, REPEALING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 51, WHICH PREVIOUSLY AMENDED, IN PART, CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 31. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF MANHATTAN, KANSAS: 
    SECTION 1. The City of Manhattan, by virtue of the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, adopted Charter Ordinance No. 31 (the "Original Ordinance") which exempted the City, and made inapplicable to it, Sections 12-3101, 12-3102, 12-3103, 12-3104, 12-3105, 12-3106 and 12-3107, Kansas Statutes Annotated, which apply to said City, but not uniformly to all cities, and Charter Ordinance No. 31 provided further substitute and additional provisions as set forth therein.
