dedications of land to the public that have not been accepted by the
responsible Governing Body.
VI-11
PART 5. APPLICATION, REVIEW, AND APPROVAL OF CONCURRENT PLAT.
6-501. Application Requirements and Approval Procedure. Whenever a subdivision
will consist of five (5) or fewer lots, the subdivider may submit an
application for the concurrent approval of a Preliminary and Final Plat. Such
application shall be on forms provided by the responsible Planning
Department. The application shall contain all the documents required for
both Preliminary Plats and Final Plats and shall be reviewed, simultaneously,
in the same manner required for Preliminary and Final Plats.
PART 6. RECORDING OF PLAT.
6-601. Upon approval of a Final Plat, and acceptance of all dedications by the
appropriate Governing Body, and upon submission of all documents required
to be submitted with a Final Plat, the responsible Planning Department shall
file the Final Plat with the appropriate Register of Deeds. If all documents,
required to be submitted with a Final Plat, have not been submitted within
one (1) year of the date upon which the appropriate Governing Body
accepted the dedications, or within one (1) year of the approval of the Final
Plat, whichever date is later, the approval of such Final Plat shall be deemed
to have been withdrawn and such Final Plat shall not be filed until it has
been submitted again for approval.
PART 7. APPLICATION, REVIEW, AND APPROVAL OF LOT SPLITS AND
BOUNDARY LINE ADJUSTMENTS
6-701. (A) The responsible Planning Department is hereby authorized to review,
and either approve or disapprove, both Lot Splits and Boundary Line
Adjustments, in accordance with these Regulations.
(B) Applications for either Lot Splits or Boundary Line Adjustments shall be
submitted to the responsible Planning Department, on forms provided by
the Department. Such application shall include a survey, prepared by
land surveyor, licensed in the State of Kansas, showing the lot(s)
involved, the precise location of all structures and easements thereon,
the location of all streets and rights-of-ways, and location and
dimensions of all boundary lines, as they currently exist, and, as they are
proposed. Such Application shall also identify any restrictive covenants
that are applicable to the property involved.
6-702 Consideration of Lot Splits.
(A) The responsible Planning Department shall approve an application for
a Lot Split if the application requests the dividing of a lot into two (2)
lots, and the original lot has not been previously split, and both new
lots conform to the requirements of these Regulations. The
VI-12
responsible Planning Department may approve an application for a Lot
Split that requests the dividing of a lot into more than two (2) lots if, in
the opinion of the responsible Planning Department, the proposed split
does not create lots that are out of character with the original
subdivision, and all new lots conform to the requirements of these
Regulations.
(B) No Lot Split shall be approved if:
(1) A vacation, modification or addition, of streets, alleys, setback
lines, access control or easement is required or proposed.
(2) An installation of a public facility is required or proposed.
(3) The lot split will result in a lot without access to a street or to
adequate services or which cannot meet flood plain requirements.
(4) A substandard sized lot will be created according to applicable
Zoning Regulations or sanitary code.
(5) A newly created lot will not comply with these Regulations.
(6) Any newly created lot will be in violation of any applicable
restrictive covenants filed of record. (The responsible Planning
Department shall be entitled to rely upon the information
provided by the applicant regarding the existence of such
restrictive covenants.)
(7) Any other factor which, in the opinion of the responsible Planning
Department, fails to comply with the intent and purpose of
existing land development regulations and Governing Body
policies.
(C) No building permit shall be issued for a lot created by a Lot Split until the
Lot Split has been approved by the responsible Planning Department.
(D) The Director, or their designee, of the responsible Planning Department
shall either approve, approve with conditions, or disapprove the Lot
Split within 30 days after submittal of the application. Upon approval of
a Lot Split, the applicant shall prepare a Lot Split Survey, as described in
Section 7-401 of these Regulations.
6-703. Consideration of Boundary Line Adjustments.
(A) The responsible Planning Department may approve a Boundary Line
Adjustment, if, in the opinion of the responsible Planning Department
VI-13
the Boundary Line Adjustment does not create lots that are out of
character with the original subdivision, and all lots, after the Boundary
Line Adjustment, conform to the requirements of these Regulations.
(B) No Boundary Line Adjustment shall be approved if:
(1) The adjustment causes one, or both, lots to be substandard sized
lots, according to applicable Zoning Regulations or sanitary code.
(2) The adjustment causes one, or both, lots to not comply with these
Regulations.
(3) The adjustment causes one, or both lots to be in violation of any
applicable restrictive covenants filed of record. (The responsible
Planning Department shall be entitled to rely upon the
information provided by the applicant regarding the existence of
such restrictive covenants.)
(4) The adjustment causes any other factor which, in the opinion of
the responsible Planning Department, fails to comply with the
intent and purpose of existing land development regulations and
Governing Body policies.
(C) The Director, or their designee, of the responsible Planning
Department shall either approve, approve with conditions, or
disapprove the Boundary Line Adjustment within 30 days after
submittal of the application. Upon approval of a Boundary Line
Adjustment, the applicant shall prepare a Boundary Line Adjustment
Survey, as described in Section 7-402 of these Regulations.
VI-14
VII-1
ARTICLE VII
CONTENTS AND SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS
FOR PLATS AND PLANS
PART 1. SKETCH AND CONCEPT PLAT.
7-101. (A) Sketch and Concept Plats may be free hand pencil drawings that are drawn to a
convenient scale no smaller than one inch to one hundred feet (1" = 100'). Three
(3) copies of the Sketch or Concept Plat shall be submitted when required.
Sketch and Concept Plats shall show the following information:
(1) Approximate topography or some indication of ridge lines and steep slope
areas;
(2) Location and direction of all water courses and areas subject to potential
flooding;
(3) Natural features such as rock outcroppings, marshes, lakes, streams,
wetlands, critical areas for habitats for endangered or threatened wildlife
and native flora and fauna, wooded areas, riparian woodlands, steep
slopes, isolated preservable trees, and other Community Assets as set forth
in Section 10-801;
(4) Approximate location of existing structures (i.e. buildings, bridges or
culverts), utility lines or other aboveground structures on or adjacent to
the tract;
(5) Existing zoning, proposed zoning and land uses of the site and adjacent
areas;
(6) Location of property lines, existing easements or rights-of-way on or
adjacent to the tract and their width and purpose;
(7) Approximate location and size of existing sewers, water mains, gas mains
and other underground structures within the tract or adjacent thereto;
(8) Location of existing and proposed public facilities such as schools, parks,
playgrounds, open space, linear trails and other public areas or features on
or adjacent to the tract;
(9) Approximate location and widths of proposed streets, fire department
access easements, pedestrian easements, bike routes, and preliminary
proposals for connection with existing water supply and sanitary sewer;
(10) The layout of proposed residential lots, commercial and/or industrial lots;
VII-2
(11) The name of the proposed subdivision;
(12) The name, address and phone number of the owner of record, subdivider
of the subdivision, and consultant that prepared the Sketch/Concept Plat
and,
(13) A brief written description of the nature, and type, of development that is
envisioned to occur on the land covered by the Concept Plan shall
accompany the Concept Plan.
PART 2. PRELIMINARY PLAT.
7-201. (A) The Preliminary Plat shall be drawn to a scale no smaller than one inch to one
hundred feet (1" = 100'); however, areas over 100 acres may be at a scale of
one inch to two hundred feet (1" = 200'). Six (6) copies of the plat shall be
submitted with the application. The Preliminary Plat shall contain the
following information:
(1) The proposed name of the subdivision. This name shall not
duplicate or resemble the name of any existing subdivision within
the City or the County. Names of new subdivisions shall not be so
similar in sound and/or spelling to existing subdivisions as to cause
confusion or misunderstanding. Subdivision names shall be subject
to the review of the responsible Planning and Engineering
Departments;
(2) The true north point, scale of drawing including a graphic scale, and
the date of preparation;
(3) An identification clearly stating that the plat is a Preliminary Plat;
(4) A vicinity map showing the location of the subdivision in relation to
major streets;
(5) Names of adjacent subdivisions or, in the case of unplatted land, the
name of the owner(s) of adjacent property;
(6) The name, address, and phone number of the owner(s) of record, the
subdivider, and the licensed professional engineer, and other
consultants that prepared the plat;
(7) The location, widths and names of all proposed and existing public
or private streets within or adjacent to the tract, together with
easements, rights-of-way and other important features such as
section lines and corners, city boundary lines and monuments;
VII-3
(8) Contour lines or spot elevations based on USGS datum (with date of
survey) having the following intervals:
(a) Two (2) foot contour intervals; or,
(b) Spot elevations where the ground is too flat for contours; or,
(c) Five (5) foot contour intervals when the average slope of the
subdivision exceeds five (5%) percent; or,
(d) Any other contour intervals deemed necessary or appropriate
by the responsible Engineering Department.
(9) The location and direction of all watercourses and areas subject to
flooding, including identification of the 100 Year and 500 Year
Flood Plains and the Flood Plain zones (i.e., Floodway and
Floodway Fringe) including base flood elevations, and other areas
outside the 100 Year and 500 Year Flood Plains that are subject to,
or are known to have been subject to, periodic flooding, and if
known, recorded flood depths in flooded areas;
(10) Natural features such as rock outcroppings, marshes, lakes, streams,
wetlands, critical areas for habitats for endangered or threatened
wildlife and native flora and fauna, wooded areas, riparian
woodlands, steep slopes, isolated preservable trees, and other
Community Assets as set forth in Section 10-801;
(11) Existing use of the property, including the location of all existing
structures (i.e., buildings, bridges or culverts) showing those that
will be removed and those that will remain on the property after the
Final Plat is recorded;
(12) The horizontal and vertical location, direction of flow and size of all
existing utilities and drainage improvements adjacent to, and within
the proposed subdivision;
(13) Zoning on and adjacent to the tract;
(14) Location, elevation and description of the bench mark controlling
the vertical survey;
(15) The legal description of the subdivision, with distances and bearings
along boundary lines, and with distance and direction to the
monuments used to locate the land described in the Certificate of
Survey;
VII-4
(16) The proposed use of the land, whether for single family, two family,
multiple family, commercial, or industrial, schools, parks, or other
uses, and the proposed zoning classification;
(17) Proposed streets showing the location, names and/or labels, widths
and approximate grades. The Preliminary Plat shall show the
relationship of all existing streets to any proposed streets, or to any
development plan adopted by the MUAPB, and any dedications that
have been accepted by the Governing Body;
(18) Proposed easements showing width and purpose;
(19) Proposed lots showing approximate dimensions, square footage and
proposed lot numbers. Numbering of lots shall be in a consecutive
order in both a logical and physical sequence;
(20) Proposed location, size and type of utilities to be installed, including
direction of flow;
(21) Proposed sites to be dedicated or reserved for park, playground or
other public purposes;
(22) Proposed front building setback lines along all rights-of-way and
travel easements;
(23) Proposed location, layout, elevation, type and size of water mains,
fire hydrants, sanitary sewer mains and laterals, storm sewers,
culverts and street improvements, including sidewalks, bike routes
and street lights, and how they connect to the existing or proposed
systems;
(24) In the case of residential subdivisions, the proposed net density of
the development shall be noted on the plat, and shall be expressed
in terms of numbers of dwelling units per net acre; and,
(25) Proposed phasing boundaries and Final Plat Schedule.
(B) Additional data and information to be submitted with an application for
Preliminary Plat include the following statements and/or plans which shall
accompany the Preliminary Plat, and when convenient, may be shown on
the Preliminary Plat:
(1) A drainage report and plan shall be submitted, unless such submittal
is waived by the responsible City or County Engineer, subject to the
requirements of the Stormwater Management Master Plan, or, if
VII-5
within the Urban Area, then a drainage report shall be submitted
subject to the Riley County Storm Drainage Design Criteria for
Platted Areas.
(2) Proposed deed restrictions, if any, in outline form.
(3) A listing, if applicable, of all off-site improvements to be
incorporated in the proposed subdivision.
(4) Any additional reports, studies, or documents, such as percolation
tests, grading plans for steep slopes, or as may be required by the
responsible Planning Department or the MUAPB in order to
completely review the proposed subdivision.
(5) Requests for Variations.
(6) Utility release forms of appropriate utility shall be submitted.
(7) A Transportation Impact Study shall be submitted, unless such
submittal is waived by the responsible City or County Engineer, based
on the Development Triggers and Minimum Study Requirements
listed in the Manhattan Area Transportation Strategy: Connecting to
2020. Minimum study requirements include:
(a) Identify the specific development plan under study and any
existing development on the site (land use types and intensities
and the arrangement of buildings, parking and access).
(b) Identify the functional classification of the public street(s) to be
accessed.
(c) Document current public street characteristics (number and
types of lanes, speed limits or 85th percentile speeds, and sight
distances along the public street from proposed access).
(d) Compare proposed access with established design criteria
(typically driveway spacing, alignment with other streets and
driveways, width of driveway, and minimum sight distances).
(e) Determine number of trips generated by the existing and
proposed development - daily and peak hours - using the latest
edition of Trip Generation published by the Institute of
Transportation Engineers. Local trip generation characteristics
may be used if deemed to be properly collected and consistent
with the subject development application. Calculate the net
difference in trips between existing and proposed uses.
VII-6
(f) Document the current peak hour traffic volumes at each
proposed access driveway on a typical weekday (Tuesday,
Wednesday, Thursday). Traffic volumes should be measured on
the public street(s) and at any existing site driveway(s). The
time periods in which existing traffic is counted should
generally coincide with the highest combination of existing
traffic plus traffic expected to be generated by the proposed
development.
(g) Distribute and assign the net development trips through the site
driveway(s).
(h) Conduct volume/capacity analyses for peak hours at site
driveway intersections using methodologies outlined in the
latest edition of the Highway Capacity Manual published by the
Transportation Research Board. The analyses should be
conducted for both existing conditions and existing plus
development conditions.
(i) Compare existing plus development conditions with established
guidelines/policies for acceptable levels of service and turn
lanes.
(j) Identify geometric and traffic control improvements to mitigate
deficiencies and/or comply with established guidelines/policies.
(k) Prepare a typewritten report outlining the findings and
conclusions of the study, including exhibits illustrating the site
plan, traffic volumes and existing street conditions.
(l) Possible Additional Requirements:
(1) Extend the study to other street segments and/or
intersections on the public street system.
(2) Compare the traffic impacts of the proposed land use
with the traffic impacts of the land use in the
comprehensive land use plan.
(3) Evaluate future (20-year) conditions.
(4) Extend the study to include peak periods outside the
typical weekday commuter periods (i.e., A.M. ad P.M.
peak periods). For example, Saturday in areas with
significant retail development.
VII-7
(8) Notwithstanding that the responsible City or County Engineer may
waive the requirement for submittal of a drainage report and plan
and/or a Transportation Impact Study, the MUAPB may require
submittal of a drainage report and plan and/or Transportation Impact
Study, prior to taking action on an application. Any decision by the
MUAPB to require such submittal shall be final.
PART 3 . FINAL PLAT.
7-301. The Final Plat shall be prepared by an engineer or land surveyor licensed to do
work in the State of Kansas. It shall be drawn in waterproof black ink on 0.004
inch mylar Cronoflex engineering photographic film, or its equivalent, as may be
approved by the MUAPB. The permitted sheet sizes shall be twenty-four (24)
inches by thirty-six (36) inches. Larger sizes will not be accepted. The scale
shall be no smaller than one inch to one hundred feet (1" = 100') except that a
variation in scale may be allowed where the responsible Planning Department
determines it is necessary for a proper exhibit of the subdivision. When more
than one (1) sheet is used for any plat, each such sheet shall be numbered
consecutively, and each sheet shall contain a notation showing the whole
number of sheets (e.g., sheet 1 of 3 sheets). Linear dimensions shall be given in
feet and decimals of a foot to the nearest one hundredth of a foot. Information
shall be provided on the Final Plat necessary for the reproduction of the plat on
the ground. Six (6) copies of the Final Plat shall be submitted with the
application.
7-302. (A) Final Plats shall be prepared with the accuracy required for traverse data.
The following sheets or drawings shall be submitted with the Final Plat.
(1) Traverse data for the plat, with the error of closure not more
than one (1) in ten thousand (10,000); and,
(2) The location of all stakes, monuments or other evidence found
or set on the ground used to determine the boundaries of the
plat.
(B) The Final Plat shall contain the following information:
(1) The name of the subdivision, adjacent subdivisions or
landowners, identification clearly stating that the plat is a Final
Plat;
(2) The date, scale of drawing including graphic scale, true north
point, legend and controlling physical features, such as water
courses, highways and railroads;
VII-8
(3) A vicinity map with current zoning identified on and adjacent to
the tract;
(4) Square footage of each proposed lot for city plats. Square
footage or acreage of each proposed lot for county plats;
(5) A legal description of the tract boundaries and any dedicated
rights-of-way, and the total acreage of the tract listed in the
legal description;
(6) All monuments, tract boundaries, block boundaries, streets or
other rights-of-way lines with distances and bearings referenced
to section corners. Where these lines follow a curve, the central
angle, the radius, points of curvature, length of curve and length
of intermediate tangents shall be shown. In addition, (using
dotted lines) the lines of all adjacent lands, and streets and
alleys with their widths and names; except that in the case of a
Replat of a platted subdivision, if it can be determined that the
requirements for the location of the subdivision and ties to
section corners have been sufficiently referenced, then the
distances and bearings to section corners need not be shown on
the Replat;
(7) Lot lines with dimensions and bearings;
(8) Lot numbers beginning with the number one (1) and numbered
consecutively through all phases or units of a subdivision;
(9) The width of the portion of the right-of-way being dedicated
and the width of any existing right-of-way;
(10) All easements shall be denoted by fine dashed lines, clearly
identified, and if already on record, the recorded reference of
such easements. If an easement is not definitely located of
record, a statement of such easement shall be included. The
width of the easement with sufficient ties to locate it definitely
with respect to the subdivision must be shown. If the easement
is being dedicated through the plat map, it shall be properly
referenced in the Owner's Certificate;
(11) Identification of the 100 and 500 Year Flood Plain, and the
Floodway and Floodway Fringe boundaries on the Final Plat,
including elevations of these lines;
(12) Identification of the Riley County N-1, Airport Noise Hazard
District and Airport Overlay District, when applicable;
VII-9
(13) Land parcels to be dedicated for any purpose, public or private,
to be distinguished from lots or tracts intended for sale;
(14) Front building setback lines along all rights-of-way and travel
easements;
(15) The name of each street shown on the subdivision plat;
(16) Location and elevation of permanent bench mark, if required;
(17) No Access shall be designated by perpendicular dashed lines
along right-of-way lines. Access points shall be designated as a
break in the no access and labeled as access. Access points
shall conform with the Subdivision Layout Standards;
(18) Any variations of the Subdivision Layout Standards granted by
the MUAPB shall be noted on the Final Plat;
(19) Letters, as required by Article X, Section 10-601 (E) from each
of such companies or persons supplying electrical or
communications service, indicating that said arrangements have
been made, shall be submitted to the applicable Planning
Department at the time that application is made for a Final Plat;
and,
(20) Any additional reports, studies, or documents as may be
required by the responsible Planning Department or the
MUAPB in order to completely review the Final Plat.
(C) The following additional documents and other information shall
accompany the Final Plat:
(1) A check payable to the County Register of Deeds in an amount to be
determined by the County Register of Deeds to pay for the recording
of the Final Plat and any other documents to be filed with the County
Register of Deeds; and,
(2) The original of a Certificate of Title, issued by an approved Title
Company, showing the ownership, for all parts of the subdivision for
the Final Plat. The Final Plat will not be approved, unless the
Owner(s) reflected thereon are confirmed by the Certificate of Title.
The MUAPB and the responsible Planning Department shall be
entitled to assume that the Owner(s) reflected on the Certificate of
Title are the lawful Owner(s) of the subject property; and,
VII-10
(3) A County Treasurers receipt that all taxes are paid in full for all parts
of the proposed subdivision; and,
(4) A complete application on the forms provided by the responsible
Planning Department.
(D) Upon acceptance of dedications by the responsible Governing Body, the
Final Plat shall be submitted in digital format approved by the responsible
Planning Department. The digital version shall contain at a minimum the
information required in Section 7-302 (A)(1-2) and (B)(1-17). Any Final
Plat not submitted in digital format will be converted by the City or
County, and the cost will be billed, and shall be paid, by the applicant
prior to recording of the plat.
7-303. The following certification shall appear on a Final Plat:
(A) At the time the Final Plat is submitted to the MUAPB, it shall contain:
(1) A certification of ownership and a dedication of the public rights-ofway
and easements by the Owner, duly acknowledged in front of a
notary public, and in a form approved by the responsible Planning
Department; and,
(2) A surveyors certification indicating that such person is duly licensed
by the applicable authority and that the property was surveyed by such
person in accordance with all applicable rules and laws, duly
acknowledged by a notary public, and in a form approved by the
responsible Planning Department.
(B) Subsequent to approval of the Final Plat by the MUAPB, it shall contain a
certification by the Chairperson of the MUAPB, that such Final Plat has
been submitted to, and approved by, or deemed approved by, the MUAPB,
in a form approved by the responsible Planning Department.
(C) Subsequent to acceptance of the dedicated public rights-of-way and
easements, the Final Plat shall contain a certification by the applicable
Governing Body, or the appropriate representative thereof, indicating such
acceptance, in a form approved by the responsible Planning Department.
(D) The responsible Planning Department may require additional
certifications, such as:
(1) A certificate by the applicable Planning Department as to the
applicability of a Planned Unit Development (PUD); or,
(2) An approval, as to form, by the applicable attorney.
VII-11
PART 4. LOT SPLITS AND BOUNDARY LINE ADJUSTMENTS.
7-401. LOT SPLITS.
(A) Upon approval of a Lot Split by the responsible Planning Department, the
applicant shall prepare a Lot Split Survey. The Lot Split Survey shall be
prepared in accordance with the approval of the application. The Lot Split
Survey shall indicate, as a title, that it is a Lot Split of Lot ___ of ______
subdivision. The Lot Split Survey shall be prepared in the same manner,
with all of the same information, where applicable, as a Final Plat. In
addition, all documents required to be submitted with a Final Plat shall also
be submitted with a Lot Split Survey. The Lot Split Survey shall contain the
following:
(1) A surveyors certification indicating that such person is duly licensed
by the applicable authority and that the property was surveyed by
such person in accordance with all applicable rules and laws, duly
acknowledged by a notary public, and in a form approved by the
responsible Planning Department.
(2) A certification by the Director, or designee, of the responsible
Planning Department indicating that it has been submitted to, and
approved by, such responsible Planning Department pursuant to these
Regulations, in a form approved by the responsible Planning
Department.
(B) The responsible Planning Department shall file the Lot Split with the
appropriate Register of Deeds when all requirements of this Section have
been met. If such requirements have not been met within one (1) year of the
approval of the Lot Split, the approval shall have been deemed to have been
withdrawn and the Lot Split Survey shall not be filed without a re-approval
by the responsible Planning Department.
7-402. BOUNDARY LINE ADJUSTMENTS.
(A) Upon approval of a Boundary Line Adjustment by the responsible Planning
Department, the applicant shall prepare a Boundary Line Adjustment
Survey. The Boundary Line Adjustment Survey shall be prepared in
accordance with the approval of the application. The Boundary Line
Adjustment Survey shall indicate, as a title, that it is a Boundary Line
Adjustment of Lot ___ and Lot ____of ______ subdivision. The Boundary
Line Adjustment Survey shall be prepared in the same manner, with all of
the same information, where applicable, as a Final Plat. In addition, all
documents required to be submitted with a Final Plat shall also be submitted
with a Lot Split Survey. The Boundary Line Adjustment Survey shall
VII-12
contain the following:
(1) A surveyors certification indicating that such person is duly licensed
by the applicable authority and that the property was surveyed by
such person in accordance with all applicable rules and laws, duly
acknowledged by a notary public, and in a form approved by the
responsible Planning Department.
(2) A certification by the Director, or designee, of the responsible
Planning Department indicating that it has been submitted to, and
approved by, such responsible Planning Department pursuant to these
Regulations, in a form approved by the responsible Planning
Department.
(B) The responsible Planning Department shall file the Boundary Line
Adjustment with the appropriate Register of Deeds when all requirements
of this Section have been met. If such requirements have not been met
within one (1) year of the approval of the Boundary Line Adjustment, the
approval shall have been deemed to have been withdrawn and the Boundary
Line Adjustment Survey shall not be filed without a re-approval by the
responsible Planning Department.
ARTICLE VIII
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS
8-101. All public improvements necessary to serve a subdivision, such as, but not limited
to, streets, sidewalks, storm sewers, utilities, drainage improvements, etc., shall be
constructed, and financed, pursuant to the policies, rules, regulations and laws of
the responsible Governing Body, and also pursuant to these Regulations, where
applicable.
8-102. The responsible Governing Body may include part, or all, of any subdivision
within a benefit district to finance the construction of public improvements
necessary to serve such subdivision, whether or not such improvements are located
within, or without, such subdivision. The responsible Governing Body shall
comply with all applicable rules, regulations, ordinances and statutes in the
creation of such benefit district.
8-103. The MUAPB may make written recommendations to the responsible Governing
Body concerning any factor the Board deems relevant related to the construction
and/or financing of public improvements necessary to serve an approved
subdivision. Such recommendations shall not be binding upon the Governing
Body and shall not affect the approval of the plat. In addition to such
recommendations, the MUAPB may deny approval of a plat, or condition such
approval, based upon a finding that necessary public facilities, or services, will not
be available to the platted area within a reasonable time, pursuant to Section 6-306
of these Regulations.
VIII-1
ARTICLE IX
RESERVED
IX-1
ARTICLE X
SUBDIVISION LAYOUT STANDARDS
PART 1. GENERAL STANDARDS.
10-101. Scope. All subdivision plats shall be prepared in conformity with the standards set
forth herein. The layout, and location, of areas on plats proposed to be dedicated to
the public for uses such as streets, storm and sanitary sewerage systems, water supply
systems and other utilities shall also be consistent with the standards for such public
improvements that may be adopted by the applicable Governing Body or the
applicable Engineering Department.
10-102. Policy and Plan Coordination. All subdivision plats shall conform with the
applicable adopted Comprehensive Plans and policies of the City of Manhattan or
Riley County.
10-103. Access. All lots located on a subdivision plat shall directly abut, and be served
directly by a public street or travel easement.
10-104. Flood Plain Areas. All subdivision plats shall conform to the requirements of the
Flood Plain Regulations of the Manhattan Zoning Ordinance, or the Zoning
Regulations of Riley County, Kansas, whichever is applicable.
10-105. Land Subject to Erosion. On land subject to excessive soil movement that may result
in erosion or deposition of soil, the MUAPB in accordance with the City or County
Engineer's recommendations, may require necessary preventive measures as part of
the Preliminary or Final Plat approval. All provisions of the Environmental
Protection Agencys National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES)
storm water regulations shall be followed.
10-106. Subdivision Name. The proposed name of the subdivision shall not duplicate, or too
closely approximate in sound or spelling, any existing subdivision in either Riley
County or Pottawatomie County.
10-107. Conformance to Applicable Laws and Regulations. In addition to the requirements
established herein, all subdivision plats, where applicable, shall comply with the
following laws and regulations:
(A) The City or County Zoning Regulations, respectively;
(B) The Riley County Health Department's regulations;
(C) The regulations of the Kansas State Department of Transportation if the
subdivision or any lot contained therein abuts a state highway;
X-1
(D) The City/County Building and Housing Codes, respectively;
(E) The City/County Fire and Life Safety Codes, respectively;
(F) The standards and regulations utilized by the City/County Engineer,
respectively;
(G) Where there is a discrepancy between minimum standards or dimensions noted
herein and those contained in the above official regulations, the more restrictive
standard shall apply; and,
(H) Any other applicable statutory provisions.
PART 2. STREET STANDARDS.
10-201. Introduction.
(A) It is the goal and the responsibility of these Regulations to provide for a safe,
convenient, adequate, and comprehensively planned street system that provides
for all forms of transportation including motor vehicles, bicycles and pedestrians.
The system should coordinate and provide connections for bicycles and
pedestrians that are an integral part of the overall transportation network. The
system should be logical and respect the natural features of the community. The
specific standards applicable to the system must address the specific needs of the
users related to the functional classification of the particular street, and bicycle
and pedestrian connections to that system.
(B) Street Classification. Streets are classified according to their function as defined
by these Regulations. Streets shall generally consist of arterial, collector and
local streets.
(C) General Requirements:
(1) The layout of streets on subdivision plats shall be consistent with the
applicable standards adopted by the respective Governing Bodies. Within
the City and the Urban Service Area, the City of Manhattans Design
Standards and Specifications shall be the applicable standard. Within the
Urban Area, The Specifications For Streets Construction And Design,
Subdivision Regulations of Riley County shall apply. In addition, such
layout of streets shall, where applicable, be consistent with the
Comprehensive Plan, Functional Street Classification Map, Bicycle
Master Plan, Manhattan Linear Park Phase II Master Plan and all other
adopted Plans of the applicable Governing Body.
(2) In order to promote connectivity to adjacent properties, every plat shall
provide multiple access points, to the greatest extent possible. Streets in a
proposed subdivision must connect, where feasible, to existing streets in
X-2
abutting platted subdivisions, and streets must be continued to the
boundaries of the tract being platted, such that future abutting subdivisions
may be connected, unless the MUAPB finds that the minimum
requirements are not reasonable, due to the topography or other existing
physical conditions of the site; or, if the MUAPB finds that such minimum
requirements are not necessary, or desirable, for coordination of the
subdivisions layout with existing adjoining layouts, or the most
advantageous future layouts of adjoining tracts. In making findings that
the minimum requirements are not required, the MUAPB shall consider
the recommendations of the applicable Fire Department.
10-202. STANDARDS REGARDING TOPOGRAPHY AND ARRANGEMENT OF
STREETS.
(A) Local streets shall be laid out to conform as much as possible to match the
existing topography, to permit efficient drainage and utility systems, and to
require the minimum number of streets for providing safe and efficient access to
property. Streets shall not intersect with themselves. Through traffic on local
residential streets should be discouraged. If four-legged intersections are
utilized, traffic calming measures may be recommended by the City or County
Engineer and approved by the MUAPB, and made a condition of plat approval.
The use of three-legged intersections (Ts) is encouraged, when appropriate.
(B) Any type of street layout pattern may be used that best fits the topography. A
curvilinear system, grid system, or modified grid system are acceptable
alternatives. Cul-de-sac use should be carefully considered in the planning of a
subdivision to ensure that all forms of vehicular and pedestrian traffic demands
and other safety issues such as fire access have been adequately addressed.
(C) In commercial or industrial developments, the streets and other access ways shall
be planned in connection with the grouping of buildings, location of rail facilities
and the provision of alleys, truck loading and maneuvering areas, walks and
parking areas, so as to minimize conflict of movement between the various types
of traffic, including pedestrian.
10-203 STANDARDS FOR BICYCLE AND PEDESTRIAN ACCESS.
(A) Bicycle and pedestrian access are an integral component of the overall
transportation network. Planning for the effective provision for bicycle and
pedestrian access begins with the subdivision process so as to ensure that safe,
convenient, and adequate facilities are accommodated.
(1) Bicycle Lanes and Routes.
X-3
(a) At a minimum, the layout of streets and other public ways on plats
shall be adequate to accommodate bicycle lanes and routes, wherever
such lanes or routes are identified by the Bicycle Master Plan.
(b) Bicycle lanes or routes must reflect the overall planning of the area in
which the subdivision is located. Bicycle lanes and routes shall
connect with any anticipated, existing or planned bicycle lane or
route, linear trail and street network.
(2) Pedestrian Access.
(a) Sidewalks.
(1) At a minimum, the layout of streets and other public ways
on plats shall be adequate to accommodate sidewalks that
comply with this Article.
(b) Linear Trail.
(1) Linear Trail extensions, and other pedestrian connections
when appropriate, shall be provided in accordance with the
Manhattan Linear Park Master Plan Phase II
Implementation Guidelines.
(c) Pedestrian Easements.
(1) Pedestrian easements shall be provided according to
Section 10-301 (C) and Section 10-601(H).
10-204. STANDARDS FOR STREET NAMES.
(A) A street, which is planned as a continuation of an existing street shall have the
same name. Names of new streets shall not be so similar in sound and/or
spelling to existing streets names as to cause confusion or misunderstanding,
irrespective of a suffix.
(B) Street names shall be subject to the review of the Planning Department(s), Public
Works Department, Fire Department, Post Office, and Police Department. Street
suffixes shall be used to provide for a uniform classification of street functions in
the following manner:
(1) Boulevard and Parkway shall be reserved for major arterial streets.
(2) Avenue and Parkway shall be used in conjunction with arterial and
collector streets.
X-4
(3) Drive, Road, Terrace, Street, and Way shall be used in conjunction with
local streets.
(4) Lane, Circle, and Court shall be used in conjunction with cul-de-sacs.
(5) Place shall only be used in conjunction with Travel Easements.
(C) Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to prevent, limit or restrict the
applicable Governing Body from renaming any street, once the street has been
dedicated to the public, to any name said Governing Body deems appropriate.
10-205. STANDARDS FOR LAYOUT AND DEDICATION OF TEMPORARY DEAD-END
STREETS AND CUL-DE-SACS.
(A) Temporary dead-end streets. If the property adjacent to a proposed subdivision is
undeveloped, any street that comes to a temporary dead-end, and would be
extended into a future subdivision on the adjacent property, may be required to
have a temporary "T" turnaround. The provision of the "T" turnaround shall not
affect street rights-of-way and the "T" shall not extend out of the street or utility
easement.
(B) Cul-de-sacs. Cul-de-sacs may be allowed where continuous street connections
are not necessary or where other options are not practical due to topographical
constraints. Cul-de-sacs shall provide adequate access to all abutting properties.
When cul-de-sacs are used, pedestrian and bicycle access through the cul-de-sac
to adjacent area shall be adequately accommodated. The cul-de-sac right-of-way
leading to the end of the turnaround shall be the minimum set out in the Table 1,
Minimum Right-of-Way Widths (Feet). The minimum diameter of the cul-de-sac
turnaround shall be one-hundred (100) feet in diameter. The maximum length of
a cul-de-sac shall be six-hundred (600) feet from the centerline of the intersecting
street, along the centerline of the cul-de-sac to the center of the turnaround. In
those instances where the MUAPB approves a Variation pursuant to Section 2-
501, allowing a cul-de-sac greater than six hundred (600) feet in length, the
subdivider shall be required to provide a street consistent with the City of
Manhattans Design Standards and Specifications, or The Specifications For
Streets Construction And Design, Subdivision Regulations of Riley County,
where applicable.
10-206. STANDARDS FOR TRAVEL EASEMENTS
(A) Travel Easements are similar to public streets in that they provide the public with
X-5
legal access to abutting private property. Travel Easements differ from public
streets in that the improvement located within the easement is owned,
constructed, repaired and maintained by the owners of abutting, or nearby,
properties.
(B) Travel Easements identified on any plat shall be deemed to grant an easement to
the public for travel, to the same extent as would be permitted over a public
street.
(C) The following shall apply to Travel Easements:
(1) Travel easements shall only be allowed in Planned Unit Developments.
(2) Travels Easements shall not be permitted if the applicable Governing
Body desires to accept dedication of such area, as a public street.
(3) Travel Easements shall only be used to provide internal access to properties
within a subdivision and shall not be permitted to provide access between
subdivisions.
(4) Improvements within a Travel Easement shall be designed, constructed,
repaired and maintained pursuant to policies adopted by the applicable
Governing Body.
(5) Subdividers desiring to create a Travel Easement shall be required to file
restrictive covenants, or similar documents, which legally bind abutting
properties to construct, repair and maintain the improvements pursuant to
these Regulations. Such covenants shall be in a form approved by the
applicable Governing Body, shall be enforceable by that Governing Body
and shall not be permitted to be amended or removed without the consent of
that Governing Body. The applicable Governing Body may require that the
enforcement of such covenants include the ability of the Governing Body to
make such repairs, or conduct such maintenance, that the abutting
properties fail to provide, and to assess the costs of such to such abutting
properties.
10-207. STANDARDS FOR ACCESS MANAGEMENT
(A) Access Management. Access management includes the control of the spacing,
location of driveways, side streets and intersections. Effective access
management is essential to achieving safe and efficient traffic operations on the
major street system. The amount of access should decrease as the functional
classification of the street increases.
(B) Driveway and Street Spacing. Driveways to abutting property should be
X-6
confined to local streets. Direct access to arterial and collector streets should be
prohibited unless no reasonable alternative is available. There are two primary
aspects to driveway spacing. One is the relationship of an intersecting side
street or driveway relative to the intersection of arterial and collector streets.
The other aspect is the relationship between intersecting local streets or
driveways along an arterial or collector street. The following standards are
hereby required:
(1)Along an arterial street with speeds equal to or greater than 50 m.p.h., no
side street or driveway shall intersect the arterial street within 660 feet of an
intersecting arterial or collector street, nor within 660 feet of an intersecting
local street or highway.
(2) Along an arterial street with speeds less than 50 m.p.h., no side street or
driveway shall intersect the arterial street within 500 feet of an intersecting
arterial or collector street, nor within 500 feet of an intersecting local street
or driveway.
(3) Along a collector street, no side street or driveway shall intersect the
collector street within 300 feet of an intersecting arterial street, nor within
150 feet of an intersecting local street or driveway.
(4) Along a local street, no local street or driveway shall intersect the local
street within 75 feet of another intersecting local street, except that a
driveway for a low density residential development may be reduced to
approximately 40 feet.
10-208. STANDARDS FOR ACCESS TO ARTERIALS AND COLLECTORS.
(A) Access to Arterials and Collectors. Direct access to an arterial or collector, in
the form of a private driveway, shall only be allowed when no other means of
access is available. The City or County Engineer shall review the subdivision
and make a recommendation to the MUAPB.
(1) Where a proposed commercial or industrial subdivision borders on, or
contains an existing or proposed limited access arterial or a collector, the
MUAPB may require a street system layout, which affords separation of
through and local traffic. This may be accomplished through reverse
frontage lots with access control provisions along the rear service areas or
frontage roads.
(2) Where a residential subdivision borders on or contains an existing or
proposed arterial or collector street, the MUAPB may require that access to
the arterial or collector street be limited by any of the following means:
(a) When a subdivision abuts an arterial or collector, the subdivision of
X-7
lots shall be laid out so as to back onto the arterial or collector
street and front onto a parallel local street, or cul-de-sac. No
access shall be provided directly to any lot from the arterial or
collector street. Pedestrian and bicycle access to the arterial or
collector sidewalk system should be accommodated by appropriate
use of pedestrian easements; or,
(b) A series of cul-de-sacs, u-shaped streets or short loops shall be
provided generally at right angles to a parallel street, with their
terminal lots backing onto the arterial or collector street and
providing no access to the arterial or collector street from such
lots. Pedestrian and bicycle access to the arterial or collector
system should be accommodated by appropriate use of pedestrian
easements. Eyebrow cul-de-sacs shall be prohibited, unless
approved by the MUAPB; or,
(c) A frontage road may be provided, and shall be separated from the
arterial or collector street by a minimum ten (10) foot wide
planting or grass strip, and providing access to the arterial street at
suitable points.
10-209. SPECIFIC STREET STANDARDS.
(A) General. In order to provide for streets of suitable location, width and
improvements to accommodate future traffic and afford satisfactory access to
emergency and service vehicles; to provide for the safe operation of the street
system; and to coordinate streets so as to develop a convenient system that
avoids undue hardships to adjoining properties, the following standards are
hereby required:
(1) Street classification shall be indicated on the Functional Street
Classification Map.
(2) Right-of-way Widths. Right- of- way widths shall not be less than the
following:
TABLE 1
MINIMUM RIGHT-OF-WAY WIDTHS (FEET)
Street Type City Urban Service Area Urban Area
Expressway 120 120 120
Arterial 100 100 100
Collector 70 80 80
X-8
Local 50 60 60
Cul-de-sac 50 60 60
Cul-de-sac
Turnaround
100 dia. 100 dia. 100 dia.
Frontage 50 60 60
(3) Right-of-way widths in excess of the minimum standards stated herein shall
be required whenever, due to topography or other considerations, additional
width is necessary to provide adequate earth slopes or sight distances as
deemed necessary by the MUAPB. Right-of-way widths may be reduced in
accordance with Companion Easements, Section 10-601 (I).
(4) Other right-of-way considerations. Rights-of-way at intersections shall be
designed for sight distance considerations. For safety reasons and for
potential improvements at intersections, no less than a thirty (30) foot Vision
Triangle shall be platted as part of the right-of-way with any subdivision. No
fixed aboveground facilities should be located in the sight triangle at the
intersection (i.e. utility poles, trees, etc.). Consideration regarding the width
of the right-of-way, and companion easements, should be taken into account
when planning the street layout.
(5) Intersection Angles. Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as
possible at right angles. A variation may be approved by the MUAPB based
upon the recommendation of the City/County Engineer. The angle of
intersection shall not be less than seventy-five (75) degrees.
(6) Multiple Intersections. Intersections involving the junction of more than two
(2) streets shall be avoided whenever possible.
(7) Multiple approach intersections. Intersections involving more than four (4)
approaches should be avoided. Properly designed intersections with an
acceptable method to control traffic may be considered.
(8) Horizontal Sight Distances. Streets shall be laid out so as to provide for
adequate horizontal sight distances on all curves.
(9) Design Speed. Design speed shall be in conformance with applicable sections
of AASHTO, A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets.
Operating and design speeds at the lower ranges identified in AASHTO are
encouraged.
(10) Street Jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one-hundred-fifty
(150) feet shall be prohibited. The MUAPB may require the same standard
for cul-de-sacs depending on length of roadway and residential density.
X-9
(11) Distance Between Reverse Curves. A tangent of at least one hundred (100)
feet along the street centerline shall be required between horizontal reverse
curves on arterial and collector streets.
(12) Curvature. When the street centerline deflects more than ten (10) degrees, a
curve shall be inserted with a radius of footage no less than:
TABLE 2
MINIMUM CURVE RADII
City Urban Service Area Urban Area
Arterial 500 500 500
Collector 300 300 300
Local 150 150 150
(a) The MUAPB may, upon the advice of the City and/or County
Engineer, require an increase in the radius of the applicable curve.
(13) Street Grades. The grades of streets should not exceed the following
percentages:
TABLE 3
MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE GRADE
Street Type Maximum Grade
Arterial 5%
Collector 8%
Local 10%
(a) Any grades in excess of the above shall be reviewed by the
applicable City or County Engineer, and a recommendation made
to the MUAPB. No street grade shall be less than five-tenths
percent (0.5%), unless reviewed and recommended by the City or
County Engineer.
(14) Traffic Calming. Traffic calming measures are tools to be used in
conjunction with the horizontal and vertical design to achieve lower speeds
in the local residential street system. These measures should be
incorporated in the design of the street system. Recommended measures
include, but are not limited to, entry treatments, chokers, roundabouts,
circles, textured pavements, colored pavement and other geometric features
which will tend to reduce speed on a local residential street.
10-210. STANDARDS FOR ALLEYS.
(A) Alleys may be approved by the MUAPB with a subdivision. In those instances
X-10
where alleys are proposed, the MUAPB shall take into account lot and street
layout, and land uses to be served. When alleys are approved with a
subdivision, the following general standards shall apply:
(1) Alleys shall be platted at a minimum twenty (20) feet in width.
(2) Alleys shall be straight with no alley intersections, except as
may be approved by the MUAPB.
(3) Dead-end alleys shall be prohibited.
PART 3. STANDARDS FOR BLOCKS.
10-301. Blocks.
(A) The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard
to:
(1) Provision for adequate building sites suitable for the special needs of the
type of use contemplated;
(2) Needs for convenient access, safety, circulation;
(3) Consideration of topography; and,
(4) Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions.
(B) Residential block lengths shall not exceed one thousand six hundred (1,600)
feet.
(C) Pedestrian easements not less than sixteen (16) feet in width shall be dedicated
to the public through blocks where deemed beneficial by the MUAPB to
provide for pedestrian access. These walkways shall be constructed in a
manner approved by the City/County Engineer.
PART 4. STANDARDS FOR LOTS.
10-401. Lots.
(A) The minimum dimensional requirements for proposed lots shall conform with the
applicable Zoning Regulations of the City and/or County that are in effect on the
date of Final Plat submittal, or as specified by the County Health Department.
(B) Each lot shall provide a buildable area. Properties reserved or laid out for
commercial and/or industrial purposes shall be of adequate size to provide for the
off-street service and parking facilities required by the type of use, zoning district
X-11
and development contemplated.
(1) Lots intended for multiple-family, commercial, or industrial structures
and/or uses shall provide a buildable area behind the required setbacks,
which has less than a twenty (20) percent slope. In cases where there is no
existing slope that is less than twenty (20) percent, the lot size should either
be increased in area to provide for a buildable area with an existing slope
less than twenty (20) percent, or a specific grading plan shall be submitted
with the Preliminary Plat, which shall be approved by the MUAPB.
Grading plans shall incorporate provisions, which minimize grading,
removal of vegetation, land instability, fire or drainage hazards, or other
public safety hazards such as steep vertical cuts. Building site, off-street
parking lots and driveways must be considered with the grading plan. The
MUAPB may require the submittal of building and off-street parking lot
and driveway plans as a condition of approval with the Preliminary Plat,
which shall be submitted with the Final Plat. The MUAPB may deny a plat
that does not adequately address the minimization of grading, the removal
of vegetation, or creates public safety hazards such as steep vertical cuts.
Final grading plans shall be submitted with the Final Plat for subdivisions
subject to the provisions of this subsection.
(C) Where lots are more than double the minimum required area for the zoning
district, the MUAPB may require that such lots be arranged so as to allow
further subdivision and/or the opening of future streets. Such potential lots shall
be in compliance with the Zoning Regulations of the City and/or County, and
these Regulations.
(D) Through (double frontage) lots shall be avoided except where essential to
provide separation of residential development from a street right-of-way (e.g.
Reverse Frontage Lots) or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography
and orientation.
(E) Side lot lines should be at right angles to streets, or perpendicular to the
tangent, except in special cases approved by the MUAPB, (such as lot
orientation for solar access).
(F) Lots shall be laid out so individual lot drainage shall be coordinated with the
existing drainage pattern for the area.
(G) The use of flag lots shall be prohibited in all subdivisions except where the
MUAPB determines that topography or other physical conditions on the
property necessitate the need for flexibility in the layout of the subdivision.
The following requirements shall apply to flag lots:
(1) The pole portion of the lot shall be at least thirty (30) feet in width.
X-12
(2) The flag portion of the lot shall comply with the minimum lot
requirements for width, depth and area for the zoning district in
which the lot is located.
(3) The area of the pole portion of the flag lot shall not be counted
towards meeting the minimum lot area requirements of the zoning
district in which the flag lot is located.
(4) If more than one flag lot is proposed to the rear of another lot, then
the subdivision shall only be considered in conjunction with a
Planned Unit Development.
(5) Access to the flag lot shall comply with the requirements of the
responsible Fire Department.
PART 5. STANDARDS FOR SOLAR SUBDIVISIONS.
10-501 Solar Subdivisions. Subdivisions that are intended to be established to provide for solar
access, are encouraged to follow the general standards set out below, in order to protect
solar access, and to provide the greatest flexibility in the design and layout of the
subdivision: The applicable Planning Department will work with a subdivider to help
place restrictions on the plat in order to protect solar access for any subdivision proposal
that will be sensitive to the need for solar access.
(A) The subdivision should be a Planned Unit Development.
(B) Open space and landscaping should be located to protect buildings and/or solar
equipment from shading from other buildings in, or adjacent to, the
subdivision.
(C) Street orientation should provide proper orientation of buildings or equipment
using solar energy.
(D) Lot orientation should allow for building placements that maximizes use of solar
energy.
(E) Buildings should be located to provide sufficient open yard to the south to
ensure solar access on the lot.
(F) Covenants and restrictions should be provided by the developer to ensure solar
siting requirements and solar access protection.
PART 6. STANDARDS FOR EASEMENTS.
10-601.Easements.
X-13
(A) Where necessary, easements across lots, or centered on, lot lines shall be
provided for utilities and shall not be less than sixteen (16) feet in width.
(B) Except where provided in this Section, all poles, wires, and overhead structures to
supply electricity, communication services and similar or associated services, for
all subdivisions within the City of Manhattan and the Urban Service Area, shall
be installed underground, within designated utility easements by the subdivider
or utility company. The provisions of this Section shall not apply to any of the
following:
(1) Poles used exclusively for street or area lighting or traffic control
signals.
(2) Radio, television, and wireless communication towers and antennas.
(3) Existing poles, overhead wires, and associated overhead structures,
when part of a continuous line, or services to individual properties
from existing overhead lines that are within a subdivision previously
approved in conformance with these Regulations. Nothing in this
Section will prevent the replacement of existing poles, overhead
wires, and associated overhead structures on lines when necessary for
the purpose of maintaining the line or upgrading the capacity.
(4) Subdivisions within the Urban Area.
(5) Electric distribution or transmission lines with capacities of three
thousand (3,000) KVA or more.
(6) Service terminals, transformers, regulators, meters or other on aboveground
facilities normally used with and as a part of an underground
distribution system.
(7) Structures on corner lots, in streets and alleys, and on easements
adjacent thereto, in cases where electrical and communication wires
cross a street or other area where overhead wires are not prohibited,
may be connected to said overhead wires, and are excepted from
these Regulations.
(8) Existing overhead lines attached to the exterior surface of a building
by means of a bracket or other fixture and extending from one (1)
location on the building to another location on the same building, or
to an adjacent building without crossing a property line.
(9) Existing poles, overhead wires, and associated overhead structures,
when part of a continuous line, or services to individual properties
X-14
from such existing overhead lines that are within a subdivision
previously approved in accordance with existing regulations.
(10) Existing poles, overhead wires, and associated overhead structures,
when part of a continuous line, or services to individual properties
from such existing overhead lines that serve properties adjacent to
but not within areas being subdivided.
(11) Any communication line, which would otherwise be required by this
Section to be underground that uses an overhead pole or structure
exempted by this Section.
(12) Underground installation of wiring or electrical power, telephone
and cable television shall not be required in flood plains, drainage
easements, major drainage ways or other areas where there is
frequently standing water.
(C) The subdivider may request a waiver from the requirements of Section 10-601
(B), if physical conditions of the land, or economic conditions associated with the
nature of the subdivision in question make underground installation infeasible.
Such request shall be accompanied by a report from the responsible public utility
stating per linear foot cost differential between the average cost for installation of
underground utilities and the estimated cost at the subdivision. The MUAPB
shall review the request and shall approve or deny the waiver.
(D) The responsible Planning Department may grant special permission of the
requirements of Section 10-601 (B) in cases where temporary electrical power or
communication service is reasonably required for emergencies or for building
construction purposes, or for other temporary purposes, to erect, construct, install
or maintain poles, wires and other overhead structures for a period not to exceed
one hundred twenty (120) days. However, in the event the purpose for which the
temporary exception referred to herein as granted cannot be completed within the
period herein provided, because of a shortage of material, a natural disaster,
strikes or payment of which the City or County may become liable to another
person, fire, or corporation by reason of any negligence by the utility in the
construction, maintenance and operation of its utility system within the City or
County, then upon written request to the responsible Planning Department, the
time may be extended an additional temporary period or periods necessary to
allow completion of such construction.
(E) The subdivider shall make the necessary arrangements for the installation of
underground facilities, including circuits for streetlights that may be required.
Such arrangements shall be made with each of the companies or persons
supplying electrical and communications service therein in accordance with the
established charges of such company or person. Letters from each of such
companies or persons, indicating that said arrangements have been made, shall be
X-15
submitted to the applicable Planning Department at the time that application is
made for a Final Plat.
(F) Whenever any stream or important surface drainage course is located in an area
that is being subdivided, or is traversed by a water course, drainage way, channel
or stream, a drainage easement shall be provided which shall run generally
parallel to such water course. The subdivider shall provide an adequate drainage
easement along each side of the stream for the purpose of future widening,
deepening, sloping, improving or protecting the stream; or for drainage, parkway
or recreational use. For areas within the City and the Urban Service Area,
drainage easements shall be provided as required by the Stormwater
Management Master Plan (SWMMP). For areas within the Urban Area,
drainage easements shall be provided as required by the Riley County Storm
Drainage Design Criteria for Platted Areas.
(G) Travel easements may be allowed in accordance with Section 10-206.
(H) Pedestrian easements may be required in accordance with Section 10-203
(A)(2)(c)(1). In those specific cases where residential subdivisions abut an
arterial or collector street, pedestrian access from the local street to the arterial or
collector street shall be provided every 600 feet. Where deemed appropriate,
commercial and industrial subdivisions shall provide pedestrian access to arterial
and collector streets, as needed.
(I) Companion Easements. Utility and other service easements may be placed along
both sides of the street right-of-way, at widths determined by the affected
utilities or services. Specific criteria for the application of Companion Easements
include:
(1) Location. Companion Easements are parallel to the right-of-way with
uniform widths, unless specified differently by the responsible Engineer.
(2) Use. Companion Easements can be used for the placement of sidewalks,
trees, utilities, street lights, street signs, etc
(3) Applicability. The use of Companion Easements shall be determined at
the platting stage, either in the Preliminary Plat or in a Replat for
residential subdivisions.
(J) Avigation Easements and Other Restrictions. Land located within the vicinity of
established flight paths and noise impact areas of public-owned or controlled
airports, as determined by the MUAPB, shall be required to grant a permanent
avigation easement to the public as may be necessary to allow aircraft to operate
within the "Navigable Airspace" as defined by the Federal Aviation Act of 1958,
as amended. Consistent with FAA Regulations, the MUAPB may disapprove a
plat or portion thereof, which could create a hazardous situation for air traffic and
X-16
the general public resulting from development and construction of a project.
(K) Conservation Easements may be allowed in accordance with Section 10-801.
(L) Fire Department Access Easement. The MUAPB, upon the recommendation of
the applicable Fire Department, may require an easement for access by fire
fighting apparatus in the following circumstances:
(1) Where appropriate street projections are not provided to urban-wildland
interface areas adjacent to developing areas; or,
(2) Where a cul-de-sac greater than six hundred (600) feet in length has been
permitted; or,
(3) Where a subdivision has been allowed with only one access.
PART 7. STANDARDS FOR STORM DRAINAGE.
10-701. Storm Drainage and Required Improvements.
(A) For all plats proposed within the City and Urban Service Area, the subdivider
shall submit a storm drainage plan that conforms with the requirements and
criteria of the Stormwater Management Master Plan (SWMMP), unless such
submittal is waived by the responsible City Engineer, pursuant to Article VII,
Contents and Submission Requirements for Plats and Plans, Section 7-201(B)(1)
and (B)(8). For all plats proposed within the Urban Area, the subdivider shall
submit a storm drainage plan that conforms with the Riley County Storm
Drainage Design Criteria for Platted Areas, unless such submittal is waived by the
responsible County Engineer, pursuant to Article VII, Contents and Submission
Requirements for Plats and Plans, Section 7-201(B)(1) and (B)(8). The storm
drainage plan shall contain such information as may be required by the City or
County Engineer, and shall be reviewed and approved by the City or County
Engineer.
(B) For subdivisions proposed within the City or the Urban Service Area, all storm
drainage improvements shall be designed according to the requirements and
criteria of the SWMMP. For subdivisions proposed within the Urban Area, all
storm drainage improvements shall be designed according to the requirements
and criteria of The Riley County Storm Drainage Design Criteria for Platted
Areas.
PART 8. STANDARDS FOR COMMUNITY ASSETS.
10-801. Community Assets. All subdivisions shall be sensitive to the protection and
preservation of existing site features within the proposed subdivision, whether natural
or man-made, such that the protection or preservation of the site feature would add
X-17
value to the development or to the community as a whole. Such site features would
include historic sites or structures, critical habitats of wildlife or rare and unusual
plants, wetlands, drainage courses, large and/or valuable trees, or similar
irreplaceable assets, that are listed on a local, state, or federal listing, shall be
preserved in the design of the subdivision, to the maximum extent possible.
Conservation easements or other similar means must be used to preserve Community
Assets.
PART 9. STANDARDS FOR PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENTS (PUD).
10-901. A request for a PUD classification, pursuant to the Zoning Regulations, shall also be
considered to be an application for a Preliminary Plat pursuant to these Regulations.
Subsequent to approval of a PUD, the subdivider/applicant shall submit a Final Plat
to the MUAPB for approval. Such Final Plat shall be approved if it conforms to the
approved PUD. In reviewing a requested PUD, both the MUAPB and the applicable
Governing Body, shall require compliance with these Regulations, unless they make a
specific finding that a Variation from these Regulations is appropriate under the
circumstances, and also set forth their reasons for such Variation. Neither the
MUAPB, nor the applicable Governing Body, shall be required to approve a PUD
simply because it complies with these Regulations. The standards for approval of
PUDs shall be governed by the applicable Zoning Regulations.
PART 10. STANDARDS FOR SIDEWALKS.
10-1001. Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be required as part of the street improvements in the City
and the Urban Service Areas in the following manners:
(A) All sidewalks shall be constructed to standards set by the responsible
Engineering Department. The MUAPB may require greater widths where
pedestrian volumes dictate.
(B) A median strip of grassed or landscaped area at least six (6) feet wide should
separate all sidewalks from adjacent curbs.
(C) Sidewalks shall be located within the dedicated non-pavement street right-ofway
or within the companion easements.
(D) Sidewalks shall be required on both sides of all arterial and collector streets and
one side of all local streets.
(E) When unique topographic, or other unique site conditions dictate, the subdivider
may submit an alternative pedestrian and bicycle circulation system to the
MUAPB for consideration, as a Variation of Section 10-203. The alternative
circulation system must be consistent with the general requirements for adequate
and functional pedestrian and bicycle circulation, and connectivity to adjacent
areas, and shall demonstrate a well documented need for an alternative approach.
X-18
(F) Sidewalks shall conform to accessibility standards.
PART 11. STANDARDS FOR WATER AND SEWER FACILITIES
10-1101. Water and Sewer Facilities.
(A) All subdivisions located either within the City limits, or in areas to be annexed
by the City, shall have water and sanitary sewer systems designed to the
standards of the City Engineering and Fire Departments.
(B) All subdivisions within the Urban Service Areas, but not on City services, shall
design the water and sanitary sewer systems to comply with City Engineering
standards and shall also be designed in a manner so as to be compatible with
City systems when such systems are extended to these subdivisions.
Installation of such improvements shall be inspected and approved by the City
Engineering Department.
(C) All subdivisions within the Urban Area shall design their water and sanitary
sewer systems in accordance with County Engineering and Health Department
standards.
PART 12. STANDARDS FOR BENCH MARKS, CORNERS, MONUMENTS AND OTHER
MARKERS
10-1201. Bench Marks, Corners, Monuments, and other Markers.
(A) Bench Marks.
(1) All elevations shown on plats shall be based on National Geodetic
Survey (NGS) datum.
(2) The permanent bench mark location and description that is used to
extend datum to the project shall be noted on the Preliminary Plat and
Final Plat.
(B) Monuments.
(1) Monuments at the main controlling corners of each unit of a subdivision
shall consist of an iron bar at least one-half (1/2) inch in diameter, three
(3) feet long, and be encased in concrete. Variations to the three (3) foot
length may be allowed based on subsurface conditions.
(2) All lot corners and control points for horizontal curves within the
subdivision shall be marked with an iron bar at least one-half (1/2) inch
in diameter at least two (2) feet long.
X-19
(3) Identification plaques indicating lot numbers shall be placed at each lot
corner along the front of the lot, and the appropriate sign posts shall be
no less than four (4) feet above ground.
(C) U.S. Government Corners. Whenever a survey originates from a United States
public land survey corner or any related accessory, the land surveyor shall file a
copy of the completed survey and references to the corner or accessory with the
Department of Archives, Kansas State Historical Society, and with the County
Surveyor. Such survey shall be filed within thirty (30) days of the date the
references are made.
(1) Any altered, removed, damaged or destroyed corner shall be restored.
(2) Whenever such a corner or any related accessory is restored, reestablished
or replaced due to construction activities, a restoration report
shall be filed with the Department of Archives, Kansas State Historical
Society as specified in Kansas Statutes.
(D) Existing Markers. At any time during construction of the subdivision, if a stone
marker should be found, the developer shall place an iron disc next to the stone
to facilitate the location of the stone in the future.
X-20
ARTICLE XI
CONSTRUCTION AND DEFINITIONS
PART 1. CONSTRUCTION.
11-101. Unless a contrary intention clearly appears, the following words and phrases
shall have, for the purpose of these Regulations, the meanings given in the
following clauses. Any word or term not defined herein shall be used in a
meaning of standard usage.
(A) Words used in the present tense shall include the future.
(B) The singular shall include the plural.
(C) The word "shall" is mandatory.
(D) The word may is permissive.
(E) The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "arranged for",
"designed for", "maintained for", and "occupied for".
(F) Unless otherwise specified, all distances shall be measured horizontally.
(G) The acronym "MUAPB" shall mean the Manhattan Urban Area
Planning Board.
(H) The word "City" shall mean the City of Manhattan, Kansas.
(I) The word "County" shall mean the County of Riley, Kansas.
(J) Whenever reference is made to either the City or County, the applicable
one, based on conditions set out in Section 5-101 (B), shall apply.
(K) The word "Township" shall mean any township as they may be affected
by these Regulations.
(L) The word "ordinance" shall include the words "resolution" or
"regulations".
PART 2. DEFINITIONS.
11-201. The following definitions shall be used in the construction and interpretation of
these Regulations.
AASHTO: American Association of State and Highway Transportation Officials.
XI-1
ALLEY: A dedicated public right-of-way, other than a street, that affords a
secondary means of access to abutting property.
ALL-WEATHER ROAD: A road of any surface material, which would normally
allow the passage of emergency service vehicles used to respond to the location
within the City or County.
APPLICANT: A subdivider submitting an application for a subdivision.
APPLICATION: An application and all accompanying documentation required by
these Regulations for approval of a plat.
AREA: The size of a tract of land, usually described in terms of square feet or
acres.
BENEFIT DISTRICT: An area deemed by the Governing Body to be benefited by
an improvement and subject to special assessment for all or a portion of the cost of
the improvement (i.e. streets, water, sewage).
BICYCLE LANE: A portion of the roadway, which has been designated by signs,
striping, and/or pavement markings for the sole use of bicyclists.
BICYCLE ROUTE: A roadway designated to provide continuity and connectivity
with other elements of a bikeway system. The bike route is usually distinguished
only by signing.
BLOCK: A unit of land enclosed by streets or by a combination of streets, railroad
rights-of-way, watercourses or any other barrier to the continuity of development.
In cases where the platting is incomplete or disconnected, the City or County
Engineer shall determine the outline of the block.
BOUNDARY LINE ADJUSTMENT: The relocation of a common boundary line
between two (2) platted lots, by mutual agreement of the owner(s) of the two (2)
lots, by following the procedure in Article VI, Part 7, of these Regulations.
BUILDABLE AREA: The area of a lot remaining after all setbacks and easements
of the Zoning Regulations have been deducted. The buildable area shall be
feasible and practical for the intended uses and structures of the zoning district in
which the lot is located.
BUILDING: Any covered structure built for the support, shelter or enclosure of
persons, animals, chattels or movable property of any kind, and which is
permanently affixed to the land.
XI-2
BUILDING SETBACK LINE: A dashed line on the Preliminary and Final Plat
which designates the distance between the front lot line and the principal building
on the lot, or the distance between a travel easement and the principal building on
the lot.
CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS PROGRAM (CIP): The process of budgeting for
large-scale public expenditures, which are expected to have a relatively long life.
The CIP usually involves an investment in land, buildings, roads and other public
works, which produce public services or benefits. The City's CIP also includes
expenditures for large, long-lasting pieces of equipment and studies or surveys that
may be done by consultants.
