COMPREHENSIVE PLAN: The Plan as adopted pursuant to K.S.A. 12-747, or as
may be amended.
CONTIGUOUS: Next to, abutting or touching and having a boundary or portion
thereof, which is the same boundary.
COVENANT: An agreement or promise to do or not to do a particular thing; to
enter into a formal agreement, binding oneself in contract, which is either
expressed or implied.
Restrictive Covenants: Private agreements between a prior landowner and a
buyer (or transferee), which restrict the use of the land in some way. For
example, restrictive covenants used in many subdivisions may limit the land
to residential use with buildings of a certain minimum size and setback.
Restrictive covenants are generally said to "run with the land" so that all
future owners are bound by them.
Deed Restriction: A covenant or condition entered in the public record to
limit the nature or intensity of land or realty.
DEDICATION: A conveyance of land by a private owner in the nature of a gift,
grant or as required by regulation, and an acceptance of that land by or on behalf of
the public (example: street right-of-way, utility easement).
DETENTION BASIN (POND): A storage facility for the temporary storage of
storm water runoff. Usually the basins are planted with grass and may be used for
open space or recreation in periods of dry weather.
DEVELOPER: The legal owner or owners of a lot or any land included in a
proposed development, or the holder of an option or contract to purchase, or any
person having the authority to submit an application for approval of a subdivision
under these Regulations (see Subdivider).
XI-3
DEVELOPMENT: Any man-made change to improved or unimproved real estate,
including but not limited to buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling,
grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations.
DRAINAGE: The removal of surface water or groundwater from land by drains,
grading or other means which include runoff controls to minimize erosion and
sedimentation during and after construction or development, the means for
preserving the water supply and the prevention or alleviation of flooding.
DRAINAGE AREA: That area in which all of the surface runoff resulting from
precipitation is concentrated into a particular stream.
EASEMENT: A grant of one or more of the property rights by the property owner
to and/or for the use by the public, a corporation or another person or entity. The
property owner retains title of the land under easement.
Avigation: An air rights easement, which protects air lanes, flight paths and
navigable airspace around airports.
Companion: An easement reducing the normal width of a public right-ofway
on local streets by providing utility and other service easements along
both sides of the street right-of-way.
Drainage: An easement required for the installation of storm water sewers or
drainage ditches, detention or retention basins, and/or required for the
preservation or maintenance of a natural stream or water course or other
drainage facility.
Pedestrian: An easement for providing pedestrian access.
Temporary: An easement utilized for construction purposes or to give
access for a limited specified period of time.
Travel: An easement created to serve by providing access to pedestrians and
vehicles in the same manner as a local street.
Utility: An easement within which the common service delivery lines
(electric, telephone, water, sanitary sewer, etc.) are located.
FIRE APPARATUS ACCESS ROAD: An all-weather road used as a secondary means
of access to a subdivision which may have only one entrance, or at the end of a dead end
cul-de-sac, or as may be determined by the MUAPB, as recommended by the City or
County Fire Department, which has a minimum width of twenty (20) feet and a clear
height of thirteen (13) feet six (6) inches, and designed to accommodate the loads and
turning radii for fire apparatus and which is gradient negotiable by the fire apparatus
XI-4
normally used at that location within the City or County.
FIRE DEPARTMENT ACCESS ROAD: An all weather road connecting to an urban
wildland interface, with a minimum width of twelve (12) feet and a minimum
unobstructed height of thirteen (13) feet six (6) inches.
FLOOD PLAIN: Any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source
(see Flooding).
Base Flood: A flood having a one percent (1%) chance of being equaled or
exceeded in any given year.
Base Flood Elevation: The elevation shown on the Flood Insurance Rate
Map (FIRM), which is representative of the base flood.
Flood Insurance Study: The official report provided in which the Federal
Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has provided flood profiles, as
well as the Flood Boundary Floodway Map and the surface elevation of the
base flood.
Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM): The official map on which (FEMA) has
delineated both the areas of special flood hazards and the risk premium
zones applicable to the community.
Flood Plain Regulations: The official Flood Plain Regulations, as adopted
by the City or County.
Floodway: The channel of a river or other watercourse and adjacent land
areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without
cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than one (1) foot.
Floodway Fringe: That portion of the flood plain outside of the floodway.
FLOODING: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation
of normally dry land areas from the overflow of waters normally confined between
the banks of a stream or other water course; or, the unusual and rapid accumulation
of runoff of surface waters from any source.
FRONTAGE: The length of a front line or lines, i.e. that side of a lot abutting on a
street.
GOVERNING BODY: The elected City Commission of Manhattan or the Board
of Commissioners of Riley County. When reference is made to the Governing
Body, it shall apply to the appropriate body having jurisdiction over the land being
developed.
XI-5
GUARANTEE: A form of security, including a cash deposit, surety bond,
collateral, property or instrument of credit in an amount and form satisfactory to
the responsible Engineer. All guarantees shall be approved by the responsible
Governing Body wherever a bond is required by these Regulations.
IMPROVEMENTS: Street pavement or resurfacing, curbs, gutters, sidewalks,
waterlines, sewer lines, storm drains, street lights, street signs, flood control and
drainage facilities, utility lines, linear trails, landscaping and other related matters
normally associated with the development of raw land into building sites.
LINEAR TRAIL: A pedestrian/bicycle way that may be located within, or away
from, a public right-of-way, and is an alternate path and usually part of a trail
system.
LOT: A designated parcel, plot, tract or area of land established by a subdivision
plat to be used, developed or built upon as a unit. A lot shall not have less than the
minimum area and width required by the Zoning Regulations for the specified
zoning district.
Corner: A lot abutting upon two or more streets at their intersection. A lot
abutting on a curved street or streets shall be considered a corner lot if
straight lines drawn from the foremost points of the side lot lines to the
foremost point of the lot meet at an interior angle less than 135 degrees.
Depth: The distance between the midpoint of the front lot line and the
midpoint of the rear lot line.
Flag: Shall mean a lot that is characterized by a strip of land, not less than
30 feet in width, which provides access to the main portion of the lot referred
to as the flag. The strip of land shall be referred to as the pole of the
flag lot.
Interior: A lot whose side lot lines do not abut upon any street.
Lines: The lines bounding a lot so defined herein.
Minimum Area Of: The area of a lot exclusive of any portion of the right-ofway
of any public or private street.
Of Record: A lot which is part of a subdivision, the plat of which has been
recorded in the Office of the Register of Deeds of Riley or Pottawatomie
County, or a parcel of land, the deed to which was recorded prior to adoption
of these Regulations.
XI-6
Reverse Frontage: A lot extending between and having frontage on an
arterial street and a local street with vehicular access solely from the latter.
Split: The subdividing of a platted lot into two (2), or more, lots by
obtaining the approval of the responsible Planning Department pursuant to
Article VI, Part 7 of these Regulations and without any necessity to follow
the normal procedure for the subdivision of land.
Through: An interior lot which fronts upon two parallel streets, or which
fronts upon two streets, which do not intersect at the boundaries of such a
lot. (Also called a double frontage lot.)
Width: The distance between the side lot lines of a lot, measured at right
angles to the line establishing the lot depth at the established building
setback line.
MANHATTAN URBAN AREA: Urban Area, Urban Service Area and the City:
Manhattan Urban Area: The area of jurisdiction for these Regulations as
established in the Interlocal Agreement, or as it may be amended. It is a
combination of the incorporated area (the City), portions of the County that
could be provided services (Urban Service Area), and those other County
areas generally adjacent to the City or the Urban Service Area (Urban Area).
Urban Area: The Urban Area is an area located adjacent to the City, or
between the Urban Service Area and Manhattan Urban Area boundary,
which is not envisioned, or identified in the Comprehensive Plan, to be
developed to an urban scale. City utilities are not recommended to be
extended into the Urban Area.
Urban Service Area (USA): Those portions of the County within the
Manhattan Urban Area that can be served by existing City public facilities
and utilities, or extension of these facilities. The Urban Service Area is
identified as the Citys growth boundary for future urban density
development through the Comprehensive Plan.
City: The incorporated portion of the City within the Manhattan Urban
Area.
MANHATTAN URBAN AREA PLANNING BOARD: The MUAPB as
established by the Interlocal Agreement between the City and County.
MONUMENT: Permanent concrete or iron markers used to establish all lines of
the plat of a subdivision, including all lot corners, boundary line corners and points
of change in street alignment.
XI-7
NET DENSITY: The number of dwelling units permitted by the zoning district in
which the subdivision is, or will be, located. Net density is calculated by dividing
the number of dwelling units by the net development area within the subdivision.
Net development area is determined by subtracting areas set aside for streets,
churches, schools or other non-residential uses from the gross acreage within the
subdivision. Land set aside for common open space or recreational use is included
in net development area for the purpose of determining the number of dwelling
units permitted.
In residential planned unit developments, the number of dwelling units is
determined by dividing the net development area by the minimum lot area per
family required by the district or districts in which the site is located.
PERMIT (BUILDING): A certificate issued by the responsible City or County
Department or an official designee to allow construction of a specific type of
structure.
PERMIT (OCCUPANCY): A permit issued by the responsible City or County
Department, or an official designee, which certifies that such land use, structure or
building is fit for human occupancy and complies with all the provisions of the
Zoning Regulations and other applicable City or County codes, ordinances, rules
and regulations.
PERSON: The word "person" shall include individuals, firms, corporations,
associations, partnerships, government bodies and agencies, and all other legal
entities.
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT (PUD): A zoning district classification that
combines subdivision, zoning, site planning and design processes to accommodate
a flexible and unified pattern of development, which can more easily address
unique constraints and conditions on a specific tract of land.
PLAT: A map as a formal document representing a tract of land, showing the
boundaries and location of individual properties and streets; a map and a legal
description of a subdivision or a site plan.
Concurrent Plat: The simultaneous submission of a Preliminary Plat and a
Final Plat consisting of five (5) or fewer lots.
Concept Plat: A preliminary presentation of a future land development
contiguous to a proposed subdivision of sufficient accuracy to be used for
discussion in order to coordinate street, utility, drainage, park and other land
development issues.
XI-8
Final Plat: The final map of all or a phased portion of a subdivision, which
is submitted to the MUAPB for final approval and to the Governing Body
for acceptance of dedications.
Preliminary Plat: A preliminary map indicating the proposed layout of the
subdivision, which is submitted to the MUAPB for consideration and
approval.
Replat: A change, redrafting and/or resubmission of a previously approved
Preliminary and/or Final Plat. Changes may include lot lines, easements,
rights-of-way, design concepts or adherence to changes in local ordinances
and/or regulations that may control subdivisions.
Short Form Plat: A plat prepared on linen ledger (100% cotton rag) paper
for concurrent plats within the Urban Area.
Sketch Plat: A rough sketch map of a proposed subdivision or site plan that
is of sufficient accuracy to be used for the purpose of discussion,
clarification and consensus.
POLES, WIRES, AND OVERHEAD STRUCTURES: Includes, but is not limited
to, poles, towers, supports, wires, conductors, guys, stubs, platforms, cross-arms,
braces, line transformers, insulators, cut-outs, switches, communication circuits,
appliances, attachments, and appurtenances located above ground, upon, along,
across or over streets, alleys and easements, and used in supplying electric,
communication or similar or related service.
PUBLIC FACILITIES AND SERVICES: Any and all public improvements, the
need for which is directly or indirectly generated by the subdivision.
RESERVATION: Willingness by a private owner to withhold specific real estate
from further development pending acquisition by a public entity.
RESERVE STRIP: A strip of land across the end of, or along the edge of, a street
or alley or lot, for the purposes of controlling access, which is reserved or held
until future street extension or widening.
RESUBDIVISION: Any change to a previously approved or recorded
subdivision plat (see Replat).
RETENTION BASIN: A pond, pool or basin used for the permanent storage of
water runoff.
RIGHT-OF-WAY (R-O-W): A strip of land acquired by reservation, dedication or
condemnation and intended for use as a public way. The R-O-W normally
incorporates the roadway, curbs, parking strips, sidewalks, lighting and drainage
XI-9
facilities, other utilities, and may include special features (required by topography)
such as grade separation, landscape areas, viaducts or bridges.
RIGHT-OF-WAY WIDTH: The shortest distance between the property lines
abutting both sides of a street right-of-way.
ROUNDABOUT: A traffic control device that provides for the safe and efficient
movement of traffic through an intersection.
SCREENING: A method of visually shielding or obscuring one abutting or nearby
structure or use from another by decorative fencing, densely planted evergreen
vegetation, earthen mounds or berms, walls or a combination of these to reduce
noise, offensive views or heat.
SECRETARY OF THE MUAPB: The responsible Staff liaison of either the City
or County.
SEPTIC DISPOSAL SYSTEM: An on-site underground sewage system which
incorporates pipes, tanks and a leach field for the collection and disposal of
domestic commercial or industrial wastes from a single source.
SETBACK: The distance between the front lot line and the principal building on
the lot.
SIDEWALK: A paved area, generally parallel to, and usually separated from, the
street, and used as a pedestrian walkway.
SIGHT DISTANCE: The length of street measured along the centerline, which is
continuously visible from any point three (3) feet above the centerline.
SLOPE: The number of feet of vertical fall or rise per one hundred (100) feet of
horizontal distance, i.e., percent grade.
(vertical change in feet)
Percent Slope = (horizontal change in feet) X 100
STREET: A public thoroughfare and vehicular way which affords principal means
of access to property abutting thereon, whether named or designated as a street,
highway, parkway, road, avenue, roadway, boulevard, lane or however otherwise
designated.
Expressway: An access controlled, multi-lane arterial highway, which may
be separated by a median, and intended for through traffic, with or without
grade separation.
Arterial: A street providing for through traffic movement to concentrated
XI-10
areas of activity with or without a median divider and providing access to
abutting property subject to necessary control of entrances, exits and curb
cuts and protected by stop signs or signals at cross streets and highways.
Collector: A street providing for traffic movement between arterials and
local streets and providing for access to abutting property. Traffic is
controlled to some extent at cross streets.
Local Street: A street used primarily for access to abutting properties and
serving the local needs of a neighborhood.
Cul-de-sac: A local street having only one open end and being permanently
terminated at the other end by a vehicular turn-around.
Frontage Road or Marginal Access Road: A street running parallel to an
expressway or arterial and serving abutting properties.
Half-Street: A street bordering one or more property lines of a tract of land
in which the subdivider has dedicated half of the ultimate street right-of-way
width.
SUBDIVIDER: The word "subdivider" shall also mean owner, applicant,
developer, or a duly authorized agent of the owner of record of the land intended
for subdivision.
SUBDIVISION: The division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more lots,
tracts, parcels of land for sale, development, lease or other similar purpose. Such
division may also include, as an integral part of such division, the dedicating,
vacating or reserving of streets, alleys, parks, and easements intended for public
use.
SUBSTANTIAL COMPLIANCE: The demonstrated adherence to conditions
established by the MUAPB or Governing Body consistent with the intent and
standards of these Regulations.
TOWNSHIP: A rural government division within the County. The term originated
from the Congressional Township; a geographical area concept of usually 35
square miles, which was used to survey America. The Manhattan Urban Area is
located within the Townships of Manhattan, Ogden and Wildcat.
TRAFFIC CIRCLE: A traffic control method used only in residential areas to
provide traffic calming to the street system. A traffic circle is generally used as a
retrofit measure.
URBAN-WILDLAND INTERFACE: An area where a subdivision or
development, and contiguous land meet, whether at a clearly or undefined
XI-11
boundary. The interface area is where combustible fuels, vegetative or other
combustible materials exist, and which have the potential to contribute to the
intensity and spread of wildfire.
VARIATION: A deviation from the subdivision layout standards of these
Regulations subject to the requirements set forth in these Regulations and as
approved by the MUAPB.
VICINITY MAP: A drawing located on the Preliminary and Final Plat, which
illustrates the relationship of the proposed subdivision to the established street
systems, other nearby developments or landmarks/community facilities for the
purpose of locating and orienting the area under consideration.
WATER BODIES: Any natural or artificial collection of water, whether
permanent or temporary.
WATER COURSE: Any natural or artificial stream, river, creek, ditch, channel,
canal, conduit, culvert, drain, waterway, gully, ravine or wash in which water flow
is in a definite direction or course. Water can flow either continuously or
intermittently and has a definite channel, bed and banks and includes any area
adjacent thereto subject to inundation by reason of overflow or floodwater.
WILDFIRE: An unplanned and uncontrolled fire spreading through vegetative or
other combustible materials, and possibly involving structures.
ZONING REGULATIONS: The official Zoning Regulations of the City or the
County, as adopted, or as may be amended.
XI-12
